fields.headline: Press Gazette
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 2
fields.trailText: March 2: Journalists and newspaper executives claim the new share-tipping laws 'will brand journalists as criminals'.
fields.body:
Journalists and newspaper executives claim the new share-tipping laws "will brand journalists as criminals", according to News International's Les Hinton.

BBC news chief Richard Sambrook is planning to launch a weekly current affairs show, which could involve resuscitating the magazine programme Here and Now.

David Sullivan has named his forthcoming Sunday newspaper UK. It will be edited by Sunday Sport editor Tony Livesey.

War has broken out between the Guardian's editor Alan Rusbridger and the Barclay Brothers' right-hand man Andrew Neil.

The ITC has unveiled rules on the recording of telephone calls by journalists and programme makers. It will become essential to disclose the recording of a conversation unless "it is clear the material so acquired is essential to establish the credibility of a story".

The Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday have been accused of offering two online publications money after breaching their copyright.

The National Magazine Company's science and technology magazine Focus could be extended into a masthead TV series with the Discovery Channel.

webTitle: Spanish media round on Camacho's team

fields.headline: Spanish media round on Camacho's team
fields.trailText: The Spanish media have rounded on their national side following their 3-0 defeat by England last night.
fields.body:
The Spanish media have rounded on their national side following their 3-0 defeat by England last night.

"Spain slumps into total discredit," read the headline in El Pais on Thursday. "No play, no goals, no motivation, nothing at all," complained sports daily As, while its rival Marca raised the question: "Why do Spanish clubs triumph and the national side always fail?"

What has made the defeat all the more galling, according to the Spanish media, is that the resounding defeat came against a England team suffering one of the worst crises in their long history.

"England, who have done nothing recently, and who lack experience with a new coach, taught us a severe lesson, a defeat that should leave us red-faced and with our heads low," Marca said.

"We played ball, while they played football," was Spain coach Jose Antonio Camacho's apt assessment of the game.

webTitle: RUC make foot and mouth arrest

fields.headline: RUC make foot and mouth arrest
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A man was arrested this afternoon on the orders of Department of Agriculture officials investigating the spread of the foot and mouth disease to Northern Ireland, as more cases were confirmed throughout Britain, raising fears of an epidemic.
fields.body:
A man was arrested this afternoon on the orders of Department of Agriculture officials investigating the spread of the foot and mouth disease to Northern Ireland, as more cases were confirmed throughout Britain, raising fears of an epidemic.

The unnamed man was detained by the Royal Ulster Constabulary in Banbridge, County Down, just hours after the department confirmed Northern Ireland's first outbreak of the disease in south Armagh.

One livestock importer at the centre of the emergency comes from Banbridge, but it was not clear whether he was the man detained. It was the livestock importer who transported nearly 300 sheep into Northern Ireland from a market in Carlisle which is suspected of being contaminated.

The sheep were licensed for slaughter but ended up on the farm in Meigh, south Armagh, where only a consignment of the flock were slaughtered and incinerated.

However, a majority of the sheep are believed to have been moved on into the Republic of Ireland and a frantic search is under way to try to trace them. Irish agriculture department officials are investigating suspicions that fraud was involved in the movement of a consignment of 248 lambs.

The alarm was raised in Northern Ireland yesterday at the farm in Meigh, on the Irish border, after 21 sheep were discovered with symptoms of the disease.

In the Republic of Ireland, the suspected lambs were delivered to the Kepak meat plant, at Athleague, county Roscommon - one of the Irish republic's biggest sheep and meat processing factories - last Tuesday, and were slaughtered immediately.

They were delivered in the name of a Roscommon sheep farmer but subsequent investigations by the department have established that the animals did not belong to the man whose name was used. The disease has not been in Ireland for 60 years.

In total, five more outbreaks were confirmed at farms today to take the total number of cases to 31. Scotland also recorded its first outbreak at two farms in Dumfries.

Both Scottish outbreaks were traced to animal movements from England including from Longtown market, Cumbria, which is known to have been a contact point for the virus. New cases were also confirmed in Longtown and Penrith, Cumbria.

In Britain, two more cases were expected to be confirmed later today, including two in Carlisle and one in County Durham, the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore said.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, this morning briefed cabinet colleagues on the crisis as preparations continued to allow some animals from uninfected areas to be sent for slaughter despite the ban on moving livestock.

The National Farmers' Union, which welcomed the plans, said the foot-and-mouth crisis would cost Britain's farming and food industry £775 million unless it was not brought under control within three months.

There were also fears that dwindling supplies of home-reared meat could soon run out as prices for cuts of beef, lamb and pork looked set to soar.

The total number of animals slaughtered or due to be destroyed in Britain is believed to stand at 11,000, with 102 farms around the country under restrictions.

Next week's Crufts dog show, due to be held at the National Exhibition Centre in Birmingham, was cancelled to the public.

Meanwhile, John Edmonds, general secretary of the giant GMB union, warned of a "jobs epidemic" unless the foot-and-mouth crisis was stopped soon.

More than 1,000 employees at meat processing plants and other factories have now been laid-off or are on short-time working, he said, while up to 20,000 workers in the slaughter industry and 40,000 in the bacon and ham processing sector faced an uncertain future if the crisis continues.

A compensation package for farmers of £170m has been announced by the government.

Meanwhile, a major supermarket chain confirmed today one of its largest northern stores had run out of pork and lamb as the foot-and-mouth crisis deepened.

ASDA, in Wakefield, West Yorkshire ran out despite the big supermarkets expressing confidence earlier in the week that shoppers would not be hit.

A spokeswoman for Asda said: "We still have plenty of meat on the shelves but our hypermarket in Wakefield has run out of pork and lamb."

Almost all National Trust sites, including countryside, houses, gardens and parks, will close today as part of efforts to contain the disease.

And supplies of disinfectant used to prevent the spread of foot-and-mouth are reportedly running critically low in some parts of the country.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey, and the Archbishop of York, Dr David Hope, asked for prayers to be said in churches across Britain on Sunday.

webTitle: Trimble calls for Good Friday review

fields.headline: Trimble calls for Good Friday review
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland first minister says republicans need to break the deadlock over policing, militarisation and disarmament
fields.body:
Following a meeting today at Downing Street, the Northern Ireland first minister and leader of the Ulster Unionist party, David Trimble, said the Good Friday peace agreement is moving toward a review while deputy first minister Seamus Mallon said the agreement could break down within a week.

Mr Trimble warned that republicans needed to make "hard decisions" to break the deadlock over policing, demilitarisation and IRA disarmament. Speaking after a meeting with the prime minister, Tony Blair, Mr Trimble added: "If there is failure to deal with these issues then obviously we have to take stock and a review is an obvious way of taking stock."

Mr Trimble spent an hour in talks with Mr Blair but declined to say whether the meeting had left him more optimistic about the possibility of a breakthrough. Mr Blair also met today with nationalist Social Democratic and Labour party member Seamus Mallon, who urged the prime minister to call a round table meeting of all pro-agreement parties in a bid to end deadlocked discussions.

Mr Trimble said: "I very much hope there is a progress as a result of these meetings but we are as yet uncertain." He appealed to republican leaders to show the "moral courage" displayed by unionists.

Mr Trimble added: "It is time for people to shoulder their obligations and I think that is true of republicans as well as nationalists."

Mr Mallon told the prime minister that with talks on decommissioning, policing and demilitarisation still deadlocked, there was about a week left to get an agreement.

The meeting came as Sinn Fein considered legal action to stop chief constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan from starting a recruitment campaign for the new policing service. In Belfast, Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness warned that without the establishment of a policing board, the decision to go ahead would be illegal.

Ahead of the today's meeting at Number 10, the Democratic Unionist party leader, the Reverend Ian Paisley, claimed the Northern Ireland peace process was now "shattered". Mr Paisley, a staunch critic of the Good Friday agreement, said Mr Trimble's recent warnings that the peace process could be heading for a review have dealt the process a critical blow. He said: "It has been shattered by what Mr Trimble has said - that they now need to devise new workable democratic structures for the agreement."

However, the Northern Ireland minister, John Reid, insisted he had been encouraged by the constructive tone of today's discussions.

"I think the positive nature of this morning's meetings means we will be able to carry through the process," he said.

He said all the suggestions put forward would be discussed with the Irish government on his trip to Dublin.

webTitle: Hugo Young on the timing of the May election

fields.headline: Only naked self-interest would allow a May election
fields.standfirst:
The burning pyres should put all thought of a spring poll from Blair's mind

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The burning pyres should put all thought of a spring poll from Blair's mind.
fields.body:
On their critical path to a May 3 election, what worried Labour strategists most was a hospital crisis. They scoured the runes and scanned the heavens for intimations of a hard winter. Before Christmas, they saw the media stirring up a crisis, with body-on-trolley stories spreading like the pox. Watching the BBC's complicity, as they regarded it, in the mongering of health scares, they knew which act of God was likely to derail their plans: 20 degrees below and not a bed to spare anywhere in the NHS.

It didn't happen. Instead they got the plague of foot and mouth, which is far worse. Their mind-set, on the other hand, is unaltered. Just as they would have to manage the politics of beds to keep their electoral plans on track, so they look on foot and mouth as a disaster they must find ways of working round, in the interests of democracy. The election must have its day.

I think, on the contrary, that this terrible visitation puts politics in perspective. If ministers fail to see this, they will enrich their reputation for being concerned only with their self-created world. There shouldn't be any doubt about it. Unless the plague is quelled in the next 10 days, it should be not merely possible but axiomatic that the May date is abandoned. What, after all, are elections for? What are they meant to be about? Who are they supposed to engage?

There's already a tendency to envisage this one as some thing like the blitz. In a land semi-paralysed by restrictions, gallant country folk will stagger to the polls, or fill in the exciting new postal ballots that everyone can now claim, to perform their democratic duty. Before election day, they may have to do without the usual round of meetings, which hardly anyone attends anyway. Campaigning could not reach them. But, immured on their farms, they can keep in touch with the candidates on the telly. In this way, the emergency need not stop the vote. The enemy shall not pass.

Actually, this is a phoney war. Only politicians call May 3 unalterable. We do not need an election until May next year. Usually we put up with the manipulations that have become legendary, by which prime ministers foreshorten their mandate. Mostly we just sigh with stoic scepticism at their reading of the national interest.

But suddenly, here we have a competing national crisis, which may well make a normal election impossible to hold. Only by transmuting scepticism into cynicism can one find the slightest explanation as to why anyone would pretend that such an election, gratuitously called, must inexorably unfold.

Naked self-interest is all that could allow that to happen. For a lot of plans have been made around it. Ever since the autumn, Downing Street has thought of little else. Next week's Budget is the centrepiece, nicely calibrated for instant political effect. Mr Blair has a reshuffle he wants to make, a reorgani sation of Whitehall that is far advanced on paper, a whole new tranche of progressive optimism that awaits release once the dreaded hurdle to the second term has been successfully negotiated. There's also the little matter of the euro. An election that had to be delayed until the autumn would postpone further the most time-sensitive battle of the next parliament.

All this has been schemed rigorously into place. So has the imminent slaughter of William Hague.Who knows what might happen in the uncharted territory between spring and autumn? Perhaps Hague could find an issue. Maybe the petrol blockaders would strike again. With all summer to debate it, the hunting bill could no longer be kicked into the post-electoral grass. The Countryside Alliance would hold its dreaded march. Such are the interventions of chance, time and fortune that May 3 is perfectly calculated to minimise.

Reckonings like this are always a bit of an insult to the electorate. They show how heavily biased the British system is against elections called for the benefit of the people, rather than for the benefit of the prime minister and his party. We live with this. But now we won't do so with indifference. Foot and mouth has blown the gaff.

The prime intention of ministers is still to call an election which nobody except them needs, even if, as would in certain circumstances be possible, the consequence was to disconnect from the campaign just about as many rural voters as the number of blacks the governor of Florida disenfranchised in Dade County last November.

For life to return to a semblance of normality after the foot-and-mouth disaster, the country needs to be free of any more cases anywhere for a fortnight after the last case is discovered. For an election to be called before that fortnight is up would risk the campaign being held while further outbreaks were flaring. For a May 3 election, the best-guess date on which Mr Blair needs to announce it is March 26. Knock a fortnight off that, and you get a date adjacent to 10 days from now. The government hasn't got long to kill foot and mouth - nor, also, to make up its mind about what its democratic priorities really are.

There are utilitarian reasons why it should already be preparing to reverse them. Insisting on the date would put turnout further at risk than it already is, albeit mainly in seats that Labour may not expect to win. A campaign fought when half the country has barely recovered from paralysis would not be much fun. It would also seem like another Labour insult to the rural population: blundering on with a premature once-in-five-year democratic opportunity, without regard to the voters all over Devon and Somerset and Cumbria and Northumberland and Hereford and wherever else the pyres are burning.

But there's a bigger reason for riding with the punches from on high. Democracy should be about more than cynical calculation. Forcing the country to go through an exercise it's in no condition to enjoy would be one more way of feeding the apathy and distaste for politics Mr Blair spends quite a lot of time railing against.

Barring a miracle, he should already be looking at June. More likely, autumn would seem to be the ticket. There'd be no harm in legislating to change the fixed-term elections we do have, the locals, to get away from May 3 as well. The same reasons apply. I don't believe the result will be much different from what it would have been if there'd been no plague, and the six-month blueprint had been kept to.

Recent evidence continues to suggest that the more the Tories talk, the deeper they plunge into incoherence and contradiction. But the voters would not have been so presumed on, so coldly manipulated as accessories to their masters' schemes. If there's any silver lining in foot and mouth, it should be the recognition by politicians that they can't always control democracy, any more than natural catastrophe.

fields.headline: Sins of the superstores visited on us
fields.standfirst:
It is big profits not 'cheap' food to blame for the latest farming crisis

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: It is big profits not 'cheap' food to blame for the latest farming crisis.
fields.body:
"You enterprised a railroad through the valley," John Ruskin charged the railway companies in 1889. "The valley is gone, and the gods with it; and now every fool in Buxton can be at Bakewell in half-an-hour, and every fool in Bakewell at Buxton." God knows what he would have made of the 21st-century livestock trade.

Today, every sheep in Northumberland can be at Devon in half a day, and every sheep in Devon at Northumberland. And, as the government discovered to its astonishment this week, their diseases travel with them. Why is this happening? Almost everyone, radical commentators included, agrees that it's because the public wants "cheap food". They're wrong.

There's no doubt that the modern food economy encourages long-distance transport. Between 1965 and 1998, the international trade in food tripled, to 600m metric tonnes. In Britain, the transport of milk has increased 30-fold since 1980. To meet the demands of the global economy, livestock hauliers routinely break the rules requiring them to rest, feed and water the animals they are transporting, in some cases all the way from Britain to Beirut.

But of one thing we can be sure: none of this has anything to do with the needs of consumers. This myth can be dismissed by means of a complex research procedure called going shopping. In my home town, independent butchers selling local meat charge some 30% less than the superstores. Even the organic lamb on sale in the farmers' market marginally undercuts the poisoned produce the big chains sell.

Yet the superstores, as they often boast, are far more efficient than small shops. They exert an iron grip on their suppliers, they employ just one-fifth of the staff per unit of turnover, they enjoy, in most places, lower business rates. Consumers have not benefited from these economies. The current epidemic of foot and mouth is the result of structural market changes introduced solely to safeguard the profits of the superstores.

They buy, for example, only from the biggest farmers, employing the fewest staff. This means that more animals are crammed together, with fewer people to check their state of health. They lobby to ensure that the burden of regulation falls not on them and their suppliers, but on small business. This is one of the reasons why so many local abattoirs have collapsed in Britain, forcing farmers to send their animals ever further afield.

Ironically, the food poisoning which helped justify the tighter inspection regime is mostly the result of the large-scale agro-industry the su permarkets have encouraged: the sins of the giants are visited upon the dwarves.

They have lobbied, too, to be allowed to cheat their customers by changing the rules on provenance. "Scotch beef" and "Welsh lamb" now come from animals pastured in Scotland or Wales for just two weeks. They are trucked all over the United Kingdom so that the stores can change their designation and thus raise the price of their meat. This is not about cheap food. It's about expensive food.

But, most importantly, by trading directly with the big producers they control, the big chains have cut out the middleman. The result is that livestock markets have disappeared as swiftly as the slaughterhouses. Now, in order to sell their animals to independent butchers, farmers in some parts of the country must drive them hundreds of miles. The superstores themselves have centralised their distribution networks, trucking livestock from Land's End to John O'Groats and the butchered meat back to Land's End.

Their profits are extracted only at enormous cost to ourselves. The billions they make are matched by the billions the taxpayer spends on road building and maintenance, environmental remediation, hospital bills for the victims of food poisoning and, of course, mass slaughter programmes.

The animals pay too, by means of the appalling conditions in which they are reared and trucked. Yet the savings the supermarkets make are not passed on to farmers, and they are not passed on to consumers.

The power of the superstores ensures that others must be blamed for the disasters they precipitate. The farmers being investigated in Northumberland may well have neglected their animals, but since the big chains started buying their pork from gigantic industrial batteries, the farm-gate price has collapsed, forcing the remaining producers to spend ever less time and money on their pigs. Badgers are blamed for bovine TB, while the mass transit of infectious cattle is overlooked. And the underlying problem, we are universally informed, is us.

webTitle: Census takers may be barred from farms

fields.headline: Census takers may be barred from farms
fields.standfirst:
Fall-out Count delay would be first since second world war peacetime for 200 years

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair may find himself recorded in history as the first prime minister in 200 years forced to postpone Britain's census in peacetime.
fields.body:
Tony Blair may find himself recorded in history as the first prime minister in 200 years forced to postpone Britain's census in peacetime.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, confirmed to MPs yesterday that ministers are drawing up plans to take the unprecedented step of postponing the census, which is due to take place on April 29, as a result of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

At a meeting of senior ministers in Downing Street on Tuesday night, the prime minister was told of growing fears that thousands of enumerators, who personally deliver census forms to millions of households, may be barred from distributing census forms to farms affected by the disease.

Such a move would be the the first time in peacetime that that the operation to count Britain's population, which takes place every 10 years, has not been held on the date set down in parliament.

The census was first held in England in 1801 after the Census Act was passed in 1800 and has been held every 10 years, apart from 1941 during the second world war.

Government sources said last night that postponing the census would be a "logistical nightmare".

As a first step, the home secretary, Jack Straw, would have to consult parliament to change the census date which has been set in law for Sunday April 29.

After that, the government would have to reprint 32m census forms, which all have April 29 printed on them, a process which would take four months.

The office for national statistics (ONS), which runs the census, would have to re-hire 70,000 enumerators who distribute the forms and visit people who struggle to fill in the forms.

The enumerators, who will wear distinctive yellow jackets and who will carry yellow bags, do not have to visit every household in Britain because many census forms will be sent and returned by post. However, people living in rural areas, especially the elderly and those who live in outlying areas, are one of the key groups which are likely to be visited by the officials.

The 1981 census was carried out during an earlier outbreak of foot and mouth disease. But this was restricted to the Isle of Wight, unlike the present outbreak which has spread rapidly across Britain.

Officials from the Home Office and the Ministry of Agriculture, who have set up a joint working party, will make a final assessment towards the end of next month on whether to postpone the census.

Government sources said last night that if the disease has not been contained by then, they are likely to decide to call for a postponement.

Britain was reluctant to introduce a census until 1801, despite William the Conqueror's efforts with the Domesday Book in 1086, because churchgoers believed that it was sacrilegious to carry out head counts.

Setting another date for the census would raise serious questions about holding the general election four days later on May 3, which is currently thought to be the preferred date.

The prime minister will have to make up his mind about a May 3 general election on around April 4 or 5.

Moving the election date would delight Tory strategists who have been praying that events force the prime minister to abandon his hopes of calling the election almost four years to the day after his first election victory in 1997.

The Tories hope that Mr Blair may not be able to maintain his momentum in the opinion polls and their fortunes will revive if the election is pushed into early summer or even the autumn.

fields.headline: Treasury mandarin to be 'sleazebuster'
fields.trailText: A Treasury mandarin and former diplomat is to become Whitehall's new "sleazebuster", the prime minister announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A Treasury mandarin and former diplomat is to become Whitehall's new "sleazebuster", the prime minister announced yesterday.

The appointment of Sir Nigel Wicks, 60, second permanent secretary at the Treasury, as chairman of the committee on standards in public life, marks a major departure. He is the first Whitehall mandarin to hold the job.

His predecessors are both judges, Lord Neill of Bladen and the law lord, Lord Nolan.

Sir Nigel, who started his career as a BP oil executive, has served in the private offices of two prime ministers, Lord Callaghan and Lady Thatcher, and was economic minister at the Washington embassy in the mid 1980s. He has been at the Treasury since 1989.

He was chairman of the European community monetary committee between 1993 and 1998 and a member of the EU committee on European securities regulation. He got on equally well with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and his Tory predecessor, Kenneth Clarke.

Whitehall insiders were predicting that Sir Nigel's establishment credentials would be no barrier to him taking a firm line over integrity in government. They were confidently predicting he would be a gamekeeper turned poacher - with the added advantage of inside knowledge. "He knows where the bodies are buried and has had first hand experience of crisis in government," a Whitehall source said.

Andrew Tyrie, former Treasury special adviser to the former Tory chancellor Lord Lamont, and now MP for Chichester, said: "He is a dedicated civil servant who loyally served his masters, whoever they were. This new job will be a challenge for him to set his own agenda."

Sir Nigel takes over today from Lord Neill, the man who devised the first rules for party political funding and campaigning. His predecessor, Lord Nolan, framed the new parliamentary anti-sleaze regulations in the wake of the "cash for questions" scandal.

The committee also announced the appointment of two women members, Rabbi Julia Neuberger, and Rita Donaghy.

Rabbi Neuberger is chief executive of the King's Fund, an independent health care charity, and is a former trustee of the Runnymede Trust.

Ms Donaghy is chairwoman of the arbitration service Acas. She is a former president of the TUC and former member of the low pay commission and the equal opportunities commission task group on equal pay.

The committee, set up in 1994, will for the first time have an equal number of men and women on it.

webTitle: Analysis: Lowest turnout since 1918 for next election

fields.headline: Ballot blues
fields.standfirst:
An audit of voters' intentions in the next election predicts the lowest turnout since 1918, with Labour being harder hit than the Tories

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: An audit of voters' intentions in the next election predicts the lowest turnout since 1918, with Labour being harder hit than the Tories.
fields.body:
We (myself with professors Patrick Seyd and Charles Pattie of Sheffield University) have been conducting a citizen audit, paid for by the Economic and Social Research Council and based on a sample of 3,000 adults. Its aim is to examine the meaning of citizenship in modern Britain and it looks at political participation and attitudes and voluntary activity of all kinds.

Some 74% of our sample claimed to have voted in the 1997 general election, a figure which is only marginally more than the 72% who really did cross their ballot papers. Asking this question is an important guide to accuracy, since there is a well-known tendency for interviewees to claim they voted when in fact they did not. Since our audit provided a fairly good retrospective picture of the 1997 turnout, this suggests that it is a reliable guide to future behaviour.

When asked how likely they were to vote next time, only 65% claimed it was "very likely" and if this works as a predictor then the 2001 general election is set to have the lowest turnout of any since Lloyd George went to the country in 1918. We also looked at differences in likely turnout among party supporters. As the chart shows, 87% of those who voted Tory in 1997 are very likely to vote in the next election. However, this is true of only 74% of those who voted Labour last time. As a political formation the Tories may be in difficulty but it appears that William Hague is shoring up support among the core Tory voters in a way which Tony Blair is not.

These apathetic Labour voters tend to be dispropor tionately semi-skilled or unskilled manual workers, in their 20s and 30s and living on relatively low incomes. They also tend to be female and have relatively limited educational qualifications. They are twice as likely to strongly disagree with the proposition that "the government is doing a good job in managing public services such as health care and education" than they are to strongly agree with it. By the same token, they are more likely to distrust the government than voters in general.

If translated into actual votes, these differences in turnout intentions between Labour and Tory supporters have important implications for the number of seats the Blair government is likely to lose in the election. Monthly opinion polls such as the Guardian/ICM suggest that Labour is far enough ahead of the Tories to repeat its 1997 victory on roughly the same scale. But take differen tial turnout into account and the picture does not look quite so rosy. In 1997, Labour got just over 13.5m votes and the Tories 9.5m. Imagine what would happen if 87% of the Tories voted again for their party and 74% of Labour supporters did the same for their party. In this event Labour would end up with 54% of the combined Labour and Tory vote total, rather than the 58% it actually took last time. The Tory share would go up from 42% of the two-party vote in 1997 to 46%.

On this basis, Labour would still win the election but would lose seats. If we apply a seat forecasting model to these vote shares we can see what effects this has on the composition of the House of Commons. The model translates shares of total vote into seats and is based on the results of all general elections since the second world war. The model predicts that Labour would win 366 seats and the Tories 234, giving the Labour government an overall Commons majority of 73. Putting this another way, some 52 Labour MPs will be looking for alternative employment on the day after polling day - and that is because of differential turnout. However, if Labour managed to persuade their erstwhile supporters to turn out on the same scale as in 1997, few if any of these MPs would lose their places.

We are simplifying. This projection does not take into account changes in the composition of the electorate over the past four years, vote switching between parties, tactical voting and several other factors. It does not take into account the extent to which Labour's grassroots will campaign to get the vote out locally. But it may be a portent of things to come, and it does have two further implications. If Labour wins the next election with a majority comparable to 1997's then this effectively leaves the Tories in the cold until the election after the election after next, which means 2009 or 2010. By contrast, a majority of 73 could easily be lost in one go, making the 2005 election an open contest.

A second implication is that a loss by the Tories on the same scale as occurred in 1997 almost certainly means curtains for William Hague. But the loss of an election in which he wins back nearly 70 seats for the Tories might well save his leadership.

fields.bodyText: We (myself with professors Patrick Seyd and Charles Pattie of Sheffield University) have been conducting a citizen audit, paid for by the Economic and Social Research Council and based on a sample of 3,000 adults. Its aim is to examine the meaning of citizenship in modern Britain and it looks at political participation and attitudes and voluntary activity of all kinds. Some 74% of our sample claimed to have voted in the 1997 general election, a figure which is only marginally more than the 72% who really did cross their ballot papers. Asking this question is an important guide to accuracy, since there is a well-known tendency for interviewees to claim they voted when in fact they did not. Since our audit provided a fairly good retrospective picture of the 1997 turnout, this suggests that it is a reliable guide to future behaviour. When asked how likely they were to vote next time, only 65% claimed it was "very likely" and if this works as a predictor then the 2001 general election is set to have the lowest turnout of any since Lloyd George went to the country in 1918. We also looked at differences in likely turnout among party supporters. As the chart shows, 87% of those who voted Tory in 1997 are very likely to vote in the next election. However, this is true of only 74% of those who voted Labour last time. As a political formation the Tories may be in difficulty but it appears that William Hague is shoring up support among the core Tory voters in a way which Tony Blair is not. These apathetic Labour voters tend to be dispropor tionately semi-skilled or unskilled manual workers, in their 20s and 30s and living on relatively low incomes. They also tend to be female and have relatively limited educational qualifications. They are twice as likely to strongly disagree with the proposition that "the government is doing a good job in managing public services such as health care and education" than they are to strongly agree with it. By the same token, they are more likely to distrust the government than voters in general. If translated into actual votes, these differences in turnout intentions between Labour and Tory supporters have important implications for the number of seats the Blair government is likely to lose in the election. Monthly opinion polls such as the Guardian/ICM suggest that Labour is far enough ahead of the Tories to repeat its 1997 victory on roughly the same scale. But take differen tial turnout into account and the picture does not look quite so rosy. In 1997, Labour got just over 13.5m votes and the Tories 9.5m. Imagine what would happen if 87% of the Tories voted again for their party and 74% of Labour supporters did the same for their party. In this event Labour would end up with 54% of the combined Labour and Tory vote total, rather than the 58% it actually took last time. The Tory share would go up from 42% of the two-party vote in 1997 to 46%. On this basis, Labour would still win the election but would lose seats. If we apply a seat forecasting model to these vote shares we can see what effects this has on the composition of the House of Commons. The model translates shares of total vote into seats and is based on the results of all general elections since the second world war. The model predicts that Labour would win 366 seats and the Tories 234, giving the Labour government an overall Commons majority of 73. However, if Labour managed to persuade their erstwhile supporters to turn out on the same scale as in 1997, few if any of these MPs would lose their places. We are simplifying. This projection does not take into account changes in the composition of the electorate over the past four years, vote switching between parties, tactical voting and several other factors. It does not take into account the extent to which Labour's grassroots will campaign to get the vote out locally. But it may be a portent of things to come, and it does have two further implications. By contrast, a majority of 73 could easily be lost in one go, making the 2005 election an open contest. A second implication is that a loss by the Tories on the same scale as occurred in 1997 almost certainly means curtains for William Hague. webTitle: Court action looms in dispute over tube

fields.headline: Court action looms in dispute over tube
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The government faces the prospect of a court action by Ken Livingstone and a campaign of strikes on the London Underground in the run-up to the election after it failed last night to meet its own timetable for agreeing a formula for the future of the tube.
fields.body:
The government faces the prospect of a court action by Ken Livingstone and a campaign of strikes on the London Underground in the run-up to the election after it failed last night to meet its own timetable for agreeing a formula for the future of the tube.

The board of the London mayor's Transport for London organisation, set up to run the city's transport system, is today expected to authorise a legal challenge to the government's part-privatisation plans after hearing a report on weeks of fruitless negotiations from the transport commissioner, Bob Kiley.

Mr Kiley, who has blamed the situation on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was yesterday given last-minute confirmation that a suggestion passed to him on Monday - offering extra powers to intervene in the private companies bidding for the tube - was in fact a firm government proposal.

But a source close to Mr Kiley said that although it represented the first time the government had offered "more than cosmetic changes" to its plans, the proposal still did not provide the "essential unified management control" that Mr Kiley and Mr Livingstone have demanded.

Early last month, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, asked Mr Kiley to "modify" the government's partial sell-off scheme with the aim of reaching a deal by the end of February.

Negotiations were continuing last night, but allies of the London mayor accused the government of reneging on that agreement and complained that sensible negotiation had proved almost impossible, with the Treasury intervening to veto any package floated by other government officials.

The Greater London Assembly yesterday voted to "call upon the government to honour its commitment to Bob Kiley to provide unified management of the London underground," with Labour members abstaining.

A transport department spokeswoman said that Mr Prescott had not regarded the end of February as a firm deadline.

But without a change of heart, the argument looks increasingly likely to end up in the high court.

Pressure on the government over the tube also intensified when the largest rail union announced a fresh ballot for strikes over jobs and safety under the part-privatisation scheme.

The Rail Maritime and Transport union was banned by the high court on a technicality from joining the traindrivers' union Aslef in a one-day walkout last month. The result of the new ballot of its 7,500 tube members is expected in a week, with renewed stoppages possible from mid-March.

The risk of court action and strikes in the run-up to a general election is alarming London Labour MPs. Leftwinger Diane Abbott said last night: "Risking the loss of a string of London marginals seems a high price to pay for Gordon Brown's stubbornness".

Opposition parties were also keen to capitalise on the impasse, with the Conservatives confirming abandonment of their previous support for outright privatisation of the underground in favour of working with Mr Kiley.

webTitle: Go-ahead for GM test sites sparks fury

fields.headline: Go-ahead for GM test sites sparks fury
fields.standfirst:
Meacher under fire for 'threatening farming livelihoods' as 58 locations get government approval

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, was pilloried by leading environmental groups last night after he announced 58 major GM test field sites for oilseed rape and beet.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, was pilloried by leading environmental groups last night after he announced 58 major GM test field sites for oilseed rape and beet.

Two of the sites are already in doubt because they are believed to be within the exclusion zones set by the government to avoid the spread of foot and mouth.

The minister's announcement of the new trial sites, which will test the seeds of Monsanto and Aventis and will be planted at the end of March in 19 English and two Scottish counties, inflamed the anti-GM lobby.

A spokesman for Friends of the Earth said: "They will lead to the widespread contamination of food and the countryside. The livelihoods of neighbouring farmers and beekeepers, who are meeting the demand for GM-free food, will be seriously threatened. The biotech industry is being allowed to gamble with our countryside."

Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace criticised the recent government decision to extend to 200m the separation distances around GM crops.

"They are entirely inadequate. Contamination could spread 800m or more," said Greenpeace.

But Mr Meacher was unre pentant last night. He said: "The purpose of these trials is to provide systematic answers to the question as to whether the planting of herbicide tolerant GM crops, and the use of weedkillers associated with them, will cause any detriment to wildlife.

"They are not about the safety of GM technology. All the evidence collected will be sifted by an independent committee, and the results made public".

Earlier, Mr Meacher had said he wanted a full-scale review of industrial farming in the UK.

He pledged to halt the closure of small slaughterhouses, which adds to the cost of small farmers.

"We are trying to stop their closure. It is a commitment in the rural white paper", he told a meeting of seven leading environmental groups.

He called for the development of more local farmers' markets, adding: "On the question of intensive farming, we do need a full-scale review."

The Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, Don Foster, told the conference that small rural abattoirs were mostly closed under the previous Conservative government, but there was now a need to develop locally sustainable economies.

"It does mean having local abattoirs, farmers' markets, local village schools and post offices and providing better forms of genuine local transport."

More GM crops than expected will be grown this year because several farmers pulled out of the tests unexpectedly last year and a handful of crops were also damaged by protesters.

But the ministry stressed that there was no increase in the original number of sites that its scientists had recommended for the tests.

The food grown is not expected to enter the British food chain.

A further 20-odd sites for GM maize trials will be announced later this month.

webTitle: Scotland's scientists to get £90m for research

fields.headline: Scotland's scientists to get £90m for research
fields.trailText: Scottish scientists have been awarded £90 million to develop groundbreaking new drugs and advanced technologies.
fields.body:
Scottish scientists have been awarded £90 million to develop groundbreaking new drugs and advanced technologies.

The Scottish Science Research Investment Fund launched today is designed to give academics more freedom in choosing their research projects.

Universities benefiting from the new fund include Edinburgh which will gain £19,499,000; Glasgow £14,561,000; and Strathclyde £6,792,000.

The fund combines a previously announced £45 million from the UK Government Science Budget and £45 million from the Scottish Executive to be spent between 2002 and 2004. Projects include marine environmental research stations for the University of Aberdeen and new astronomy facilities at Glasgow University that will enable the identification of black holes and stellar collapses. Scottish lifelong learning minister Wendy Alexander promised academics more control over their own work: "The really innovative feature of the Scottish Science Research Investment Fund is that it allows universities a great deal of freedom to follow their own investment strategies."

The science departments will, however, have to put forward a priority list for approval before going ahead with their investigations.

Universities warmly welcomed the awards. Glasgow University said that it is too early to specify what they will spend the money on but today's announcement would enable them to plan and develop the key research strengths of their university. Strathclyde University stressed that the money would be put into areas of research badly in need of investment.

fields.headline: Students stage poverty protests
fields.trailText: Since 8am this morning students have been staging events across the country to mark National Shutdown Day.
fields.body:
Since 8am this morning students have been staging events across the country to mark National Shutdown Day.

Some 200 early risers at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside, along with the President of the National Union of Students, Owain James, were on campus hours before lectures were due to start to demonstrate the need for improvements in student funding. There was a human chain in South London and mass balloon launches nation-wide with students writing their debts on cards to send aloft.

In the run up to the general election, National Shutdown Day aims to push student hardship up the political agenda, though the Selby train disaster and the foot and mouth crisis ensure that student protests will not make headlines tomorrow.

Education Secretary David Blunkett's recent decision to rule out top-up fees has given the NUS some comfort. Now they are still campaigning for the reintroduction of targeted maintenance grants and raising the student loan repayment threshold above £14,000 so that students do not have to start to pay back loans until they can better afford to.

Student debt has trebled in the last three years. Mr James said: "No matter how frivolous or serious the activity, the message is clear; students are angry that debt is increasing by £1.5 billion per year. NUS estimates that next year's students will each owe an average of £12,000 on graduation."

Most institutions are compiling petitions and boycotting lectures, but at Luton they will be showing their grief over student debt by wearing black armbands as they stage their protest. Black armbands also appeared among the early risers at Lincoln. Their president Verity Coyle said: "Students are stereotyped as being lazy and having trouble making it for nine o'clock lectures, our students feel so strongly about the 'Grants not Fees' debate that they are walking out."

At Aston University in Birmingham students are staging a cardboard city sleep out. Goldsmiths College, London, is joining forces with nearby Lewisham College of Further Education to show that the journey from further to higher education is the most expensive one students will ever make by forming a human chain along the bus route linking the two campuses.

Following the NUS support for the lecturers picketing over the last few months UNISON, NATFHE and AUT members are supporting students in today's action. They encourage lecturers not to penalise those who take part in the boycotts.

webTitle: Portrait of Oxford historian Niall Ferguson

fields.headline: Dial-a-don
fields.standfirst:
Niall Ferguson is prolific, well-paid and a snappy dresser. Stephen Moss hated him - at least until he spent an hour being charmed in the historian's Oxford study

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Niall Ferguson is prolific, well-paid and a snappy dresser. Stephen Moss hated him - at least until he spent an hour being charmed in the historian's Oxford study.
fields.body:
I think I may hate Niall Ferguson. He is 36, extremely good-looking, has just been given a chair in history at Oxford, and today publishes a voluminous history of money and power over three centuries, less than three years after his equally substantial revisionist history of the first world war. Ferguson received a £500,000 advance for a three-book deal with Penguin, yet this new book isn't even part of that. He had a year's sabbatical at the Bank of England and did the research there. Has he never heard of writer's block? Frankly, his apparent lack of suffering is insufferable.

He greets me warmly in his immaculate room at Jesus College, Oxford, and abandons his humming laptop to make me coffee. He is beautifully dressed in perfectly tailored suit and mauve shirt. I can't help notice his matching mauve cufflinks. Now, I'm sorry, but it is a well-known fact that dons must wear baggy pullovers and corduroy jackets, preferably patched at the elbow. They should give tutorials while in the bath or perched on the branch of a tree, and publish occasional, esoteric articles on the prevalence of the Black Death in Bolton or Henry VIII's flute sonatas. How on earth did this fellow, with his gorgeous clothes, vast books, frequent forays into journalism and outrageous productivity, ever get in?

The worst thing is, he is extremely likeable. I have come armed with a charge sheet - populist, kowtowing to publishers' love for ridiculously wide-ranging histories, rightwing, an uneasy union of historian and polemicist - but I'm not sure I can make it stick. He is polite, reasoned, fluent, clever and modest. He also makes very good coffee, and insists that we interrupt the interview so that his tutorial student gets her full hour on the Habsburgs. I am beginning to forgive him his precociousness, his prolific output, perhaps even his adoration of Lady Thatcher, though not the mauve cufflinks.

I fearlessly put my case that his vast advance and large sales demonstrate the speciousness of his academic credentials. "I'm a little wary of anyone who makes the argument that Ferguson is suspect because he publishes books that are read and discussed," he says. "The idea that the media don is a modern invention is absurd. In many ways the separation of the public from the academic is the real novelty. In the 19th century if you were a historian, you might not necessarily be an academic. In fact, the best historians in this country weren't. Somebody like Carlyle never had a university post." But did Carlyle have mauve cufflinks and a half-million pound advance for Sartor Resartus?

"Envy is something you have to live with," says Ferguson, as if reading my thoughts. "Compared with the editor of a newspaper, I don't earn that much. There is a tremendous ethic of scholarly poverty in British academic life, and it is funny how reluctant academics are to say 'we're not paid enough'. This is an issue that will become more and more crucial if British academic life is to survive in the international premier league, because if you really carry on with these ridiculous salaries the system is not going to be a very healthy one."

Ferguson was born in Glasgow and produced his first book - home-made with a tinfoil cover - at the age of 10. (When I ask him how he can possibly produce so much, he looks as if the thought had never struck him: "I get up in the morning and work. My puzzle is with people who spend 10 years not producing a book. What do they do?") He was an undergraduate at Oxford and did his doctorate there, though it was completed after he had been given a research fellowship in Cambridge. This book was more to the taste of the cloistered critics. Called Paper and Iron: Hamburg Business and German Politics in the Era of Inflation 1897-1927, it was, says Ferguson, a triumph of Teutonic impenetrability.

Ferguson returned to Oxford in 1992 and lived what he describes as a double life: working on a densely researched history of the Rothschilds, and writing articles for newspapers. He had been an active proponent of Thatcherism as an undergraduate and found a natural home at the Telegraph, but also wrote for the Mail, where he met the journalist Sue Douglas, whom he married in 1994. He continues to produce articles and reviews, but evidently has no sympathy for the post-Thatcher Tory party and considers himself politically "stateless".

He is unrepentant both about his Thatcherite past and his polemical present. "I disagreed with some of her policies but I don't regret supporting her. The only thing that's slightly boring is to end up being pigeonholed as a right-wing Thatcherite historian, because those sort of labels don't mean anything any more. The big issues that were at stake in the 1980s when I was an undergraduate - the cold war and the British economy - have been resolved. The Conservatives were right and the Labour party capitulated. To label someone a Thatcherite is just a term of abuse, but if the Blairites were honest, they would label themselves that too, because in most essentials that's what they are.

"I get bored with the assumption that everything can be understood in terms of a left-right dichotomy. Nineteenth-century politics wasn't like that. In the 19th century there were two critiques of liberal capitalism: one was socialist and the other was Conservative, and they had a great deal in common. So I would rather be seen as radical and revisionist. I'm interested in questioning received wisdom, whether it is from the left or the right."

Ferguson's latest book, The Cash Nexus, emerged when he was awarded a year-long fellowship at the Bank of England. He had originally intended a history of the bond market, the anarchic nature of which bears out his chaos theory of history, but to the disappointment of the cloisters it has grown into an all-encompassing history of money, power and war.

"The idea was to address a series of questions," he explains. "It is a rather Oxford or Cambridge style of writing, where you set yourself an exam and try to answer the questions. I like that kind of writing. I think history proceeds rather well through essays, because it is not the pursuit of the definitive; it's an argument. I am making arguments and making them on a very big canvas in this book."

He still owes Penguin two books - one on European monarchy, the other on ethnic conflict - but his current preoccupation is a Schama-esque history of the British empire for Channel 4, which is sure to be controversial. "The project appealed to me because the British empire is connected with The Pity of War, it's connected with The Cash Nexus; it is precisely about the relationship between economics and politics," he says.

But don't we know what to expect, given his political views? "I can imagine people saying: 'Ah, the dreaded Thatcherite Ferguson writes a great defence of empire,' " he admits. "But if that is the expectation I think they will be surprised. All attempts to categorise my work in political terms seem to me to fail. I don't think the way I approach the British empire will be some sort of jingoistic celebration of Kitchener's great victory at Omdurman."

Despite his wealth and success, his wavy hair and worked-out life, I'm inclined to believe him. I just hope he doesn't wear those cufflinks for the walking shots in the Sudan.

 The Cash Nexus: Money and Power in the Modern World 1700-2000 is published today by the Penguin Press (£20).

This is an issue that will become more and more crucial if British academic life is to survive in the international premier league, because if you really carry on with these ridiculous salaries the system is not going to be a very healthy one." Ferguson was born in Glasgow and produced his first book - home-made with a tinfoil cover - at the age of 10. (When I ask him how he can possibly produce so much, he looks as if the thought had never struck him: "I get up in the morning and work. My puzzle is with people who spend 10 years not producing a book. What do they do?") He was an undergraduate at Oxford and did his doctorate there, though it was completed after he had been given a research fellowship in Cambridge. This book was more to the taste of the cloistered critics. Called Paper and Iron: Hamburg Business and German Politics in the Era of Inflation 1897-1927, it was, says Ferguson, a triumph of Teutonic impenetrability. Ferguson returned to Oxford in 1992 and lived what he describes as a double life: working on a densely researched history of the Rothschilds, and writing articles for newspapers. He had been an active proponent of Thatcherism as an undergraduate and found a natural home at the Telegraph, but also wrote for the Mail, where he met the journalist Sue Douglas, whom he married in 1994. He continues to produce articles and reviews, but evidently has no sympathy for the post-Thatcher Tory party and considers himself politically "stateless". He is unrepentant both about his Thatcherite past and his polemical present. "I disagreed with some of her policies but I don't regret supporting her. The only thing that's slightly boring is to end up being pigeonholed as a right-wing Thatcherite historian, because those sort of labels don't mean anything any more. The big issues that were at stake in the 1980s when I was an undergraduate - the cold war and the British economy - have been resolved. The Conservatives were right and the Labour party capitulated. To label someone a Thatcherite is just a term of abuse, but if the Blairites were honest, they would label themselves that too, because in most essentials that's what they are. "I get bored with the assumption that everything can be understood in terms of a left-right dichotomy. Nineteenth-century politics wasn't like that. In the 19th century there were two critiques of liberal capitalism: one was socialist and the other was Conservative, and they had a great deal in common. So I would rather be seen as radical and revisionist. I'm interested in questioning received wisdom, whether it is from the left or the right." Ferguson's latest book, The Cash Nexus, emerged when he was awarded a year-long fellowship at the Bank of England. He had originally intended a history of the bond market, the anarchic nature of which bears out his chaos theory of history, but to the disappointment of the cloisters it has grown into an all-encompassing history of money, power and war. "The idea was to address a series of questions," he explains. "It is a rather Oxford or Cambridge style of writing, where you set yourself an exam and try to answer the questions. I like that kind of writing. I think history proceeds rather well through essays, because it is not the pursuit of the definitive; it's an argument. I am making arguments and making them on a very big canvas in this book." He still owes Penguin two books - one on European monarchy, the other on ethnic conflict - but his current preoccupation is a Schama-esque history of the British empire for Channel 4, which is sure to be controversial. "The project appealed to me because the British empire is connected with The Pity of War, it's connected with The Cash Nexus; it is precisely about the relationship between economics and politics," he says. But don't we know what to expect, given his political views? "I can imagine people saying: 'Ah, the dreaded Thatcherite Ferguson writes a great defence of empire,' " he admits. "But if that is the expectation I think they will be surprised. All attempts to categorise my work in political terms seem to me to fail. I don't think the way I approach the British empire will be some sort of jingoistic celebration of Kitchener's great victory at Omdurman." Despite his wealth and success, his wavy hair and worked-out life, I'm inclined to believe him. I just hope he doesn't wear those cufflinks for the walking shots in the Sudan.  The Cash Nexus: Money and Power in the Modern World 1700-2000 is published today by the Penguin Press (£20).

webTitle: School dinners link to infected pigs

fields.headline: School dinners link to infected pigs
fields.standfirst:
Source Concern over waste feed

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The search for the source of the foot and mouth epidemic switched to pig swill made from the left-overs from schools and restaurants yesterday.
fields.body:
The search for the source of the foot and mouth epidemic switched to pig swill made from the left-overs from schools and restaurants yesterday.

Robert Waugh, the Northumberland farmer whose pigs are thought to have been the source of the outbreak, said they had been fed on swill made from waste collected from schools in Sunderland and Gateshead.

Sunderland city council confirmed that it had had a con tract with Mr Waugh's brother Ronnie to collect school waste for free, but the contract had been terminated in January when he asked for money for taking it away.

Gateshead council said that it had an informal arrangement for the collection of "plated waste" from their schools.

The Waughs also used waste from local restaurants.

Robert Waugh was licensed by the Ministry of Agriculture to feed the waste to his pigs and says that it was heat-treated as required by law.

Heating should inactivate foot and mouth, according to Stephen Curry, a researcher in the biophysics department at Imperial College, London.

But there has been anecdotal evidence of meat products being the cause of the disease in the past. Mr Waugh's suggestion that he had not fed his pigs "anything that hadn't already been served up on bairns' plates" caused alarm among parents.

Although humans cannot catch foot and mouth from eating meat, and the source cannot yet be confirmed, it raised the possibility that the school meals had contained infected meat.

All large catering companies use burgers, sausages, mince and other cheap processed meats in their cooking, and the quality depends on the cost specified in their contracts with schools.

"There have been so many problems around meat that people do now distrust school meals," said Joe Harvey, direc tor of the Health Education Trust.

New standards for school meals will be enforced from April.

But processed meat is often made from inferior quality materials.

Mechanically recovered meat (MRM), a slurry produced from pig and chicken bones, is still used. The regulations permit the use of the rectum, testicles, udders, feet and tails in MRM for cooked meat products.

Because of BSE, MRM may no longer be made from the vertebral columns of ruminants in the EU, but the rules do not apply to meat products imported from outside the EU.

It is an offence to import meat products from a country which has foot and mouth.

webTitle: When a call from a buddy keeps truancy at bay

fields.headline: When a call from a buddy keeps truancy at bay
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Fifty "truancy busting" schools across the country yesterday received cash awards from the government for making strides in reducing high levels of truancy and poor attendance.
fields.body:
Fifty "truancy busting" schools across the country yesterday received cash awards from the government for making strides in reducing high levels of truancy and poor attendance.

The primary, secondary and special schools have used a range of initiatives, including pupil reward systems, to encourage full attendance, registration throughout the school day, and recruitment of learning mentors to tackle the problems and take the pressure off teachers.

One of the schools praised for closely involving pupils in their strategies was Water Hall combined school in Bletchley, Buckinghamshire. At the 500-pupil primary school, headteacher Jackie Barnes explained that pupils have been key to the success of the school's "buddy" system.

Children with a record of not turning up are paired up with a "buddy" - a fellow pupil who lives close by - who calls on them every morning to escort them to school. This system has been highly effective in providing motivation for disorganised children who find it difficult even to get out of bed.

"Where the kids take control of something themselves, it has a better chance of being successful," Mrs Barnes said. "You can't rely on parents when they have problems themselves, such as drugs or long-term unemployment. The buddy system fosters friendships and a sense of belonging, which is an additional reason for going to school."

Calling parents on the first day of a child's absence is a time-consuming exercise, but it yields results. On Monday Mrs Barnes made 62 calls. Weekly class awards and termly awards for pupils with 100% attendance are made, with individual pupil records displayed in school. The school's target is for 95% attendance, although a handful of children remain at the bottom of the league on less than 30%.

The £8,000 award from the Department for Education will be used, appropriately, to help fund a breakfast club.

fields.headline: Blair's £1.5bn adult literacy drive
fields.standfirst:
Jobless who refuse to learn to read and write may lose benefit

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today signal one of his big second term themes when he calls for a drive to improve the reading and writing skills of 7m British adults whose literacy is below that of the average 11-year-old.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today signal one of his big second term themes when he calls for a drive to improve the reading and writing skills of 7m British adults whose literacy is below that of the average 11-year-old.

He will propose that as a condition of benefit, the illiterate unemployed or claimants on the new deal be required to go on basic read ing and writing courses. Those who took intensive courses of up to three months would receive about £10 extra in benefits. But some claimants might lose benefit if they refused.

Mr Blair and David Blunkett, the education secretary, will promote a £1.5bn programme over three years following the government report, A Fresh Start, written by Sir Claus Moser two years ago. It has been estimated that Britain's low skills base costs the economy £11bn a year.

Since then the government has set up the learning and skills council, replacing the training and enterprise councils.

Bryan Sanderson, the chairman of Sunderland football club and executive director of BP Amoco, is chairing the council. Ministers claim he is so concerned by levels of adult illiteracy that he is trying to improve the quality of the Sunderland football programme, as it is probably one of the few pieces of printed material that fans read each week.

Pilot projects will require early basic skills screening of claimants on job seekers allowance, as well as anyone on the voluntary new deal for lone parents or for the older unemployed. Screening will take place after six months on the programme.

Ministers are also examining family literacy programmes, in which parents and their children learn together; tailor-made strategies for targeting resources on disadvantaged areas; and more opportunities for basic skills training in the workplace.

Government estimates suggest that on average an employed person could earn an extra £1,000 a year with improved numeracy skills.

Ministers want to make the materials used for improving basic adult skills more relevant to everyday situations.

Illiterate and innumerate adults are less likely to vote or own their own home, and more prone to physical and mental health problems.

The government is already committed to doubling the numbers taking part in basic literacy and numeracy programmes to 500,000 by 2002. Ministers have also set a target to reduce the number of adults who have difficulty with literacy or numeracy by 750,000 by 2004. Research published yesterday by the office of national statistics showed that 14.9% of adults of working age in England - 4.8m - have no qualifications.

Ministers have also encouraged trade unions to appoint learning representatives, as they already appoint health and safety representatves.

Ministers have already announced an increase in spending on adult skills from £241m this financial year to £403m in 2003-4.

Research by the National Foundation for Education Research shows adults involved in family learning have higher attendance, retention and completion rates than adults on courses and their progression to further study or employment is high. The research also showed little is known about basic skills teaching on the ground.

National surveys of adults' attainment in literacy and numeracy show that about 20% have less than functional literacy, and about 20% have poor numeracy.

At the launch in Downing Street today, the TUC general secretary, John Monks, will say that the number of adults lacking basic literacy and numeracy "is nothing short of a national disaster, a strain on our economy and a blight on individual lives".

He will urge companies to do more for workers who struggle to read and write.

webTitle: Comment: Woodhead's attack on government education policy

fields.headline: More style than substance
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education editor Ros Taylor unpicks a broadside against the government by the former Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText:
Guardian Unlimited Education editor Ros Taylor unpicks a broadside against the government by the former Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead has spoken, again, and the Telegraph columnist and educational consultant has surprised no one, fulfilling his new brief as a rightwing stalwart with ease. He has told his new readership just what they wanted to hear: that Labour is "betraying" our children.

In 1994 when the former Ofsted chief first began to attack teachers, universities, unions, exams and local education authorities, Telegraph readers were reassured. Here was a man who would not let those leftwingers get away with implementing new-fangled educational theories. He had, it was true, flirted with them as a young teacher, but local authority admin and promotion to the National Curriculum Council had changed all that.

Mr Woodhead's article in today's Telegraph starts with an easy shot at a delegate at a schools standards meeting who suggested that teachers should be renamed "learning professionals".

Fifteen hundred words later, he sets out the reforms he sought, and which, he claims, he did not secure because Tony Blair and David Blunkett refused to support him: to identify failing schools and teachers, to publish reports written in "plain English", to challenge "child-centred orthodoxies" (orthodoxies which, oddly, were also "progressive"), to stress mental arithmetic and phonetic reading, to challenge "irrelevant" teacher training, to inspect local education authorities and expose their "waste of taxpayers' money", and to expose (again) "vacuous" educational research.

So what would take the place of the child-centred orthodoxies? What does Mr Woodhead believe in?

We know that he subscribes to educationalist Michael Oakeshott's belief that education is "a conversation between the generations in which the young learn what they can about the cultural inheritance upon which their humanity depends". We also know that he thinks education "must be much more than a preparation for life in the utilitarian sense" and that it is "intrinsically valuable". (Is this a broadside against the government's plans for specialist schools, which have attracted criticism from across the political spectrum? He does not say.)

We also know that he wants to cut down on bureaucracy, which is laudable. But red tape is an inevitable result of reform. You cannot have one without the other, and to focus on the packaging rather than tackling the substance is an easy target.

For all the apparent pragmatism of Mr Woodhead's approach, and his gift for identifying failure, he has little to offer that is new. Labour knew that, which is why it retained him for just long enough to reassure parents that traditionalism still had a place in government education policy. Now it is time to move on.

webTitle: Woodhead lays into Blair and Blunkett

fields.headline: Woodhead lays into Blair and Blunkett
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools in England, last night launched a bitter attack on Tony Blair and the education secretary, David Blunkett, for "betraying" a generation of children.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools in England, last night launched a bitter attack on Tony Blair and the education secretary, David Blunkett, for "betraying" a generation of children.

Released from the three-month purdah imposed after he resigned suddenly last November, Mr Woodhead began his new career as a writer for the Daily Telegraph by accusing the prime minister of being "incapable of seeing anything through".

Mr Blair "has failed to focus with sufficient rigour on what he repeatedly declared to be his number one priority", Mr Woodhead said.

This allowed Mr Blunkett to preside "over a set of initiatives that has wasted taxpayers' money, distracted teachers from their real responsibilities and encapsulated the worst of the discredited ideology that has done so much damage since the 1960s".

Mr Blunkett adopted a measured tone in a statement last night, praising Mr Woodhead's work as chief inspector but rejecting his criticisms. His close colleagues were rather less sanguine in private.

Mr Woodhead wrote that he decided to quit as chief inspector because he could no longer support many of the government's policies. He "no longer knew what to say" when head teachers complained about bureaucratic interference. "As a taxpayer I could not stomach the way in which public money was being squandered and, as an individual, I was no longer prepared to waste my time in discussions that had no connection with the classroom."

He recounts a meeting of Mr Blunkett's Standards Task Force where a member said the term teachers should be replaced by "learning professionals". When none of those present - including the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, and Michael Barber, Mr Blunkett's senior adviser - seemed to agree "the time had come, I realised, to go".

But Mr Woodhead said he was torn about whether to resign. The issue was forced when Mr Blunkett discovered during the Labour conference last year that the chief inspector was thinking of resigning. At the end of a second meeting, Mr Woodhead wrote: "I concluded that he wanted me to go - and the sooner the better. He could then appoint someone who might cause less trouble."

Mr Woodhead points to a "black hole" in government education policy - "the failure to understand that education is important because it is intrinsically valuable, not just because it contributes to our social and economic good".

Mr Blunkett's friends rejected this view last night and said that Mr Woodhead himself had constantly argued behind the scenes for a primary curriculum that had no prescribed subjects beyond literacy and numeracy, and lobbied for the introduction of more vocational qualifications.

The chief inspector said he had only one conversation with Mr Blair about education away from his advisers, snatched on a staircase at a party at Buckingham Palace. "As I spoke, his brow furrowed and the usual smile vanished ."

A Downing Street spokes-man said: "I have no interest in helping columnists promote their columns. This government's commitment to raising standards is total and remains so."

Answering back
Chris Woodhead: "I have often wondered why Tony Blair seemed so sympathetic and yet turned out to be so incapable of seeing anything through. The real problem, I believe, is that he has failed to focus with sufficient rigour on what he repeatedly declared to be his number one priority. So reluctantly and sadly, I concluded that Tony Blair would never push through the reforms that we both - in theory - wanted. Nor was he prepared to force David Blunkett to follow my advice...

"David Blunkett has presided over a set of initiatives that has wasted taxpayers' money, distracted teachers from their real responsibilities and encapsulated the worst of the discredited ideology that has done so much damage since the 1960s. He has just not delivered. A generation of children has been betrayed."

David Blunkett: "It is a shame that Chris Woodhead has chosen to start his career as a Daily Telegraph columnist in the way he has. But that doesn't change my view that he made an important contribution to our shared goal of raising standards as chief inspector.

"My drive to improve schools has come from the deepest personal conviction born from my own experience of what it is like to be let down by school and seeing pupils in my constituency not getting a decent education. That drive and passion has been shared at all times by a prime minister who has a greater commitment to education than any of his predecessors.

"As a result of that drive this government has achieved considerable progress. It is simply untrue to suggest that the measures we have taken have not made a difference."
