"My drive to improve schools has come from the deepest personal conviction born from my own experience of what it is like to be let down by school and seeing pupils in my constituency not getting a decent education. That drive and passion has been shared at all times by a prime minister who has a greater commitment to education than any of his predecessors. "As a result of that drive this government has achieved considerable progress. It is simply untrue to suggest that the measures we have taken have not made a difference."

webTitle: Selby car driver 'may have fallen asleep'

fields.headline: Selby car driver 'may have fallen asleep'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The driver of the Land Rover that caused the Selby rail disaster may have fallen asleep at the wheel, police said today.
fields.body:
The driver of the Land Rover that caused the Selby rail disaster may have fallen asleep at the wheel, police said today.

Investigators said it was one of the possible reasons why the four-wheel drive vehicle careered off a motorway into the path of an express train, killing 13 people in the crash.

Police in north Yorkshire today recovered the bodies from the wreckage of the mangled GNER passenger train, but say further victims may still be discovered as the carriages are cleared from the track.

Ten victims of yesterday's train crash near Selby have now been identified. Another 70 people were injured when the high-speed Newcastle-to-London service was derailed by a Land Rover that had slid onto the tracks. The GNER service then smashed into an oncoming freight train carrying over 1,000 tonnes of coal.

During the night, the ground leading to the accident scene was flattened and wooden pallets put down to enable heavy lifting equipment to be brought in, a police spokesman said. He said that the operation to remove the shattered carriages was already under way and was likely to take many hours and even days. It was likely to be a long and difficult job, he added.

Relatives of those passengers missing and presumed dead were gathering at two reception centres set up in nearby towns, and were to be allowed to visit the crash site later if they wished.

The driver of the Land Rover that sparked the accident - Gary Hart, 36 - is said by relatives to be "inconsolable with grief." Mr Hart escaped the crash with minor injuries, having jumped from his car to call emergency services to warn them of the danger.

GNER today confirmed that three of its staff were unaccounted for after yesterday's crash. Two of the train drivers are known to have died in the crash, and a third was injured. Crash investigators hope that a black box recorder from the freight train will provide vital evidence on the cause of the accident.

A memorial service for the victims will be held on Sunday afternoon at Hensall parish church, a mile from the scene of the tragedy in Great Heck.

This morning there were still 15 survivors of the train crash at Pontefract general infirmary, according to A&E consultant Mike Playforth. He said two were in a serious condition - one with a collapsed lung and another who had been suffering severe internal bleeding - but both had improved overnight.

"I have just been up to intensive care to enquire about the two critically injured patients and they had a comfortable night," he said. "They are still poorly but not as critical as they were last night."

Mr Playforth said they would remain in intensive care probably until tomorrow.

Of the other 13 patients, he said: "They are a mix of mostly cuts, bruises and broken bones. They are stable, some of them are feeling very, very sad this morning and the impact of what has happened to them is starting to break through."

One of the survivors of the crash relived her terrifying ordeal today. Janine Edwards, a 22-year-old drama student from York, was treated at Pontefract general infirmary for backache.

She said: "With everything going on yesterday, I didn't have time to think, but I couldn't sleep last night.

"I saw people just lying in this barn, people just lying, covered in blood, just deformed. What I saw was horrible. I couldn't believe it."

fields.headline: Vodafone sponsors F1 team
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Vodafone is entering the high-octane world of Formula One by sponsoring the Benetton team, reports Julia Day.
Feb 23: Philip Morris signs new deal with Ferrari
fields.body:
Vodafone is entering the high-octane world of Formula One, with a one-year sponsorship of the Benetton team.

As part of a strategy to become a global brand, the Vodafone logo will feature prominently on the team's cars at all 17 races throughout this season.

"Formula One is an exciting global sport with tremendous public appeal and following," said Thomas Geitner, Vodafone Group Products and Services chief executive designate.

"Its massive television exposure across all continents will help us build Vodafone into a global brand," he added.

It is not known how much Vodafone paid for the deal but Philip Morris's Marlboro sponsorship with Ferrari is worth around £45m a year.

Last year, the telecoms giant signed a £30m sponsorship deal with Manchester United.

Vodafone will make its Formula One debut this weekend in the Australian Grand Prix at Albert Park, Melbourne.

The red livery will appear on the front and rear wings and nose of the Enstone-based challenger.

Young English racer Jenson Button is in Benetton's driver line-up this year.

The sponsorship replaces that of D2 Mannesmann, now called D2 Vodafone, which has been on the Benetton team cars for the past two years.

Vodafone purchased German telecoms company Mannesman for £105bn in 1999.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: From wallflowers to world-beaters in just 90 minutes: no wonder many of you are excited by Sven-Goran Eriksson's new England.
fields.body:
From wallflowers to world-beaters in just 90 minutes: no wonder many of you are excited by Sven-Goran Eriksson's new England.

Bella Abrams gets her praise in first. "Last night's game cheered me up," she chirps. "I had become resigned to only caring about my club as I felt completely let down by my country. I am glad that the FA has the courage to bring in Eriksson and hope that things get even better from here."

Her views probably reflect those of the majority of England fans today. But they still fall a long way short of the response from the Swedish branch of the Sven-Goran Eriksson fan club.

"Sven is just what England need. With him as coach England will be the best team in world!" exclaims Lars-Ove Bachzelt from Stockholm.

"I'm glad to see that you now can appreciate Sven's deep knowledge of football. Trust him, he knows what he's doing," reckons Mattias Ljungberg. "You are going to experience some truly positive and attacking football with him as your coach."

Meanwhile Per Olsson says: "For the first time in history I hope England qualify for the World Cup - and I am not the only Swede who hope that Svennis succeeds."

But amid all that joy and exuberance, there are a few prophets of doom out there.

"A wonderful night for English football and the new regime starts here! But then again, I believe that we said that back in 1974 when the new look England, got a 3-0 result playing their first game under Don Revie," says Len Pedroza.

"Look at the tears when all that ended - so let's keep our feet on the ground and not be too judgmental when the tickets to Japan and Korea have to be cancelled and St. Sven deserts to pastures new," he warns.

Len receives some unlikely support - from a Swede! "Eriksson is a weak coach in the long run," says Per Rosendahl. "He tends to let old players and friends play for too long a time. And he is very democratic in the extreme Swedish way - he has to ask everyone before he decides what to do.

"By his side he now has Grip and his mental guru Raillio," he says. "In a week or two I think Mancini, Hoddle and Keegan will be by his side too - not to mention Mihajlovic. You just watch and see!"

Meanwhile Paolo Nistri can't help thinking the reaction to England's win has been a bit too over the top.

"I am always amazed by the vehemency with which the England football team are announced as glorious world beaters whenever we manage to win a friendly. David Lacey reports that, "England appear to have rediscovered the art of winning" - when we have done no more than beat an average Spanish team in a match so meaningless that the term "friendly" seriously overstates its importance.

"It is sad that such weight is given to results like these, and high time that we took notice of matches that count: in tournaments", he observes. "Mind you in that case there'd be virtually nothing to write about."

England U-21s 0 Spain U-21s 4: your verdict

The reaction to the caning of England's U21 side can be summed up in five words: It's all Howard Wilkinson's fault.

"How on earth can he hold his head up?" thunders Joe Pepper. "He was instrumental in the sacking of Peter Taylor, who had worked wonders with the U21s. Since then he has taken a team that was looking unbeatable to the largest defeat on home soil in living memory. He is a dinosaur of a previous era, an era distinct only for being tactically inept.

"His first move as England U21 manager was to get rid of all the Nationwide League based players. This myopic view was evident last night when he fielded Mark Wilson, who has played only two competitive games for his club, both of which were in the Worthington Cup, and chose to ignore the likes of Clinton Morrison."

Michael Kitchen agrees. "The difference between the performance of the senior England team and that of the U21 side, should leave no doubt in the minds of FA as to Howard Wilkinson's future. There might be a vacancy in Dubai well suited to Howard's level of expertise," he opines.

Finally J Inman (not the Are You Being Served star, surely?) says: "Howard Wilkinson is shit. No-one understands what he says. His teams never play with any coherence. The one thing he had going for him was his insistence on developing international coaches, and the moment he had the chance he shipped Peter Taylor out.

"A 4-0 drubbing shows how Howard Wilkinson lacks resources, not our young players."

webTitle: Disaster avoided after driver is stranded on railway line

fields.headline: Disaster avoided after driver is stranded on railway line
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Another train crash was avoided last night after an elderly woman drove her car onto a busy main rail link between London and Portsmouth, just hours after a Land Rover on the line derailed a GNER passenger train near Selby.
fields.body:
Another train crash was avoided last night after an elderly woman drove her car onto a busy main rail link between London and Portsmouth, just hours after a Land Rover on the line derailed a GNER passenger train near Selby.

A 90-year-old woman drove her Morris Minor convertible from a level crossing onto the track at Petersfield, Hampshire. She was just a foot away from high voltage power lines that would have killed her.

Police immediately attended the scene and contacted Railtrack, which switched off the power to the line and stopped all trains for more than an hour while the Morris 1000 was winched to safety.

Police praised the quick actions last night of a 46-year-old motorist who averted the possible disaster by pulling the woman to safety and alerting emergency services to the danger.

The motorist, who chose to remain anonymous, said he had to stop the woman from going back for her handbag after he had dragged her from the vehicle.

He said he was following the old Morris 1000 along Kingsferndon Lane in Petersfield just after 7pm last night, when he noticed the vehicle was being driven slowly and erratically.

"I knew something was up when she started indicating right near the level crossing. I started beeping my horn to alert her and immediately dialled 999," he said.

"She turned onto the track and got stuck on the cattle grid next to it. She tried to reverse and simply slid between the grooves."

The driver pulled up beside the track and told the woman to get out of her vehicle as she was just a foot away from the live railway line. He said she refused to leave her car and he had to pull her from it and hold onto her as she attempted to return to the vehicle to retrieve her handbag.

The elderly lady said she was "very sorry" for the incident. Police are taking no action against her.

A police spokesman said: "The motorist's quick thinking may not only have saved her life, but also prevented an extremely hazardous situation for any trains using the track.

"In light of the tragedy in Yorkshire, we cannot praise his actions highly enough."

webTitle: Welsh children's charities call for radical improvements

fields.headline: Welsh children's charities call for radical improvements
fields.standfirst: Childcare agencies say the appointment of the children's commissioner should initiate a major rethink of child welfare
fields.trailText: A coalition of leading Welsh children's charities has launched a manifesto calling for radical measures to improve the lives of children in Wales.
fields.body:
A coalition of leading Welsh children's charities has launched a manifesto calling for radical measures to improve the lives of children in Wales.

The call comes as Wales begins a new era of children's rights with the Children's Commissioner for Wales, Peter Clarke, taking up his appointment this week.

The group of charities, who were instrumental in setting up the commissioner's post, have highlighted major obstacles to the wellbeing of many children in the principality.

One of their most urgent concerns is that the new commissioner does not have access to routine statistics on children's welfare. They say that no such figures are collated in the UK, so information that could be used to map children's quality of life is not readily available.

The manifesto, called Wales' Children Our Future, has been put together jointly by Children in Wales, Barnardo's Cymru, Children's Society, NSPCC, Save the Children and the Child Poverty Action Group.

It details the measures needed to help eradicate child poverty, educate and protect children, keep them healthy, build child-friendly communities, support families and support vulnerable children.

"The major charities meet regularly to pool resources and to identify campaigns and we really try to work jointly where there are important issues to be addressed," said Maria Battle of the Children's Society. "This is a good time with the appointment of the commissioner and in the run up to an election to really put children at the top of the agenda here in Wales.

"Devolution has made changes to the way things are done here and there are serious concerns particularly in relation to poverty indicators, health and education that are different from the rest of the UK. Because of the differences we felt that it was important that we put together our own document for Wales."

Gwen Carrington, Director of Barnardo's Cymru, added: "Many children and young people in Wales get a raw deal. Children born into poverty in Wales are likely to be unhealthy, have a poor education and limited employment prospects. They are also more likely to become homeless and to be exposed to crime, misuse of alcohol or drugs and to experience abusive relationships.

"We also need to look at the most vulnerable groups in our society - disabled children, children living away from home and children from refugee families - who are more likely to be socially excluded."

The charities are calling for an integrated approach to tackle the broad range of issues outlined in the manifesto which include:

 The creation of a set of child wellbeing indicators which can inform policy and track improvements in the quality of their lives.

 Increased powers for the children's commissioner to extend to non-devolved matters.

 A minister for children at Westminster and at the Welsh Assembly to ensure children have a high political priority and are central to government agenda.

 Increased financial support through child benefit, income support and new integrated child credit to counteract the disadvantages many children suffer through poverty and family breakup.

 Politicians to engage with young people so they can have a say in decisions affecting their lives.

webTitle: Welsh plan welcomes improvements in childcare

fields.headline: Welsh plan welcomes improvements in childcare
fields.standfirst: A new strategy for children in care encourages councils to act as 'good parents' and children to play an active role in their treatment
fields.trailText: A far-reaching children's action plan for local authorities in Wales has been launched by the Welsh Local Government Association and its sister group, Syniad.
fields.body:
A far-reaching children's action plan for local authorities in Wales has been launched by the Welsh Local Government Association and its sister group, Syniad.

The plan comes almost a year after the Waterhouse report on abuse of children in care in North Wales, and includes examples of good practice among the 22 unitary authorities.

It commends the move by some councils to use children in care to interview candidates for social services posts and help produce information packs and videos for young people coming into care.

Lynda Bransbury, head of social affairs for WLGA, said the plan reflects improvements that have been made in childcare.

"The recommendations that came with the Waterhouse report were narrowly based. They were about how to improve social services and they related mainly to officers who run social services and the politicians who at that time were sitting on social services committees. It was very much about improving what adults do for children," she said.

"The action plan that we have put together reflects how things have changed within local government and how children as service users now participate in how local government is run."

The publication of the action plan coincides with the appointment of the Welsh children's commissioner - a first for the UK. It focuses on local authorities' corporate commitments to children and is intended primarily as a tool for councils.

"What is needed is a mechanism for assisting local authorities to fulfill their new role including corporate parenting. The local authority as a whole is expected to act as a good parent and not just social services departments because all elected members now have that responsibility.

"There is a very strong sense within local authorities in Wales that one of the reasons that Waterhouse happened was because the children were invisible. They were contained within institutional care," said Ms Bransbury.

The plan suggests strengthening and supporting councillor's roles, developing services to comply with children's rights and fully involving children in these strategies.

Some councils who were consulted included suggestions from young people for council initiatives, some of which are highlighted in the plan. Around 100 organisations with links to childcare also gave their views.

"The plan also looks at the role of politicians within the authority. webTitle: Clarke pledges to involve Welsh youth

fields.headline: Clarke pledges to involve Welsh youth
fields.standfirst: Peter Clarke, the new children's commissioner for Wales, pledges to involve young people in all levels of decision making.
fields.trailText: Peter Clarke, the new children's commissioner for Wales, pledges to involve young people in all levels of decision making. Maggie Murray reports
fields.body:
The new children's commissioner for Wales, Peter Clarke, today begins the task of safeguarding the country's young people.

Mr Clarke, who takes up his appointment on St David's Day, said children and young people would be involved in the selection of all the team members who will work alongside him.

"In order to be a champion and advocate for children, I have to be in touch with the views of young people in a direct way. They need to have an input into all the services that are put in place," he said.

The new commissioner - the first in the UK - will have two offices, in Swansea and north Wales, and is expected to have a staff of 25.

Mr Clarke began his career in social work in London 30 years ago and was director of Childline Cymru before his appointment as children's commissioner. He is expected to have wide powers to review and monitor complaints procedures in a range of bodies in Wales, including social services departments, local authorities, NHS hospitals, GPs and schools.

"In my team I will have people dedicated to examining advocacy procedure and complaints systems, as well as a research unit that will gather data enabling us to pinpoint problem areas in children's services," he said on the eve of taking up the appointment.

"There are two major areas where I see my role as improving the lives of children in Wales. The first is by communicating with children and young people. We will use new technology to do this, and we may, for example, have dedicated links to every school in Wales so that email communication can take place."

He says there will also be outreach work, and adds: "There is going to be a lot of communication between children and us. Over time I hope that we will get views from children in Wales which we will feed into debates on various issues as they come up.

"Initially I want to look at the complaints procedures and advocacy systems that were recommended by the Waterhouse tribunal. I will need a children's lawyer because I do have the power to take individual cases through the courts. It is also important that we keep in touch with what is going on in other parts of the world, as well as keeping an eye on impending legislation."

He says the staff of the office will come from a number of different backgrounds. Those who are looking at service evaluation, for example, are likely to come from a social services background or from education or health.

"Those who are looking at communicating with children are at the core of what I want to do. I am going to be very open-minded about where I recruit from, but young people will be involved in every single appointment from admin right through to any assistants-to-the-commissioner that I may appoint. I am already talking to children about bringing together a panel to help me decide on staff," he said.

He added, "I was myself interviewed by children for the post and we are drawing on the experience from that. I am absolutely determined that what young people think will inform and influence everything that I do."

webTitle: Crash brings further chaos to train timetables

fields.headline: Crash brings further chaos to train timetables
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Travellers already suffering from rail slowdowns in the wake of the Hatfield crash today faced delays of up to an hour because of the Selby train disaster.
fields.body:
Travellers already suffering from rail slowdowns in the wake of the Hatfield crash today faced delays of up to an hour because of the Selby train disaster.

GNER services from London's King's Cross station to Scotland were departing on time, but terminating at Doncaster in South Yorkshire. From there passengers were taken by bus to York where a special train timetable was in operation.

GNER London-bound services originating north of Doncaster were also leaving on time but terminating at York. Passengers were then being bussed to Doncaster and transferred to London-bound trains.

The Hull Trains company was operating rail services to Hull via Goole instead of Selby, and Virgin CrossCountry trains between Sheffield and York were travelling direct and not calling at Doncaster.

GNER said it expected to operate its revised service "for several days" until the line between Doncaster and York reopened.

Railtrack said it was working closely with the emergency services on the site of the crash and would start the recovery process only when investigations had finished.

webTitle: Leader: No travel will ever be risk free

fields.headline: Dreadfully random
fields.standfirst:
No travel will ever be risk free

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Another place name, Selby, joins Hatfield and Paddington in the litany of recent fatal railway accidents and a beleaguered industry trembles anew. For the relatives of those killed and injured and survivors of the wreck, cause is a secondary question.
fields.body:
Another place name, Selby, joins Hatfield and Paddington in the litany of recent fatal railway accidents and a beleaguered industry trembles anew. For the relatives of those killed and injured and survivors of the wreck, cause is a secondary question.

Getting help to the victims was, of course, the first claim on the attention of police, fire crew and paramedics who were so impressively quick to reach the scene - another example of exemplary public service planning and provision - and of the public following the drama. Yet, almost as soon as the sequence of events early yesterday morning on this fast, flat stretch of the East Coast line became known, their nature was seen to be quite unlike those two previous crashes. Public policy consequences may be derived from Selby once accident investigators have done their work. But at this stage the accident appears to have been just that, a dreadful concatenation of random events. Subtract any one of them - the vehicle leaving the road a moment later, the freight train a moment earlier - the result might have been altogether different.

An irony of Selby is that there appears to have been a direct connection between what happened on a road and the railway. The two forms of transport are bound together. Rail freight and some types of road haulage compete and the government, at last, is seeking to push the former. Some - by no means all - journeys can be made either by road or by rail and the case for rail is strong.

Measures of accidents per distance travelled show rail travel to be safer, but of course they do not excite the concentrated attention rightly paid such an accident as yesterday's. Rail is also greener. However forlorn he sounded in post-petrol protest political circumstances, environment minister Michael Meacher was spot on yesterday in saying our car culture and climate deterioration are causally linked.

Nothing that happened at Selby should delay plans to upgrade east and west coast intercity rail lines, which of course means faster trains. Nor should it deter travellers. The economic health of the north-east and north-west, plus the future of such cities as Newcastle (see above), the starting point of a number of Selby's victims, depend on good rail links with the rest of Great Britain. Rail travel - no travel - will ever be risk free. No one can be immunised against the sometimes fatal operations of chance.

webTitle: 'There were screams, then a huge impact'

fields.headline: 'There were screams, then a huge impact'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Janine Edwards, 22, of York
fields.body:
Janine Edwards, 22, of York

"It was still dark and at first I thought there was snow on the track. But it felt thicker than that, like grit. I was told later by a railway worker on the train that we were already derailed at this point.

"The train wasn't that busy because it was so early in the morning but there were about eight or 10 people in my carriage.

"I heard screaming and shouting and the lights went out. I held on to the table in front on me and then there was a huge impact.

"My carriage was on its side. I was lucky, I was still in my seat, clinging to the table.

"But one lady, who was travelling with her daughter, had been flung into the air and was lying in the next corridor. Her leg was trapped.

"The man opposite me was streaming with blood. The window next to him was smashed and the frame had come out and hit him.

"His wife sitting next to him was covered in his blood. She stayed really calm and found a towel to try to stem his bleeding.

"People were all phoning the police and ambulance but they seemed to take for ever to get to us. We had to wait 45 minutes before they turned up.

"I was shaken and it was still dark and very cold.

"The daughter of the lady who was trapped was very upset. Her mum didn't know what was happening and didn't know who she was or where she was. I was cuddling her."

"Another lady in the carriage said she could feel a bone coming though her leg.

"It seemed like we waited ages for help. In fact I'm disgusted with how long it took the police. It was 7am before they arrived.

"We had only just gone under a little bridge before the smash happened. People had been flung into different seats. The tables were ripped up, chairs all over the place and windows broken.

"It was like a rollercoaster ride. It was strange; you could even feel the impact against your face as the train tried to brake.

"There are so many people badly injured. I feel so lucky. If I had been in the front two carriages, I think I would have been killed.

"When I got out, I could see four carriages on their sides. The two in front, which I think were the first class section, were up on the bank. The driver's carriage was in a field."

'The train's coming!' And then a huge bang

2 At 6.12am driver of Land Rover calls 999 on his mobile phone to warn of vehicles on track, as the 04.45 London-bound GNER passenger train approaches

4 Freight train carrying 1,000 tonnes of coal ploughs into passenger train

3 High-speed train ploughs into vehicles. Some of the carriages start to derail although train remains upright. 800 yards further down line train bounces over set of points throwing it into path of freight train

fields.headline: Hospitals quick to treat injured
fields.standfirst:
Survivors Serious injuries among 38 still being cared for

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Hospitals were treating 38 victims for a range of injuries last night following the north Yorkshire train crash. At least one was in a critical state, another was in intensive care and a third was recovering from emergency surgery.
fields.body:
Hospitals were treating 38 victims for a range of injuries last night following the north Yorkshire train crash. At least one was in a critical state, another was in intensive care and a third was recovering from emergency surgery.

Within minutes of the crash, the hospitals had instigated their well-drilled major incident plans and had begun to make sure operating theatres were free by cancelling non-urgent procedures.

Initially, some of the injured were moved across a muddy field to a barn which was transformed into a field hospital.

Then 76 patients were ferried in a fleet of more than 30 ambulances - or flown in west Yorkshire's air ambulance and two RAF Sea King helicopters - to hospitals in Hull, Leeds, Doncaster, York and Wakefield.

Though the crash site was isolated, the proximity of the M62 and a network of main roads meant that patients reached the hospitals quickly. After dropping patients off, the ambulances and heli copters took extra staff back to the scene.

Pontefract general infirmary took most casualties, 31 in all.

Fortunately, the accident had coincided with its shift change so there were almost twice as many nurses and doctors on site. Others who had been due to have days off were drafted in.

Three areas were set up in accident and emergency - a resuscitation area, an area for serious injuries and an area for walking wounded.

The first patients arrived at the hospital at just before 7.30am. Most were male and there were no children. The first to arrive were badly hurt but their injuries were not life-threatening. The next wave of patients, however, included some whose lives were in danger. Five were later transferred to the Leeds hospitals, St James's and the general infirmary, and Wakefield's Pinderfield hospital for specialist treatment and one underwent an operation. By the evening, nine had been discharged from Pontefract, 15 were being kept in for treatment and one was in intensive care.

Mike Playforth, accident and emergency specialist, said the patients had suffered a range of injuries and all were in shock. He said: "They are not speaking about it, they are all very shocked at what's happened. I think as you can imagine when you're travelling on a train and this sort of thing happens it is just unbelievable."

Patients consoled each other as they were treated and then while they waited for relatives to arrive.

Dr Playforth said: "I think because there are no restraints on trains, the sort of injuries that you get can be very varied. They range from head injuries to those suffered through being trapped by the legs. They tend to differ from those involving people in cars."

The hospital has had to launch its major incident plan twice in the last nine years - in 1992 after an explosion at a chemical works in Castleford, west Yorkshire, and following a pile-up on the M62 involving a tanker, coach and 10 other vehicles in 1995.

Dr Playforth, who had just stepped out of the shower at home when he got the call about the accident, said: "We are used to dealing with such emergencies, if you can ever get used to them."

Seven of the region's hospitals were forced to instigate their major incident plans.

York district hospital took 24 patients with less serious injuries. By teatime all but one had been discharged. Hull royal infirmary received seven patients, most of whom had suffered impact, chest, spine and head injuries. Three were discharged during the afternoon.

Three patients went to Doncaster royal infirmary, one of whom was "critical". The others were scattered among the remaining hospitals.

By mid afternoon, survivors were beginning to leave Pontefract general. Ann Homa, of Wetherby, said: "I feel lucky. I remember nothing. I was just reading the paper and suddenly there was all this noise. I felt like we had hit a branch and then it just got worse. I can't remember getting to the hospital."

Laurie Gunson, of York, said: "I was travelling from York to London on business and was at the counter of the buffet car when the crash happened. The carriage roof was torn off and I was flung down the length of the corridor and found myself on the floor together with a fellow lady passenger. We talked to keep our spirits up. The paramedics and fire service seemed to be there very quickly, it didn't seem long at all, and they were tremendous."

fields.headline: New blow leaves industry reeling
fields.standfirst:
Services PR disaster as curbs were starting to ease

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The crash at Great Heck, north Yorkshire, was the last thing the rail industry needed after spending the last four months nursing its shattered confidence following the Hatfield tragedy last October.
fields.body:
The crash at Great Heck, north Yorkshire, was the last thing the rail industry needed after spending the last four months nursing its shattered confidence following the Hatfield tragedy last October.

When senior industry executives woke up yesterday to learn that there had been another serious accident - the fourth in less than three years - they must have felt sick at heart. Would there be any end to the industry's misfortunes?

One executive, told of the barest details at a meeting with German colleagues,said: "I was made to feel awful. They said Britain was falling part with foot and mouth and now another rail disaster. It was difficult to take."

The severe restrictions imposed by Railtrack following Hatfield have been largely lifted, but many are still in place and in spite of the company's promises, there is unlikely to be a return to normality before the summer.

Inter-city services are being regularly delayed, some of the re-railing performed by Rail track has had to be carried out again and new incidents of rail cracking have been found.

However, there was some small solace and considerable relief that yesterday's accident was not due to a train running through a signal or a cracked rail, or a fault for which the industry could be blamed. The executive said: "It's little consolation. It's still a public relations disaster."

Yesterday's events are likely to concentrate the industry's efforts on trying to restore public confidence in a system of transportation that many, particularly in London and the south-east, have to use each day to travel to work.

Since Hatfield, passengers have gradually been returning to rail. Though they have little faith in the system, the car and the bus are not permanent alternatives.

It is on the long-distance routes where considerable gaps in the system still exist. Poor punctuality still plagues the east coast, west coast and inter-city connections between London, south Wales and the West Country. Some services have been 50% down.

Stewart Francis, chairman of the Rail Passengers Council, the independent body which monitors rail operators, said: "This is an enormous tragedy, and it has come at a time when passenger confidence in the railway network was slowly getting back to normal."

If yesterday's crash had been Railtrack's fault, the pressure on the government to renationalise the company would have been irresistible. As it is, the need for Labour to make a positive declaration on the future of the railways before the election, is overwhelming.

Railtrack will get a further £1bn from the government to help it out of its post-Hatfield mess, but it will be at a price.

The company will effectively lay itself open to tighter regulation, allowing inspectors to examine its books and report their findings to the rail regulator, Tom Winsor.

It means that Railtrack will have to appoint a new chairman to succeed the outgoing Sir Philip Beck, and a fresh board will eventually be appointed. fields.bodyText: The crash at Great Heck, north Yorkshire, was the last thing the rail industry needed after spending the last four months nursing its shattered confidence following the Hatfield tragedy last October. When senior industry executives woke up yesterday to learn that there had been another serious accident - the fourth in less than three years - they must have felt sick at heart. Would there be any end to the industry's misfortunes? One executive, told of the barest details at a meeting with German colleagues,said: "I was made to feel awful. They said Britain was falling part with foot and mouth and now another rail disaster. It was difficult to take." The severe restrictions imposed by Railtrack following Hatfield have been largely lifted, but many are still in place and in spite of the company's promises, there is unlikely to be a return to normality before the summer. Inter-city services are being regularly delayed, some of the re-railing performed by Rail track has had to be carried out again and new incidents of rail cracking have been found. However, there was some small solace and considerable relief that yesterday's accident was not due to a train running through a signal or a cracked rail, or a fault for which the industry could be blamed. The executive said: "It's little consolation. It's still a public relations disaster." Yesterday's events are likely to concentrate the industry's efforts on trying to restore public confidence in a system of transportation that many, particularly in London and the south-east, have to use each day to travel to work. Since Hatfield, passengers have gradually been returning to rail. Though they have little faith in the system, the car and the bus are not permanent alternatives. It is on the long-distance routes where considerable gaps in the system still exist. Poor punctuality still plagues the east coast, west coast and inter-city connections between London, south Wales and the West Country. Some services have been 50% down. Stewart Francis, chairman of the Rail Passengers Council, the independent body which monitors rail operators, said: "This is an enormous tragedy, and it has come at a time when passenger confidence in the railway network was slowly getting back to normal." webTitle: 'It was like a bomb had gone off'

fields.headline: 'It was like a bomb had gone off'
fields.standfirst:
The scene Survivors and rescue teams tell of carnage after 120mph crash

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The driving conditions were horrendous: sweeping sleet and snow, ice on the road, not to mention the early morning winter gloom. It would have been an unpleasant journey, even without a trailer loaded with another car.
fields.byline: Stuart Millar, Jamie Wilson, Helen Carter, Martin Wainwright and Angelique Chrisafis
fields.body:
The driving conditions were horrendous: sweeping sleet and snow, ice on the road, not to mention the early morning winter gloom. It would have been an unpleasant journey, even without a trailer loaded with another car.

But as the Land Rover and trailer headed west along the M62 through North Yorkshire, the driver could at least content himself with the knowledge that he was nearing the halfway point of the trip from his home in Lincolnshire to Wigan where he would drop off the blue Renault estate he was towing.

Minutes later, however, the journey came to a sudden and horrific end. A little after 6am, just as he approached the bridge which carries the M62 over the east coast mainline railway south of Selby, the driver lost control. Still doing about 60mph, the Land Rover, the trailer and the Renault swept off the motorway through a gap in the crash barrier and down the embankment before coming to rest on the southbound railway track.

The driver, 36, suffered whiplash injuries in the crash. But realising the danger his stricken vehicle posed for oncoming trains, he managed to get out and rang 999 on his mobile. The call was put through to the emergency services control centre in York at 6.12am. By then it was already too late.

As the operator took down his details, the driver shouted: "The train's coming," before making a vain attempt to warn the train driver. Seconds later, there was a huge bang as the 04.45 Great North Eastern Intercity service from Newcastle to London King's Cross ploughed straight into the Land Rover at 125mph.

As the train hurtled down the track at more than two miles a minute, some of the carriages started to derail. But many of the 100 or so slumbering passengers were slow to realise that they had been involved in a crash at all. Some noticed that the line had become rougher, describing it as a "gritty" feeling beneath the wheels. A few mistook it fleetingly for deep snow on the line. Then they noticed gravel flying past the windows and realised the train had left the tracks.

Even then, however, the carriages were staying upright and for a few minutes, it looked as if disaster could be averted. But about 800 yards down the line, the express bounced over a set of points which threw it into the path of a 1,500-tonne freight train heading in the opposite direction at 60mph.

The effect was catastrophic. The express locomotive - later revealed to be the same one involved in the Hatfield crash - was mangled in the impact and left strewn across the two lines. All nine of the other carriages derailed. The buffet car was thrown on to its end, forming a twisted pyramid with a wrecked first-class car. Another coach was thrown through the trees lining the track and came to twisted rest 50 yards away in an adjacent field; two more slewed off the track into the same field.

The freight train locomotive, carrying coal to Ferrybridge power station, ended up on its side in the garden of a house next to the track. Four of the wagons also derailed.

"Everything seemed to be fine," said Raymond Pringley, a former train conductor from York, who was in a carriage at the back of the express. "But all of a sudden the track seemed to give way under us and the lights went out and then there was strong smell of diesel."

For the first few moments after the carriages came to rest, there was silence. Then, through the smoke and darkness, survivors began picking their way through the broken glass, luggage and other wreckage to safety.

Mr Pringley got out through an emergency door and used a phone at the side of the track to contact the signalman, before returning to the train. "It was utter chaos. A lot of people were shouting. There were fumes and we were worried in case there was a fire." By this time, other passengers had used their mobiles to ring 999.

Within seconds of the first call to the emergency services at York an ambulance was dispatched from Selby.

It may have appeared callous to the villagers of Great Heck, who had been woken minutes earlier by the sickening noise of scraping iron and steel, but the ambulance crew ignored the casualties. Instead they walked up the side of the train peering into the carriages to try and make an initial assessment of the scale of the disaster. They were left in little doubt. "Appalling carnage - it looked as though a bomb had gone off," was how a spokesman for North Yorkshire ambulance service described the scene that greeted the crew at 6.33am.

Survivors

Thirteen people were dead at the scene, 30 were seriously injured, and another 40 had suffered more minor injuries. Inside the train, survivors were screaming for help while mobiles rang unanswered as anguished friends and relatives tried to contact loved ones on the train.

With the crash site shrouded in driving sleet and snow the crew returned to their ambulance and radioed back to York control the scale of the disaster. Thirty ambulances from all over Yorkshire, and Lincolnshire, were ordered to the site, along with two RAF SeaKing helicopters and the West Yorkshire air ambulance.

Five minutes later, the first of 20 fire engines arrived. "This is the worse scene I have come across in 14 years with the fire service," said assistant divisional officer Graham Buckle, from the North Yorkshire fire and rescue service. "When I arrived it was still semi-darkness, there were people wandering around and screaming for help.

"It was a scene of shock and bewilderment, people not knowing where they were. Many had dialled 999 on their mobile phones but were unsure where they were or what had happened. Many were not hurt but could not get out of the train so we forced open doors and broke windows to get them out."

The emergency services job was made more difficult by the location of the crash. "Our crews had to carry patients about 100 yards across muddy fields to the field hospital where they could be picked up by ambulance. It was very depressing and distressing," said Nigel Metcalfe of the Tees, East and North Yorkshire ambulance service.

As trauma teams from hospitals in York, Hull, Leeds and Pontefract headed for the scene, a triage area was set up on an adjacent farm where the most seriously injured were treated before being transferred to hospital.

Firefighters using heat- and sound-seeking equipment battled in the wreckage for hours to free trapped casualties, some of whom were heard tapping signals to rescuers and pleading for help.

Five hours after the crash the emergency services had given up any hope of finding anyone left alive. "We've swept the whole train four times with thermal imaging equipment and sound detectors," said divisional officer Brian Bell of North Yorkshire fire service, as his team made a final attempt to check reports of a weak voice from the void beneath the train's upended buffet car. Cautiously cutting a hole in the crumpled metal the firefighters lowered a colleague down a ladder. But he was soon back up with nothing to report.

By 1pm, the last of the survivors had been freed. Firefighters then began the task of removing the bodies of the remaining dead from the wreckage. The full extent of the carnage may be yet to emerge.

"There is debris strewn over a large area," said North Yorkshire police area commander Gary Barnett. "With the sheer weight of the two trains there's a possibility that as the wreckage is cut more victims may be found."

fields.headline: New misery for commuters
fields.standfirst:
Disruption Services face yet more chaos

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Travellers on the east coast main line face fresh further delays after the Selby tragedy, following more than five months of misery caused by post-Hatfield safety checks, floods, a landslide and improvements to Leeds station.
fields.body:
Travellers on the east coast main line face fresh further delays after the Selby tragedy, following more than five months of misery caused by post-Hatfield safety checks, floods, a landslide and improvements to Leeds station.

The familiar sight of temporary bus services and long diversions on local trains will greet north-south passengers for at least a week, while police and rail inspectorate checks are made on the wreckage.

Although four heavy lifting tenders were driven to the scene yesterday, the lifting of debris will not start for at least three days because of difficult access to the site.

The railway inspectorate, Railtrack and the two train companies involved will want information on how the trains collided and whether the disaster could have been less severe. Officials are looking at the role of set of points serving a local cement works' marshalling yard, which the derailed GNER express tore over between the first crash and impact with the goods train.

Research on whether the points helped jolt the express closer to the goods train, and similar detailed work will cause "massive delays", Railtrack said last night.

The line between York and Doncaster, which was closed in the autumn by a landslide at Great Heck, will take no services apart from repair trains and locomotives to remove the coal wagons.

The link between London, the north-east and Scotland will be maintained by diversion to Leeds from Doncaster and York. Bus connections will also be provided directly between York and Doncaster. Mainline services from Leeds to London will not be affected.

webTitle: Xan Brooks previews the Pandaemonium Festival 2001

fields.headline: Sublime, startling and, inevitably, bleeding pretentious
fields.trailText: What, precisely, is pandaemonium? The dictionary defines the term as signifying "wild confusion" or "a place of uproar and chaos". Xan Brooks wouldn't argue with that definition as he takes a look at the highlights of this year's Pandaemonium Festival
fields.body:
What, precisely, is pandaemonium? The dictionary defines the term as signifying "wild confusion" or "a place of uproar and chaos". Negative connotations aside, it's as good a way as any of tackling what is arguably the most eclectic and exotic festival on the calendar. From its inauguration in 1996, the London-based event has blossomed into a vibrant catch-all showcase, a celebration of art that defies easy categorisation. Pandaemonium 2001 includes special events, talks, screen commissions, installations and more than 150 film screenings (whittled down from over 1,000 open submissions). The official Pandaemonium website dubs it "a festival of bleeding media".

Pandaemonium, then, provides a rich lucky-dip of the sublime, the startling and the (inevitably) downright pretentious. Undeniably many of the films boast a crazed invention. Simply check out video artist Sam Easterson's idiosyncratic series of animal-eye shorts. In hitching a mini digital camera onto critters that range from the mundane (sheep) to the ridiculous (tarantulas), Easterson has but one grand ambition: "To create the world's largest library of animal point-of-views". Istvan Blasz's Another World, meantime, offers an unsettling account of a 14-year-old kid's day to day life on a Hungarian farm (entirely shot by the child in question).

Elsewhere there is The Dutch Act, Fred Pelon's mesmerising documentary about an Internet suicide club, and Allah Acbar (For the Love of God), by Israeli film-maker Uri Tzaig, which dares to break the act of creation down into a series of seven playful "advertisements". Or check out Nest of Tens, a haunting series of American vignettes (tales of missed connections and everyday madness) from artist Miranda July.

After that, you're largely on your own (although the official Pandaemonium website will help with schedule and booking information). Because what we have here is largely alien, uncharted terrain; a strange hybrid hinterland where cinema intersects with clubland and the weirder realms of live performance. Whether this is a fascinating cul-de-sac or the way of the future, Pandaemonium gives us mixed-up mixed media in all its glory.

The Pandaemonium 2001 Festival runs March 2-9 at the Lux Centre (box office: 0207 684 0201).

webTitle: Prescott's Commons statement on Selby disaster

fields.headline: Prescott's Commons statement on Selby disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, gave the following statement to the House of Commons at 7pm last night:
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, gave the following statement to the House of Commons at 7pm last night:

With permission, Mr. Speaker, I should like to make a statement about the tragic accident at Selby at about 6.20 this morning. I am grateful to the house, in particular to the honorable member for Brentwood and Ongar (Mr. Pickles) for concluding his speech and to the opposition for giving me the opportunity to speak at this later time, which allowed me to visit the scene and report back to the House.

The latest casualty figure is 13 killed. At this time we believe that that includes two train drivers. There are 75 other casualties, 10 of whom are in a serious or critical condition. I am sure that all honorable members will wish to join me in expressing our deepest sympathy to the injured and to the families and friends of those who have lost their lives in this tragic and horrific accident.

When I visited the scene, I again saw for myself the tremendous efforts of our emergency services and the many agencies that were involved in dealing with the accident. As always, they showed true professionalism, courage and efficiency in, yet again, the most difficult circumstances.

The house will want to join me in paying tribute to the North Yorkshire police, working in conjunction with the British Transport police and other forces, the local fire brigades and ambulance services, the Royal Air Force air sea rescue helicopters, which attended the scene, and the local hospitals that treated the injured.

The minister for public health, my honorable friend the member for Pontefract and Castleford (Yvette Cooper), is visiting hospitals this evening and will thank hospital staff for their work. I also want to pay tribute to the way in which members of the local community responded so quickly to provide help and comfort to the passengers who were involved in the accident.

Let me turn to the facts of the tragedy in so far as they are known. At approximately 6.20 this morning, a Land Rover was travelling west along the M62 motorway, pulling a trailer that was carrying another car. It left the motorway as it approached a bridge that crosses the east coast main line. The bridge is protected by crash barriers, but the vehicle left the road some 30 meters before the beginning of the crash barrier. It then travelled along and down the embankment, behind the safety barrier, before falling down the railway cutting and on to the track. In all, on present information, it is estimated that the vehicle travelled more than 100 meters from leaving the main carriageway before reaching the railway line.

The driver got out of the vehicle and phoned the North Yorkshire police. As he was speaking to them, the 4.45am Great North Eastern Railway Newcastle to London train, carrying more than 100 passengers, collided with the vehicle on the track. The passenger train left the rails as a result of the collision, but remained upright. Almost immediately, it collided with the oncoming freight train. The time between the emergency call and the first collision was 40 seconds, and the two trains crashed within seconds of that.

It is essential that this appalling tragedy is subject to the fullest investigation. A number of agencies are involved - the health and safety executive, its railway inspectorate, British Transport police, North Yorkshire police and the highways agency. All of them will conduct their own investigations. Therefore, I have asked the health and safety executive to provide me with an interim report within the next few days. I shall then make a decision on what further steps may be appropriate.

I shall ensure that report is made public.

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: An interim report on the Selby rail crash will be given to the government within the next few days, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, told the Commons last night.
fields.body:
An interim report on the Selby rail crash will be given to the government within the next few days, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, told the Commons last night.

In an emergency statement after visiting the crash site, Mr Prescott said that once the Health and Safety Executive had given him the report, he would make a decision on "what further steps were appropriate".

He added: "You can rest assured that we will strive to secure that safe railway. There will be a full investigation. I await the interim report to see what I do about it, but I will report back to you and the House as soon as possible."

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said Mr Prescott spoke for the whole House when he expressed "shock and sympathy for the victims and their families".

"We join with you in sending our sympathies and condolences to the injured and to the bereaved."

He stressed: "It is hard to know how to express what everyone feels, but nothing should stand in the way of our determination to rebuild confidence in the safety of the railway."

Mr Jenkin welcomed Mr Prescott's call for an early report from the HSE.

fields.headline: Road safety investigated
fields.standfirst:
Barriers Highways Agency to review policy

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: The Highways Agency is to review its policy on crash barriers at bridges over railways and trunk roads as a result of the Selby crash.
fields.body:
The Highways Agency is to review its policy on crash barriers at bridges over railways and trunk roads as a result of the Selby crash.

The vehicles involved in the crash came off the M62 well before the motorway bridge over the east coast main line. A Highways Agency spokeswoman said there were no marks on the crash barrier running across the bridge, and that the bridge itself had not been damaged.

She said that the barriers are built to a standard design, and run for 30ft either side of the bridge. They are built to withstand the direct impact of a car weighing up to 1.5 tonnes.

The agency said that the barriers were built after discussion with the industry and the railway inspectorate. They are maintained by the agency.

Other fences or barriers alongside motorways or trunk roads are the responsibility of local authorities or private landowners.

However, there was no fence or barrier on the M62 where the motorist came off the carriageway. The vehicles then careered down an embankment behind the crash barrier from the bridge before finishing up on the line.

Inspector Steve Page, of Humberside police, said the force was concentrating inquiries on how the vehicle came to be on the railway line.

Highways Agency representatives joined Railtrack, British Transport police, the Health and Safety Executive and a six-strong team from the transport research laboratory in Crowthorne, Berkshire, at the accident scene.

The M62 bridge was built in 1974 and is one of 589 Highways Agency bridges over railway lines, of which 230 are motorway bridges.

The railway inspectorate reported last night that 29 vehicles have come off bridges or gone through fencing in the last three years and two have been struck by trains.

The last incident was in February 1997 when a train struck a car which had fallen on to a track close to a road over a railway bridge in Oxfordshire.

Nobody was injured in the incident, Railtrack lost the use of the track for seven hours, and four arrests were made. The car's driver was subsequently jailed for 12 months at Oxford crown court.

In two further incidents, a motorist lost control of his car, which ran down an embankment and collided with a passing train at Burbage, Wiltshire, and at Three Bridges, Sussex, a motorist left the M23 Brighton motorway, and was struck by a passing train. He was killed and his passenger seriously injured.

fields.headline: Carlton's advertising revenue continues to slide
fields.trailText: 4pm: The advertising downturn will blight Carlton Communications' fortunes until the summer, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITV giant Carlton Communications has confirmed the advertising downturn blighting the network will continue into the summer.

Carlton chairman Michael Green told shareholders at the company's annual general meeting that advertising revenue had slumped by 5% since last October.

"The UK TV advertising market is subdued compared with last year's buoyant levels," he said.

"We believe a resumption of like-for-like growth is unlikely before the fourth quarter of Carlton's financial year."

Granada, the main power in ITV, recently said advertising income had declined by 5.1%.

Along with Carlton, it expects figures to pick up in the summer, when its financial year draws to a close.

The downturn in income growth has been caused by the lack of big sporting events, such as the Rugby World Cup that boosted 1999 figures.

The knock-on effect of the downturn in the US economy has also been a contributory factor.

However, Mr Green said the long-term prospects for ITV advertising are good as companies seek to protect the diminishing life-cycles of their products.

"ITV gives advertisers fast access to a mass audience. Interactive advertising offers an important new opportunity for television to gain a greater share of the total display advertising market," he added.

fields.headline: Tragedy returns to the tracks
fields.standfirst:
· 13 dead, 75 injured after freak crash · Car slews off M62 into path of express· Passing freight train in head-on collision

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Tragedy returned to Britain's railways yesterday leaving 13 people dead and 75 injured after a freak road accident caused a devastating collision between a high-speed passenger train and a freight train on one of the country's fastest lines.
fields.byline: Martin Wainwright, Helen Carter, Jamie Wilson and Stuart Millar
fields.body:
Tragedy returned to Britain's railways yesterday leaving 13 people dead and 75 injured after a freak road accident caused a devastating collision between a high-speed passenger train and a freight train on one of the country's fastest lines.

In an appalling blow to an industry already reeling from a series of disasters, a Land Rover hauling a trailer careered off the M62, down an embankment and was struck by a London-bound train on the east coast main line travelling at 125mph. The derailed intercity was then hit seconds later by a freight train travelling at 60 mph in the opposite direction.

The accident happened at 6.15am. Emergency services worked for more than five hours to free trapped passengers from the wreckage of the train at Great Heck near Selby in North Yorkshire.

Police were last night interviewing the 36-year-old driver of the Land Rover at Goole police station to try to find out why the car slewed off the M62 westbound carriageway. One theory being examined was a blown-out tyre.

The man, who is believed to have suffered only whiplash injuries, was delivering a car from his home county of Lincolnshire to Wigan. North Yorkshire police said he was in a distressed state.

Last night John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, told the Commons he had ordered the health and safety executive to produce an interim report into the crash within the next few days so that he could make a decision on what further steps needed to be taken.

Attention is likely to focus on the absence of adequate crash barriers at such a vulnerable spot. Although the bridge and a few metres either side were protected, the Land Rover left the carriageway before the barriers began.

The Highways Agency last night announced a review of barriers over rail bridges on motorways and trunk roads. In the past three years, 29 vehicles have come off bridges or gone through fencing, and two have struck trains.

The chief executive of Great North Eastern Railways, Christopher Garnett, made no attempt to hide his incredulity at the circumstances of the tragedy. Touring the crash scene, where his company's dark blue and crimson coaches lay mangled and strewn across a field, he said: "How can a car have got on to our railway line? It's terrible, unbelievable. It's something which has got to be investigated."

In a bizarre coincidence, the locomotive on the passenger train in yesterday's crash was the same as the one involved in the Hatfield accident in October last year, GNER said.

"We put different locomotives on different trains everyday. It had no material effect on the accident, it is just a coincidence," said a spokesman.

Last night the emergency services were still working to free 11 bodies still in the wreckage. Among the dead were two of the train drivers. A third driver who was in the cab of the intercity was among the 10 people remaining in hospital with serious or critical injuries.

The crash is the third major disaster on Britain's railways in the space of 18 months, following the Paddington crash in October 1999 which claimed 31 lives and last year's Hatfield derailment when four people were killed.

The Land Rover was travelling at about 60mph when it left the carriageway and its momentum took it over rough grass and gravel before toppling down an embankment on to the railway line. As the driver scrambled clear of his vehicle and frantically alerted the emergency services on his mobile phone, the 0445 Newcastle to London train travelling at 125mph careered into the Land Rover and its trailer.

The impact derailed the train, which slewed on to the northbound track where it collided almost head on with a 1,500-tonne freight train carrying coal.

Several carriages were crushed by the impact, while another was thrown down an embankment coming to rest in a field near Great Heck, where villagers were woken by the sound of the crash.

Drama student Janine Edwards, 22, from York, who was on the train, said: "I heard screaming and shouting and the lights went out. I held on to the table in front of me and then there was a huge impact."

The emergency services were confronted with a scene of utter devastation. An ambulance spokesman said the crash site was "like a scene from a bomb explosion".

A temporary hospital was set up in a barn before a fleet of ambulances and helicopters took the injured to hospital.

More than 100 firefighters used chain saws and thermal rescue equipment to tunnel to trapped survivors who were banging on carriage walls. The 75 injured passengers were taken to seven hospitals across Yorkshire, where 30 were described as having serious injuries. The remaining passengers were walking wounded.

The last casualty was cut free at 1pm, after Mr Prescott had arrived by helicopter to thank rescuers and offer condolences to the injured and relatives of the dead.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, told the Commons that all MPs shared "profound distress" at yesterday's accident while the Queen expressed her sympathy for those who had lost loved ones.

Last night, Gary Barnett, area commander with North Yorkshire police, said he could not rule out the possibility that the death toll may rise once the wreckage has been lifted.

webTitle: Naomi Klein on fighting free trade laws

fields.headline: Fighting free trade laws
fields.standfirst: The best-selling Canadian author of No Logo, the international anti-corporate activists' guide, begins her fortnightly column for the Guardian today.
fields.trailText: Anyone still unclear about why here in Canada the police are constructing a modern-day Bastille around Quebec City in preparation for a forthcoming American summit and the unveiling of the Free Trade Area of the Americas should take a look at a case being heard by one of the Canadian provincial supreme courts.
fields.body:
Anyone still unclear about why here in Canada the police are constructing a modern-day Bastille around Quebec City in preparation for a forthcoming American summit and the unveiling of the Free Trade Area of the Americas should take a look at a case being heard by one of the Canadian provincial supreme courts.

In 1991, a US waste management company, Metalclad, bought a closed-down toxic treatment facility in Mexico, in Guadalcazar. The company wanted to build a huge hazardous waste dump and promised to clean up the mess left behind by the previous owners.

In the years that followed, it expanded operations without seeking local approval, earning little goodwill in Guadalcazar. Residents lost trust that Metalclad was serious about cleaning up, feared continued groundwater contamination, and eventually decided that the foreign company was not welcome.

In 1995, when the landfill was ready to open, the town and state intervened with what legislative powers they had available: the city denied Metalclad a building permit and the state declared that the area around the site was part of an ecological reserve.

By this point, Nafta, the North American free trade area, was in full effect, including its controversial Chapter 11 clause which allows investors to sue governments. So Metalclad launched a legal challenge, claiming Mexico was "expropriating" its investment.

The complaint was heard in Washington by a three-person arbitration panel. Metalclad was awarded $16.7m. Using a rare mechanism allowing appeal to a third party, Mexico has chosen to challenge the ruling before a Canadian court.

The Metalclad case is a vivid illustration of what critics mean when they allege that free-trade deals amount to a "bill of rights for multinational corporations". Metalclad has successfully played the victim, oppressed by what Nafta calls "intervention" and what used to be called "democracy".

Sometimes democracy breaks out when you least expect it. Maybe it's in a sleepy town, or a complacent city, where residents suddenly decide that their politicians haven't done their jobs and step in to intervene. Community groups form, council meetings are stormed. And sometimes there is a victory: a hazardous mine never gets built, a plan to privatise the local water system is scuttled, a rubbish dump is blocked.

These outbreaks of grassroots intervention are messy, inconvenient and difficult to predict. It is precisely this kind of democracy that the Metalclad panel deemed "arbitrary".

Under so-called free trade, governments are losing their ability to be responsive to constituents, to learn from mistakes and to correct them before it's too late. Metalclad's position is that the federal government should simply have ignored the local objections.

There's no doubt that, from an investor perspective, it's always easier to negotiate with one level of government than with three. The catch is that our democracies don't work that way: issues such as waste disposal cut across levels of government, affecting not just trade but drinking water, health, ecology, and tourism.

Furthermore, it is in local communities where the real impacts of free-trade policies are felt most acutely. It is cities which are asked to absorb the people pushed off their land by industrial agriculture, or forced to leave their provinces due to cuts in federal employment programmes.

It is cities and towns which have to find shelter for those made homeless by deregulated rental markets, and municipalities which have to deal with the mess of failed water privatisation experiments - all with an eroded tax base. There is a move among many local politicians to demand increased powers in response to this offloading.

For instance, citing the Metalclad ruling, Vancouver city council passed a resolution last month petitioning "the federal government to refuse to sign any new trade and investment agreements, such as the Free Trade Area of the Americas, that include investor-state provisions similar to the ones included in Nafta".

Cities and towns need decision-making powers commensurate to their increased responsibilities, or they will simply be turned into passive dumping grounds for the toxic fallout of free trade. Sometimes, as in Guadalcazar, the dumping is plain to see. Most of the time it is better hidden.

fields.headline: EM.TV pledges to keep F1 on free-to-air TV
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: German media group EM.TV has promised to keep Formula One on terrestrial TV, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German media group EM.TV has promised to keep Formula One on terrestrial TV, as the firms behind the sport threaten to bring the company to its knees.

The Formula One carmakers have said they will scupper a deal that gives EM.TV control of the commercial rights to the sport, because it could see motor racing confined to pay-TV.

However, the German group today said it would broadcast the sport on free-to-air TV, even though pay-TV company Kirch co-financed the deal.

"We are not interested in putting it solely on pay-TV, so there is no reason for the car companies to be concerned," said an EM.TV spokeswoman.

"There has been irritation on all sides, but there is no need for it because all of us want to expand the business and make it more attractive."

A spokesman for FIA, Formula One's ruling body, confirmed that the organisation could veto any deal it regards as not in the best interests of the sport.

They car owners want as many viewers as possible to watch Formula One, as it publicises their products and boosts car sales.

"If there is a change in ownership of the commercial rights, FIA has 60 days in which to examine the arrangement. It has the right to veto it," he said.

The veto allows FIA to strip the commercial rights from holding company SLEC, which is now 75%-owned by EM.TV and Kirch.

If FIA carries out its threat, both companies will have paid £700m for a worthless asset and cash-strapped EM.TV could be staring at bankruptcy.

The other figure looming over the complex negotiations is Bernie Ecclestone, the billionaire owner of SLEC who can veto any change of ownership in the company.

But EM.TV today said it was in constant contact with the tycoon, and was "not concerned" with the possibility of him blocking the arrangement.

"We do not anticipate Mr Ecclestone stopping the deal," said the EM.TV spokeswoman.

In a further twist to the convoluted proceedings, Kirch can pull out of the deal if it is not satisfied with EM.TV's financial results, which must be produced before March 30.

EM.TV became a stockmarket pariah last year when it was forced to slash its profit forecasts by a staggering 90% following a series of accounting errors and ill-advised acquisitions.

fields.headline: Online estate agent closes its doors
fields.standfirst: Easier's farewell message
fields.trailText: The free online estate agent, easier.co.uk, yesterday abandoned its search for a buyer and ceased operating its website.
fields.body:
The free online estate agent, easier.co.uk, yesterday abandoned its search for a buyer and ceased operating its website.

The company had put up the 'For Sale' sign in November 2000, after spending millions of pounds on a massive TV and billboard campaign.

Its revenues - based on a model of selling customer details to third parties - failed to compete with such a level of spending. Shares, once worth over £3, ceased trading at 16.5p.

Easier announced its closure with a simple message on its website, and by emailing its 70,000 registered users.

"It is with great regret that I must inform you that as of February 28 2001, the easier.co.uk web site will cease operation," the email message said.

"Please do not reply to this email as there will be no one to read your mail."
