Commissioners decided to limit the amount of funding the UK government could hand out, and confined the scheme to assisted areas - those such as Cornwall - that receive funding from Europe aimed at supporting the continent's poorest regions. The new schemes allow businesses with less than 250 staff to benefit from state aid no matter where in England their regeneration project is situated. Larger firms will only be able to claim help if they are redeveloping sites within assisted areas. Mike Shields, chief executive of the Northwest Development Agency, which will help administer the gap funding programmes, said: "These new schemes don't go all the way to replacing the PIP, but they go a long way. It's really good news, I'm telling you." Mr Shields estimates that the new schemes could mean an extra £200m in public and private money is invested in brownfield land across the country next year. The schemes will provide a range of government support for regeneration programmes in which the final user of the development is already known, or in which the development is due to be sold on the open market. The local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, said: "This will allow us to harness the expertise and commercial awareness of the private sector, achieving better value for money for tax payers." The government is still in negotiations with the commission over a new regeneration framework under which state aid could be further extended.

fields.headline: BBC News in 10pm victory
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: ITV is counting the cost of delaying News at Ten for its Nearly Popstars special, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV is today counting the cost of delaying News at Ten for its Nearly Popstars special last night.

On a day when the nation was numbed by yet another tragedy, viewers switched on in their droves to watch both ITV and BBC news.

But the absence of News at Ten delivered a clear public relations victory to the BBC's 10 O'Clock News in the key late evening slot.

The bulletin, presented by Peter Sissons, scooped 7.5m viewers and a third of audience share at 10pm.

ITV's News at 10.25pm pulled in only 4.6m and a 26% share.

ITV didn't ignore the event - it made a late change to its early evening schedule slipping in a news special between Coronation Street and its movie Bean.

That pulled in 8m viewers - the biggest news audience for ITV this year.

Yesterday's Selby rail crash, the deepening foot and mouth crisis, an earthquake in Seattle and England's 3-0 victory against Spain made for the busiest news day since the resignation of Peter Mandelson.

ITV's Popstars documentary, which displaced the news, attracted 5.7m viewers between 9.40pm and 10.25pm.

Channel 4's new series of ER - featuring Dr Carter's continuing struggles with drug abuse - failed to generate the sort of audiences the show enjoyed at its height.

The medical drama pulled in a fairly average 2.8m viewers and a 12% of share at 9pm on Channel 4.

fields.headline: Alcohol al fresco
fields.standfirst: Ian Traynor on Moscow's street life
fields.trailText: Seryozha's 24-hour store on the corner of our street is a blessing. Shopping and driving remain a trial in Moscow, so it is ideal for that late-night jar of cheap caviar, hunk of black bread and bottle of vodka.
fields.body:
Seryozha's 24-hour store on the corner of our street is a blessing. Shopping and driving remain a trial in Moscow, so it is ideal for that late-night jar of cheap caviar, hunk of black bread and bottle of vodka.

Seryozha has more than a dozen brands of vodka, maybe 18 different bottled beers, plus the fizzy cans of alcohol-laced sugar that are all the rage. These lethal tinned cocktails are treated as soft drinks, as is beer.

There's also a cheese and bread counter, and a section doling out grim cold cuts. But there's only one queue, and that's for the drink. Seryozha's is really an off-licence, with its round-the-clock opening hours guaranteeing a steady stream of customers day and night.

The customers are mostly street drinkers. There's no stigma attached to being half-cut on the streets. Indeed, these stores serve as a substitute for the pub or cafe societies of other European countries.

Invariably every evening - rain, hail or shine, and currently in temperatures of minus 20C - a huddle of drinkers congregates outside. This is what passes for social life for the majority, who can't afford the much higher prices in bars. You can buy a bottle of extra-strong Russian-brewed beer here for 45 cents. In a bar it might cost five times that.

One of the most striking sights for a newcomer to Moscow must be the scale of street drinking. In the parks, in the metro, huddled outside stores, walking down any city street, young men or prim middle-aged women clutch bottles of beer and cans of carbonated alcohol.

It's less common to see someone clasping a bottle of vodka, though the average Russian male is thought to imbibe almost a litre of it a week. Temperance, in short, is not a word that figures prominently in the vocabulary of most Muscovites.

After the revolution Lenin continued with the dry laws that the Romanovs imposed at the outbreak of the first world war. Mikhail Gorbachev traumatised Russians by rationing vodka in 1985 which, in turn, made many country crones rich from the moonshine boom. Vladimir Putin has limited himself so far to pushing up vodka prices by 30%.

It was the 90s, Boris Yeltsin's era, that put drinking on the streets of Moscow. Gennady Kolomentsev, a KGB agent who ran the Kremlin's catering service for 40 years, revealed that Mr Yeltsin used to order several bottles of vodka and cognac every day from the cellars.

Mr Putin, we are told, is more of a red wine tippler. And his time in Germany has also left him partial to a Pils. But not on the street.

fields.headline: French letters from French Connection
fields.trailText:
3pm: French Connection customers buying a shirt will soon be able to stock up with something for the weekend as well, writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 1: Beattie lashes out against TV prudes
Click here to see the ad
Mar 1: Beattie's ode to mediocrats
Is Beattie right? Click here to talk
fields.body:
We've had FCUK t-shirts, FCUK watches and even a range of FCUK men's grooming products.

Now the famously provocative retailer is introducing a product that might have been made to carry its slogan - condoms.

From next month, French Connection customers popping in for a new dress or shirt will be able to stock up with something for the weekend as well.

The condoms, which come in matt black packaging and carry the FCUK logo, are not the first to be branded by a retailer. Benetton has already launched a condom under its Colors brand.

But other brands have actively fought against having their brand appear on condoms. A company that wanted to launch condoms carrying the Visa brand was prevented from doing so by the credit card company following a legal battle. Visa clearly did not believe the association would be beneficial.

The FCUK condom will make its first appearance in French Connection's new advertising campaign.

Advertising agency TBWA introduced a shot of the condom at the end of the commercial to satisfy regulators, who had called for a reference to safe sex in the raunchy new advertising campaign.

Shoppers will not be able to buy the condoms until next month.

webTitle: 'Worryingly high' number of student nurse dropouts

fields.headline: 'Worryingly high' number of student nurse dropouts
fields.trailText: The government must curb the student nurse drop-out rate and improve training courses if it is to meet recruitment targets, two major reports warn today.
fields.body:
The government must curb the student nurse drop-out rate and improve training courses if it is to meet recruitment targets, two major reports warn today.

Some nursing courses have a drop-out rate of nearly 40% and on average one in six students does not complete training.

Researchers said the numbers not finishing their nursing degree were worryingly high as vocational courses generally have lower drop-out rates than other subjects.

The government's NHS plan set a target of increasing the number of nurses in the health service by 20,000 over the next five years, while also filling the vacancies created by nurses quitting the profession or retiring. It is also aiming to reduce the drop-out rates for nurses and midwives to 13% this year.

But the two reports - by the National Audit Office (NAO) and the audit commission - put both targets in doubt.

The NAO report focuses on student nurses, while the audit commission investigated the training and development of qualified staff in the NHS.

The government pledged to train an extra 5,500 nurses, midwives and health visitors a year to meet the NHS plan recruitment target and the extra staff are key to meet other action priorities in the plan, such as faster treatment and improved care for patients.

However, the reports concluded that the ambitious targets could be still be achieved - but only if the drop-out rate was reduced and investment in education and training increased.

Both reports said the Department of Health had a package of measures to ensure problems were being addressed, but warned that changes and improvements were needed for the promises in the NHS plan to be delivered.

The audit commission report found that in the majority of NHS trusts, at least a third of nurses had not updated their skills in basic life support.

One in five trusts uses less than three-quarters of the training places for qualified nurses available to them, meaning millions of pounds dedicated to funding post-qualification training are going to waste each year.

Meanwhile, the NAO report said some universities offering nursing courses are already reaching full capacity.

Wide variations in the cost of training were also revealed in the report, with some universities charging five times more than others to educate each nurse.

Many colleges are finding it increasingly difficult to get enough good-quality practice placements in hospitals for their students, partly because of chronic staff shortages in the NHS, meaning there are not enough staff to supervise students.

The problems in finding proper work placements is limiting the expansion of training places and could threaten the proposed increase in student numbers.

A statement by the NAO said: "Sir John Bourn [head of the NAO] has concluded that delivery of the planned expansion in the numbers of new staff undergoing training depends on increased investment in teaching staff and accommodation at higher education institutions; achieving improved value for money in the provision of training courses; a reduction in student drop-out rates and a larger number of good-quality practice placements."

Health minister John Denham said: "These reports identify good practice and also highlight the fact that we have already taken action in the areas where there is room for improvement.

"We are committed to ensuring high quality education, training and development for all NHS staff.

"Well-trained staff are key to modernising the NHS and providing patients with high-quality services."

This year there were 50,000 nursing and midwifery students in training, as well as 14,000 others on other healthcare courses.

At the same time, nurse vacancies within the NHS have risen from 7,300 in 1999 to 10,000 last year.

Nursing unions' research shows health service bureaucracy is the main cause of dissatisfaction among those who decide to quit the profession or take early retirement - rather than pay and conditions.

The unions say many nurses opt for a career change because of the demands of frequently changing priorities imposed by NHS managers responding to government policy.

"Given the nod ahead of an unhappy David Seaman, he wanted an easy evening and got one." (The Sun)

"Enthusiastic and lively on a great debut." (The Mirror)

"The England captain was strangely subdued by his usual impeccable standards." (The Sun)

"Filled England's problem position on the left like he had been playing there all his career." (The Express)

"Ran all night and kept his head perfectly for the opening goal. His best England display." (The Mirror)

"Lively up front and was unlucky not to find himself on the scoresheet. The Spanish defence always struggled to deal with his strength and pace." (The Mirror)

"Led the line superbly and did everything Eriksson could have wanted." (The Sun)

Michael Owen (7.5)

"Showed glimpses of his vast potential and looked a constant danger." (The Mirror)

"Struggled early on, but settled down to create the opener." (The Daily Mail)

Substitutes

"A man with plenty to prove and made a great penalty save." (The Daily Mail)

Ugo Ehiogu (7.25)

"Inspired return capped by headed goal. Unlucky to concede penalty." (The Mirror)

Michael Ball (6.75)

"Had plenty to live up to, but not as prominent as Powell." (The Mail)

"A typically all-action performance." (The Express)

Gavin McCann (6.75)

"Looked comfortable on his England debut after coming on at half time." (The Mirror)

Emile Heskey (7)

"Was well placed for second goal to top a typically robust performance." (The Mirror)

"Possibly the easiest of his 42 internationals." (The Express)

fields.headline: Out of the game
fields.standfirst:
Toyzone joins e-commerce casualty list

More net news
fields.trailText: Toyzone.co.uk, the high profile toys e-tailer, yesterday added to the carnage in the e-commerce sector by closing the business, writes John Cassy .
fields.body:
Toyzone.co.uk, the high profile toys e-tailer backed by entrepreneur Tom Hunter and TV presenter Jonathan Ross yesterday added to the carnage in the e-commerce sector by closing the business, writes John Cassy .

The 15-month-old company's decision to shut its doors came a day after the online toy sector's biggest player, eToys, filed for bankruptcy protection in the US.

"We've been out in the market for the last six months trying to raise money with no luck, and when the market leader with revenues of $160m a quarter files for bankruptcy, you realise you've absolutely no chance of getting finance," said Matthew Freud, the PR guru who co-founded Toyzone.co.uk in November 1999.

"We had a robust business model and were making money on every shopping trolley, but ultimately investors just don't have an appetite for B2C plays."

A year ago reports suggested Toyzone could be floated for £250m.

Marketing, fulfilment and technology were all outsourced, meaning there would be very few job losses, Mr Freud said.

Toyzone generated sales of around £2m. Mr Hunter, who earned the title of Scotland's second richest man after selling his Sports Division retail chain to JJB Sports, was the firm's biggest shareholder.

fields.headline: Beattie rails against mistresses of mediocrity
fields.standfirst: Trevor Beattie, the advertising man who amuses and enrages in equal measure, asks what kind of utopia the arbiters of taste live in
fields.trailText: "There is a world, in a far-flung corner of our galaxy, where women have no nipples and motor cars, though legally capable of 70mph, never trundle a smidgen over 30. A world where alcohol never makes people drunk and is only consumed in moderation by responsible adults who appear to be at least 25 years old.
fields.body:
"There is a world, in a far-flung corner of our galaxy, where women have no nipples and motor cars, though legally capable of 70mph, never trundle a smidgen over 30. A world where alcohol never makes people drunk and is only consumed in moderation by responsible adults who appear to be at least 25 years old.

A happy clappy, cuddly wuddly world where no-one ever smokes, swears, fights, defecates, belches, farts or dies. Where nothing is better than anything else but might, on occasion and where the principles of fair competition are upheld, be deemed to be almost as good... probably.

A weasel-worded world, where coffee is never more than rich and smooth yet never less than harsh and bitter. Where hair is always healthy looking and no-one ever refers to quilted bathroom tissue as bogroll. A perfectly perfumed, hermetically-sealed utopia where busy people don't have time for pain. But where you home is at risk if you do not keep up repayments on a mortgage or other loans secured on it.

Kingston-upon-Thames? Nope. Advertising-upon-Television. The truth is out there alright. But we're very rarely given clearance to tell it. In full, anyway.

That's why we end up telling it like it isn't. We're told to."

Feb 28: Coke and GM carry Olympic torch
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is linking up with the Walt Disney Company to create Mickey Mouse and Winnie the Pooh drinks.

Coke-owned company Minute Maid will launch the Disney-branded drinks in the US this year.

They will hit the shops in the UK and elsewhere in 2002.

But in a first for Walt Disney, the drinks will not be temporary promotions sitting alongside other noveltry drinks.

Instead, the movie and TV company hopes its "Mickey's X-treme Cooler" and "Pooh's 100 Acre Wood Apple-Berry" will to take on children's favourites such as Tango and Sunny Delight.

The Disney drinks range will include milk, juice and water-based drinks, fruit punches and smoothies.

The Mickey Mouse juice drink has added vitamins and comes in flavours including Raspberry Rage, Bora Bora Berry and Citrus Chiller.

Mickey's X-treme Coolers will be packaged in single-serve pouches and plastic bottles.

The Pooh drink is a 100% juice, designed for younger children. It comes in four apple and berry blends, fortified with vitamin C and calcium.

The product will be packaged in single-serve drink cartons and plastic bottles.

Disney Consumer Products Worldwide president Andy Mooney described the move as "an exciting new direction".

webTitle: Beattie lashes out against TV prudes

fields.headline: Beattie lashes out against TV prudes
fields.standfirst: See the commercial here
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Advertising guru Trevor Beattie has launched a full-scale attack on advertising watchdogs after his new French Connection commercial was banned, writes Claire Cozens.
See the commercial here
fields.body:
Advertising guru Trevor Beattie has launched a full-scale attack on an advertising watchdog after it refused to allow the new French Connection commercial to be shown on TV.

He branded the decision "scandalous" berating regulators for letting "mediocrity" rise above ingenuity and creativity.

Mr Beattie, creative director of TBWA/London and the brains behind Labour's election campaign, accused the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre of censorship after it rejected his script for the advert saying it contained an "unacceptable level of sexual innuendo".

Mr Beattie began his attack in characteristically quirky fashion by reading out a poem about the state of UK advertising.

"Our TV script was rejected -- I'm not supposed to say banned - by the BACC. It could not be shown on national TV, even after the nine o'clock watershed. A spokesman was said to be 'shocked and surprised' that we even had the gall to send the script in," he said.

Mr Beattie slammed the BACC as condescending and out of touch with the British public, saying its hang-up with sex was impossible to understand.

He said the watchdog's rules stifled creativity and made it virtually impossible to make good commercials for TV.

"We don't get many complaints about our ads," he said. "The real scandal here is not ads like this but the mediocrity of most of ads.

"British advertising has to jump through so many hoops. People are allowed to watch all sorts of violence on their screens, but advertising has to be 'U' certificated."

The commercial, provocatively entitled "Kinky bugger", shows an attractive young couple engaged in foreplay. As they undress they whisper phrases to each other that, as in the last French Connection advert, contain only words beginning with the letters F, C, U and K.

But Mr Beattie, who created the traffic-stopping Hello Boys! campaign for Wonderbra, rejected accusations he deliberately courted controversy to gain publicity.

"The worst thing that can happen to an advertising campaign is for it to be banned," he said.

"If that happens you might get a few lines in a newspaper but you can't show your ad. What would be the point in doing that deliberately? You might as well not bother to shoot the ad."

The campaign will not appear on British TV, but cinemas will be allowed to show it alongside films with a '15' rating. The Cinema Advertising Association initially offered an '18' certificate, but agreed to downgrade it if TBWA replaced the word "copulation" with "collision" and introduced a "safe sex message".

The advert will now end with a shot of a French Connection condom, due to be introduced in stores later in the year.

fields.headline: LWT recreates race riots for Othello
fields.trailText: 1pm: LWT is courting controversy with a modern-day adaptation of the Shakespeare classic, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Race riots will be recreated tonight on the streets of London as part of a controversial production of Shakespeare's Othello.

LWT staged one riot in north London last night and it will shoot more scenes involving clashes between the black community and the police tonight.

The scenes are inspired by the riots in Brixton, Toxteth and Broadwater Farm in the 1980s.

The production team last night used a housing estate in Hendon, north London, to stage scenes of a raging mob battling with riot police.

Pyrotechnic experts created bursts petrol flames.

Tonight, a south London police station is to be used as the scene for more race-related violence.

Around 100 extras took part in the riot scenes.

The production is the latest adaptation by script writer Andrew Davies, who was behind the acclaimed TV versions of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice and Kingsley Amis's Take a Girl Like You.

The adaptation is bound to upset Shakespeare purists - Othello is portrayed as the first black commissioner of the Metropolitan police.

Mr Davies, who is notorious for embellishing literary classics, is also planning to include some racy scenes of Othello "making the beast with two backs" with Desdemona.

Eamonn Walker plays John Othello, with Christopher Ecclestone as his angry lieutentant Jago and Keeley Hawes as his wife Dessie.

The drama is being directed by Geoffrey Sax, who was behind the acclaimed series Clocking Off starring Sarah Lancashire.

webTitle: James Meek on the complexity of modern life

fields.headline: Things fall apart
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth, savage blizzards and now a catastrophic train crash. Suddenly it seems our modern and apparently robust nation is as fragile as a house of cards. The trouble, says  James Meek, is that we don't notice how complex our world is until things go wrong
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth, savage blizzards and now a catastrophic train crash. Suddenly it seems our modern and apparently robust nation is as fragile as a house of cards. The trouble, says James Meek, is that we don't notice how complex our world is until things go wrong
fields.body:
In their book The Collapse Of Chaos, Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart tried to explain that the apparent simplicities of our commonsense view of the world hid a teeming ocean of complexity. "If our brains were simple enough for us to understand them," they wrote, "we'd be so simple that we couldn't." Britain in the 21st century is a bit like that. If the web of electricity cables, microwaves, rails, roads, airways, computers, fibre-optic links, retailers, distributors, sewage systems, phone lines, warning systems, farmers and manufacturers was simple enough for us to understand it, it would be too simple to exist.

We only notice the complexity of the technology we have come to rely on when it stops working. We only marvel at smooth roads and cars travelling along them at 90 miles an hour when they are blocked by snow. We only realise the incredible level of mechanisation and international animal-shuffling of modern farming when a disease breaks out in livestock at opposite ends of the country and rural life shuts down.

We only remember that it is complicated to have hundreds of people and tonnes of goods, travelling in four different directions, on two levels, in two different kinds of transport, in all weathers, at combined speeds of hundreds of miles an hour, when they collide and people are killed.

Except that we don't marvel, we don't realise, and we don't remember. By entering a "just-in-time" era of high-speed transport and communication, with high standards of health care and thousands of standard products available anywhere, anytime, we have only raised our threshhold of expectations. We think of technology and the fantastic degree of organisation and interlinkage that makes Britain work, when we think of it at all, as making the country a more convenient place to live. Often it does. But convenient isn't the same as robust. When things go wrong, convenient Britain can turn out to be fragile Britain.

Cohen recalls the words of Arthur C Clarke: "Any well-developed technology is indistinguishable from magic."

"We've turned so much of our technology into magic that when it turns into something else it seems hard to comprehend," he says. "Like when getting into a room in Newcastle and walking out of the room a few hours later in London turns into a train, crashing into another train.

"It's a lot to do with how complicated life is. We couldn't live the kind of complicated life we live if we had to deal with our own waste, build our own fires and generate our own electricity. It's only when things go wrong, when trains crash and sewage floods into the street that you remember the complexity is there."

The piling-on of crises and disasters can give the impression that Britain stands on the brink of chaos. For once, the Queen spoke for many people yesterday when she said of the Selby train disaster: "This is a particularly shocking tragedy coming on top of so much anxiety and loss from the foot-and-mouth outbreak and, before that, the recent floods."

She could have added the autumn fuel crisis, the Hatfield disaster and its aftermath, and an unlucky bag of other mixed woes. It's tempting to invoke chaos the ory; the notion that a small event, such as the flutter of a butterfly's wings, can produce huge consequences elsewhere, like a tropical storm.

But chaos theory is not involved. The common factor is the ugly sister of chaos - complexity. "In the jargon of the mathematicians, this is complexity rather than chaos," says Ian Stewart. "A lot of people get them mixed up."

Chaos theory, first developed by meteorologist Edward Lorenz in the 60s, involved unpredictable results emerging from minute changes in the data fed into a calculation. It was all about simple systems obeying simple rules - as the weather, for all its unpredictability, does.

Complexity produces unpredictable results from the interaction of a whole host of actions which, by themselves, seem simple. The fuel crisis, says Stewart, was a classic example - a protest outside a few oil refineries could shut down an entire country with astonishing swiftness. So are the paralysing effects of computer viruses, simple programs that can bring great institutions to their knees because of their complete reliance on technology.

"Complexity is the world we live in. People still think it isn't. People still think that when they go to a supermarket and buy a pound of meat it's exactly the same thing they used to do 30 years ago when they went to a shop up the road. In no respect is it the same. The meat has gone through the hands of 75 different people. It might be a French sheep, slaughtered in Belgium, butchered in Germany, part sent to Saudi Arabia and part sent here.

"I blame the training of today's managers. They've not been trained to think about robustness and stability. They've been trained to think about efficiency. Efficiency, to a modern manager, means that every conceivable component is just about to break down.

"The big problem here is reductionist managers operating with a complex system as if it was simple."

In complex Britain, a problem can not only spread rapidly, as it has with foot and mouth disease, but problems can be compounded by other problems. In the Scottish Borders, where snowfalls have been so deep that they have been compared with the savage winter of 1947, many farmers postponed deliveries of feed and fuel and didn't clear the snow from their roads as normal because of fear of infection. Now, with electricity supplies cut off by the weather, many are in desparate need for fuel for emergency generators - but the snow is still blocking their roads.

The speed and efficiency of the rescue operation around the Selby crash was an example of complexity at its best. The reason why the car and its trailer came off the motorway are not yet known. But the conjunction of the country's fastest rail line and one of its major roads were ultimately summoned up by our demand for speed and efficiency, our impatience with delays and hitches.

"We're a very intolerant society nowadays," says Andrew Porteous, professor of environmental science and technology at the Open University. "We expect instant perfection. You see it everywhere. People have a fit when their computer crashes. They don't expect it to happen."

In low-tech societies, such as Britain in the past, or parts of the developing world today, societies tend to take a more fatalistic attitude to disasters and crises. It doesn't protect them from destitution or suicidal despair. Nor does it stop them doing everything they can to put things right. If we have become impatient with technology which might as well be magic to us, people such as the cattle-herding Fulani of Nigeria and Cameroon make no distinction between magic and technology when they are seeking to cure their livestock.

The Fulani have a wealth of ancestral veterinary knowledge to fall back on - they practise a form of vaccination against foot and mouth disease in their cattle, for instance - but also go to wise men who, they believe, might cure their beasts by picking out good verses from the Koran.

Their low-tech world leaves them and their livestock vulnerable to a host of diseases such as rinderpest and HIV. They are at the mercy of the weather. At the same time, they are less reliant on technology they don't understand; they may have radios and bicycles, but they don't depend on them. The lack of a media blanket such as the one covering Britain means that a tragedy that affects one group has little impact on another 50 miles away. The lack of functioning African governments means that compensation and inquiries are not expected.

"Here there's the expectation of a safety net arrangement, of society owing something to them," says Phil Burnham, professor of social anthropology at University College, London, who has worked with the Fulani. "Out there, they may feel their kin owe them help in times of crisis, but there's no one else they can turn to, other than to pray."

In spite of the small backlash from environmentalists and anti-globalism protesters, compared to the Fulani, we remain wedded to progress, demanding of efficiency, and condemning when something goes wrong. We're hooked on complexity.

"The classic difference between peoples like the Fulani and a modernist society like ours is that we believe things are going to get better, that we're going to continue to develop new technologies, knowledge and science," says Prof Burnham.

"If something happens to suggest things aren't going to get better, somebody immediately starts blaming somebody, because there's a faith that science should be able to sort it. The idea that there are things we don't know about, or beyond our control - that's not a part of the modernist orientation. In so-called traditional societies, they think there are things you can't control. You can't just invest more money and get a breakthrough. Things aren't always going to get better tomorrow."

webTitle: Harry Potter trailer launched on website

fields.headline: Harry Potter trailer launched on website
fields.trailText: The long-awaited first glimpse of the Harry Potter movie was today posted on the film's official website to coincide with World Book Day
fields.body:
Harry Potter devotees can have their first glimpse of the upcoming movie adaptation today, as the trailer went live on the official web site to coincide with World Book Day.

Opening up with a flock of flying owls, who burst through the Warner Brothers logo, the trailer serves up a teasing assortment of sights and sounds from Hogwarts school, where the tale's hero is tutored in the arts of wizardry. It also pinpoints the moment when Harry (played by Daniel Radcliffe) discovers his magical powers after letters from a mysterious source invade the living room of his evil uncle and aunt. Early evidence suggests a high-gloss tale strung someplace between Roald Dahl and Charles Dickens, althought the trailer has presumably been assembled from scant material. Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is officially still in production.

The film adaptation of the first of JK Rowling's bestsellers has become national news since the project was announced last year. Rowling has been involved with the film from the start,apparently forcing original director, Steven Spielberg, to quit the project after she refused to allow an American child actor to take the role of Harry. The director's chair is now filled by Chris Columbus, best known for his Home Alone films and Mrs Doubtfire.

The star-studded cast includes John Cleese, Robbie Coltrane, Alan Rickman, Julie Walters, Dame Maggie Smith and Richard Harris. The film is due for release in the UK and the US in November.

fields.headline: Fresh cigarette curbs planned
fields.trailText: Pictures of cancer-ridden lungs may cover 30% of the surface of a cigarette packet under new European Union laws.
fields.body:
Pictures of cancer-ridden lungs may cover 30% of the surface of a cigarette packet under new European Union laws.

New rules on marketing tobacco will mean all cigarettes sold in the EU from 2003 must have a health warning covering almost a third of the packet.

Current UK warnings cover as little as 4% of the packet.

The wording will also take on a more explicit tone - with phrases such as "Smokers die younger" or "Smoking severely harms you and those around you".

Under the new law, individual governments can demand that the harmful effects of tobacco on the body are graphically illustrated on cigarette packets.

Words such as "light", "mild" and "low tar" will be banned from cigarette marketing.

It will mean that brands such as Marlboro Lights and Camel Lights will either have to change their names or be sold outside the EU.

The Marlboro Lights manufacturer, Philip Morris, said it would change the name of the product if the law required it.

The EU health and consumer protection commissioner, David Byrne, said the new laws should reduce the number of smokers in Europe.

He hoped it would bring down the number of smokers from one in three of the adult population to the US level of less than one in five.

Words such as "light", "mild" and "low tar" will be banned from cigarette marketing. It will mean that brands such as Marlboro Lights and Camel Lights will either have to change their names or be sold outside the EU. The Marlboro Lights manufacturer, Philip Morris, said it would change the name of the product if the law required it. The EU health and consumer protection commissioner, David Byrne, said the new laws should reduce the number of smokers in Europe. He hoped it would bring down the number of smokers from one in three of the adult population to the US level of less than one in five.

fields.headline: Political posters fail to make an impact
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Labour and Tory posters are not achieving the impact they got in the run-up to the 1997 election, writes Claire Cozens.Feb 27: Lib Dems unveil campaign poster
Feb 15: Tory posters blast bureaucracy
Jan 22: Election ad millions is 'wasted money'
fields.body:
Labour and Tory posters are failing to achieve the level of impact they got in the run-up to the 1997 election.

Outdoor specialist Concord said the latest political posters were scoring much lower recall levels among the public than those recorded for the previous general election.

This year's posters are scoring a recall average of 41 points out of 100, compared with 71 points in 1997.

It is a far cry from the 80-point impact made by the Conservatives' infamous "demon eyes" poster by M&C Saatchi in 1997.

Concord has measured the impact of the posters on several criteria: branding, colour and contrast, imagery, clarity of message, involvement and overall impact.

Labour's current campaign was created by TBWA/London and uses a pair of scissors to illustrate Tory cuts.

The Conservative campaign by Yellow M features a photo of a teacher engulfed with paperwork and promises teachers will not be pen pushers under the Tories.

webTitle: Foot and mouth spreads to Scotland

fields.headline: Foot and mouth spreads to Scotland
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The first cases of foot and mouth disease in Scotland were confirmed today as fears grow that the virus may have also taken hold across the Irish Sea.
fields.body:
The first cases of foot and mouth disease in Scotland were confirmed today as fears grow that the virus may have also taken hold across the Irish Sea.

Farms in Lockerbie and Canonbie, in Dumfries and Galloway, have been hit, along with Longtown, Cumbria, officials said.

Irish agriculture department officials are investigating suspicions that fraud was involved in the movement of a consignment of 248 lambs from a suspected contaminated farm in Northern Ireland.

In Britain, four more cases were expected to be confirmed later today, including one in Northern Ireland, two in Carlisle and one in County Durham, the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore said. Eight new incidents of the disease were confirmed elsewhere on the British mainland yesterday.

The alarm was raised in Northern Ireland yesterday as 200 sheep at a farm at Meigh, South Armagh, on the Irish border, were discovered to have been imported after being bought at a market in Carlisle. Farmers feared the worst after 21 sheep were discovered with symptoms of the disease.

The flock was destroyed and incinerated while a livestock importer and dealer were being questioned on suspicion that they breached animal movement regulations.

In the Republic of Ireland, the suspected lambs were delivered to the Kepak meat plant, at Athleague, county Roscommon - one of the Irish republic's biggest sheep and meat processing factories - last Tuesday, and were slaughtered immediately.

They were delivered in the name of a Roscommon sheep farmer but subsequent investigations by the department have established that the animals did not belong to the man whose name was used. The disease has not been in Ireland for 60 years.

The total number of animals slaughtered or due to be destroyed in Britain is believed to stand at 11,000, with 102 farms around the country under restrictions.

The new cases have brought the total to 29, as Mr Scudamore admitted it was "impossible" to predict how many more cases could be expected.

The latest outbreaks were at a cattle and sheep farm in on the Warwickshire-Leicestershire border; a sheep and pig farm in Essex; two Welsh farms in Powys; a farm in Herefordshire; an abattoir near Preston, Lancashire; a sheep farm in Leicestershire and another sheep farm in Devon.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, insisted measures to contain the disease, including the ban on moving livestock, were working as all but one of the new cases were linked to existing outbreaks.

Despite Tuesday's announcement to extend the nationwide movement ban for a further two weeks from Friday, Mr Brown said he was still determined to introduce special measures on Friday allowing some uninfected animals to be transported to abattoirs and enter the human food chain.

Cattle and sheep will also be held at sterilised collection centres before being sent for slaughter, although pigs, which are more likely to carry the disease, will only be sent directly to abattoirs.

The move was welcomed by the National Farmers' Union president, Ben Gill, who said the scheme was "badly needed" to continue putting British meat on shop shelves.

A compensation package for farmers of £170m has been announced by the government.

In Germany, agriculture officials confirmed that sheep imported from the UK had shown signs of the disease although more extensive tests on further animals were negative.

webTitle: EU staff bow to Kinnock reforms

fields.headline: EU staff bow to Kinnock reforms
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Unions representing the European commission's 20,000-strong workforce backed away yesterday from threatened strikes but warned they were still far from satisfied with Neil Kinnock's plans to shake up Eurocrats' pay and perks.
fields.body:
Unions representing the European commission's 20,000-strong workforce backed away yesterday from threatened strikes but warned they were still far from satisfied with Neil Kinnock's plans to shake up Eurocrats' pay and perks.

The former Labour leader unveiled radical reforms that would link pay to performance for the first time and remove a raft of anachronistic and politically unacceptable privileges.

The largest and most powerful union, Union Syndicale, had previously threatened to call a strike, accusing Mr Kinnock, the EC vice-president, of failing to consult it about the changes. But yesterday its president, Alan Hick, said his members had been placated after the EC president, Romano Prodi, agreed to meet one of the union's key demands.

However, one EU official, who declined to be named, claimed the unions had won no concessions: they had just been looking for a way out. "This looks like they're grasping a fig leaf so as not to have a strike. They have talked themselves into a corner and now they're trying to back down."

Mr Kinnock's plans, which now go through a four-month consultation period, include sweeping away a controversial bank transfer arrangement whereby officials are allowed to send up to a third of their salary home at a special low exchange rate. British officials have been able to make up to 50p on every pound they send.

A special travel allowance that allows Eurocrats to claim the equivalent of first-class return rail fares to their countries of origin twice a year will also be discontinued.

webTitle: US father faces child abuse allegations

fields.headline: US father faces child abuse allegations
fields.trailText: An American father who is taking a Welsh couple to court over the custody of twin girls bought on the internet has been arrested on suspicion of child abuse.
fields.body:
An American father who is taking a Welsh couple to court over the custody of twin girls bought on the internet has been arrested on suspicion of child abuse.

US police said they were investigating allegations that Richard Allen had sexually molested two teenage sisters at his home while they were babysitting.

A 13-year-old girl said an assault took place at Mr Allen's home in November last year. Her 14-year-old sister later said she had also been molested. Mr Allen is being held on $100,000 (£71,000) bail at a detention centre in southern California.

The arrest comes just seven days after detectives quizzed Judith Kilshaw, the British woman at the centre of the internet adoption affair, over the alleged theft of travellers' cheques used to fund the trip to the US with her husband Alan.

Mrs Kilshaw was released on police bail without charge.

The two couples hit the headlines after it emerged that the Allens claimed already to have adopted the baby girls before the Kilshaws took them to Britain.

Mr Allen, who served a writ on the British couple after they appeared on the Oprah Winfrey show, claims that he and his wife, Vicky, paid a fee to adopt the twin girls when they were six months old. He says the Kilshaws then abducted the children and took them to Wales.

In their defence, Mr and Mrs Kilshaw said they had used the internet to find the girls but they had not discovered the babies were already with Mr and Mrs Allen until they travelled to San Diego, California, to adopt them.

At this point Mr and Mrs Allen say the twins were snatched back by their biological mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, a twice-divorced hotel receptionist, and an internet adoption broker Tina Johnson.

In a fourth investigation, Mr and Mrs Kilshaw visited Mold police station in north Wales last week to provide statements about Ms Johnson.

Mr and Mrs Kilshaw were reported to have paid Ms Johnson a "non-refundable arrangement fee" of £8,200 after she promised to find a child for them.

fields.headline: Government clamps down on flyposting
fields.trailText: A London council is threatening to take legal action against sports giant Nike over an illegal flyposting campaign as the government plans a national crackdown on the practice.
fields.body:
A London council is threatening to take legal action against sports giant Nike over an illegal flyposting campaign as the government plans a national crackdown on the practice.

The move signals a new crackdown on global corporations that are willing to break the law to get products as mundane as catfood and noodles noticed.

The challenge to Nike is the latest move by Westminster city council to counter the flyposters. It has been particularly active in its efforts to fight the practice and recently introduced a type of paint that makes it impossible for billboards to be posted on its property. It is planning to increase its budget for fighting the flyposters by £200,000 this year.

"We are beginning to consider the origins of the problem and look at how we can target the culprits," said a Westminster council spokesman. "Practices like this create an atmosphere that makes it easier for crime to breed. Flyposting is technically illegal but, until recently, many councils turned a blind eye, reasoning that no real harm was being done."

The huge increase in the number of multinationals using flyposters - along with the establishment of specialist agencies dedicated to the practice - has led to a crackdown in both local and national government.

The Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions recently introduced guidelines for councils that explain the kind of action they can take. These include how to recoup the cost of cleaning up from the advertisers themselves.

A spokesman for the department said it was hoping to increase government powers in the area as soon as possible. "We definitely want to toughen up on this," he said.

Flyposting, once limited to independent record labels and music promoters, has expanded in recent years.

Major blue-chip companies such as Mars and Unilever are now just as likely to get involved in the practice.

Current campaigns plastered up on walls around London include those for Whiskas catfood and Batchelors Supernoodles.

Both campaigns are designed to look as if they have come from small rebellious companies unable to afford billboard advertising.

No one at Batchelors was available for comment and a spokesperson for Mars, which owns Whiskas, said the company was not willing to comment on its involvement in illegal flyposting.

However, a recent press release issued on behalf of Whiskas said the company was embarking on a "guerilla" marketing campaign that would include flyposting.

webTitle: In brief: Crowe and Zeta-Jones eye Onassis biopic

fields.headline: Crowe and Zeta-Jones eye Onassis biopic
fields.standfirst: Plus: Tom Cruise seeks more security; Owen Wilson signs for remake of I Spy; Monica Bellucci in line for Matrix sequels; Planet of the Apes trailer online now
fields.trailText: Plus: Tom Cruise seeks more security; Owen Wilson signs for remake of I Spy; Monica Bellucci in line for Matrix sequels; Planet of the Apes trailer online now
fields.body:
 Oscar nominee Russell Crowe is being tipped to take the lead role in a biopic of Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis. Based on Nicholas Gage's book, Greek Fire, the film will focus primarily on Onassis's love affairs and if rumours are to be believed, the Gladiator star will begin work on the project after he finishes Ron Howard's A Beautiful Mind. Catherine Zeta-Jones is apparently close to signing up to play alongside Crowe as legendary opera singer, Maria Callas, with whom Onassis had a long-term love affair. Entertainment site PeopleNews reports that Zeta-Jones has turned down the role of Elizabeth Taylor (see earlier story) in favour of the Callas role, which she believes is more likely to attract an Oscar nomination.

 Security around the current Tom Cruise film is reaching ridiculous proportions, according to sources close to the film. The Vanilla Sky set has become like Fort Knox, with extra security being brought in to check that no secret recording devices, cameras or mobile phones make it through. Extras on the film are apparently being forced to reveal the contents of their bags and cast and crew members have to go through a metal detector before they are allowed within 100ft of the 38-year-old actor. Cruise's publicist, Pat Kingsley tried to play down the reports, saying: "It is wrong to suggest Mr Cruise is being heavy handed. Yes he is insisting on high security, but only to protect the safety of himself and others." The move comes after Cruise's high-profile split from his wife, Nicole Kidman.

 Owen Wilson has signed up to appear alongside Eddie Murphy in the forthcoming comedy, I Spy, for 28 Days director Betty Thomas. Based on the 1960s American TV series of the same name, the film will centre on a top-secret government agent (played by Wilson) who helps recover a missing jet with the help of a professional athlete (played by Murphy). Wilson will next be seen alongside his Meet the Parents co-star Ben Stiller in Zoolander.

 Italian actress Monica Bellucci is in negotiations to star opposite Keanu Reeves in the back-to-back sequels to The Matrix, according to Variety. Bellucci, who most recently starred in the Italian-language film Malena, is hotly tipped for superstardom. The films are slated to begin production next month in Oakland, California. In addition to Reeves, original cast members Carrie-Anne Moss, Laurence Fishburne and Hugo Weaving are returning for the sequels which will again be directed by Andy and Larry Wachowski.

 The long-awaited Planet of the Apes trailer goes online today. Catch it at the film's official site.

fields.headline: Attic abandons Good Health
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Attic Futura is pulling out of Good Health magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Attic Futura is pulling out of Good Health, the magazine it publishes in conjunction with Jack Hay Publishing.

Good Health publishing director Bridget Marrison said Attic Futura had "taken a strategic decision to exit this particular part of the health market".

Attic Futura signed a joint publishing agreement last summer to publish the magazine after its founder, Jack Hay, resumed control.

Jack Hay Publishing said two publishing houses were interested in the title.

Six journalists on the magazine are facing redundancy if the company fails to find a co-publisher.

Good Health was published on alternate months to Attic's other health title, Real Health & Beauty.

Good Health was previously bought from Mr Hay's company Good Health Publishing by Sally O'Sullivan's Cabal Communications.

The magazine did not record a circulation at the last round of ABCs but a spokeswoman said the title was selling around 50,000 copies.

Attic Futura says that most of the journalists on Good Health are freelance, and the company would endeavour to redeploy the staff on other titles.

Good Health was previously bought from Mr Hay's company Good Health Publishing by Sally O'Sullivan's Cabal Communications. The magazine did not record a circulation at the last round of ABCs but a spokeswoman said the title was selling around 50,000 copies. Attic Futura says that most of the journalists on Good Health are freelance, and the company would endeavour to redeploy the staff on other titles.

webTitle: US father faces child abuse allegations

fields.headline: US father faces child abuse allegations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Babies for sale
fields.trailText: An American father who is taking a Welsh couple to court over the custody of twin girls bought on the internet has been arrested on suspicion of child abuse.
fields.body:
An American father who is taking a Welsh couple to court over the custody of twin girls bought on the internet has been arrested on suspicion of child abuse.

US police said they were investigating allegations that Richard Allen had sexually molested two teenage sisters at his home while they were babysitting.

A 13-year-old girl said an assault took place at Mr Allen's home in November last year. Her 14-year-old sister later said she had also been molested. Mr Allen is being held on $100,000 (£71,000) bail at a detention centre in southern California.

The arrest comes just seven days after detectives quizzed Judith Kilshaw, the British woman at the centre of the internet adoption affair, over the alleged theft of travellers' cheques used to fund the trip to the US with her husband Alan.

Mrs Kilshaw was released on police bail without charge.

The two couples hit the headlines after it emerged that the Allens claimed already to have adopted the baby girls before the Kilshaws took them to Britain.

Mr Allen, who served a writ on the British couple after they appeared on the Oprah Winfrey show, claims that he and his wife, Vicky, paid a fee to adopt the twin girls when they were six months old. He says the Kilshaws then abducted the children and took them to Wales.

In their defence, Mr and Mrs Kilshaw said they had used the internet to find the girls but they had not discovered the babies were already with Mr and Mrs Allen until they travelled to San Diego, California, to adopt them.

At this point Mr and Mrs Allen say the twins were snatched back by their biological mother, Tranda Wecker, 28, a twice-divorced hotel receptionist, and an internet adoption broker Tina Johnson.

In a fourth investigation, Mr and Mrs Kilshaw visited Mold police station in north Wales last week to provide statements about Ms Johnson.

Mr and Mrs Kilshaw were reported to have paid Ms Johnson a "non-refundable arrangement fee" of £8,200 after she promised to find a child for them.

webTitle: Leeds: Verve and confidence help prosperity, but a dark side remains

fields.headline: Leeds: Verve and confidence help prosperity, but a dark side remains
fields.trailText: When you hear that Leeds has got a new statue, images of Yorkshire pudding or rugby league may come to mind. But instead, in the busy "pocket park" of Bond Court, you can eat your sandwiches by the sculpture of a local family watching a bronze Frenchman at boules. Under the trees you may find French students, or a waiter from Sous le Nez or La Grillade, watching Yorkshire citizens pitch their boules.
fields.body:
When you hear that Leeds has got a new statue, images of Yorkshire pudding or rugby league may come to mind. But instead, in the busy "pocket park" of Bond Court, you can eat your sandwiches by the sculpture of a local family watching a bronze Frenchman at boules. Under the trees you may find French students, or a waiter from Sous le Nez or La Grillade, watching Yorkshire citizens pitch their boules.

It's a scene which tells the story of how one northern city has prospered through verve and imagination, as Raymond Vaillant, deputy mayor of Leeds' twin city, Lille, said when he unveiled the statue in October.

Like Lille, Leeds has reinvented itself with a self-confidence that assumes that the city's clubs and commerce giants like PricewaterhouseCooper, HSBC bank and Colliers Conrad Rittblat (donors of the annual Colliers cup for Leeds boules) will find an outdoor French game good for networking.

The buzz is palpable. Skating, at the temporary ice rink in Millennium Square, was sold out in February. This is where students dominate, another indicator of a confident city - and Leeds University vies with Nottingham as the UK's most popular.

But there is another Leeds, as the Labour council leader, Brian Walker, mentions even at the glitziest celebrations of this "British Barcelona". Leeds has families evicted from the Halton Moor and Hawksworth Wood estates for using airguns and lighting letterbox fires, a postal area (LS2) that is the most burgled in the country, and a recent "doped" gang murder on Lincoln Green.

The great debate, since Leeds won European assistance for five inner wards two years ago, has been whether the booming city centre can help. John Ansbro, director of the Leeds development agency, thinks it can. "Unemployment is down to 3.5% Leeds still has more vacancies now than people looking for work."

Skills and the jobs on offer do not, of course, perfectly match. And the general view is that there is maybe a 7,000-strong core of people alienated by endless hard times.

The regional development agency Yorkshire Forward has earned marks in Leeds for community and sustainability programmes. But government help is needed with jobs and learning schemes.

The big fear is that Leeds' overall boom could fast turn to bust. But fear, as they say on the boules piste, is the greatest enemy of self-confidence - and gloom is not excessively discussed.

fields.headline: Dot.coms sting Durlacher for £14m
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Investment firm Durlacher is £14m out of pocket after a string of bad investments in dot.coms, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Hi-tech investment firm Durlacher has found itself £14m out of pocket after a spate of bad investments in internet companies.

In less than a year, its market value has plummeted to £62m - a far cry from the £2bn valuation it enjoyed during its heyday.

Total pre-tax losses for the six months to December 31 were £13.9m from a profit of £5m and revenues of £6.7m.

The loss included write-offs of £13m, prompted by the dramatic change in the investment climate that wrong-footed Durlacher.

The past year has been a tough one for Durlacher - 18 months ago it was one of the leading lights of the dot.com boom, boasting a valuation of more than £2bn.

The value of its investments now stands at no more than £32m.

Durlacher is now said to be in talks with a competitor about a merger and hopes to have signed a deal by August.

"We remain focused on achieving our strategic objective of creating a premier European emerging technology and new media investment group," said Geoffrey Chamberlain, chairman of Durlacher.

He was responsible for turning Durlacher from a small stockbroker into a leading investment group.

Durlacher shares sank 11% on the back of the six-month figures to reach 14p, down from a peak of £3.94 last year.

Durlacher said it would now focus on Nothing-ventured.com, its own online brokerage service.

However, it will continue to pursue IPO agendas or trade sales for its investees, which include Talkcast, the451.com, Popworld, Shopsmart, Online Travel Corporation and 365.

Both the451.com and Shopsmart are rumoured to be discussing such trade sales.

webTitle: EU plans fresh curbs on tobacco merchandising

fields.headline: EU plans fresh curbs on tobacco merchandising
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Photos of cancer-ridden lungs may cover a third of a cigarette packet under new EU laws, reports Julia Day.
Feb 15: Clampdown on tobacco loopholes
fields.body:
Pictures of cancer-ridden lungs may cover 30% of the surface of a cigarette packet under new European Union laws.

New rules on marketing tobacco will mean all cigarettes sold in the EU from 2003 must have a health warning covering almost a third of the packet.

Current UK warnings cover as little as 4% of the packet.

The wording will also take on a more explicit tone - with phrases such as "Smokers die younger" or "Smoking severely harms you and those around you".

Under the new law, individual governments can demand that the harmful effects of tobacco on the body are graphically illustrated on cigarette packets.

Words such as "light", "mild" and "low tar" will be banned from cigarette marketing.

It will mean that brands such as Marlboro Lights and Camel Lights will either have to change their names or be sold outside the EU.

Marlboro Lights manufacturer Philip Morris said it would change the name of the product if the law required it.

EU health and consumer protection commissioner David Byrne said the new laws should reduce the number of smokers in Europe.

He hoped it would bring down the number of smokers from one in three of the adult population to the US level of less than one in five.

Related story

fields.headline: Northern renaissance
fields.standfirst: City-based regions could be the answer
fields.trailText: Just over a year ago the prime minister challenged the idea of a north-south divide. Some of his arguments were indisputable: the extraordinary prosperity to be found in parts of even the poorest regions; the pockets of poverty in the most prosperous regions.
fields.body:
Just over a year ago the prime minister challenged the idea of a north-south divide. Some of his arguments were indisputable: the extraordinary prosperity to be found in parts of even the poorest regions; the pockets of poverty in the most prosperous regions.

Where we disagreed was with his assertion that "the disparity within regions is at least as great as that between them" and his suggestion there should be "a more even-handed debate". The first ignored the depth and spread of deprivation in the north, while his even-handed debate, posed the threat of even-handed help that would only widen the divide.

Now, specially commissioned research for a Guardian North debate in Salford tonight, shows the economic divide between London and the once powerful northern cities has widened over the past four years and shows little immediate sign of narrowing.

Professor Brian Robson, a long-standing government adviser and head of the centre for urban policy studies at Manchester University, has compiled an array of indicators - GDP, unemployment, mortality rates, concentrations of deprivation and housing - all of which show just how far the north lags behind the south.

In his words: "The disparities are undeniable and their roots are systemic and structural." Merseyside, Tyneside and Sheffield have continued to lose jobs and people; Manchester has stood still; only West Yorkshire, reflecting a regenerated Leeds, has expanded. Yet even within half a mile of prosperous central Leeds and Manchester, now boasting penthouses, restaurants and smart boutiques, lie surrounding rings of dilapidated and unsellable terraced housing.

Professor Robson draws several lessons. First the need to encourage investment in more high-quality jobs in regional cities. There have to be more options for the trainees on the myriad new deal schemes than just the call centre or the job centre. He rightly notes that the current regional development agencies, which were given more budgetary autonomy last year, do not have the political clout or the resources, let alone a city regeneration focus.

Second, and most interesting, is his idea of widening the current tightly drawn administrative boundaries of cities to take in the travel-to-work hinterland. This would widen the tax base considerably and increase the argument for giving local government more tax raising powers. Current city regeneration policy falls between two stools: regional development agencies with their wide focus and the narrowly focused neighbourhood renewal schemes announced in January for the 840 poorest wards in the country.

Both are needed, but neither provide northern cities with the boost that they urgently require. Politically, all major parties will be wary of redrawing local government boundaries. Wilmslow's wrath was unconfined when it was placed within Manchester's postal area - later rescinded - let alone within its political reach. Yet the rivalry within regions between cities - Manchester v Liverpool - is well known. City-regions would be far more meaningful than the current idiosyncratic boundaries.

Last November's urban white paper failed to produce the renaissance that Lord Rogers's taskforce called for. Yet urban campaigners can focus on two other dates: an urban summit planned for 2002 and a state of the cities report in 2005. Redeveloping the north is as much in the interests of the south as the north. Without regeneration, northern migration will continue - as will housing demand on southern green spaces.

fields.headline: Norway cruise, Lennon abused
fields.standfirst: Helstad 20 49, Carew 30, Stensaas 37
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland were frozen out by Norway in icy Belfast last night, the Norwegians looking much more at home in the cold conditions, skating to an easy win.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland were frozen out by Norway in icy Belfast last night, the Norwegians looking much more at home in the cold conditions, skating to an easy win.

But the game was overshadowed by events surrounding the midfielder Neil Lennon. His recent move to Celtic, and his support for an all-Ireland team, have proved unpopular in some quarters and he was barracked by a group of home fans before his substitution at half-time.

He left the ground before the second half and went to his parents' home in Lurgan, where there is newly scripted graffiti on a wall that reads "Neil Lennon RIP".

Rumours circulated that he has decided never to play for his country again. But Sammy McIlroy, the manager, denied it. "No one has said anything to me," he said. "As far as I'm concerned he'll be in the squad for the next game.

"I've heard worse and there were cheers as well as boos. But it's part and parcel of the game. I actually thought it would have been a hell of a lot worse, the way people were talking about it."

McIlroy had plenty of other things to worry about after the heaviest defeat of his 14- month reign, such as the "non-existent" defence that allowed Norway three simple goals in the first half.

They changed to a flat back four for the second period, but within four minutes Thorstein Helstad's second goal of the night had killed the game. "That is the worse performance that I have had here as a manager," said McIlroy.

Northern Ireland (3-5-2): Taylor (Fulham); Hughes (Newcastle), Taggart (Leicester; Griffin , Dundee Utd, h-t), Murdoch (Preston); McCarthy (Birmingham; Johnson , Blackburn, 62min), Magilton (Ipswich), Lennon (Celtic; Elliott , Motherwell, h-t), Whitley (Manchester City; Sonner , Birmingham, 66), Kennedy (Watford; Williams , Wimbledon, h-t); Healy (Preston; Kirk , Hearts, 69), Ferguson (Linfield; Gray , Oxford, 69).

Norway (4-5-1): Myhre; Bergdolmo, Lundekvam, Stensaas, Berg (Eggen, h-t); Solskjaer (Aarsheim, 77), Tessem, Larsen, Bakke, Helstad (Berre, 77); Carew (Andersen, 77).

Referee: K Clark (Scotland).

webTitle: Police chiefs call for fair treatment of asylum seekers

fields.headline: Police chiefs call for fair treatment of asylum seekers
fields.trailText: The overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding and are entitled to the same protection to live free from harassment and intimidation as any other member of society, senior police officers said yesterday.
fields.body:
The overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding and are entitled to the same protection to live free from harassment and intimidation as any other member of society, senior police officers said yesterday.

Launching an official guide for all forces on meeting the policing needs of asylum seekers and refugees, its author, Robert Ayling, deputy chief constable of Kent, said that contrary to media impressions crime had gone down in Dover and the Kent area since the recent asylum influx.

"As in most groups, the overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding citizens. There are criminals who are asylum seekers and often their victims are other asylum seekers.

"Those who offend will be treated treated exactly as any other offender."

The Association of Chief Police Officers' guide stresses the positive contribution that asylum seekers can make to Britain, and goes as far as to suggest that forces should distribute welcome leaflets to newly dispersed asylum seekers, explaining their rights and responsibilities, and thus challenging inaccurate and irresponsible media reporting.

The guide says that intense media interest in Dover had focused on the apparent increase in crime since asylum seekers had come to the town. "In line with general trends in Kent, the local commander was able to report an actual reduction in all aspects of reported crime over a three-year period.

"This generally resulted in the national media not reporting anything, as this was not what they had been told by some locals and was not what their editors wanted. Local media was more positive."

Mr Ayling said it was "vital that communities receive accurate messages, and that irresponsible and inflammatory comments are avoided".

"Experience has been that where asylum communities have been established there has been ill-informed adverse media coverage, which has contributed to heightened local tensions and resentment of asylum seekers."

The guide makes clear that there is no question of the police being "soft" on crime among asylum seekers, and spells out how they need to co-operate with the immigration service in reporting and deporting illegal entrants.

fields.headline: A life inside
fields.standfirst: Grassing on fellow inmates - the worst crime a prisoner can commit. And  Erwin James  smells a rat ...
fields.trailText: Grassing on fellow inmates - the worst crime a prisoner can commit. And Erwin James smells a rat ...
fields.body:
One of the first lessons you learn in jail is: "no grassing." Anybody informing on his fellow cons, or even suspected of colluding with the prison authorities, is treated like a pariah. "A grass is worse than the worst nonce," Jack, an experienced prisoner, told me early on in my sentence.

It is a powerful message to those new to prison life: an unwritten golden rule that parades as an aspirational and binding community value. For the uninitiated it gives the impression that access to an exclusive club is on offer - members of which adhere to a certain code, and among whom there exists a particular kind of honour.

But it doesn't take long before you find out that in truth, it's a pretty rotten club. When I parted company from Jack and was transferred north, the prison officer to whom I was handcuffed in the back of the van took great delight in divulging that Jack was the security department's most reliable source of information in that prison.

Of course I was sceptical. Jack had been a respected figure in the jail. As a bank robber he automatically occupied a lofty position. And he was "staunch" - always first to bang on his cell door when unlock was late, or to rear up at the servery officers when the food was cold.

There were only two reasons, it appeared to me, why the prison officer should tell me that about Jack. Either it was true and he was trying to educate me in the duplicitous nature of prison life. Or it was false and he was trying to undermine any ideas I might have been forming regarding camaraderie among prisoners. "Divide and rule," Jack used to say. "That's how they keep control." Was that what the officer was attempting, I wondered. But then I remembered how Jack often spent time in the wing office. "Family problems," he would explain. He seemed to have a lot of those.

But what could Jack's motivation be? What about the "code"? Jack was always going to be a "con's con" - a stalwart defender of the prison culture. Doubtless his reports would reflect this. Men like Jack rarely give any serious thoughts to "rehabilitation". Did he gamble that by betraying the secrets of the wing, prison officials would reward him in some way? It seemed a perilous strategy. Life on the landings could be dangerous indeed for an informer exposed.

Eight or nine years later I discovered the existence of the official Inmate Informants System. The jail I was in had a flourishing magazine. One day an article critical of the informants system and the policy of offering inducements to vulnerable and desperate men was submitted. The amount of detail in the article led the governor to believe that a prison service security manual was at large. Apologies were proffered however, when it was found that the revelations had come from a new book on prison law available to all in the prison library.

Later I went to check the book out with the magazine editor. It made spectacular reading. Staff were instructed that prisoner informants should be offered rewards such as incentive bonuses in their pay, the promise of positive recommendations to the parole board, transfers to preferred prisons, or even recategorisation, perhaps to "open conditions" where town visits and home leaves were possible.

The part that really caught my eye was the paragraph explaining that the best informants were "prisoners who have the respect of other prisoners and who are regarded as above suspicion". "It's like a rats' charter," said the magazine editor. Jack sprang to mind. So he was not gambling after all.

Last week I heard that Feckles was on his way here. When I overheard him being described as "good stuff" I was tempted to issue a warning. "I smell a rat," discreetly whispered, would perhaps have been appropriate in the circumstances.

But no. Those who transgress and confide their transgressions on others have only themselves to blame for the consequences. And anyway, I might be wrong about Feckles.

webTitle: A tale of twin cities, reinvented and now thriving

fields.headline: A tale of twin cities, reinvented and now thriving
fields.standfirst: A mayor's vision and freedom to act got industry back on track
fields.trailText: A mayor's vision and freedom to act got industry back on track.
fields.body:
Up to 750 British tourists arrive in Lille on Friday evenings, joining Belgian and Dutch weekenders who leave the futuristic Lille-Europe railway station, walk past the skyscrapers of a new business complex and between sandblasted 17th century Flemish facades into the heart of town.

Lille resembles a British provincial city with pedestrianised streets, Marks and Spencer and packed bars. But it is much wealthier than its counterparts across the channel. The centre shows few signs of post-industrial woe. Tourists may ride on the city's two-line metro to visit A l'Huitierie, the city's two-star Michelin restaurant. Most will enjoy a drink in one of Vieux-Lille's revamped squares.

It may not be as posh as it was in its 17th century heyday, when the dukes of Burgundy ruled a thriving commercial centre, but Lille radiates success. Euralille, the major business centre that celebrated its 10th anniversary last September, is the focus. It employs nearly 6,000 people in its offices - half of them in banking and insurance - and many more in its shopping centre. Such is demand for office space that public and private funding are building Euralille 2, due to open in 2010. Lille has won the title of European Capital of Culture for 2004. Its centre will be the Palais des Beaux-Arts, the country's largest provincial art gallery, which has just been sumptuously refurbished.

Lille's new identity was unthinkable 15 years ago. De Gaulle's birthplace seemed past its sell-by date, an old Flemish town near the Bel gian border with an overwhelming aura of decline.

It had thrived because of the region's coal, steel and textile industries. When those collapsed - along with half a million jobs - the city, the hub of a conurbation of nearly 3m people, set about reinventing itself. How did Lille rise again? The city press officer is clear: "Our success is thanks to your Margaret Thatcher. She is the saviour of this city."

During negotiations for the Channel tunnel rail link, Mrs Thatcher agreed that the Eurostar should stop at Lille. But the person with Lille's interest close to his heart was Pierre Mauroy, known by some as the Bulldozer. A 72-year-old socialist, Mr Mauroy has been mayor for 28 years. "If they call me the Bulldozer, it's because the city needed to be transformed," he said.

And, unlike his counterparts in Britain, Mr Mauroy had the power to do it. The mayors of the great French provincial cities - Montpellier, Nmes, Strasbourg - have been able to imaginatively reinvent their patches.

This, and growing fiscal autonomy from the capital, has often lured senior politicians in Paris to establish regional power bases. In this month's municipal elections, a host of former and current ministers are standing for mayoral posts in the French provinces. Mr Mauroy's reign ends in a fortnight when he will hand over to a fellow socialist and former national politician. Until last year, Martine Aubry was Lionel Jospin's deputy prime minister. She has also served as Lille's deputy mayor for six years.

Mr Mauroy admits it is not all rosy; regional unemployment remains higher than the national average and Lille holds the national record for alcoholism per head. "But you have to realise where we came from," Mr Mauroy said. "I'm leaving a city that's renewing itself."
