webTitle: While England becomes ever more divided, Europe's provincial cities forge ahead

fields.headline: While England becomes ever more divided, Europe's provincial cities forge ahead
fields.standfirst: Report says uneven distribution of wealth has widened despite hundreds of millions spent on renewal schemes
fields.trailText: Economic divisions between London and England's northern cities have widened over the past four years and show little sign of narrowing, despite government plans to pump hundreds of millions of pounds into neighbourhood renewal schemes, according to a study.
fields.body:
Economic divisions between London and England's northern cities have widened over the past four years and show little sign of narrowing, despite government plans to pump hundreds of millions of pounds into neighbourhood renewal schemes, according to a study.

Presenting a dismal picture of two nations, with the south motoring ahead at the expense of less-favoured conurbations and regions, it portrays English provincial cities as pale shadows of their European counterparts.

Outlining "northern sluggishness and southern ebullience" in a new league table of city prosperity, Brian Robson, head of the Centre for Urban Policy Studies at Manchester University and a government adviser, and Iain Deas say that narrowly focused Whitehall regeneration programmes will fail unless they address the wider economy.

And with high-value companies ever more concentrated in the south-east, they warn that the prospects for a "reserve army" of workers in northern cities barely rise above the call centre. "What is it that trainees on the myriad of New Deal schemes can look forward to at the end of their training?" the research, commissioned by the Guardian, says.

The analysis (the basis for a Guardian North debate in Salford tonight), which could make grim reading for politicians desperate to bring new life to Labour's fragile heartlands, also warns of a "pressing need" to link the new-found prosperity of city centres to surrounding areas of "impoverished households".

"Nowhere is this seen more clearly than in the northern conurbations," the report says. "Despite the welcome recent city centre developments in places like Leeds and Manchester, go half a mile away from the new penthouses, restaurants, offices and multi-screen cinemas and you will be in the land of the forgotten - the endless rows of impoverished (private) terraces and half empty council housing where unemployment levels are horrendous, where houses sell - if at all - for less than £10,000, where crime or the fear of crime traps people in their homes where drugs are common currency."

Housing provides one of the more graphic illustrations of the north-south city divide. There is little sign of property markets collapsing in Greater London - unlike in parts of the north.

Outlining the "worst" 30 districts on a deprivation table, the researchers found that only one district in London and the south-east - Hastings - has houses selling at under £20,000, while 25 are in the north. And while acknowledging that inner London has a substantial number of impoverished neighbourhoods, they argue that the capital's poorer areas still have a buoyancy which contrasts with northern cities.

To place the performance of England's provincial cities in a European context, the Guardian asked Professor Robson and his team to draw comparisons with France, a country with a similar population although almost three times as large.

Using four indicators of employment and population change, GDP (or wealth) per head and unemployment, the researchers found that, across the channel, jobs had grown more markedly in the towns of the south and the west (from Bordeaux, Toulouse and Nantes to Montpellier and Marseille) than in the centre. But per capita, GDP remained remarkably uniform across the country with an "economically prospering set of provincial cities".

England, by contrast, displayed a consistent pattern of higher growth in Greater London and the south-east, followed by the midlands, with the north showing slowest growth. Calculations by Prof Robson's team indicate a "much greater evenness of economic performance across the provincial cities of France than is true of England".

Crucially, they note: "The regional problem appears to be an English phenomenon that is no longer shared with French cities." Prof Robson said the French pattern is repeated across most other European countries, making England the exception as a highly centralised country.

Underperforming

His report says that Newcastle-centred Tyneside, Liverpool-centred Merseyside and Sheffield-centred South Yorkshire have consistently lost employment, while Greater Manchester and Birmingham-centred West Midlands have remained static. Only West Yorkshire, reflecting the relative health of Leeds, had experienced some growth, while still underperforming. The only places outside London showing expansion on the scale of Montpellier, or Toulouse, were new towns such as Milton Keynes and Swindon.

Using a new method to chart the fortunes of London and seven English cities and surrounding conurbations, the Robson team has set urban assets - skills, quality of higher education, quality of land and buildings and efficiency of communications - against six performance measures, from the health of firms, to new business registrations, GDP and the number of economically active residents. They can then judge whether cities are performing to their full potential. On almost every level they are not.

Greater London stands alone in both the positive levels of its assets and performance, with even the West Midlands and West Yorkshire - conurbations which are supposed to have turned the corner - well below the capital with marginal performance "pluses" along with Greater Manchester. Merseyside, Tyne and Wear and Cleveland, on the other hand, have "minus" values.

"Greater London is clearly endowed with substantial land, labour, infrastructure and other assets and these are reflected, unsurprisingly, in terms of correspondingly buoyant economic performance," says the report. "Even for inner London, in spite of the substantial number of impoverished neighbourhoods - the strength of the asset base and resultant buoyancy are in conspicuous contrast to the listlessness of the provincial cities."

On the latter, it warns: "The pattern, for the most part, is one of economic underperformance and this potentially imperils government regeneration efforts."

So what to do? Given that the comparison with French cities makes a "sobering contrast", the report urges the government to channel more important research funding, currently concentrated largely in the London-Oxford-Cambridge triangle, to northern conurbations to encourage higher-value industries in cities rather than on (southern) greenfield sites.

It also suggests that the "illogically" tightly drawn boundaries of cities, such as Manchester, should be widened to reflect the wider conurbation.

Finally, the Robson team says there is a "pressing need" to link the new-found prosperity of city centres to the unemployed a mile or so away in areas often characterised by collapsing house prices. "Success in turning around the prospects of the cities is now all about linkages - between neighbourhood, city, region and nation, between departments in local and central government."

In short, says the report, it is time to act - before it is too late.

fields.headline: Seattle quake hits Gates conference
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Pictures of Bill Gates reduced to jelly by the Seattle earthquake have amazed web surfers worldwide, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Pictures of Bill Gates reduced to jelly after the room in which he was giving a presentation started to crumble around him have amazed staff and microsoft users around the world.

The computer billionaire was in mid-flow addressing a conference when the Seattle earthquake struck.

The stage, chandeliers and Gates all started to shake in unison as tiles fell from the ceiling and the audience ran for cover.

Some were knocked down by others trying to get out and overhead lights fell to the floor.

Then Gates himself was forced to leave the stage while inspectors checked the building.

Elsewhere in Seattle, the quake caused mayhem.

One person was killed and 100 injured, eight seriously. Microsoft headquarters in nearby Redmond suffered gas leaks, power cuts, and other damage.

fields.headline: Bags of style
fields.standfirst: Samsonite makes leap from luggage carousel to catwalk
fields.trailText: Samsonite makes leap from luggage carousel to catwalk.
fields.body:
Suitcases, it seems, are the new handbags. Hot on the heels of the renaissance of venerable luggage company Louis Vuitton comes a new name determined to launch itself from the baggage carousel to the catwalk: Samsonite.

Samsonite, started in 1910 with the promise of clothes trunks "stronger than Samson", was the first company to produce the now-ubiquitous wheeled suitcase. The label is best known for its bestselling Oyster suitcases and classic attaché cases. Now, with the help of 37-year-old designer Gigi Vezzola, previously head assistant to Dolce & Gabbana, Samsonite hopes to crack the fashion market with its Blacklabel range.

Vezzola is going after the kind of woman who prefers a sleek, well-designed but anonymous suitcase to a monogrammed Louis Vuitton trunk. This, his second womenswear collection, features comfortable, elegant basics: winter white fleecy skirt suits and car coats, trouser suits in salt-and-pepper wool with wide pink belts and belted olive velvet coats with leather trim. Shapes were slim and cosy: polo neck sweaters, ribbed cardigans with deeply cuffed sleeves and neat sheepskin jackets with fur-lined turn-up collars which looked perfect for napping on Concorde. Buttons and belts prominently featured the Samsonite propeller logo, one that the label hopes will soon be as well known as Chanel's interlocking Cs.

Appropriately for a company whose heritage lies in luggage, the highlight of the collection was the vanity case-style handbag. In pink or olive, made up of two stacked sections zipped together, they dangled from the models' wrists, boxy with a buckled strap.

 In Paris, the fashion rumour mill is already hotting up in anticipation of next week's fashion shows, with renewed speculation that Stella McCartney may leave her post at Chloe, either to replace the departing Alexander McQueen at Givenchy or to relieve Tom Ford at Gucci - a post she previously refused on grounds of her principle of not using leather or fur.

However, all the labels currently deny a move is in the offing.

webTitle: Gianni's vision remains Donatella honours her brother while claiming Versace name

fields.headline: Gianni's vision remains Donatella honours her brother while claiming Versace name
fields.trailText: Last night's Versace catwalk show in Milan confirmed that four years after the murder of Gianni Versace, the Versace name is no longer Gianni's. In the male-dominated environment of Italian business and family politics, the late designer's sister, Donatella, has achieved the seemingly impossible and made the Versace name indisputably her own. fields.body:
Last night's Versace catwalk show in Milan confirmed that four years after the murder of Gianni Versace, the Versace name is no longer Gianni's. In the male-dominated environment of Italian business and family politics, the late designer's sister, Donatella, has achieved the seemingly impossible and made the Versace name indisputably her own. That she has done so without straying from Gianni's vision, and without ever calling into question her devotion to her brother, makes her achievement all the more formidable.

Donatella Versace's secret is that she indulges women's love of fashion for fashion's sake, without ever forgetting that what they really want is to look gorgeous. Many designers have gone bankrupt through imagining that women will sacrifice looking good for looking hip; Donatella never, ever makes that mistake.

This season's silhouette, which Donatella called "an exultation of femininity", was long yet curvy: polo necks and voluminous shoulders to make hips look slimmer by contrast; high, wide belts to make legs look longer. The only bulk was in the turquoise-dipped mink jackets, and even these were dragged along the floor rather than worn, the better to show off backless dresses.

First on to a catwalk lit from beneath with flashing neon pink strip lights came tight, one-button-only trouser suits that would leave the average party dress standing for sheer jaw-dropping sex appeal; next were plunge-neck blouses tightly belted into stretchy bootcut trousers. All teamed, needless to say, with spike heels and huge sunglasses.

Last season's painterly splashes were revisited in a print of red and black feathers on slinky jersey dresses. A Versace dress always showcases cleavage or thigh, if not both -Donatella never lets the paparazzi down. There were attention-grabbing colours - a silk halter dress with zipped leather neck cuff came in emerald green, a slinky turtle neck micro-length sweater dress in shocking pink. But there were also the latest must-have little black dresses - a strapless, boned bustier number in ribbed jersey, and a plunge-neck, semi-sheer knee-length cocktail frock. Even seemingly demure floor length dresses had a kick. A coffee-coloured jersey dress looked positively chaste from the front, but fastened at the small of the back with bondage-style heavy buckled leather straps.

fields.headline: Viz achieves respectability
fields.trailText: 11am: Viz, the magazine that brought us the Fat Slags, is to be moved off the top shelf, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Viz, the magazine that brought us the Fat Slags, Sid the Sexist and a range of politically incorrect icons, has finally won its battle to be moved off the top shelf.

And in a move that reflects men's magazines' increasing leaning toward lad culture, the comic is now being classified as a "men's lifestyle" title.

WH Smith has confirmed it will move the magazine, published by John Brown Publishing, from its adult humour/graphic novel ghetto and on to the lower shelves beside Loaded, FHM and Maxim.

Ed Axon, publisher of Viz, said the move highlighted today's more tolerant attitudes towards taste and decency.

"There has been a major shift in public attitudes towards what is seen as acceptable over the past 10-15 years," he said.

"This is reflected in the controversial content of most men's magazines. It's therefore right Viz has been repositioned to join the men's lifestyle section.

"I am only thankful for WH Smith's measured approach to the subject."

Viz, which was started by Chris and Simon Donald, became one of the publishing sensations of the 80s when it accelerated the backlash against political correctness.

Its star waned in the 90s after the lads' magazine explosion.

However, John Brown Publishing is hopeful the move by WH Smith could rejuvenate the title's fortunes.

fields.headline: Jesus Christ, not again
fields.standfirst: Lack of interest almost killed off the latest art-inspired controversy. But they got there in the end, reports Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: New York dispatch: Lack of interest almost killed off the latest art-inspired controversy. But they got there in the end, reports Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
As scandals go, the latest collision between art and authority in New York got off to an uncharacteristically slow start.

The first anyone knew that Brooklyn Museum of Art, which has a track record in such matters, was showing a photograph of a naked black woman where normally Jesus Christ would be was when the Associated Press news service put out a piece that mentioned the work.

There it was, under the heading Living Black Photographers Get Due, in the seventh paragraph: "Renee Cox depicts a nude, female Christ figure in a five-paneled series called Yo Mama's Last Supper". And that was it. Not much scandal there, but then the AP had made the initial error in the genesis of an outrage of deeming the matter worthy of a review.

By the next day, the Daily News ("New York's Home-Town Newspaper") was on the case, elevating the matter to its proper position in the scale of things.

But even this was not as successful as it might have been. Its piece was a rather timid effort at scandalising the populace, saying that the museum "could" be back in trouble. The worst it got anyone to say of Ms Cox's photograph was offered by William Donohue, president of the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights. "It is unfortunate that it was included in the selection," he did not exactly fulminate.

The artist, though, was quite happy to take on her almost non-existent critics. "As an artist my role is to create a discourse the Catholic church should talk about.

"I don't think its anti-Catholic at all. I grew up Catholic. Being a Catholic, they are about business. Money. I don't believe in all the philosophy and how it's set up. Catholics had no interest in the abolition of slavery." And so on. You get the picture, as it were. Ms Cox may well qualify for the epithet feisty, but this was just not good enough.

A crucial element was missing. But New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani was only one day behind and finally had the good grace to give everyone what they required: the media got the story; Ms Cox's silly snap got attention it would not otherwise have received; the museum continued to show that it could do "cutting edge" (they had a bit of hip-hop a few months ago) despite all appearances to the contrary; and Mr Giuliani, who quits at the end of this year, was able to remind "his" city that he is still around.

"I think what they did is disgusting, it's outrageous," said the mayor, who added for good measure that it was anti-Catholic, thereby denying members of other faiths with an interest in Christ the opportunity of venting their anger.

"I'm going to look at what penalties are available for this." Now, that's much better, even if the answer is almost certainly "none." He talked about a visit to the supreme court and setting up a decency commission to keep this sort of filth out of institutions that receive public money. Rather appropriately, Mr Giuliani suggested that this decency commission might be made up of "basically decent people".

What must, in this context, be considered basically indecent people likened the mayor's performance to something akin to Berlin in 1939, though it undoubtedly had more to do with Brooklyn in 1999.

That was when the museum, sadly off the pace when it came to using art in the service of shock, found that it was actually not that difficult to wind up City Hall and whistle up hordes at the gates at the same time.

Then, the cause of outrage was the Turner Prize-winner Chris Ofili's Virgin Mary with elephant dung, part of the Sensation exhibition of pretty old work by no longer very young British artists. Mr Giuliani tried to close the museum and was defeated when a judge ruled that he had breached the first amendment, which guarantees freedom of expression.

This time the museum's director, Arnold Lehman, delivered himself of a po-faced statement: "Throughout history, the artist's responsibility has been to make us think."

It certainly worked with the mayor, who did not even need to see the exhibition in order to get the thought process going. "They do it on purpose; they do it to get more attention." For once he really was speaking for all the participants, himself included.

webTitle: Ali G heads for the big screen, innit?

fields.headline: Ali G heads for the big screen, innit?
fields.trailText: Sacha Baron Cohen, the creator of the controversial TV character, is working on a film version of Da Ali G Show
fields.body:
Ali G is to become a star of the big screen, if plans for a £5m film featuring the controversial comedy character go ahead.

The character's creator, Sacha Baron Cohen, is writing and producing the comedy drama which is based on his hit TV show, Da Ali G Show, the Sun reports today. The film will be made by Working Title, the production company responsible for such smash hits as Four Weddings and A Funeral and Notting Hill, and is scheduled for release next year.

TV actress Angela Griffin, best known for her roles as the feisty hairdresser Fiona in Coronation Street, is being lined up to play G's girlfriend, "Me Julie". The project will make millions for Cambridge-educated Cohen who will receive a cut of box-office takings and spin-off merchandising.

Ali G is a middle-class white boy who pretends he's a cool West Indian. After his appearance on Channel 4's 11 O Clock Show as a spoof "yoof" presenter who sent up politicians and actors, the character was such an immediate success that he was given his own series which pulled in around five million viewers per show.

But perhaps the greatest proof that Ali G had really hit the big time was when notorious trend-spotter Madonna chose him to appear in the video for her single, Music.

 More on Ali G.

fields.headline: Disney slashes more web jobs
fields.trailText:
11am: Disney's latest round of internet cutbacks has hit Soccernet, its football website in the UK, reports Amy Vickers.
Feb 6: Disney counts cost of online losses
fields.body:
Disney has wielded the axe across its internet operations for the second time in as many months.

This latest round of cuts have spread to Soccernet, Disney's football website in the UK.

Soccernet was one of the first and best-known football websites in the UK and was originally owned by Daily Mail publisher Associated Newspapers.

However, the newspaper publisher bailed out and sold the service to Disney who wanted to use it as a promotional tool for its ESPN sports TV network.

It is believed almost half of Soccernet's staff, including the entire marketing and PR department, and some sales staff, have left this week.

A skeleton salesforce and a handful of editorial staff are left running the site.

"Soccernet has always been a very lean ship," said Soccernet editor Mike With.

"We've not grown as much as other sites in this sector so there's not much to cut back on."

The reorganisation is part of a second round of cutbacks at Disney, which axed 400 jobs and its flagship portal Go.com only last month.

The cuts this week hit 135 jobs and ABCNews.com and ABC.com.

Disney Internet Group chairman Steve Bornstein said the cuts would help the company operate "in a more efficient and streamlined manner" to help it move towards profitability.

In less than a month, the group has slashed the size of its workforce by around 25%.

It started the year with 2,100 employees and is now down to 1,500.

Tellingly, even when announcing the latest cuts, Disney bosses made no promises that these would be the last.

Disney bought 60% of Soccernet for £15m from Associated New Media in late 1999, then topped this up with the remaining 40% in August last year.

Soccernet was only recently brought further into the Disney group through stronger ties and cross-promotion with subsidiary EPSN.

Related story

fields.headline: Sportsworld presses on with expansion
fields.trailText:
11am:The sports marketing group is to continue its two-year acquisition spree after a rise in profits. By Dan Milmo.

Oct 9: Geoff Brown interview
fields.body:
Sports marketing group Sportsworld Media has promised to continue its two-year acquisition spree after announcing a rise in first half profits.

The group has made 11 acquisitions since 1999, including the company that co-owns the global rights to ITV smash Popstars, and said it has identified a number of new targets.

"Acquisitions continue to play a part as the group builds upon its current television content, sports marketing and youth lifestyle interests," said Geoff Brown, chief executive of Sportsworld.

Sportsworld announced a pre-tax profit of £5.6m for the last six months of 2000, against a profit of £0.4m for the same period in 1999, and turnover soared by 324% to £16.8m.

The group is best known for its opportunistic development of the extreme sports market, and is credited with introducing surfing and snowboarding to a wider global TV audience.

"There is a growing demand for extreme sport and youth lifestyle content from broadcasters," said Mr Brown.

Sportsworld is also turning to the catwalk in a bid to repeat the success of the Popstars series.

The group is working on a series of follow-ups, which include tracking the progress of a would-be supermodel.

fields.headline: Thursday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are still reeling from England's Sven-sational performance last night
fields.trailText: Sol Campbell says he knows nothing about a potential summer move to Bayern Munich. "It's news to me. I've had no approach from Bayern and I don't know anything about the rumours," he said after England's victory over Spain.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell says he knows nothing about a potential summer move to Bayern Munich. "It's news to me. I've had no approach from Bayern and I don't know anything about the rumours," he said after England's victory over Spain.

Fulham are preparing a £8m bid for Monaco centre-half Martin Djetou, reports the Mirror. The paper reports that Jean Tigana is willing to offer Djetou £40,000-a-week to sign for the club.

Juventus coach Carlo Ancelotti is interested in Internazionale striker Christian Vieri. "I think that Vieri is one of the best strikers in the world and I think that Vieri and Zidane could work well together," he admitted.

fields.headline: 365 looks to 'Guardian Angel' after revenue rise
fields.trailText: 10am:365 Corporation is counting on its 'Guardian Angel' voice portal to boost revenues, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online content company 365 Corporation is counting on its "Guardian Angel" to boost revenues this year.

Its voice portal, which has been given a celestial codename, will launch this spring and the company has high hopes that it will prove a hit with consumers.

365 said it will bring "significant revenue and profit generation opportunities", after the company reported a 13% rise in third quarter revenues.

Guardian Angel allows mobile phone users to buy goods, access content and send emails by using their own voice, with access charges providing most of the revenues.

365 has signed up record retailer HMV, betting agency William Hill, Domino's Pizza and Teleflorist to the portal.

Between October and December last year 365 reported a widening pre-tax loss of £10.1m, against £6m for the same period in 1999.

But 365's shares rose 2.8% in early trading after the company said revenues had risen from £12m in the previous quarter to £13.6m.

"Since our IPO in December 1999, 365 has succeeded in building both its divisions - consumer and business - into large, fast-growing operations with considerable profit potential," said Dan Thompson, chief executive of 365.

365 runs a series of websites, including football365.com and gardening365.com, and offers information through mobile phone text messages and internet-enabled phones. It also provides communications services to businesses.

webTitle: The rise and rise of reading circles

fields.headline: The rise and rise of reading circles
fields.trailText: With an estimated 50,000 people in reading groups, the first research into the habit reveals that the runaway favourite is Captain Corelli's Mandolin, by Louis de Bernières
fields.body:
When they first got hooked on the habit, it gave the little group of women neighbours in Goole, Yorkshire, "a delicious feeling of decadence", about which some of them still feel guilty.

They pooled their tea rations, prepared food to keep them going, went into the poshest room in the house and got down to it.

They sat down to listen to somebody reading two chapters a day from a library book, then talked about it.

That was in 1948. The book was Kathleen Winsor's searing bodice-ripper Forever Amber, about a mistress of King Charles II. They were one of the first modern reading groups, the forerunners of a movement which has swept Britain since the 1990s and is still growing.

Now, with an estimated 50,000 people in these groups, taste has moved up several notches into literary fiction. The runaway favourite is Captain Corelli's Mandolin, by Louis de Bernières, followed by Angela's Ashes, by Frank McCourt. Other popular titles included Sebastian Faulks's Birdsong, Beryl Bainbridge's Every Man for Himself, E. Annie Proulx's The Shipping News and Pat Barker's Regeneration.

Readers still meet mainly in people's homes but also in prisons, north Norfolk beach huts, pubs, a zoo and a dentist's waiting room.

One group is tackling Dickens's Little Dorrit in instalments, to recreate the excitement of Victorian readers, for whom the book was serialised. And a group in Britain with time to spare is inching through James Joyce's Ulysses.

These trends are disclosed today - World Book Day - in Jenny Hartley's new book Reading Groups*, the first research into the communal habit.

Ms Hartley, principal lecturer in English literature at Surrey University, studied more than 1,000 readers in a total of 350 reading groups. Their excited and engaged voices, she writes, "sound as if they're living on a different planet from the current batch of literary and social commentators weighed down by millennial lamentations".

The lamentations are about a book culture allegedly drowned out by media culture, the internet and other pressures on leisure.

Ms Hartley said her results show that "reading groups read widely and well and the literary fiction they favour is in good heart and financial shape both in the US and the UK".

Historically, too, groups have had more social influence than commentators allow, she adds. In late 19th century America, women's reading groups provided the sinews of the women's suffrage movement. In Britain, 69% of groups are all-female, with 27% mixed and only 4% all-male. But people under the age of 30 now joining their first groups prefer mixed company.

Two thirds of members are more than 40 years old, with 20% in their 30s and virtually nobody younger than this.

The groups are almost all newish, with 67% less than five years old and 79% less than a decade old. More than half the members in nearly all groups have been in higher education and two thirds are in paid work. Geographically, they are evenly spread, with slightly more in the countryside.

"We share a common culture, which we take for granted, but which comes under scrutiny every month," one reader told the survey.

Another said: "I love the buzz and the sharing of opinions and chat." In others, the old motive which stirred their parents and grandparents in Goole still lives: "We love 'having to read', so don't feel guilty. It allows me a few legitimate hours to myself away from the kids".

webTitle: Rumour mill pumps out Clinton fiction

fields.headline: Rumour mill pumps out Clinton fiction
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Washington is buzzing with rumours that Bill Clinton may be about to notch another White House first by becoming the only former US president to publish a novel.
fields.body:
Washington is buzzing with rumours that Bill Clinton may be about to notch another White House first by becoming the only former US president to publish a novel.

He has made no definite announcement about any future writing plans, but in recent days there have been recurring reports that he is trying to tempt publishers into a two-book deal which would cover his White House memoirs and a second - this time officially fictional - volume.

There have been no hints about the kind of subject matter Mr Clinton may be toying with, but as he struggles to adjust to life after the Oval Office his detractors have been quick to point out that he has never found much difficulty making up a story.

Several American presidents have been successful writers - Ulysses Grant, Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson and John F Kennedy among them - but their literary legacies are stacked firmly on the non-fiction shelves.

The mere thought of a Clinton novel has got the gossip columnists chattering. The Washington Post has weighed in with a "Help Bill Write" contest in which readers are invited to think up a title and a catchy opening.

"They've sent in some wonderful suggestions," the columnist Al Kamen wrote yesterday, while refusing to unveil any examples until the contest closes this week.

Other columnists have been less restrained, their suitably Clintonesque suggestions including The Pardoner's Tale, Catcher in the Thigh, Devil with a Blue Dress On, From Rags to the Riches, and It Takes a Pillage.

Mr Clinton's spokeswoman said yesterday that he had made no decision about future writing plans.

His former aide Sidney Blumenthal, taking time off from writing a book about his own White House years, said: "He will certainly write his memoirs, but I think this could be the latest made-up story about the president."

A Clinton novel would be a guaranteed bestseller, and would complement other improbable literary efforts to which the former president and his household have lent their names, including a collection of letters to his dog Buddy and his now spurned cat Socks.

webTitle: 'Cruel' dog film passed for UK viewing

fields.headline: 'Cruel' dog film passed for UK viewing
fields.trailText: The controversial Oscar-nominated film, Amores Perros, has been passed without cuts by the censor despite protests from the RSPCA which claims it will glamorise dog fighting.
fields.body:
The controversial Oscar-nominated film, Amores Perros, has been passed without cuts by the censor despite protests from the RSPCA which claims it will glamorise dog fighting.

The film, by first-time director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, has become a cause célèbre since it cleared the board at Critics' Week in Cannes. Fears were raised that it would never be shown here because of a 21-second scene in which a rottweiler and a pit bull terrier simulate a fight to the death in a Mexico City gambling den.

British distributors were wary because of the strict provisions of the obscure Cinematograph Films (Animals) Act 1937, which outlaws goading of animals for the camera, despite protests that it would be a national embarrassment if a film which has won more than 20 international prizes was not shown here.

However, after prolonged examination of the film, and with pressure building from such distinguished directors as Stephen Frears to have the law changed, the British Board of Film Classification has ruled that the scene does not break the law.

But the RSPCA said that it was "extremely concerned and disappointed" by the ruling, which it said "could contribute to the glamorisation of a horrifically cruel underground activity we spend a large part of our resources trying to combat. Only this week four men have been jailed because of our investigations".

Chief inspector Mike Butcher, who has led special operations against dog fighters for 15 years, viewed the film, and although he conceded that the fight scene "was not used for gratuitous shock value, it was just too realistic for my liking, which raises the question of whether there was cruelty involved".

The BBFC, in its judgment, said it was happy no animals were hurt or abused during the filming. This has not satisfied the RSPCA, however, whose spokesman insisted that the animals must have "been goaded to fury in order to fight".

Gonzalez Inarritu claims that he went to extreme lengths to make sure no animals were harmed, even sacking one handler who he felt was willing to cut corners. "I lost so much sleep over it. We used plastic muzzles on the dogs. They just did what came naturally, they played. The camera lies, we made it more dramatic than it was."

fields.headline: Smartlogik flotation shelved
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet technology group Bright Station yesterday postponed indefinitely the flotation of Smartlogik, its knowledge management software division. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Internet technology group Bright Station yesterday postponed indefinitely the flotation of Smartlogik, its knowledge management software division.

The company, run by entrepreneur Dan Wagner, had intended that Smartlogik would make its stock market debut at the start of this year, but changed its mind because of hostile market conditions for technology companies.

"The flotation of Smartlogik is planned for when market conditions improve," Mr Wagner said.

Bright Station reported an operating loss on continuing operations of £16.8m, excluding exceptional items, for the year to the end of December.

Losses for the quarter were £6.7m, excluding an exceptional cost of £3m, compared to £4.6m for the previous three months.

fields.headline: P&G to launch Pampers bibs
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Procter & Gamble is to introduce disposable bibs under the Pampers brand, reports Julia Day.
Feb 21: Coke and P&G form joint marketing company
fields.body:
In its never-ending quest to create new product categories, Procter & Gamble is launching disposable bibs under the Pampers brand.

The new product, Pampers Bibsters, will make its debut in the US and is likely, if successful, to be rolled out worldwide.

The Bibsters come in a box of 20 costing around £2.70.

The bib features an absorbent top - which is made to look and feel like cloth - and has a protective barrier layer underneath.

Pictures of animals are printed on the bibs, which come in two sizes - small for babies aged 0-6 months and large for babies aged six months and older.

P&G has already launched Pamper Baby Wipes and Pampers Care Mats.

It had to label the packaging of the disposable changing mats with a safety warning after there was some consumer confusion about how to use them.

Related stories
Feb 21: Coke and P&G form joint marketing company
Feb 5: P&G unveils cunning product plan

fields.headline: Government clamps down on flyposting
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The government is to crack down on multinationals that defile public property with flyposters, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government is planning a crackdown on multinationals that defile public property with illegal flyposters.

And Westminster Council is threatening to take legal action against sports giant Nike over an illegal flyposting campaign.

The move signals a new crackdown on global corporations that are willing to break the law to get products as mundane as catfood and noodles noticed.

Flyposting, once limited to independent record labels and music promoters, has expanded in recent years.

Major blue-chip companies such as Mars and Unilever are now just as likely to get involved in the practice.

Current campaigns plastered up on walls around London include those for Whiskas catfood and Batchelors Supernoodles.

Both campaigns are designed to look as if they have come from small rebellious companies unable to afford billboard advertising.

The department for the environment, transport and the regions recently introduced guidelines for councils that explain the kind of action they can take.

These include how to recoup the cost of cleaning up from the advertisers themselves.

A spokesman for the department said it was hoping to increase government powers in the area as soon as possible.

"We definitely want to toughen up on this," he said.

No one at Batchelors was available for comment.

A spokesperson for Mars, which owns Whiskas, said the company was not willing to comment on its involvement in illegal flyposting.

However, a recent press release issued on behalf of Whiskas said the company was embarking on a "guerilla" marketing campaign that would include flyposting.

Westminster Council has been particularly active in the effort to combat the practice.

The council recently introduced a type of paint that makes it impossible for billboards to be posted on its property.

It is planning to increase its budget for fighting the flyposters by £200,000 this year.

"We are beginning to consider the origins of the problem and look at how we can target the culprits," said a Westminster Council spokesman.

"Practices like this create an atmosphere that makes it easier for crime to breed."

Flyposting is technically illegal but, until recently, many councils turned a blind eye, reasoning that no real harm was being done.

But the huge increase in the number of multinationals using flyposters - along with the establishment of specialist agencies dedicated to the practice - has led to a crackdown in both local and national government.

Related story
Feb 14: Taking a pasting

fields.headline: 'Tip' law to force disclosure
fields.trailText: The head of the newspaper industry's code of practice committee yesterday condemned proposed new legislation forcing journalists to declare their interest in any shares they tip.
fields.body:
The head of the newspaper industry's code of practice committee yesterday condemned proposed new legislation forcing journalists to declare their interest in any shares they tip.

Les Hinton, chairman of the committee and executive chairman of News International which publishes the Times and the Sun, described the rules as "completely unworkable".

The legislation is being introduced following the controversy last year surrounding the financial tipsters of the Mirror newspaper, who were found to have been routinely tipping companies in which they owned shares.

Under the new legislation, any journalists writing articles that "constitute advice" must make it clear to readers if they own the stock.

Mr Hinton made his views known in a letter to the economic secretary to the Treasury, Melanie Johnson. He wrote: "The regime you are proposing is completey unworkable. In any newspaper or magazine, a substantial number of people have an involvement in an article - not just the journalist who writes the article, but the commissioning editor, the City - or possibly political or home affairs - editor, the sub-editor, on occasion the picture editor, a copy taker, a lawyer who may clear the article, the deputy editor and the editor.

"Which of these is to declare an interest?... You are processing a criminal law which is completely unworkable."

The Treasury responded by saying that readers "should be entitled" to know of any interests when an article amounts to a promotion for a share.

fields.headline: Desmond takes Jobson off OK! Express
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Express's assistant editor Robert Jobson has been moved off the OK! Express supplement, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
OK! Express, the newspaper supplement based on Richard Desmond's celebrity magazine OK!, has been revamped to bring it in line with the glossy magazine.

And the Express's assistant editor, Robert Jobson, who has edited the supplement since it launched just over a month ago, will move into another role.

Express editor Chris Williams said the move had been "to make OK! Express more like an exact version of OK! rather than the hybrid it was before".

Mr Williams played down speculation that OK! would take a greater editorial role on the Express's showbusiness desk.

He said the strategy was implemented in order to share resources.

Insiders say Mr Desmond lost his temper on discovering Riverdance star Michael Flatley was the cover star for last week's edition and insisted the cover be redesigned to include model Caprice.

Mr Desmond subscribes to the received magazine wisdom that men on covers fail to pull in readers.

"We don't tend to put blokes on the cover," said OK! editor Martin Townsend.

"I wasn't there but I think that cover just sort of shook around for a bit before we decided not to go for it," he added.

webTitle: Lancashire to star in ITV drama

fields.headline: Lancashire to star in ITV drama
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV has ordered a TV adaptation of a novel by Goodnight Mr Tom author Michelle Magorian starring Sarah Lancashire. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV controller of drama Nick Elliott has ordered a TV adaptation of another novel by Goodnight Mr Tom author Michelle Magorian, starring Sarah Lancashire.

Back Home tells the story of a 12-year-old girl who has trouble readjusting to life in England after spending the second world war as an evacuee in America.

The novel is to be made into a two-hour TV drama by newly formed independent producer Danny Rose Productions and is the company's first commission.

Danny Rose has been formed by former Lucky Dog chief executive Geoff Deane, managing director Mia Jupp and head of drama Philip Palmer.

Lucky Dog, which was a joint venture between Mr Deane and Chrysalis Visual Entertainment, is to be merged into the new Chrysalis Entertainment division.

"Chrysalis is going through a process of merging its TV interests while we still cherish our independent status," Mr Deane said.

"It has been a wholly amicable parting of company. In Danny Rose we will pick up where we left off as one of the few writer-based indies operating in high quality, mainstream TV production."

The trio secured the Back Home commission while still at Lucky Dog and will now make it under licence for Danny Rose.

Back Home will go into pre-production immediately, with Ms Jupp producing and Simon Massey directing.

Lucky Dog's credits included ITV sitcom Babes in the Wood and BBC1 comedy A Many Splintered Thing.

fields.headline: Pools operator talks to Camelot
fields.trailText: The Littlewoods Pools owner, Sportech, is in talks with lottery operator Camelot and broadcaster BSkyB about distributing its gaming products through lottery terminals and interactive television.
fields.body:
The Littlewoods Pools owner, Sportech, is in talks with lottery operator Camelot and broadcaster BSkyB about distributing its gaming products through lottery terminals and interactive television.

Managing director Colin McGill said the gaming group backed by leisure tycoon Trevor Hemmings was examining "every possible way" of expanding its distribution network. At present this involves mainly door to door sellers collecting weekly football pools stakes from 1.6m homes.

"We're talking to BSkyB, Camelot and others about delivering our content in new ways and to new places," he said.

Mr Hemmings - with backing from Bank of Scotland - bought the Littlewoods Pools empire from the Liverpool-based Moores family last year.

They then engineered a stock market listing through a reverse takeover by former computer disk maker Rodime. Revenues from football pools stakes have been declining by around 27% per annum over the last few years, but Sportech believes the trend can be reversed. By introducing new products and games it has been able to slow the decline to an annual 20%.

A marketing campaign aimed at attracting younger players and modernising the image of football pools is planned for later in the year. Results for the 15 months to December 31 showed a business in transition.

The operating profit of £28.5m was due almost entirely to the settlement of a legal dispute dating from the period during which Sportech was still named Rodime and trading as a technology business. Turnover of £63m was made up of £44m from football pools, and the remainder from games and lotteries and sports betting.

The company's shares climbed 8% to 20p.

fields.headline: Danger in the night
fields.standfirst: It's late and the last bus has gone. A man approaches and asks if you want a minicab.  Tania Branigan reports on new crime figures that might make you think twice
fields.trailText: It's late and the last bus has gone. A man approaches and asks if you want a minicab. Tania Branigan reports on new crime figures that might make you think twice.
fields.body:
For most young women, it is as much a part of a Saturday night as the preparatory swipe of mascara or the third vodka-tonic. With demand vastly outstripping the supply of black cabs, flagging down a minicab or accepting a ride from a pavement tout often seems the easiest - and safest - way of getting home.

But convenience comes at a price. In the past six months alone, women in London have reported to police 19 rapes by minicab drivers; the real figures may well be higher. Despite legislation passed in 1998, the capital remains the only place in the country where minicabs and their drivers are unlicensed. The result is that anyone with a driving licence and a battered Cortina can proclaim themselves a minicab driver, though legally they can take only pre-booked passengers.

Last week, Scotland Yard launched a crackdown on cowboy drivers as part of a wider operation to tackle crime. But while police can root out the touts, uninsured drivers and unroadworthy vehicles, it remains perfectly legal for a convicted rapist to drive a minicab.

Drivers may not be fully licensed until the end of 2004, though Transport for London, part of the Greater London Authority, is trying to speed up the process. The regulations permitting licensing were introduced late last year and the body is registering the 1,600 firms before starting on the 40,000 or more individual drivers.

The delay has been attacked by everyone from the Licensed Taxi Drivers Association, which represents black cab drivers, to safety campaigners such as Diana Lamplugh, founder of the Suzy Lamplugh Trust. Initial opposition to legislation came from black cab drivers who objected to a two-tier licensing system; subsequently, regulations had to be altered after responsibility for licensing was transferred from the police to Transport for London. Critics now say that licensing drivers should be the priority but Transport for London insists that it is taking the logical course.

People use minicabs because they have little choice; as few as 2,000 of Greater London's 23,000 black cab drivers work in the centre at night at weekends. Bob Oddy, general secretary of the Licensed Taxi Drivers Association, believes only a 50% increase in night-time fares will encourage his members to work antisocial hours. In the meantime, faced with few black cabs and unpredictable public transport, women often choose minicabs as a safety measure.

"The trouble is, mothers say, 'Do get a taxi, dear,' because they want their children to be safe," Lamplugh says. "But if you're in a car made of steel, going at a high speed, with its doors locked, you're about as vulnerable as you can be. You're trapped and that can be totally misused."

Laura Topham, a 20-year-old student in Birmingham, ordered a minicab from a local firm because she was too safety-conscious to walk to a friend's house after dark. "As soon as I got in, the driver started asking whether I'd got a boyfriend and telling me I was a nice-looking girl," she says. "I knew it was taking too long to get there, but he just said it was a short cut. I told him to stop the car and he started driving faster. In the end I called my friend on my mobile and said I'm in a red car, this is the name of the driver and if I'm not there in 10 minutes, call the police."

That was when the driver stopped and turned around. "It took half an hour to get back to the house - it should only have taken five minutes to start with - and I didn't realise at the time but he had been driving right out into a wooded park area. I just think I've been very, very lucky."

Ruth Davies, a 30-year-old solicitor, had a similarly frightening experience when she booked a cab from a local firm. "The driver was going through central London at 60mph, pulling out to overtake in front of buses and accelerating through red lights," she recalls with a shudder. "I was screaming at him to let me out but he didn't speak any English and wouldn't stop. I couldn't open the door because he was charging about and we were going round for an hour and a half.

"It was terrifying. I realised he could have taken me anywhere, but fortunately I think he was genuinely lost. I haven't been in a minicab since."

Lucy Lee, 34, a tax manager, was badly injured after taking a minicab. "I spotted he'd rigged the meter and I complained," she says. "All of a sudden, he opened the car door and pushed me out while we were going at 20 or 30mph. I tried to get up off the road but kept falling over because I was concussed. I had a broken cheekbone and eye socket - my eye was completely shut and my face was black from the bruising."

All these women were safety-conscious, yet it didn't keep them safe. Rogue minicab drivers are just one of the risks women face - Lucy, who has sworn off private hire vehicles, was mugged at a bus stop the other night - and while licensing will reduce the problem, it will not eliminate it. Suzy, a 32-year-old journalist, was dumped on an empty street at midnight by a black cab driver after she turned down his offer of a threesome with his wife.

The risks are always relative, although most experts agree that accepting a ride from a pavement tout is top of the danger list because there is no record of your journey.

"It worries me that my daughter or wife or sister could be using this method of transport and be vulnerable," says chief inspector Tony Robinson, who led last week's purge, urging women to protect by planning ahead. "If you were walking down the street and someone pulled up alongside you, ordinarily, you'd say no. That should be your reaction when you're in the West End because you have no idea who is driving that vehicle."

Travelling with friends, using black cabs, calling a minicab from a firm you trust and checking the driver's ID are all sensible tactics. Many women are turning to firms that use only women drivers or who are known to be women-friendly, such as Ladycabs in Highgate and Freedom Cars in Soho, which were set up in response to sexual and homophobic assaults on passengers by drivers. But Ladycabs says its perennial problem is finding enough drivers to meet demand.

The trouble is that women are always balancing priorities and relative risks: the ability to move around freely versus the threat of assault, or the risk of leaping into a cab compared with that of waiting on a deserted street. Men may put themselves at risk because they fail to anticipate danger; women often put themselves at risk by trying to avoid a different threat.

"There are no guarantees of safety," says Professor Betsy Stanko, director of the UK violence research programme at Royal Holloway, the University of London, who has worked on women's safety for 25 years. "You are always trading the do's and don'ts off against each other, measuring what's more safe and more unsafe. If women are getting into minicabs because they're concerned about their safety on the streets, and they are finding unsafe men in those cars, then it's not that women are making mistakes, but that men are using their knowledge of women's fear as a way of preying on them.

"There ought to be far more outrage about the fact that this is the situation women are put in. The approach has always been to rein in your daughters. Why not teach your sons how not to be jerks?"

But Ladycabs says its perennial problem is finding enough drivers to meet demand. The trouble is that women are always balancing priorities and relative risks: the ability to move around freely versus the threat of assault, or the risk of leaping into a cab compared with that of waiting on a deserted street. Men may put themselves at risk because they fail to anticipate danger; women often put themselves at risk by trying to avoid a different threat. "There are no guarantees of safety," says Professor Betsy Stanko, director of the UK violence research programme at Royal Holloway, the University of London, who has worked on women's safety for 25 years. "You are always trading the do's and don'ts off against each other, measuring what's more safe and more unsafe. If women are getting into minicabs because they're concerned about their safety on the streets, and they are finding unsafe men in those cars, then it's not that women are making mistakes, but that men are using their knowledge of women's fear as a way of preying on them. "There ought to be far more outrage about the fact that this is the situation women are put in. The approach has always been to rein in your daughters. Why not teach your sons how not to be jerks?"

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
A cold house, lost sheep and sleepless nights - but at least the milkman gets through

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A cold house, lost sheep and sleepless nights - but at least the milkman gets through.
fields.body:
It is Ash Wednesday and the name takes on a whole new meaning for the farmers as thousands more farm animals are condemned to be burned. Our view of the distant horizon has shrunk considerably in the past 10 days, and by teatime on Tuesday we couldn't see a thing. Every window in the farmhouse was covered in thick snow and even letting the dogs out for a wee was becoming almost impossible. Tigger the terrier disappeared a few times under the shifting drifts and pretended she simply didn't need to go, but as we had a suspicious puddle in the office on Monday afternoon we ignored her pleading looks.

The situation by bedtime was so bad we didn't know whether to laugh or cry. And I almost did. Our immense worry over foot and mouth had been temporarily eclipsed by the age-old winter risk - a severe storm, which felt like a direct descendant of the infamous 1947 storm. The lights flickered on and off, but we were lucky and remained connected - some areas have been without power for more than 24 hours. But still our house remains cold - the Aga is unable to keep the kitchen warm, but it dries the outdoor gear over and over again.

Peter put the water pump on nearly all day yesterday because on remote farms like ours, no power means no water. We have an 8,000-gallon holding tank, but with three sheds full of cattle and two houses it wouldn't last 48 hours.

The priority after a bad storm is to find the sheep, feed and count them, and then check for foot and mouth. This is not easy as the sheep are bedraggled and their fleeces are caked with snowballs that make the fleece look dirty. So when the researcher from Irish radio rang and asked if we were constantly checking our sheep for symptoms I said: "Yes, of course we are, but in truth we can't do it as thoroughly today because of the weather." I am sure she thought I was either joking or crazy.

Sleep is becoming a yearned-for luxury. I was up again at 1.30am, because the house was groaning as if in an age-old protest against the fierce weather. Eventually I managed to nod off but we were up at 6am to find blue skies, deep drifts and the house bedecked by long icicles. Don't fairy tales and legends usually have a darker side?

Peter dug his way out of the back door through three feet of snow and then dug his way into the cattle sheds to feed and check the cattle. So far, so good. After breakfast we went searching for the outlying sheep. We used tractors instead of the quad bike to get through the four-foot drifts. By lunchtime only two sheep out of our large flock were unaccounted for. The search to find them has since begun. I expect they were in shelter somewhere trying to keep warm and the snow blew in on top.

The media coverage of the crisis is good, but at times I feel there is too much speculation and not enough hard facts, especially on television. There is a world of difference between a confirmed case and a suspected case of foot and mouth. I learned today that some of the blood tests can take up to 96 hours - which is why in some regions we wait so long for news.

Still, the total of confirmed cases grimly rises - 24 as I write this - and I believe that a larger area of the UK is affected now than in the last serious outbreak. And yet the government spent time yesterday debating the contentious hunting issue. Nick Brown seems sincere, but why wasn't the debate scrapped, or at least postponed?

When we are confident to go out and about again (if ever) and the countryside march is rescheduled, we'll all be there, whatever our opinion is over the hunting issue. Solidarity in the countryside is what counts. This epidemic will bind us together tighter than ever.

The latest sector to suffer is rural tourism. I have spoken to several farmers' wives who run successful B&B establishments and rent out holiday cottages in Northumberland. They have all cancelled their visitors. In many cases these operations earn more than the livestock business. They need information and guidance and they need it now.

Peter has cleared our road with the JCB, but the main road is really bad. Around 60 farmers are usually employed by the county council to clear and grit roads, so it will take longer without them to get the county travelling again.

No post today, but our heroic milkman somehow left us fresh pints and eggs at the road end, which was wonderful, because we were down to powdered milk.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText:
"He turns his round, flat, rather red face towards me, with a look both enigmatic and full of hostility ... Forget about his pretensions to intellect. He is a man who can seriously put a woman in her place. That is why we like him so much"
Jane Kelley on Russell Crowe, Daily Mail
fields.body:
"He turns his round, flat, rather red face towards me, with a look both enigmatic and full of hostility ... Forget about his pretensions to intellect. He is a man who can seriously put a woman in her place. That is why we like him so much"
Jane Kelley on Russell Crowe, Daily Mail

"Masculinity was never much to do with being a man, any more than femininity was much to do with being a woman. Each has only ever been a complementary construct for the other. With the erosion of traditional ideas of femininity, old ideas of masculinity have also been exposed ... As an identity to hide behind, it no longer works. Whether this amounts to a crisis depends on how willing people are to adapt ...

"There is evidence that some men are opting out altogether, of work and of family. This speaks less of 'masculinity in crisis' than of 'masculinity in retreat'. The inference could be drawn that instead of adapting, some men are withdrawing, blaming women for their troubles, and punishing women and children accordingly. Which is tragic, not just for those men, but for all of us"
Deborah Orr on the so-called crisis in masculinity, Independent

"I have become a housewife and there is no better job"
Singer Celine Dion, Hello!

"Jeffrey Archer's latest girlfriend Nikki Kingdon is said to have had liposuction to reduce her thighs, implants in her calves, eyeliner tattoo, collagen injections for the lips, botox for the forehead and a couple of boob jobs. And all she got was Jeffrey Archer. She should ask for her money back"
Sue Carroll, Mirror

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Debbie Harry

fields.headline: No 1829
fields.standfirst: Debbie Harry
fields.trailText: Debbie Harry.
fields.body:
Denis! Picture This! Dreaming! Heart of Glass! Debbie Harry is my all-time hero! Go on, indulge me in some Proust-like reminiscences. Right. Well, pop/punk/disco/Blondie, and singer Debbie Harry, have been around for, well, yonks. Aside from her unquestioned musical importance, she is the woman who launched 100 bad dye jobs by impressionable young teenagers.

None of your sarcasm about the goddess-like Harry. Not at all. In fact, Harry has just received the highest accolade one can get these days - an homage at a fashion show.

Funny, I never would have thought that Harry's scruffy clothes, ripped fishnets and bad peroxide jobs would become a high-fashion statement. Actually, it's Harry herself who has become a fashion statement rather than her clothes. Italian cheeky chappies Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana kicked off Milan fashion week on Tuesday with their collection for D&G, which included diamante-studded Debbie Harry T-shirts.

So, a bit more glam than our Debs' usual goth-with-an-80s-twist ensemble. She must be so honoured. Maybe. But she might be miffed to be given hand-me-downs. Last season D&G included diamante-studded Madonna T-shirts in its collection.

Brilliant! If a blonde icon on a T-shirt worked last season, may as well do it again this season! But, you know, these slogan T-shirts look kind of familiar ... That might be because every celebrity and hanger-on wore one last year. It all started when Madonna asked, yes, D&G to design a "Kylie" T-shirt for her, then a "Britney Spears" one, then one with the names of her kids. Then the copycatting began: Robbie Williams, Nigella Lawson, Donna Air, Kate Sanderson from Newsround and Bryan from Westlife were all spotted wearing "ironic" names across their chests.

Do say: "Ironic chic - it is just so in tune with the zeitgeist."

Not to be confused with: Madonna.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: One of the best and most easily kept (after all, who cares?) British political secrets is that, by way of a memento, outgoing ministers can take one red box with them.
fields.body:
 One of the best and most easily kept (after all, who cares?) British political secrets is that, by way of a memento, outgoing ministers can take one red box with them. Think of it like the BBC letting Andrew Neil present late-night, zero-ratings political shows - it's just a way of helping people harmlessly cling on to the belief that they are still somehow important.

Anyway, most shadow ministers - Hague, Polly, Maude, Big Mick Ancram, Widders, etc - have served in government, and may thus swank around with their red box if they choose. Others, like culture spokesman Little Ainsworth, were never ministers, but seem to cope. There is one, however, whose sense of intellectual security and self-confidence is such that, despite not being entitled, he has had a red box specially made for himself, bearing the name of Archie Norman, the wealthy grocer who shadows John Prescott. Ah, the sweetness. It's as close to owning one as he'll ever get.

 And so to To Dream a Dream: The Amazing Life of Phillip Schofield (Blake Publishing), written in 1992 by Piers Morgan when the subject was Joseph in Lord Lloyd-Webber's musical and the author was hard-hitting showbiz columnist of the Sun. "Confident, amusing, thoughtful and intelligent, Phil has proved himself to be one of the most genuinely NICE guys in showbusiness," writes Piers in the foreword. "Typically, he wasn't keen on being the subject of a book, claiming with ludicrous modesty: 'There's nothing about my life that would be of remote interest to anyone. I'm nobody special.' Millions of fans in Britain would disagree -and so do I." More soon.

 The election may not be as close as we thought, but it's still close enough for us to think about building bridges with Downing Street. So my colleague Marina Hyde rings the No 10 press office and explains to Marcus (our best boy James Fletcher won't talk) how uneasy we feel about the bad blood. We would like a greater spirit of cooperation, she says, and propose a weekly Monday breakfast to set the agenda for the week ahead. "I don't think we'd have time," sighs Marcus. "I'm sure it seems a good idea to you but ..." Perhaps Ali's deputy Godric Smith would find it helpful? "I doubt there's space in his diary, but a nice thought. Goodbye." Cheeky pup.

 Surveillance: bison-headed football hack Brian Woolnough on porn channel Red Hot Amateur, interrupting the crucial 10 free minutes punters get at midnight by advertising his move from Sun to Star. Poor show.

 Thanks to those in touch over Brentford Nylons, especially Francis Wheen who calls from rural Essex with these facts. In 1976, Lonrho bought the company from the receiver. If only Tiny had put Professor Donald Trelford in charge, who knows? He didn't, though, and it was all downhill from here, the retail side eventually being sold on and then disappearing after a snappy two-year closing sale; and the manufacturing part going into receivership (also after being flogged) in 1999. How sad it all is.

 With debate raging at the Times over whether managing editor George Brock wears tank tops or, as he is said to claim, crop tops, Marina rings and asks him to confirm that the Times's Lisa Armstrong is fashion journalist of the year? This he does. Well, she tells us that a crop top is a short, midriff-baring thing, while a tank top is what we wore in the 70s and get embarrassed about now. It's quite clear, isn't it, George, so why deny it? "I did indeed say to someone that I thought 'tank top' referred to knitted sleeveless garments of decades gone by." And what do you wear? "Simply sleeveless jerseys." Not knitted then? Pause. "Not hand knitted ..." Thanks for clearing that up. " I knew you'd be pleased," says Beau Brock.Click brrrrr.

fields.headline: High jinks
fields.standfirst: Rocketman thrills Rio carnival
fields.trailText: Carnival took off in Rio de Janeiro when a stuntman swooped over the parade with a jet pack strapped to his back.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Carnival took off in Rio de Janeiro when a stuntman swooped over the parade with a jet pack strapped to his back.

Eric Scott was the most closely guarded - and most expensive - secret of this year's festivities.

His five flights propelled by the 800hp backpack developed by Nasa cost £170,000, and lasted only 30 seconds each.

"This type of innovation is one of the reasons for the longevity of samba. The whole point of the parade is to attract attention," said Jose Carlos Rego, an authority on the carnival.

The procession was also notable for attracting a large number of topless paraders with silicone implants. One model, Angela Bismarchi, had several cosmetic operations - all performed by her 53-year-old plastic surgeon husband - to win a place on a prominent float.

The festivities began less than a week after 19 prisoners died in jail riots in Brazil, adding resonance to the theme of peace chosen for many of the parades.

But this did not stop sporadic outbreaks of violence. Several people died and many were wounded in street fights.

An Australian-Chinese tourist was assaulted and killed on a bus near the Sambadrome, the purpose-built avenue-like stadium which is the centrepiece of the festivities. In Rio state, 238 people died violently during the festival.

International celebrities and hundreds of thousands of tourists descended on Brazil for the week.

Arnold Schwarzenegger was banned from the Sambadrome's VIP area because he refused to wear the sponsor's T-shirt.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Holocaust suit by Slovak Jews
fields.body:
Holocaust suit by Slovak Jews

Jewish leaders in Slovakia suing Germany for £48m compensation for the "deportation fees" Slovak Jews had to pay for being transported to Nazi death camps.

Germany rejects such claims because it paid billions after the second world war for Holocaust wrongs. AP, Berlin

Taliban urged to spare statues

The UN cultural agency, Unesco, asked the Taliban regime in Afghanistan yesterday to reverse its decree that all non-Islamic statues must be destroyed. Buddhist statues at Bamiyan are in danger.

The Unesco director general, Koichiro Matsuura, said the Taliban would be "irreversibly wrecking heritage of universal value". Reuters, Paris

Pakistan hangs extremist

A Sunni Muslim was hanged yesterday in Pakistan for killing a diplomat from Shi'ite Iran in 1991.

Haq Nawaz, 35, belonged to the militant Sipah-e- Sahaba group, which sees Shi'ites as non-Muslims. The execution at Mianwali in the Punjab set off rioting by the group in Jhang, Nawaz's home town. AP, Jhang

Silver twin dies in Japan

Gin Kanie, the surviving half of the most celebrated twins in Japan, died yesterday aged 108. Her sister Kin died early last year.

Gin, whose name means silver, and Kin (gold) were believed to be the country's oldest twins. In their kimonos, they were often seen exhibiting wit and a zest for life on TV chat shows. AP, Tokyo

Snow blankets the Riviera

The French Riviera woke up to heavy snow for the first time in 15 years yesterday. The overnight storm cut power to 100,000 homes. Reuters, Grenoble

AP, Berlin Taliban urged to spare statues The UN cultural agency, Unesco, asked the Taliban regime in Afghanistan yesterday to reverse its decree that all non-Islamic statues must be destroyed. Buddhist statues at Bamiyan are in danger. The Unesco director general, Koichiro Matsuura, said the Taliban would be "irreversibly wrecking heritage of universal value". Reuters, Paris Pakistan hangs extremist A Sunni Muslim was hanged yesterday in Pakistan for killing a diplomat from Shi'ite Iran in 1991. Haq Nawaz, 35, belonged to the militant Sipah-e- Sahaba group, which sees Shi'ites as non-Muslims. The execution at Mianwali in the Punjab set off rioting by the group in Jhang, Nawaz's home town. AP, Jhang Silver twin dies in Japan Gin Kanie, the surviving half of the most celebrated twins in Japan, died yesterday aged 108. Her sister Kin died early last year. Gin, whose name means silver, and Kin (gold) were believed to be the country's oldest twins. In their kimonos, they were often seen exhibiting wit and a zest for life on TV chat shows. AP, Tokyo Snow blankets the Riviera The French Riviera woke up to heavy snow for the first time in 15 years yesterday. The overnight storm cut power to 100,000 homes. Reuters, Grenoble

webTitle: Spain succumbs to new Moorish invasion

fields.headline: Spain succumbs to new Moorish invasion
fields.standfirst: The Gulf rich and Moroccan poor find their El Dorado
fields.trailText: The motorway signs to Algeciras, where the ferry sails for Morocco, are in Arabic as well as Spanish. At the the turn-off for Marbella signposts point to the Mosque of King Abdul-Aziz. Women in  djellabas - the long hooded cloaks worn in North Africa - are now a common sight on the streets of the resort.
fields.body:
The motorway signs to Algeciras, where the ferry sails for Morocco, are in Arabic as well as Spanish. At the the turn-off for Marbella signposts point to the Mosque of King Abdul-Aziz. Women in djellabas - the long hooded cloaks worn in North Africa - are now a common sight on the streets of the resort.

At Fuengirola, along the Costa del Sol, the Saudi royal family has built a dazzling white theological college for the burgeoning Muslim population.

Spain's Islamic community is coming of age. Britons and Germans may have been buying holiday homes here for decades, but the high-walled villas overlooking Puerto Banus are now owned by wealthy arrivals from the Gulf.

In a country which until Franco's death in 1975 was almost exclusively Catholic, the culture shock is profound. Not all of modern democratic Spain is enjoying the transformation.

No one is sure how many Muslims there are. Estimates range up to 500,000 in a population of 40m. A small proportion are affluent professionals who fled the civil war in Lebanon or, later, the Gulf conflict. They are joined in summer by families fleeing the stifling Middle East heat.

But the vast majority have come from Morocco and Algeria in search of work and a better life.

The number has been swollen in the past year by Pakistanis who discovered the migrant smuggling route across the Strait of Gibraltar.

Most EU states have had a sudden influx of asylum seekers. What distinguishes Spain's experience is that the journey from the Arab world is not only an arrival but a return.

For more than 750 years, from AD711 when the Moors invaded until 1492 when the kingdom of Granada fell to Ferdinand and Isabella, much of what was then known as al-Andalus was ruled by Muslim caliphs.

The Spanish tourist industry has long exploited that Moorish heritage: the Alhambra palace in Granada attracted 2.25m visitors last year and Seville has staged a week's festival to commemorate the Moorish poet and 11th-century ruler of the city al-Mu'tamid Ibn' Abbad.

In the Islamic world there is a growing awareness of the Iberian peninsula's Arabic legacy. Last year, for example, the Arab League, which represents most Middle East states, paid for the restoration of a "Moorish meditation garden" in Silves, in the Algarve, because of its importance to Arab history.

The nostalgia for a lost, brilliant civilisation in Europe is encapsulated in the fable of Boabdil, the last Moorish sultan of Granada, who paused on his way into exile for a last glance at the city, and wept.

The mountain pass is called El Ultimo Suspiro del Moro (The Moor's Last Sigh), a name taken by Salman Rushdie for a novel in which he portrays the moment as an expulsion from paradise.

King Fahd bin Abul Aziz of Saudi Arabia has set the Arab trend for a return to southern Spain summer after summer. In 1999 his retinue included ministers, 400 retainers, 200 tonnes of luggage, and 25 Rolls-Royces and limousines.

The "Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques" has built a minaret and prayer hall on the southernmost tip of Gibraltar and another in Madrid.

King Fahd has a private mosque in his high-walled compound on the hills between Marbella and Puerto Banus.

The white villas in the surrounding "al-Riyadh" enclave have Arabic arches and motifs. The gardens have cypress trees and massive satellite dishes.

"There are at least 10,000 Muslims living along the Costa del Sol," Rachid, a Moroccan who has lived in Spain for 18 years, said as he prepared for morning prayers in Marbella. "There are rich Arabs from Syria, Jordan and Palestine. Moroccans come for the jobs, not so much for the history."

In the main street advertisements for doctors, dentists and plastic surgeons are often in Arabic as well as Spanish. There are at least two Arab banks.

"In summer, Saudis and Kuwaitis arrive and fill all the big villas," said Nadir Ahmed, a Pakistani restaurant owner who has lived in Spain since 1988. "Some have been coming for 10 or 20 years. The Gulf war encouraged many to stay.

"In the past few years Spain became the easiest place for Pakistanis to get residency status, so they poured in from Holland, France and all across Europe.

"People are very hospitable in Andalucia, but it's a very Catholic society. There's more religious sensitivity. Muslims have strong feelings about their faith, as do the Spanish, so you have to be careful."
