fields.headline: Northern renaissance
fields.standfirst: City-based regions could be the answer
fields.trailText: Just over a year ago the prime minister challenged the idea of a north-south divide. Some of his arguments were indisputable: the extraordinary prosperity to be found in parts of even the poorest regions; the pockets of poverty in the most prosperous regions.
fields.body:
Just over a year ago the prime minister challenged the idea of a north-south divide. Some of his arguments were indisputable: the extraordinary prosperity to be found in parts of even the poorest regions; the pockets of poverty in the most prosperous regions.

Where we disagreed was with his assertion that "the disparity within regions is at least as great as that between them" and his suggestion there should be "a more even-handed debate". The first ignored the depth and spread of deprivation in the north, while his even-handed debate, posed the threat of even-handed help that would only widen the divide.

Now, specially commissioned research for a Guardian North debate in Salford tonight, shows the economic divide between London and the once powerful northern cities has widened over the past four years and shows little immediate sign of narrowing.

Professor Brian Robson, a long-standing government adviser and head of the centre for urban policy studies at Manchester University, has compiled an array of indicators - GDP, unemployment, mortality rates, concentrations of deprivation and housing - all of which show just how far the north lags behind the south.

In his words: "The disparities are undeniable and their roots are systemic and structural." Merseyside, Tyneside and Sheffield have continued to lose jobs and people; Manchester has stood still; only West Yorkshire, reflecting a regenerated Leeds, has expanded. Yet even within half a mile of prosperous central Leeds and Manchester, now boasting penthouses, restaurants and smart boutiques, lie surrounding rings of dilapidated and unsellable terraced housing.

Professor Robson draws several lessons. First the need to encourage investment in more high-quality jobs in regional cities. There have to be more options for the trainees on the myriad new deal schemes than just the call centre or the job centre. He rightly notes that the current regional development agencies, which were given more budgetary autonomy last year, do not have the political clout or the resources, let alone a city regeneration focus.

Second, and most interesting, is his idea of widening the current tightly drawn administrative boundaries of cities to take in the travel-to-work hinterland. This would widen the tax base considerably and increase the argument for giving local government more tax raising powers. Current city regeneration policy falls between two stools: regional development agencies with their wide focus and the narrowly focused neighbourhood renewal schemes announced in January for the 840 poorest wards in the country.

Both are needed, but neither provide northern cities with the boost that they urgently require. Politically, all major parties will be wary of redrawing local government boundaries. Wilmslow's wrath was unconfined when it was placed within Manchester's postal area - later rescinded - let alone within its political reach. Yet the rivalry within regions between cities - Manchester v Liverpool - is well known. City-regions would be far more meaningful than the current idiosyncratic boundaries.

Last November's urban white paper failed to produce the renaissance that Lord Rogers's taskforce called for. Yet urban campaigners can focus on two other dates: an urban summit planned for 2002 and a state of the cities report in 2005. Redeveloping the north is as much in the interests of the south as the north. Without regeneration, northern migration will continue - as will housing demand on southern green spaces.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a report headed Drink and assault sealed fate of hangman's butcher, page 11, February 24, we said Albert Pierrepoint was the last executioner in Britain. He was not. Pierrepoint's period in office ended in 1956. Harry Allen and Robert Leslie Stewart simultaneously dispatched the last two men hanged in Britain, at Strangeways and Walton, on August 13, 1964.
fields.body:
 In a report headed Drink and assault sealed fate of hangman's butcher, page 11, February 24, we said Albert Pierrepoint was the last executioner in Britain. He was not. Pierrepoint's period in office ended in 1956. Harry Allen and Robert Leslie Stewart simultaneously dispatched the last two men hanged in Britain, at Strangeways and Walton, on August 13, 1964.

 In our report of the Bafta awards, page 3, February 26, we said the best newcomer award went to Pawel Pawlikowski the director of Lost Weekend. The film is actually called Last Resort.

 Herpreet Kaur Grewal, a former student at Brunel University, now studying newspaper journalism at the City University, has asked us to confirm that she is not the Herpreet Kaur referred to in an article, pages 10 and 11, Education, November 7, last year. Herpreet Kaur in that article was, in fact, a pseudonym chosen to conceal the identity of another student still at Brunel. We are sorry if the similarity of the names caused embarrassment, and regret that on this occasion the paper's policy of making it clear when names have been changed was not followed.

 William Cobbett did say what we attributed to him, page 4, yesterday (a report headed: Global trade forces exodus from land), but not when we said he said it, in 1753. He was not born until 1763. In a panel, page 5, February 27, about precautionary measures brought about by the foot and mouth crisis, we said Magdalene College, Oxford, had closed to the public to protect the deer in its grounds. That is Magdalen College, Oxford, the one that has indeed taken the step. Magdalene College is in Cambridge.

 In a map of the danger areas in the present outbreak of foot and mouth disease, page 29, yesterday, we placed Bangor national hunt racecourse at Bangor in Gwynedd, near one of the sites affected by the disease. The racecourse is not there. It is at Bangor-on-Dee, near Wrexham. English department, from page 9, G2, yesterday where someone "flits about wrecking ghostly havoc." Havoc is usually wreaked.

 It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Fax 020-7239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Immigrants provoke ire in Catalonia
fields.trailText: The wife of the regional premier of Catalonia has denounced Muslim incomers for wanting to impose their culture on the region, and a prominent separatist leader has complained of there being "too many foreigners".
fields.body:
The wife of the regional premier of Catalonia has denounced Muslim incomers for wanting to impose their culture on the region, and a prominent separatist leader has complained of there being "too many foreigners".

Marta Ferrusola, who is married to the long-standing regional premier, Jordi Pujol, told an audience of elderly Catalans in Girona: "They want to impose their own way. All they know how to say is: 'Give me something to eat.'"

She claimed that immigrants were the main beneficiaries of social security payments to large families, and were living in houses built by the regional government. "These benefits go to people who do not even know what Catalonia is.

"My husband says he is fed up with having to give them to people from the Maghreb [north Africa] and places like that."

Catalonia's churches would soon be overshadowed by mosques, she added.

Mr Pujol said his wife was expressing personal opinions, but added:"Most people feel the same way."

Her views are echoed in a political memoir by a senior figure in Catalan separatism, the former regional parliamentary president and secretary of the Catalan Republican Left Heribert Barrera, who wrote that the region would "disappear" under the weight of immigration.

"When [the Austrian far right leader Jörg] Haider says that there are too many foreigners in Austria he is not being racist," he wrote.

Immigrant workers should be progressively expelled from certain regions, he said. He suggested that Spaniards who opposed Catalan separatism were encouraging immigration, to dilute the culture.

Its opponents say such remarks prove that Catalan nationalism is motivated by a deep sense of racial, or at least cultural, superiority.

"These are comments worthy of the extremist right," said Rafael Ribo, of the United Left party.

A political commentator, Rosa Regas, said: "Mrs Ferrusola has given us a clear example of fascist exclusivism."

Mass immigration is a recent thing in Catalonia. Only 2% of its people come from outside the country. Most work in Barcelona or on the flower farms in the north.

webTitle: Bush budget drives home missile shield priority

fields.headline: Bush budget drives home missile shield priority
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush has put extra spending on the national missile defence (NMD) project at the centre of his budget, it emerged yesterday when the White House released further details of the Republican administration's plans.
fields.body:
George Bush has put extra spending on the national missile defence (NMD) project at the centre of his budget, it emerged yesterday when the White House released further details of the Republican administration's plans.

Mr Bush reiterated his strong commitment to NMD in his 50-minute keynote speech to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday night.

The White House's detailed budget plan, published yesterday, confirms that the controversial missile shield is at the heart of its planning for the next decade.

"To protect our own people, our allies and friends, we must develop and we must deploy effective missile defences," Mr Bush told Congress.

"And as we transform our military, we can discard cold war relics and reduce our own nuclear forces to reflect today's needs."

The budget plan allocates an extra $14bn (£9.7bn) to defence spending, taking the Pentagon's budget for next year to $310bn, or about a third of the total world military spending.

A key element is a $2.6bn allocation - part of a $20bn five-year programme - to fund research and development of new weapon technologies.

Roughly half of this is earmarked for NMD, and for what yesterday's budget plan describes as "new technologies to support the transformation of US military capabilities".

Pentagon officials say the money is intended to underscore the administration's intention of expanding NMD beyond the ground-based system under consideration by the Clinton administration.

Other leading items in the Pentagon budget plan are an already promised extra $1.4bn for armed forces pay and a swingeing round of US military base closures at home and abroad, money-saving exercise certain to be controversial in Congress.

Current Pentagon estimates indicate that as much as a quarter of its current base capacity may be closed.

The total Pentagon budget for 2002 is much lower than many Republican politicians and members of the administration want.

Washington observers believe the figures should be seen very much as a down payment on a potentially huge shake-up of Pentagon spending, including large amounts of new money, in later years of the administration.

The full extent of Mr Bush's military spending plans, including NMD, will only become clear once his defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, has completed three parallel reviews of military priorities.

The first and most important will re-examine national security strategy, the structure of the forces, and budget priorities, and is designed "to create a vision of the nation's military in the 21st century", according to yesterday's paper.

The second focuses specifically on deterrence and missile programmes, including the US nuclear stockpile and NMD. The third will look at military pay and quality of life.

Mr Bush began a two-day tour of five states yesterday to help promote the economic package at the centre of his address to Congress.

The speech, which took the place of this year's State of the Union address, focused overwhelmingly on his budget plans.

Political pride of place was given to the $1,600bn tax cut package, which Democrats have attacked as excessive.

"Some say my tax plan is too big. Others say it is too small. I respectfully disagree. This plan is just right," Mr Bush told Congress, delivering what is likely to be the most-quoted line of his address.

The speech was by far the most important Mr Bush has given since becoming president, and showed the extent to which he is attempting to push America's centre of political gravity to the right after the Clinton years.

He offered big tax cuts, partial privatisation of the federal pension scheme, private school vouchers, cuts in public expenditure, and a restructuring of health care for the elderly. None of these plans was on the table in Mr Clinton's time, nor would any of them have been if Al Gore had won last year's election.

"He talks to the middle while governing to the right," the conservative Wall Street Journal observed.

The speech was by far the most important Mr Bush has given since becoming president, and showed the extent to which he is attempting to push America's centre of political gravity to the right after the Clinton years. He offered big tax cuts, partial privatisation of the federal pension scheme, private school vouchers, cuts in public expenditure, and a restructuring of health care for the elderly. None of these plans was on the table in Mr Clinton's time, nor would any of them have been if Al Gore had won last year's election. "He talks to the middle while governing to the right," the conservative Wall Street Journal observed.

fields.headline: My father was a man of integrity
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams and whoever gave him information for his article on my father, Charles Boxer, must stand accused of calumny and cowardice (Secret history of a hero, Saturday Review, February 24). Calumny for misconstruing facts so that my father is portrayed as a possible traitor to his adored England, and cowardice because this article has been written after my father's death and he is unable to defend himself.
fields.body:
Hywel Williams and whoever gave him information for his article on my father, Charles Boxer, must stand accused of calumny and cowardice (Secret history of a hero, Saturday Review, February 24). Calumny for misconstruing facts so that my father is portrayed as a possible traitor to his adored England, and cowardice because this article has been written after my father's death and he is unable to defend himself.

My father was a stoic man of integrity. I am glad that his biography will be available soon and that people will be able to read truthful, historical facts about him. He was a lover of England, but nobody's fool. He was aware of, and wrote about, the evils of colonialism, just as he was aware of and wrote about the evils of imperialism. He admired Japanese culture, but this admiration did not turn him into a traitor or counterspy. He was an aesthete and admired many different cultures.

Since my father spoke Japanese he was treated with respect by some of his captors. At times he was also treated brutally and endured solitary confinement for months on end. He was scheduled for execution and saved by the bombs dropped by America on Japan.
Carola Boxer Vecchio
White Plains, New York CarvFrench@aol.com

The files detailing the operations of the British Army Aid Group between 1942 and 1945, when fully opened, will provide at least some answers. Stray reports emanating from this group, which monitored the situation in Hong Kong by means of agents and intercepts, give some idea of the extent of collaboration between British officers and the Japanese. The senior British officer in the largest prisoner of war camp in Hong Kong was court-martialled after the war on 12 charges of having "voluntarily aided the enemy". He was acquitted, but the information gathered by the BAAG indicates clearly the nature and scale of treachery in the camps.

Hong Kong was the only British colony occupied by the Japanese in which it was deemed necessary after the war to conduct an official enquiry into collaboration. The conclusions have never been made public.
Sibylla Jane Flower
London

fields.headline: The last straw for lawyers
fields.trailText: I am so pleased that, after 40 years in the Labour party, I left three years ago on the basis that the government would not tax the rich to aid the poor and the deprived, otherwise I would be forced to resign now after the insulting remarks about lawyers made by that little man Jack Straw (Straw angers lawyers, February 28).
fields.body:
I am so pleased that, after 40 years in the Labour party, I left three years ago on the basis that the government would not tax the rich to aid the poor and the deprived, otherwise I would be forced to resign now after the insulting remarks about lawyers made by that little man Jack Straw (Straw angers lawyers, February 28).

For someone who worked in law centres for 10 years (indeed I was the first law centre worker), I resent his attack on all lawyers as being greedy, lacking community spirit and eager and willing to mix with criminals.

His and the lord chancellor's drive towards crippling the legal aid scheme by severe financial cutbacks and general abuse have resulted in my early retirement because of the vast sums having to be spent on bureaucracy instead of case preparation, resulting in solicitors being forced to give a much poorer service to their clients.

The home secretary has always been a bullshitter, as can be seen from his silly remarks about 24-hour courts, when most courts in London are half empty most of the time, and often there are more court staff and police than defendants.

Labour has presided over a removal of defendants' rights and a substantial decrease in the number of people being arrested and brought before the courts - and has made a general mess of its legal policies - and the home secretary has the nerve to call me names.
Peter Kandler
London

Jack Straw does not attack city lawyers, who earn considerably more than legal aid lawyers. If he was serious about saving legal aid money, then he would legalise cannabis.

For the record, I had three years academic training and three years legal training before qualifying as a criminal lawyer (resulting in £10,000 of debt). Current adverts show that a newly qualified police officer after 18 weeks of training earns more than I do. How much does Jack Straw earn for his constant attacks on civil liberties, such as the right to jury trials?
Matt Foot Christian Fisher solicitors mattf@christianf.co.uk

Is it too much to ask for ministers to provide an accurate and informed view of the least well-paid section of the profession, rather than seeking to undermine their efforts in pursuit of cheap political points? Mr Straw knows very well that most criminal defence lawyers, who in most cases undertake work at a salary reflecting the appalling rates authorised by his government, are dedicated honest professionals on call at all hours.

Perhaps his comments would be more appropriately directed at the greedy practices of members of the corporate sector which his government seems so keen to sidle up to. I, for one, no longer intend to vote Labour at the forthcoming election.
Nick Brett
London brett@saunders.co.uk

Jack Straw complains of the growing number of lawyers. When I was in the US in the 80s, I observed a similar trend. I concluded it had two causes: the need to secure compensation in the absence of an adequate welfare state; and the need to pay off student loans. Both now operate here. Since I first attended the Lords 13 years ago, the upper reaches of the legal profession are the only part of the British political establishment for which my respect has increased. They are better able to distinguish the public interest from their personal interest than any other part of the system. Those least able to do so are ministers of the crown of any political persuasion.
Conrad Russell
House of Lords

fields.headline: Our world and beyond
fields.trailText: Farming desperate, police shortages, NHS underfunded, teachers striking over staffing levels, transport system in chaos - meanwhile Gordon Brown has more money than he knows what to do with. If there is life on Mars (Report, February 27), can I book the next available seat please?
fields.body:
Farming desperate, police shortages, NHS underfunded, teachers striking over staffing levels, transport system in chaos - meanwhile Gordon Brown has more money than he knows what to do with. If there is life on Mars (Report, February 27), can I book the next available seat please?
M Papworth
Barnstaple, Devon

John Gray is confusing "globalisation" and "Americanisation" (Comment, February 27). If George Bush decides to put a hold on making the rest of the globe American, it doesn't follow all the rest of us who live on it have to stop getting to know one another.
Jonathan Holland
Madrid, Spain

"Hard-headed focus on American national interest" surely means increased homogenisation of markets, with brand saturation exacerbating environmental damage, sweatshop labour and neglect of human rights in the name of capitalism.
Rachel Burgess
Sandhurst, Berks

I didn't hear England whingeing (Leader, February 27). This team are not prone to moaning and are building a good spirit so they probably won't take any notice of snide comments. Nasser Hssain in particular came out well, giving praise where due and refusing to be drawn on the indisputably dire umpiring.
Liz Baldwin
Macclesfield, Cheshire

While I'm loath to stand up for Tony Blair (Letters, February 26), I'm sure the phrase was: "Et tout va bien?" Surely not even the gnarliest of peasants could object to that?
Shaun Whiteside
London

Any doubts on the euro (Letters, February 24) were laid to rest by Telford Sainsbury's new trolleys - one slot £, one slot €.
Philip Spark
Iron Bridge, Salop

fields.headline: Foot in mouth
fields.trailText: As Animal Aid launches Veggie Month today, yet another crisis in farming tells us that there has never been a better time to go vegetarian. Whatever the cause of this foot and mouth outbreak, it is exacerbated by intensive methods.
fields.body:
As Animal Aid launches Veggie Month today, yet another crisis in farming tells us that there has never been a better time to go vegetarian. Whatever the cause of this foot and mouth outbreak, it is exacerbated by intensive methods.

We are not convinced that consumers will be happy to eat meat from an animal which may be full of foot and mouth disease. Given the assurances offered over the safety of beef, many people will be sceptical about current government statements.

The farming industry is now scratching around for who to blame other than its own oppressive and unhygienic practices. It is fixing on foreigners, and wild animal species, when it should be questioning its own practices. Farmers should remember that this outbreak is not the fault of the infected animals, which deserve maximum consideration during this crisis.
Kay Holder
Animal Aid
Veggie@AnimalAid.co.uk

The consumer has to be courted in an effort to convince them that the high-quality "welfare-friendly" meat produced by British farmers is worth a few pennies more. But does Carole Mann (Letters, February 27) really think that farmers like herself will get any support from the public by hurling insults at them for buying cheaper products? I can think of no other business that would dare be so rude to their its customers and then be surprised that they don't get their loyalty or trade.
GE Purser
Cheltenham, Glos

Today the European parliament will vote a supplementary budget of €971m in light of the BSE crisis. This will then leave a margin of only €506m for agriculture out of a total package of €44.5bn. If the BSE crisis in Europe worsens and if the outbreaks of foot and mouth disease spread, then it is likely that amounts well in excess of the remaining margin will be necessary. What the council of ministers and the commission seem determined to ensure is that any further compensation must come from within the existing budget. The consequence of this is that CAP expenditure in other areas will have to be cut. These tragedies could well be the catalyst for reform of the CAP in the not too distant future.
Terry Wynn MEP
Chairman, European parliament budget committee

I cannot but reflect that if the nation is deprived of meat for weeks or months due to the current crisis it will - as during the healthy years of wartime rationing - do us all a power of good.
Audrey Eyton
Author, F-Plan Diet

webTitle: £12m investment for tech sector in Wales

fields.headline: £12m investment for tech sector in Wales
fields.standfirst: The north-south divide
fields.trailText: The Welsh Development Agency plans to invest £12m over the next year to create 50,000 jobs in the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
The Welsh Development Agency plans to invest £12m over the next year to create 50,000 jobs in the hi-tech sector.

The Technium initiative is designed to create skilled, highly paid jobs for a region gutted by steel plant closures and suffering from relatively high unemployment.

Sir David Rowe-Beddoe, chairman of the WDA, said the initiative will create hi-tech business centres across Wales, stimulating homegrown businesses and attracting foreign technology investment.

"We will spend £52m in a mixture of public and private money to create this network of research and development centres across Wales in the next five to six years," he said.

The first centre has been built in Swansea, and tenants - including healthcare and electronics giant Agilent Technologies - are moving in. Future centres will include a biotech venture near the national botanic gardens in Llanarthne, an automotive technology site at Pembrey and an electronics centre at Bangor.

Unemployment is running at 4.5% in Wales in contrast to 3.5% for the UK as a whole. The region also has a lower proportion of "knowledge economy" jobs: 12% for Wales and 18% for the rest of the UK.

Sir David said that the imbalance can be redressed within five years. He added that the current restructuring facing Wales will be far easier to deal with than the shutdown of the steel industry in the 1970s.

The WDA was introduced in 1975 to create jobs when tens of thousands were lost as steel plants closed.

"There are many misperceptions about Wales, not least in the UK," he said. "But today Wales is in a far more powerful position to deal with another restructuring."

fields.headline: Europe awaits crucial findings
fields.standfirst:
Exports: Thousands of animals killed as UK is accused

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: With a mixture of hope and trepidation, farmers across Europe were last night awaiting the final outcome of tests that will show whether foot and mouth has spread from Britain to the continent.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin, Stuart Jeffries in Paris,  Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and Giles Tremlett in Madrid
fields.body:
With a mixture of hope and trepidation, farmers across Europe were last night awaiting the final outcome of tests that will show whether foot and mouth has spread from Britain to the continent.

Officials in the German region of North Rhine-Westphalia said on Tuesday that sheep imported from Britain had tested positive for antibodies, suggesting that they had been in contact with animals that had the disease. But the federal agriculture minister, Renate Künast, said yesterday that the risk of an outbreak was low.

She said two sets of subsequent tests had found no indication that the sheep were themselves infected. The results of a third and definitive test were expected today.

Elsewhere, there were recriminations against Britain. A senior veterinary inspector at Ciney cattle market in Belgium, Paul Pilotte, told the daily Le Soir: "It was the English who pushed for abolishing Europe's foot and mouth vaccination programme and look where we are now. "The English only value their land in order to extract profit from it and agriculture there has become an industry. Those who don't respect normal standards should be nailed to the stake."

The Belgian government is slaughtering 2,000 British sheep and goats and has shut cattle markets.

In Spain, where more than 2,000 pigs and sheep imported from Britain are to be slaughtered, the daily El Mundo accused the British government of being too lax in its controls on livestock.

"Vaccinations against this disease stopped being compulsory in the EU in 1990 but the UK had stopped well before that now Europe is paying for Britain's excess confidence," it said.

In North Rhine-Westphalia, two farms that had imported sheep from Britain were yesterday still under quarantine as a huge, two-day disinfection operation began.

A spokesman for the regional agriculture ministry said 1,850 sheep on the farms had been slaughtered as a precaution. Other farms in Brandenburg and Lower Saxony that had imported animals from Britain recently were also put under quarantine.

Outside Germany, fears over the spread of disease were greatest in France. Some 45% of the sheep and pigs Britain sells to Europe go to France.

Le Monde yesterday called the foot and mouth scare "the gravest sanitary alert in Europe for 30 years".

The French agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, has ordered the destruction of 20,000 sheep exported to France from Britain since last February.

Among those affected by the outbreak are Belgium's 450,000 Muslims who had been planning to sacrifice thousands of sheep during the annual Aid-El-Kebir festival next month.

fields.headline: Turkish Cypriots reply
fields.trailText: Hardly surprising perhaps, but Christopher Hitchen's view is completely one-sided (A nation betrayed, February 26). In his critique of Henry Kissinger's Cyprus policy he says "the total of falsity is so impressive". Indeed it is.
fields.body:
Hardly surprising perhaps, but Christopher Hitchen's view is completely one-sided (A nation betrayed, February 26). In his critique of Henry Kissinger's Cyprus policy he says "the total of falsity is so impressive". Indeed it is.

The US and the UK believe that the attempted genocide of Turkish Cypriots by Greek Cypriots in 1963-64, 1967 and 1974 never happened, despite being documented in the The Genocide Files and in contemporary reports. Former British prime minister, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, said: "I was convinced that if Archbishop Makarios could not bring himself to treat the Turkish Cypriots as human beings, he was inviting the invasion and partition of the island."

The US and the UK believe that the Turkish Cypriot MPs and officials walked out of their offices, when they were thrown out at gunpoint. They believe that the Greek Cypriot government is the government of Cyprus, a status to which it has no legal or moral right. Not until the US and UK address the falsehoods will there be any settlement.
Hakki Muftuzade
London office, Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus

fields.headline: Don's party
fields.trailText: It was good to see that photo again of Bradman batting at Worcester in 1948 (Obituary, February 27).
fields.body:
It was good to see that photo again of Bradman batting at Worcester in 1948 (Obituary, February 27). Along with my school friends I was there, aged 11. In mid-morning, as Bradman and Barnes were both more than half way to their centuries, our headmaster called the whole school together. He told us all lessons were suspended and we were to get ourselves to the County Ground as fast as we could - or miss history being made. We saw both make their hundreds and the great Don get bowled for 107.
David Westgate
Hexham, Northumberland

webTitle: Police chiefs call for fair treatment of asylum seekers

fields.headline: Police chiefs call for fair treatment of asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding and are entitled to the same protection to live free from harassment and intimidation as any other member of society, senior police officers said yesterday.
fields.body:
The overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding and are entitled to the same protection to live free from harassment and intimidation as any other member of society, senior police officers said yesterday.

Launching an official guide for all forces on meeting the policing needs of asylum seekers and refugees, its author, Robert Ayling, deputy chief constable of Kent, said that contrary to media impressions crime had gone down in Dover and the Kent area since the recent asylum influx.

"As in most groups, the overwhelming majority of asylum seekers are law-abiding citizens. There are criminals who are asylum seekers and often their victims are other asylum seekers.

"Those who offend will be treated treated exactly as any other offender."

The Association of Chief Police Officers' guide stresses the positive contribution that asylum seekers can make to Britain, and goes as far as to suggest that forces should distribute welcome leaflets to newly dispersed asylum seekers, explaining their rights and responsibilities, and thus challenging inaccurate and irresponsible media reporting.

fields.headline: Outbreak haunts deserted market town
fields.standfirst:
The heart of Hatherleigh is agriculture. This week the only farmers to be seen there were made of stone

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The three farmers are standing at the edge of a pen looking at sheep in the middle of the west Devon town of Hatherleigh. They are peering at them, sizing them up to see if they are worth buying. It is a poignant scene, but it is not real. The farmers and the sheep are stone. It's a sculpture highlighting the history of this town that has farming at its heart.
fields.body:
The three farmers are standing at the edge of a pen looking at sheep in the middle of the west Devon town of Hatherleigh. They are peering at them, sizing them up to see if they are worth buying. It is a poignant scene, but it is not real. The farmers and the sheep are stone. It's a sculpture highlighting the history of this town that has farming at its heart.

This week, in the wake of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease, these stone statues, made by Roger Dean, were the only farmers and livestock to be seen in the town. Foot and mouth has closed the livestock market and the nearby abattoir, and sealed off every farm in the area.

For a place usually bustling with livestock traders and people out buying provisions from the market, Hatherleigh is, as the locals say, a ghost town now. The fear, and the unanswered question, is: for how long? Hatherleigh is just a few miles from Highampton, where a further outbreak of foot and mouth was confirmed yesterday, and the disease has also been discovered at the closed abattoir that sits at the centre of the town.

At the weekly livestock market, which has been going for more than 500 years, traders sell plants, cut flowers, locally produced honey and other goods as well as animals. This week, however, there were few people around, except for those stopping by the agricultural merchants to pick up disinfectant, which is running low. At the bar of the George hotel, which has slaked the thirst of farmers for hundreds of years, the barman said it was "dreadfully quiet". The Tally Ho inn has shut its doors early.

The signs of the impact of foot and mouth are everywhere. A poster at the town's church asks the people to pray. "Our farmers need our help," it says. There are fewer children about, as parents have been advised to keep them from school for fear of spreading the disease.

Frank Yeo, a director of KVN Stockdale, which owns Hatherleigh market, explained the importance of the market. "We have a market here three days of the week. Our average weekly throughput is in the region of 500 cattle and 2,000 sheep. On Tuesdays there'll be about 150 farmers selling and about 80 farmers buying. Then we have have market stalls for all the ancillary trades."

Mr Yeo said that across the town there was "a feeling of apprehension". The market's 10 staff may have to be laid off, much as has happened at the abattoir, where the 40 people working there were sent home on Monday afternoon.

Deborah Lang-Trengrove, Hatherleigh's lord of the manor, said: "It's really quite desperate in the town. People are in shock and wondering what's going to happen. It's quite disastrous. I am quite worried about what will happen to an awful lot of local, family-run businesses. There is a horrible knock-on effect because of the market being closed. Hatherleigh has already been greatly depressed by things that have hit agriculture because it is such a farming centred town."

Ms Lang-Trengrove said that usually on market days the pubs and shops are packed. This week they were not. "It is absolutely catastrophic and for a lot of businesses this will be the end of them."

John Entwistle, who has run the town's General Stores for more than 20 years, said he had never seen it so quiet. On market day he does "a rip roaring trade in pasties". But the town has lost its bustle. People who are venturing out are terrified about what's happening, he said, recalling one woman in his shop who remembered the last foot and mouth outbreak. "She says it took her 45 years to build up her dairy herd. You can't replace that. You can't go out and buy a new one."

Of all the town's people, Denis Bater probably understands best the impact of foot and mouth. He runs the fish and chip shop which services the market, he is the postman and he is Hatherleigh's mayor. He knows and talks to everyone. "We really are completely reliant on agriculture here. This closure has had a tremendous impact. People from all the villages come here for shopping, a lot of retired people like to come on Tuesdays - it's their social day. Since foot and mouth, no one's coming. A lot of businesses here are small, run on a shoestring. It's difficult to say what's going to happen."

For the time being in this ghost town there is a hiatus - with the virus centre-stage.

fields.headline: Best behaviour in unnaturally sterile house
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: In the face of the Selby rail crash and the foot and mouth crisis, the Commons was grave, measured and responsible. There were almost no party political points made during prime minister's questions. It was what old hands call "the house at its best". I thought it was awful.
fields.body:
MPs were in a sombre mood yesterday. Stunned, I thought, as you feel on a day when something has gone badly wrong at work, you discover that the roof leaks and smoke pours from the engine of your car when you turn on the ignition. You wonder how much more you can take, and at the back of your superstitious mind you ask yourself whether in some way you have offended the fates.

So in the face of the Selby rail crash and the foot and mouth crisis, the Commons was grave, measured and responsible. There were almost no party political points made during prime minister's questions. It was what old hands call "the house at its best". I thought it was awful.

William Hague nearly apologised for this complacent consensus. "Everyone will understand if the normal robustness of our exchanges is subdued," he said.

Robustness? I've seen wet J-cloths more robust than Mr Hague's questions. According to his spin doctors, this was a deliberate decision. The country would not have understood if such a sad day were used for scoring cheap political points.

But if ferocious political debate has to halt whenever there's a crisis, why don't we suspend it over education, crime, the health service, all of which are in constant crisis? If the house must, so to speak, stand around like paid mutes on an occasion like this, doesn't that imply that their fierce, heated, angry discussions are wasted time, a harlequinade upon which the curtain can always be brought down?

We realised that things were out of control when the usual frantic exchanges between the Tory leader and the prime minister dwindled into a polite discussion on the topic of disinfectant. Mr Hague said that farmers would need lots of disinfectant, and some of them couldn't find supplies.

Mr Blair replied that there was plenty of disinfectant, but it wasn't necessarily in the right places. Obviously it was a fluid situation. The Jeyes to the right, the noes to the left, as MPs say.

Mr Hague finally decided that the house was now reduced to such a somnolent torpor of agreement that he could try to smuggle in a political point, like a little old lady sneaking duty-free scent through the green channel. The Countryside Alliance, he said, had shown its calmness and restraint by cancelling its march. It would be a proper recognition of this for the government to delay sending the hunting bill to the Lords, "until those who wish to protest have been able to do so!"

Suddenly Labour MPs realised that this was a sneaky attempt to get the bill killed. They began to boo. It was a heartening reminder that the old politics was not dead, but was merely atrophied.

(Mr Blair has adopted a curious new style of sitting. Some Labour MPs used the day to ask even creepier questions than usual. The prime minister sat with forehead resting on fist, just like Rodin's Thinker, as if the lickspittle request was some vital yet almost impenetrable philosophical point.)

There was at least one bizarre moment during Northern Ireland questions, taken for the first time by the new secretary of state, John Reid. Peter Mandelson came in to hear his successor, and asked him to support the Omagh bombing survivors' group.

"The Rt Hon member has put his money where his mouth used to be," Dr Reid replied.

What could he mean by this? As so often in the Commons, my brain began to feel as if it were casting loose from my skull, and I felt the need to lie down, perhaps with a disinfectant-soaked handkerchief clamped to my mouth.

fields.headline: Computer masters baby talk
fields.trailText: A software-based baby "chatterbot" called Hal - named for the villainous computer in 2001: A Space Odyssey - could be about to command the language ability of a five-year-old.
fields.body:
A software-based baby "chatterbot" called Hal - named for the villainous computer in 2001: A Space Odyssey - could be about to command the language ability of a five-year-old.

According to New Scientist, the programme is said to have fooled independent experts into believing that they were talking to a 15-month-old child.

Of the 900,000 robots at work on the planet none can be trusted with commands in natural language. None could really tell the difference between "I would like to recognise speech" and "I would like to wreck a nice beach". Scientists keep hoping their systems will pass the famous conversation test set by the pioneer British computer scientist Alan Turing - could you tell it was a computer that answered you? - but success eludes them.

But Jason Hutchens, an Australian scientist now with Artificial Intelligence Enterprises of Tel Aviv, has high hopes for his toddler Hal. Rather than write complex programmes trying to anticipate the niceties of language, he argues, why not give the com puter a collection of learning algorithms and let it learn language the way children do. So Hal has a single carer who types in children's stories and talks back to it like a parent.

From these beginnings, Dr Hutchens says, Hal may one day be able to tell the difference between challenging sentence structures such as "Time flies like an arrow" and "Fruit flies like a banana". So far, it can manage only simple sentences. The programme does not have to be told how to learn a language, it figures it out for itself. "The whole point is we don't know how it is do ing it," said Dr Hutchens. He has already produced a conversational programme called MegaHal, which has come up with surreal quotes such as "Dr Stephen Hawking is a reality. One of the exploited working class," but which are never completely successful.

Alan Turing also suggested the best way to pass the test would be to build a machine and train it. With a machine that could talk and listen, we could discard keyboards. But so far, the only answer is that given by Hal in 2001: A Space Odyssey. "I'm sorry, Dave, I can't do that."

fields.headline: Tongues wag as 'King Coal' quits
fields.trailText: Richard Budge, the "king coal" of UK's depleted mining industry, unexpectedly quit his post as chief executive yesterday amid speculation of a board room row at RJB Mining, the company he created.
fields.body:
Richard Budge, the "king coal" of UK's depleted mining industry, unexpectedly quit his post as chief executive yesterday amid speculation of a board room row at RJB Mining, the company he created.

The UK's biggest coal producer insisted Mr Budge had left with mutual consent and without acrimony. But the City was unconvinced, given his departure with an undisclosed compensation package.

The timing was also a surprise, given the fact that RJB, named after Mr Budge's initials, is to report annual earnings next week and no permanent successor has been chosen to replace him.

RJB, which took over most of the assets of the former National Coal Board in England on privatisation in October 1994, said it had appointed finance director Tony McPhee as its acting chief executive. It would look around for a successor.

Chairman John Robinson insisted it was business as usual at the group, which employs 8,000 people at 17 deep mines but once employed 230,000 at 211 sites. "Richard has been chief executive for an awfully long time and wanted a change. There has been no argument on policy or direction and everything has been perfectly amicable."

Mr Robinson denied that there had been any further approaches from would-be buyers after the recent collapse of an offer from US conglomerate Renco. But analysts were still struggling last night to make sense of the change.

Martin Potts, an analyst with Williams de Broe, said: "I cannot imagine what provoked the timing of this. He did not always have the total support of shareholders all the time, but RJB has the subsidies and its results should be as expected. Clearly there are some issues going on behind the scenes."

Mr Budge was keeping a low profile yesterday, but in a formal statement he said: "I am proud to have been the founder of the company and its chief executive since before the listing on the stock exchange in 1993. I have always profoundly believed in retaining the largest viable coal industry within the UK, and we have achieved that."

Mr Budge was deemed a controversial figure because of his abrasive style and connections with the family firm AF Budge, which went into receivership in 1992, triggering a Department of Trade investigation.

He was not mourned by the National Union of Mineworkers, which had failed to win recognition in RJB pits. David Douglas, an official who runs the NUM's community advice centre in Doncaster, said he hoped his successor would take a more conciliatory view towards the NUM.

But Ann Fellows, general manager at the Confederation of UK Coal Producers where Mr Budge is president, said: "The industry is in much better state than it would have been without him. He was a great ambassador."

Mr Budge once owned a majority of the company but has sold down his stake to 3.67%. He said in his statement the company was in good shape to face the challenges of the future.

RJB is expected to announce 2000 pre-tax profits of around £12.5m compared with £11m the previous year.

The company saw a quarter of its stock market value wiped out last October after the collapse of the Renco bid talks. Renco failed to meet the company's deadline to table an offer, pushing RJB's share price down 17p to 46.5p. Yesterday RJB's price rose 1.25p to 79p.

webTitle: Leeds: Verve and confidence help prosperity, but a dark side remains

fields.headline: Leeds: Verve and confidence help prosperity, but a dark side remains
fields.trailText: When you hear that Leeds has got a new statue, images of Yorkshire pudding or rugby league may come to mind. But instead, in the busy "pocket park" of Bond Court, you can eat your sandwiches by the sculpture of a local family watching a bronze Frenchman at boules. Under the trees you may find French students, or a waiter from Sous le Nez or La Grillade, watching Yorkshire citizens pitch their boules.
fields.body:
When you hear that Leeds has got a new statue, images of Yorkshire pudding or rugby league may come to mind. But instead, in the busy "pocket park" of Bond Court, you can eat your sandwiches by the sculpture of a local family watching a bronze Frenchman at boules. Under the trees you may find French students, or a waiter from Sous le Nez or La Grillade, watching Yorkshire citizens pitch their boules.

It's a scene which tells the story of how one northern city has prospered through verve and imagination, as Raymond Vaillant, deputy mayor of Leeds' twin city, Lille, said when he unveiled the statue in October.

Like Lille, Leeds has reinvented itself with a self-confidence that assumes that the city's clubs and commerce giants like PricewaterhouseCooper, HSBC bank and Colliers Conrad Rittblat (donors of the annual Colliers cup for Leeds boules) will find an outdoor French game good for networking.

The buzz is palpable. Skating, at the temporary ice rink in Millennium Square, was sold out in February. This is where students dominate, another indicator of a confident city - and Leeds University vies with Nottingham as the UK's most popular.

But there is another Leeds, as the Labour council leader, Brian Walker, mentions even at the glitziest celebrations of this "British Barcelona". Leeds has families evicted from the Halton Moor and Hawksworth Wood estates for using airguns and lighting letterbox fires, a postal area (LS2) that is the most burgled in the country, and a recent "doped" gang murder on Lincoln Green.

The great debate, since Leeds won European assistance for five inner wards two years ago, has been whether the booming city centre can help. John Ansbro, director of the Leeds development agency, thinks it can. "Unemployment is down to 3.5% Leeds still has more vacancies now than people looking for work."

Skills and the jobs on offer do not, of course, perfectly match. And the general view is that there is maybe a 7,000-strong core of people alienated by endless hard times.

The regional development agency Yorkshire Forward has earned marks in Leeds for community and sustainability programmes. But government help is needed with jobs and learning schemes.

The big fear is that Leeds' overall boom could fast turn to bust. But fear, as they say on the boules piste, is the greatest enemy of self-confidence - and gloom is not excessively discussed.

This is where students dominate, another indicator of a confident city - and Leeds University vies with Nottingham as the UK's most popular. But there is another Leeds, as the Labour council leader, Brian Walker, mentions even at the glitziest celebrations of this "British Barcelona". Leeds has families evicted from the Halton Moor and Hawksworth Wood estates for using airguns and lighting letterbox fires, a postal area (LS2) that is the most burgled in the country, and a recent "doped" gang murder on Lincoln Green. The great debate, since Leeds won European assistance for five inner wards two years ago, has been whether the booming city centre can help. John Ansbro, director of the Leeds development agency, thinks it can. "Unemployment is down to 3.5% Leeds still has more vacancies now than people looking for work." Skills and the jobs on offer do not, of course, perfectly match. And the general view is that there is maybe a 7,000-strong core of people alienated by endless hard times. The regional development agency Yorkshire Forward has earned marks in Leeds for community and sustainability programmes. But government help is needed with jobs and learning schemes. The big fear is that Leeds' overall boom could fast turn to bust. But fear, as they say on the boules piste, is the greatest enemy of self-confidence - and gloom is not excessively discussed.

fields.headline: Schroders funds droop at £132bn
fields.trailText: Schroders lost £10bn in funds under management last year as pension funds quit the company following prolonged investment underperformance.
fields.body:
Schroders lost £10bn in funds under management last year as pension funds quit the company following prolonged investment underperformance.

Total funds slipped from £142.6bn to £132.5bn, the company said yesterday, with institutional clients withdrawing £6.3bn and market losses cutting a further £5.9bn off assets. Schroders said it was the victim of a structural shift to index management of pension funds - a business dominated by Barclays and Legal & General - but claimed the trend was slowing.

"We had relatively weak performance in 1998 and 1999 and saw a number of major funds restructure and direct money to passive management. It's a trend we now expect to slow," a Schroders spokesman said.

The figures were the first since Schroders sold its investment banking business to Salomon Smith Barney last year. Headline pre-tax profits fell from £324m to £275m, mainly due to a slowdown in investment banking. Underlying profits on continuing operations rose 25.3% to £228.2m.

Profits were held back by a surge in costs from £346m to £427m, prompting speculation of further bonus and salary increases at what is already renowned as the FTSE 100 company with the highest average pay per head.

Schroders said increased costs resulted from a 15% rise in headcount as the company took on staff previously working partly for the investment bank. It also invested heavily in building fund distribution in Europe and in website links to institutional clients.

Peter Sedgwick, the company's chairman, said: "While there are inevitable lags in the impact of performance on asset growth, we are enjoying an improved level of new business interest. We would hope to re-establish our path of growth in funds under management by the end of 2001."

fields.headline: Rentokil clears the air
fields.standfirst: Chief executive draws a line under 'worst year in company's history'
fields.trailText: Clive Thompson, the Rentokil Initial chief executive who was once known as Mr Twenty Percent in the City because of the company's earnings record and ambitions, yesterday drew a line under one of the most difficult years in the history of the pest control to tropical plants combine.
fields.body:
Clive Thompson, the Rentokil Initial chief executive who was once known as Mr Twenty Percent in the City because of the company's earnings record and ambitions, yesterday drew a line under one of the most difficult years in the history of the pest control to tropical plants combine.

Full year figures from the group showed pre-tax profits from its core businesses had fallen to £413m from £424m, but Sir Clive claimed that the radical restructuring which had seen the group sell some £619m worth of businesses, had left Rentokil well positioned to move ahead.

"We have now achieved our aim of making the company leaner, more efficient and fitter to take advantage of the ex cellent opportunities in our markets," he said.

Rentokil was forced to abandon its target of annual earnings growth of 20% in 1999 and is now measuring itself more flexibly against the per formance of its leading peers. Despite experiencing a difficult year, Sir Clive was able to point to signs of recovery in the second half, where core profits were slightly ahead of those for comparable operations in 1999, and he noted yesterday that the company retained plenty of financial firepower despite spending £1.3bn last year on buying back more than a quarter of its own shares.

Sir Clive acknowledged that the uncertainties stemming from the wide ranging changes had had an impact on the operating performance of the company.

But he added that those uncertainties had now been removed. "The restructuring programme is finished.

"People know that if they are with Rentokil Initial now they will remain with Rentokil Initial." Rentokil would be looking for bolt-on acquisitions and would consider buying back more shares, although he did not entirely rule out a bigger acquisition if the right opportunity occurred.

Sir Clive said that - based on 2000 earnings - a share buy-back programme would be earnings-enhancing up to 272p a share. That compared with yesterday's closing price of 205.25p, up 1.25p on the day.

Although the group is trading on a lower rating than some of its peers, Sir Clive argued Rentokil investors would best be served by the company remaining independent.

As an indication of its confidence in better times ahead, the board is proposing a full year dividend pay-out of 4.53p - up 10.2% on last year.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: The rather dry and obscure VAT and Duties Tribunal is not usually the site of high political drama.
fields.body:
 The rather dry and obscure VAT and Duties Tribunal is not usually the site of high political drama. But it was recently the scene of a showdown between the Labour party and Customs and Excise, which resulted in Labour winning a stunning £1.2m refund from the exchequer - just in time to fight the coming election.

What a stroke of luck, eh? The payout came after the tribunal ruled that Customs and Excise had overcharged Labour by £1.2m in value-added tax. The case revolved around an agreement Labour made with the tax collectors way back in 1978 over how it calculated the party's VAT, because of the difficulty in deciding what are Labour's business and non-business activities (it's a common problem, just look at the present Lord Chancellor).

At the tribunal Labour argued that changes in policy on VAT for membership fees and fundraising meant the 1978 agreement had become invalid - and the VAT tribunal bravely agreed with the party of government. Tony McClenaghan, top VAT partner at accountants Deloitte & Touche, said: "The method Customs used for determining Labour's recoverable VAT was pretty unusual." Indeed, and that £1.2m will come in handy.

 Dutch prostitutes are reporting ING bank to the country's equal opportunities commission, after it refused to give them a bank account. "ING is discriminating against women," said Lavina Dick, policy adviser at the group representing prostitutes.

 The phone rings. "Hello, this is David Hargreaves, the chief executive of Agricola Resources." Oh dear. Regular readers may recall yesterday's charming story about a foul-mouthed staff member at the Ofex 2001 exhibition, who wandered about the Agricola stand telling investors to "f*** off". "It was all true," says David. "I only hired her for the day because I anticipated we would be very busy." But after a liquid lunch it all become too much for the temporary employee, and David poured her into a taxi with some relief. Phew. David and marketing manager Kathy Chappell managed to cope with the resulting 12-hour shift without further excitement.

 Readers have pointed out that the Financial Times's Robin Lane Fox (who printed a recipe to cook squirrels in last weekend's FT) has been conducting a savage anti-squirrel vendetta for several weeks now through the pages of the FT. The weekend before last he complained that the furry rascals were digging up his garden bulbs and re placing them with peanuts.

One reader was rude enough to suggest that the squirrel's activity was no different to that of Robin's daughter Martha and shares in her Lastminute.com online bucketshop: people thought they had bought something valuable, but were later surprised to find they had been replaced by peanuts.

 How The City Really Works (Part 275): some insights into the strange world of analysts in the latest issue of Management Today, and their supposed "independence" in the advice they give clients about stocks. "If there was a placement, a rights issue or some other activity in the pipeline, woe betide the analyst who regarded the stock as a sell," according to one nameless former analyst. "Everyone knows how it is. I was once in a lift with my boss and told him I was putting a sell notice on a particular company. By the time we reached the ground floor, the stock had become an add. By the evening it was a buy."

 Poor old Turkey might be suffering from financial meltdown. But what's a crisis for one is an opportunity for another - so fezzes off to the foreign exchange division of American Express for spotting the opening. "Sterling work for British holidaymakers," it crows in a press release, "best value to be found in Turkey as government devalues currency."

webTitle: £7,000 for window view of Mir fireworks

fields.headline: £7,000 for window view of Mir fireworks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: As Russia mournfully awaits the imminent destruction of the Mir space station, due to plunge into the Pacific later this month, some American entrepreneurs have spotted a lucrative business opportunity.
fields.body:
As Russia mournfully awaits the imminent destruction of the Mir space station, due to plunge into the Pacific later this month, some American entrepreneurs have spotted a lucrative business opportunity.

They are marketing Mir's last moments as "one of the most spectacular celestial events of the 21st century" and inviting enthusiasts eager to watch its blazing descent to pay $10,000 (£7,000) for a seat on a chartered jet that will circle the crash zone.

The passengers should be able to see "140 tonnes of man-made technology careering towards the earth in a fiery display of pyrotechnics", the promotional material promises.

They can also expect a storm of fragmented solar panels, rocket engines, tubing, cabling and fuel tanks raining down on the ocean in "streaming trails of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of incandescent pieces".

The man behind the idea, Bob Citron, has reassured the 60 passengers already signed up to the trip that the plane will remain a safe distance from the exploding space station and that no risk is involved.

"We will be hundreds of miles from even the beginning of the debris footprint, so really there is no danger of being hit," he said.

The display is expected to last about five minutes - working out at about £1,400 a minute for each passenger.

Poorer space fanatics are offered an aisle seat for $5,000; the poorest a free simulation of the destruction on the company's website.

The success of the event will depend a lot on whether scientists at mission control in Moscow guide the jet to the best viewing position: the pilot will be in constant contact with them to pick the safest and best path for the plane.

A group of Russia's most senior cosmonauts, including Sergei Avdeyev, who spent more than a year in the station, has been invited to join the plane. Leonid Gorshkov, one of the main architects of Mir, has also been given a free seat.

The date of Mir's death is scheduled between March 13 and 18, depending on the speed of its current descent. The 35 tonnes of Mir that are expected to survive re-entry are expected to hit the sea at 120mph about halfway between New Zealand and Chile over a stretch of ocean 120 miles by 3,600 miles.

fields.headline: Eidos signals more cost cuts
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games company that has seen its once high flying share price shattered by a string of profit warnings over the past year.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games company that has seen its once high flying share price shattered by a string of profit warnings over the past year, yesterday signalled that it would continue to cut costs in anticipation of further tough trading conditions.

Chief executive Mike McGarvey said the belt tightening was necessary due to delays to the distribution of the new PlayStation 2 console and the launch of Microsoft's Xbox machine, which made a big increase in games sales and a return to profitability unlikely until 2002 or even 2003.

"This company grew very fast and the mentality used to be one of spend, spend, spend rather than save, save, save, and it didn't perhaps have the focus on costs that it should have," Mr McGarvey said.

"There will be a drive to significantly reduce fixed costs over the coming year."

Mr McGarvey's cost-cutting measures have already led to a 17% drop in fixed sales and marketing spend and an 11% reduction in research and development costs. However, the firm has still be able to increase its market share in Britain, Germany and France and third-quarter sales showed signs of improvement.

Shares in the company behind the popular Tomb Raider franchise yesterday fell 15% to 229p as the dealers digested figures showing a pre-tax loss of £68m and revenues of £127m during the nine months to December 31.

The stock once traded at more than £10.

Some analysts said they were concerned about Eidos' long-term financing position given that it had used up more than half of its £50m overdraft facility and had just £7.7m cash in the bank.

The lack of a full-time finance director was also seen as a negative, but the company hopes to fill the post shortly.

House broker Dresdner Klienwort Wasserstein was thought to be revising downwards its financial forecasts.

However, other analysts said that fees owing by retailers from Christmas games sales would make the balance sheet seem more healthy once they were received.

They also pointed to an investment in a Scandinavian technology firm named Opticom, which was worth around £15m and could easily be sold. "Eidos has a history of over-promising and under-delivering, but now it looks like they plan to under-promise and over-deliver, and we'd much rather have it that way," said one analyst.

Last year Eidos received a takeover approach from Infogrames, a French rival keen to take advantage of the weakness in the British company's share price.

Several analysts believe Eidos may eventually be swallowed up by a bigger group.

"I don't see great numbers of people frothing at the mouth to buy us, and some of the firms who might want to have their plates full integrating other acquisitions," said Mr McGarvey. "But if someone approached us we'd obviously need to look at it on behalf of our shareholders. There will probably be a lot more interest in the later part of this year or maybe next year."

Computer games sales tend to peak when new consoles go on sale and players upgrade to faster and more powerful models, but slow in the months before they are introduced.

Eidos believes that this cycle is nearing its low point, and that the industry is about to enter its biggest boom period to date as gamers play on multiple platforms - including mobile phones, interactive televisions and PCs.

fields.headline: Telecoms factories face tough year
fields.trailText: Telecoms equipment manufacturers have a tough year ahead after enjoying double-digit growth in 2000, a report from IT research group Gartner predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
Telecoms equipment manufacturers have a tough year ahead after enjoying double-digit growth in 2000, a report from IT research group Gartner predicted yesterday.

Gartner said manufacturers faced the disappearance of some customers as dot.coms fold, while new clients were likely to request repairs and maintenance to networks instead of building new ones.

"The slowing economy and recent struggles in the dot.com industry will make 2001 a turbulent year in the telecommunications industry," said Dean Eyers, the vice-president of Gartner's telecoms and networking group.

The report shows a shift among the top eight manufacturers, with Lucent slipping from first to the fourth spot after a year of missed earnings targets, share price falls and an investigation by US stock market authorities into accounting irregularities.

Ericsson, which is winning many contracts to build networks for third-generation mobile services, takes top spot.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

D1 On Tuesday which of the following parts of Britain was not affected by heavy snow?

(a) Northern England

(b) Scotland

(b) Northern Ireland

(c) Those soft southern nancys

D2 What does the word "qanuk" mean to the Central Alaskan Yupik eskimos?

(a) Snowflake

(b) Drifting snow

(c) Sludge

(d) The type of snow that falls down the gaps in your wellies.

D3 In Raymond Briggs's The Snowman, what are the colour of the little boy's pyjamas?

(a) Green paisley

(b) Red and white striped

(c) Blue and white striped

(d) He wore a nightshirt

D4 Rapper Vanilla Ice hails from

(a) Miami

(b) Dallas

(c) Denver

(d) The streets, man

D5 Mr Frosty, the ice-lolly-making toy, was assisted by

(a) Peter Polar Bear

(b) Rocky Robin

(c) Percy Penguin

(d) Robbie Reindeer

fields.headline: Just close friends
fields.trailText: Brookside | Raw Blues
fields.body:
These days, no one in Brookside (Channel 4) ever watches The Magic Rabbits on TV. There was a time when it was all Terry Sullivan and Barry Grant would do of a morning. Sometimes, their marathon telly-watching sessions would make Jim Royle look like Zola Budd (except at that time, Jim Royle looked like Bobby Grant). Now, no one even mourns the passing of The Magic Rabbits, let alone chats about them nostalgically in the pub as they maybe would about Bagpuss or Chorlton And The Wheelies.

Of course, that was in the days before they even had proper music in Brookside. At that time, whenever anyone turned on a radio, what piped out wasn't the same kind of music that was played in Kaff's Caff in Walford or on the jukebox in the Rovers (which is to say, music we all recognise that had to be paid for before it could be broadcast). Oh no - it was music that sounded as if it was recorded round Liverpool's Further Education colleges by aspiring indie bands. Which it probably was.

Nowadays though, the makers of Brookside have forked out for proper music, and you can't move in Bev's Bar for a bit of Britney. The Manor Park Massive's trip to Southport was no different. They had a right good sing-along to The Troggs' Wild Thing, which seemed all too appropriate, what with Lance and Leanne (troglodytes of the lowest order) cosied up with Dr Darren the (im)patient fiddler, Bernie Nolan and Rachel Jordache-Dixon (who, if her current run of bad luck is anything to go by, will shortly be marrying Max Farnham).

I admit that Brookside can be a bit fanciful on occasion, but this homage to Una Stubbs and Cliff Richard seemed a bit much. Certainly, Dr Darren should get full marks for bravery for staring Leanne in the face (he's a braver man than me), but would he and Posh Victoria really share a minibus with the woman who not only accused him of assaulting her but also served time for throwing acid in the face of their mate, Jacqui Dixon? Doesn't the same go for Rachel, who seems far too keen on Bev who tried to ruin her and Mike's life not long ago? And surely Bernie Nolan would have suggested one of her own back catalogue for a sing-along instead of The Troggs?

The only explanation for all this must be that proffered by Madonna. Music really does make the people come together.

But all the Southport shenanigans faded into the background with the traumatastic goings-on in the Dixon household. No, not the hostage situation, which perhaps induced a heart attack in Ron (we live in hope). Rather, the big news of the night was the revelation - voiced by Kitty the California Raisin - that Jessie has got, and I quote, "a pokey hole". Can't say I'm surprised but that is way too much information.

Like Police Dog Academy without the dogs, Raw Blues (BBC1) follows new recruits to the Metropolitan Police through their four-month training course. A cursed docusoap that verged dangerously on recruitment video, it began with a speech about how there was no room for sexism, racism, homophobia or bullying in the Met. This is not, as you might expect, because it is already jam-packed full of those things and there simply isn't room for any more but because the Met wants to change its bad old, sad old ways.

With 180 recruits needed every five weeks, the trainers at Hendon were trying to come over all touchy-feely with the 93 in this intake. Hence, there was much talk of police officers having enormous responsibility and being examples of good citizens, of how much the police had changed and were adapting to a modern world - effectively, of how the police were nice really.

And then Sergeant Dave appeared. He described himself as a disciplinarian but a teddy bear - Paddington in jackboots, I suppose - and proceeded to give his recruits a hard time for being a couple of minutes late and early alarm calls for not shaving that morning. Either you are clean-shaven or have a full beard, he explained to Craig, who was growing a goatee. (Apparently, if you are the one running towards a detonated bomb while everyone else is running away, or helping an old lady who's been mugged, having a goatee is a real handicap.) Poor Sergeant Dave clearly hasn't realised that the best cops are mavericks. Well, they are the ones who get their own drama series.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: She Wore A Yellow Ribbon | Plein Soleil | When We Were Kings
fields.body:
Films

She Wore A Yellow Ribbon
(John Ford, 1949)
10am, 4pm, Sky Cinema

Second of Ford's cavalry trilogy and the only one in (often sombre) colour. John Wayne leads again, as ageing Captain Nathan Brittles, saddled with escorting two women when he should be tracking Arapahos on the warpath. Lots of frontier violence, but the aftermath rather than the deed - a ruined stagepost, the accounts of the survivors. Wayne's Brittles is noble, strong, but fallible too, in his early failures and talking at his wife's grave: not death and glory, but the hard business of day-to-day survival.

Plein Soleil
(René Clément, 1959)
6pm, FilmFour

Interesting to see Clément's thriller in the light of Anthony Minghella's adaptation of the same novel, The Talented Mr Ripley. Alain Delon is an altogether icier presence as Ripley, who conceives a plan to murder the industrialist's dissolute son and grab the money and the girl.

Mutiny On The Bounty
(Frank Lloyd, 1935)
9pm, TCM

Glossy, Oscar-winning MGM treatment of the infamous 1787 mutiny, with a memorable confrontation between Charles Laughton's weak and vicious Captain Bligh and Clark Gable's Fletcher Christian. Lloyd focuses on Bligh's 3,500 mile open-boat voyage to safety, fuelled by the desire for revenge: "I'll live to see you - all of you - hanging from the highest yardarm."

Bulworth
(Warren Beatty, 1998)
12 midnight, Sky Premier

Democrat senator Jay Bulworth, sick of the empty promises he mouths, takes out a large insurance policy, hires a hitman to assassinate him, and starts giving the voters the truth, whether they like it or not. Amid the sharp, rapping politics, his romance with a young woman (Halle Berry) is a little obvious, but this is an astute, barbed, brave and entertaining satire that director Beatty also co-produced, co-wrote and stars in. Small wonder it raised the possibility of Beatty for president.

Mad City
(Costa-Gavras, 1997)
3.25am, Sky Premier Like

any good newshound, Dustin Hoffman's TV reporter Max is in the city museum the very day John Travolta's sacked security man Sam blows a gasket, shooting a colleague and barricading himself in with a class of schoolkids as hostages. Max, his career on hold, sees a chance to use the siege, and simple Sam, to his advantage, just like Kirk Douglas in Ace In The Hole. This isn't as compelling as Billy Wilder's classic, but it's brilliantly acted, and there's a slimy turn from Alan Alda as the cynical anchorman.

Sports

When We Were Kings
9pm, BBC Knowledge

There's plenty of live sport around today, with golf and tennis dominating Eurosport's schedules, but the real action comes in this documentary about the world heavyweight title fight between George Foreman and Muhammad Ali in October 1974, better known as "The Rumble in the Jungle". An Oscar-winner in 1997, it has been shown before (its introduction, on the BBC, comes from Des Lynam) but if you missed it, don't do so again.

fields.headline: Bark up the wrong tree
fields.standfirst: Eggleston Burn, Teesdale
fields.trailText: Eggleston Burn, Teesdale.
fields.body:
The calm, mild afternoon hinted that spring might have arrived. Common sense and a weather forecast predicting snow by Friday dictated otherwise. But there were signs of new life - tiny flower buds in the centre of golden saxifrage shoots, fresh violet and wood sorrel leaves, and vivid new growth of mosses and liverworts under the alder roots along the edge of the beck.

During the torrential downpours on either side of Christmas, the water gurgling over the rocks in the stream bed would have been a thundering torrent, scouring earth and stones from the bank that these plants cling to. The evidence of the flood was still there, in the exposed alder roots and debris tangled in their branches above our heads.

These old trees hold the burn bank together. Some are multi-stemmed and must have been coppiced in the distant past. Most are riddled with rot holes that could accommodate anything from a great tit's to an owl's nest. And most support a rich flora of epiphytic plants - mosses, polypody fern, dandelions, herb Robert, even seedlings of other trees - that have taken root on the humus in the crooks of their branches. One alder plays host to a mature rowan.

The colonist's seed, dropped by a bird, sent roots six feet down through the alder's rotting heartwood until they reached soil, swelled and created a chimera. Now a full-sized rowan tree, sheathed to head height in alder bark, sprouts from the alder's crown. The purple of the alder's lengthening catkins is just beginning to deepen and in a few weeks time they'll be joined by rowan foliage, before alder foliage unfurls amongst corymbs of white rowan blossom.
