fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Morning Performance | Performance On 3 | In Tune
fields.body:
Today being St David's Day, Radio 3 has a Welsh theme. Morning Performance (11.30am) revisits last summer's music festivals in Wales, while Performance On 3 (7.30pm) features the BBC National Chorus and Orchestra of Wales, who play Rhian Samuel's Dawnsiau'r Nant (Dances Of The Stream) inspired by her childhood.

Beforehand, in In Tune (5pm) Sean Rafferty looks at Welsh cultural stereotypes of the past and those markers that might define a modern Welsh identity. All well and good, except that the interval talk, Wales - A Case Of Mistaken Identity (8.10pm), has Welsh writers Patrick Hannan, Menna Elfyn and Owen Sheers on the same subject. While for Rafferty the Male Voice Choir deserves to be saved from the scrap heap, these three say it should go the same way as miners' lamps and leeks.

The residents of York have barely put their wellies away this winter, and houses and offices along the banks of the River Ouse suffered costly flooding. As Material World (Radio 4, 4.30pm) discovers, the floods gave one York institution the opportunity to get up-to-date with its conservation techniques. When businesses discovered valuable documents had become soggy mush, they turned to Borthwick Institute Of Historical Research. Conservationists there more used to dealing with medieval manuscripts rescued many contemporary documents.

webTitle: What to read in the loo

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Remember sociology? Fashionable in the 1970s, it was eventually consumed by the monster that is media studies. Back then it was all-pervasive, annexing all other disciplines by means of the prefix "socio".
fields.body:
Remember sociology? Fashionable in the 1970s, it was eventually consumed by the monster that is media studies. Back then it was all-pervasive, annexing all other disciplines by means of the prefix "socio". Thus socio-economics, socio-history, even socio-PE. My flirtation with it came in the form of socio-linguistics, which taught me that only middle-class people have reading matter in their toilets.

Well, put me down for the bourgeoisie, since I like nothing more than to linger over some challenging prose on the crapper. The combination of intellectual intake and bodily discharge is heady indeed. But what to read? Fact or fiction? Poetry or prose? National Enquirer or New Statesman? A newspaper (eg, the Bog Standard) seems an obvious choice since it can, in an emergency, revert to its true role, but actually it's more refreshing to wipe your arse with a page newly torn from a novel by AA Gill.

After extensive research, I have finally settled on the publication that, I believe, should lie by every toilet. Unlike the other candidates, this book does not shy away from the subject of defecation. It is by Dr Ken Heaton and is called Understanding Your Bowels.

This admirable pamphlet engenders in me a delicious tension. On the one hand, I admire Dr Ken's sensible prose and am finding out more about what I am doing; on the other, I am sniggering at all the toilet jokes. The Bristol Stool Form scale - a sort of Richter scale for turds - is useful, but I am also titillated like a schoolboy. The ideal stools, we learn, are types three and four: four is "like a sausage or snake, soft and smooth", and three "like a sausage with cracks in the surface". Beware type seven (watery) or, worse, type one (separate hard lumps, like nuts).

If all this disgusts you, I suggest you pay attention to Dr Ken. Understanding your bowels is a good thing, and when I come to your house, I want to see Dr Ken's book by the loo. Ah, "loo" - now there's a word for the lost sociologist.

webTitle: Portrait of surrealist painter Conroy Maddox

fields.headline: Me, Dali and the deep-sea diving suit
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones on the life and strange times of Conroy Maddox - the world's oldest practising surrealist painter
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones on the life and strange times of Conroy Maddox - the world's oldest practising surrealist painter.
fields.body:
The British surrealists used to meet at the Three Horseshoes pub, recalls Conroy Maddox, next to the Dominion Theatre in London's Tottenham Court Road, every Wednesday at 6pm, through the late 1930s and into the second world war. A more refined cultural outfit, Poetry London, also met at the same time, at the same place. Insults flew threw the air: "We always hated each other." Rowdier still were the monthly dinners at the Barcelona restaurant: at the end of every meal, complete chaos broke out. The surrealists were thrown out every time, but always allowed back because they brought along celebrities such as Dylan Thomas.

Conroy Maddox is dapper and a bit elfin, with a dark moustache that belies his 88 years. The world's oldest practising surrealist painter has never retired - how can a surrealist retire? He still dreams, and paints. He takes me into his studio, full of canvases from different periods in his career, ready to be taken to the gallery for his latest exhibition. The canvas he's finishing on the easel looks just like the ones he was painting in the first half of the 20th century: empty colonnades, figures isolated in vast landscapes, living statues - a lexicon of surrealism.

Relics of the surrealist movement fill his two-storey flat, from Christ on the cross in a bottle - one of his - to works by Max Ernst and the Belgian poet, musician and artist ELT Mesens. It's a sublime Freudian chaos. Every picture tells a story: he explains that one of his paintings, entitled Passionate Attitudes at Saltp trière, propped up on the landing, refers to the experimental treatment of hysterics by the late 19th century psychiatrist Charcot. The surrealists, he explains, got their hands on the records of Charcot's dealings with his patients - "he'd slept with them" - and explained hysteria not as an illness but as a poetic condition.

Outside, it's rainy north London in 2001. In here it's Paris 60, 70, 80 years ago. Dreams suspend time. The famous arcades of Paris which inspired Walter Benjamin's Arcades Project and Louis Aragon's rambling reverie Paris Peasant had disappeared almost entirely by the time Conroy Maddox first visited Paris in 1937. But in 1940, he depicted them in his most famous work, Passage de l'Opéra, a classic of surrealist painting owned by the Tate, which takes its title from one of the most celebrated Paris arcades.

It takes a long view down the arcade, which recedes in an uncanny geometrical perspective under its transparent roof. Although there is a bright blue sky, the neatly-suited figures walking through it are somnambulant. An archway to the right is a gaping tomb-like recess, and in the foreground a white stone lion clutches a blanket.

You can't explain an image like this, he says, and you shouldn't. "A surrealist does not know what he is doing. Dali didn't know what he was doing. I don't know what I'm doing. Something happens and it develops, but you don't analyse it. By doing that you destroy a surrealist image."

There's a bit of free association: He points to one of his recent collages hanging in the lounge. "For example, you see a picture of a pair of scissors and cut it out and immediately it becomes a pair of eyes. There was a philosophy behind it, you see. Surrealism is a kind of exploration and discovery; it draws on dreams and obsessions and fears and all these things. What do you prefer, the night or the day?"

His painting is partly a vision of Paris as the surrealist city, capital of the unconscious. When Maddox went there in the 1930s, it was a city of freedoms beyond anything you were likely to encounter in dowdy Britain. He remembers getting off the train and trying to walk to the premises of the publisher he'd agreed to meet, and on the way getting into a sword fight with rolled-up umbrellas.

His opponent turned out to be Isadora Duncan's brother who took him to a toga party. He finally got to the publishers where he bumped into the German surrealist Hans Bellmer, "who was really quite odd". Bellmer was there to pick up his book, La Poupée, still today deeply disturbing in its sexual violence.

To understand why Paris meant so much to Conroy Maddox, you have to begin in Birmingham. Britain in the 1930s was, after Hitler's Germany, the least sympathetic country in the world to modern art. The director of the Tate Gallery despised Picasso, and Peggy Guggenheim was thwarted in her attempts to create a gallery of modern art here. Yet surrealism did put down roots in Britain. Talking to Maddox you begin to see why. Growing up in Birmingham, Maddox read about surrealism in the city library and connected it to British life. Indeed, the person who made him a surrealist was Queen Victoria.

"At the same time that I was reading about surrealism in the Birmingham library, I came across a book of the letters of Queen Victoria. She's writing to a woman friend, talking about things generally, and she suddenly writes, 'I'm wondering what to give dear Willy,' who of course was the Kaiser, and she's wondering what to give him for his birthday. To the same person she writes, a few pages on, 'I had a marvellous idea, I'm going to give dear Willy Mount Kilimanjaro. Isn't it a marvellous gesture?' That triggered off an idea - you thought of the Kaiser, who had one arm shorter than the other, and Queen Victoria on a horse, and I did my first surrealist painting on that subject."

He wasn't alone in seeing a natural fit between surrealism, which sought to expose the irrational underpinnings of modern life, and Britain's flamboyant peculiarities. While Maddox and his friends Robert and John Melville set up a surrealist group in Birmingham, the movement was creating a sensation in London. Surrealism was chic in the 1930s, from Cecil Beaton's photography for Vogue to the surrealist home of Dali's patron Edward James, with its lip sofas and lobster telephones, to the leading artists who came out as surrealists - Eileen Agar, Roland Penrose, Paul Nash and Henry Moore.

The leading critic of the day, Herbert Read, argued that surrealism was a natural aesthetic for the British because it was essentially a form of romanticism. webTitle: How fragile virus can wreak havoc

fields.headline: How fragile virus can wreak havoc
fields.standfirst:
Disease spread only occurs in moist conditions

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The virus which causes foot and mouth disease is a paradox. It is tough enough to survive for six months in the frozen soil of a Russian winter - yet so fragile that the mild acidity of a glass of Coca Cola would destroy it instantly.
fields.body:
The virus which causes foot and mouth disease is a paradox. It is tough enough to survive for six months in the frozen soil of a Russian winter - yet so fragile that the mild acidity of a glass of Coca Cola would destroy it instantly.

It is wreaking havoc on British farming, sport and even politics. But it is so simple, with only 11 genes, that many scientists would dispute whether it counts as a life form at all.

The virus consists of a nothing more than a piece of RNA, a substance related to DNA, wrapped in a coat of protein. Without a host, it is harmless and helpless - it cannot reproduce.

It drifts into its animal host through their mouth or nostrils when the animal breathes in, and immediately sets about breaking into the cells of the throat. The virus comes equipped with a way of latching on to a group of molecules on the surface of animal cells called integrins.

They are there to help cells send messages to each other but once in a while the cell will bring an integrin back inside. This lets the virus sneak into the cell along with the integrin.

Once inside the cell, the virus takes over. Unlike most viruses, it does not barge its way in among the host's genes. It bypasses them, commandeering the machinery inside the cell that manufactures proteins and ordering it to make fresh virus particles instead.

The virus spreads from the throat to the lymph glands, the bloodstream and the skin, multiplying all the time as hijacked cells are turned into virus factories. Viruses can leave the host by many means, including from infected meat or milk.

The most likely route of foot and mouth infection, as with the common cold to which it is related, is by proximity of healthy and infected animals. But what makes foot and mouth particularly dangerous is the way it can become airborne.

Alex Donaldson, head of the Institute for Animal Health's laboratory at Pirbright, said that by the time the virus entered the host's bloodstream the animal's breath would be extremely infectious, particularly if the animal was a pig.

Dr Donaldson said it was the sheer number of virus particles, rather than any special aerodynamic properties, which enabled it to become airborne. The airborne spread of foot and mouth only happens when conditions are just right. The key is humidity: too little moisture, and it won't happen. That is why the phenomenon is largely confined to northern Europe.

When it does happen, the effects can be devastating - in 1967 foot and mouth floated 37 miles from Oswestry across the Cheshire plain, infecting hundreds of farms.

The foot and mouth virus disintegrates easily. It likes a neutral environment, neither acid nor alkali, and does not flourish in heat.

Outside the host, in non-acid soil, the virus can stay intact for a week in the British summer. In our winter, that can be lengthened to a month.

Dr Donaldson said foot and mouth was very unlikely to be spread by ramblers, riders or countryfolk in general.

"The only exception would be carriers who have intimate contact with animals, like people handling livestock, especially if they restrain them by catching them by the nose. Then they can get the virus under their fingernails."

Dr Donaldson said a car might conceivably pick up virus particles - but that did not mean that it would spread the disease.

webTitle: Arts: Tim Ashley on Czech music

fields.headline: The sound of freedom
fields.standfirst: From the Prague Spring to the velvet revolution, Czech music has been first to the barricades. That's why we're called Bohemians, conductor Jiri Belohlavek tells  Tim Ashley
fields.trailText: From the Prague Spring to the velvet revolution, Czech music has been first to the barricades. That's why we're called Bohemians, conductor Jiri Belohlavek tells Tim Ashley.
fields.body:
I am in Prague, trying to solve a mystery. Unlike many of the visitors who weave their way through these streets, I am not here to marvel at the city's architecture, nor am I following the Kafka trail. Instead, I am in search of music, trying to understand why Czech music gets under the skin of so many people, including mine. It hits you with a force that can only be described as instinctual - and once it grabs you, you're hooked, and unable to shake off its influence.

Prague itself supplies some of the answers to this conundrum. It is a place through which music sweeps inescapably. The city seems incapable of functioning without melody. Its clock towers mark the passing of time with tunes, not chimes. Record shops pipe operatic arias into the street. At night the squares reverberate to the sound of jazz from myriad clubs and cafes.

Standing on the banks of the river Vltava, you can't help but hear Smetana's orchestral depiction from Ma Vlast in your head, and be struck by the fact that his music uncannily progresses at the exact speed of the river's flow. In the souvenir shops, along with the usual tat, CDs are for sale as images of national pride. For a few crowns, you can pick up the major works of the composers who put Czech music on the map and made it great - Smetana, Dvorak, Suk, Janacek and Martinu.

This month, London's Barbican opens its Bohemian Spring season, a massive celebration that explores works, familiar and un familiar, by all five composers. The principal participants are the London Symphony Orchestra and the National Youth Orchestra. Conducting duties, meanwhile, are shared between Colin Davis and Jiri Belohlavek - a familiar figure to British audiences thanks to his work with the BBC Symphony and at Glyndebourne, where last year he conducted a revival of Janacek's Jenufa, considered by many to be definitive.

It is Belohlavek whom I have come here to meet, at the rehearsal rooms of the Prague Philharmonia, the chamber ensemble he founded in 1993. The orchestra is housed in a Baroque building behind the National Theatre, where Belohlavek is also music director.

Arriving early, I crash through the Philharmonia's front door, nearly colliding with a young oboist practising in the hallway. The oboist ushers me into an elaborately decorated Jugendstil room, where I sit surrounded by musicians marking up scores, packing and unpacking instruments, snatching cups of coffee. Occasionally doors open to reveal glittering salons beyond.

A rehearsal of Jean Françaix's Divertissement is in progress somewhere, its pungent, French harmonies flooding the building. Belohlavek presides over this rigorous yet enthusiastic world like a benevolent deity. He talks about Czech music, in a lilting mixture of English and German, with warm-hearted eloquence.

Why, I ask, is its impact so visceral? "It's difficult to put into words," he says. "It's music that's frank, open. Bohemian music is always very natural. You feel it at the bottom of your belly." He clutches his stomach and laughs. "The composers are giving themselves from their full hearts. You can't always analyse it. It's not just the composer's skill. The spirit, rhythm and melody is strongly connected to the simple song of the people."

The Czechs have always sung, even when they have been, almost literally, robbed of speech. Czech music came into being as a revolt against the suppression of language. The Austro-Hungarian Empire imposed German on its subjects. Czech was unofficial and proscribed. "Music was one of the very few areas where the Czech element could express itself freely," says Belohlavek. "The whole population was always making music for its daily use."

After the abortive revolutions of 1848, Hapsburg rule slowly crumbled and the linguistic strictures were gradually lifted. Perhaps the most astonishing fact in the history of Czech music is that Smetana, its effective founder, was a German speaker and had to learn the language from scratch in order to write his operas when the government finally permitted a Czech theatre in Prague in 1861. It became the National Theatre in 1881, and opened with a performance of Smetana's Libuse, a great opera which, like too much of his output, is shamefully neglected outside the Czech Republic.

Unlike German musical nationalism, which was founded on the idea of the unification of disparate political states, Czech music has always been about freedom of speech and autonomous expression. Janacek's music explosively enacts the conflict between oppression and liberty in acutely personal, psychological terms through his operatic experiments with naturalistic speech patterns.

His reversion to medieval language in the Glagolitic Mass can be seen as an extension of the same political development. The ricocheting, brass-rich ebullience of his Sinfonietta was a direct response to the founding of Czechoslovakia in 1919. Freedom proved brief. In 1938, the Nazis arrived and Czech music once again demanded autonomy as the exiled Bohuslav Martinu produced his searing Concerto for Double String Orchestra in violent protest at the invasion.

For many, however, it is Dvorak who is synonymous with Czech music. He made the world sit up and listen. In the late 19th century his work was deemed the embodiment of a "national" (as opposed to a "nationalistic") style, whence his famous invitation to the US, made in the hope that he would provide American music with a suitable model. Belohlavek is conducting Dvorak's Stabat Mater as the opening work of the Barbican season, the programme for which includes a number of spritual or religious works, including the British premiere of Petr Eben's Prague Te Deum, written after the velvet revolution of 1989.

Under the communist regime, religious music was associated with freedom of speech. "It was always a fight to get permission to perform a religious piece," says Belohlavek, "and you had to be sure that there would be a good balance with other types of music. On the other hand, we never came to the situation where we couldn't perform the Stabat Mater. Every couple of years, you could put one of the main religious works on. They were always packed. People were waiting for them."

Belohlavek knows all about the difficult relationship between Czech music and politics. The son of a lawyer, he was born in 1946 and trained at the Prague Conservatoire. "I was lucky that in the time of the Prague Spring in 1968, Sergiu Celibidache was working here, and he put on some masterclasses for conducting students," he says. Celibidache, considered by some to be one of the greatest 20th-century conductors, was based in Sweden at the time. "He invited me to visit him in Stockholm. That was my great chance. I lived in Sweden for two years to assist him and to study."

After that came years of apprenticeship with the Czech Philharmonic, of which Belohlavek eventually became principal conductor from 1990 to 1992. He founded the Prague Philharmonia the following year in bizarre circumstances. Whereas in Britain we have military bands, the Czech Ministry of Defence had an entire orchestra at its disposal - namely the Prague Symphony. Its playing was, as Belohlavek put it, "dubious", and he was asked to establish a new ensemble to replace it. "I said no - I'd been in the army for two years."

But when the ministry pointed out that they had the funding to train 40 young musicians, Belohlavek changed his mind - on condition that he be allowed to form a chamber orchestra. "People came from all over the country to audition. We had the cream of young musicians. We started work. Then there was a change in the Ministry of Defence. They cancelled everything. We were on the streets." Mercifully, another change in the law allowed him to continue to run the orchestra as a non-profit-making organisation, and he has turned it into a force to be reckoned with.

When I leave him, I go round the corner to the National Theatre for a performance of Smetana's The Bartered Bride. As the overture begins, there is that familiar lurch "at the bottom of my belly", as Belohlavek would describe it, that I always get when I hear the piece. For many, this is the work with which the history of Czech music begins and that exemplifies its volatile exuberance, the immediacy of its impact and, above all, the heady sense of liberty that informs it. Is it any wonder that the word "Bohemian" is synonymous with freedom?

The Czech list: Five essential Bohemian works

Smetana: Ma Vlast

Ma Vlast (My Country) is a cycle of six thematically interrelated tone poems that depict the Bohemian landscape and explore Czech legend and mythology. The whole ranks among the most staggering achievements in the symphonic repertoire, though complete performances in the UK are still rare. (Barbican, March 29)

Dvorak: Stabat Mater

A fervent Catholic, Dvorak began his Stabat Mater after the death of his daughter. Though written on a massive scale, this is a poignant, intimate work that strives for spiritual solace rather than the expression of intense grief. The Barbican's line-up of soloists is drawn from the outstanding ensemble of Prague's National Theatre. (Sunday)

Janacek: The Fiddler's Child

A hymn to the transforming power of music, this depicts an impoverished boy, haunted by the ghost of his dead musician father, whose playing releases him from the anguish of earthly existence. It explores the elation and sorrow of the human condition in music of intense compassion and vividness. (March 7 and 8)

Martinu: Concerto for Double String Orchestra

Written as the Nazis marched into the Sudetenland in 1938, the Concerto for Double String Orchestra is perhaps the most intensely political of Martinu's works, as well as his most thrilling. It is a passionate, virtuoso duel for two string orchestras locked in seemingly irreconcilable conflict. (March 21)

Suk: Asrael

The least overtly political of Czech composers, Suk is temperamentally and stylistically close to Mahler. Taking its title from the Islamic conveyor of souls to the afterlife, Asrael was written after the deaths of Suk's wife Otilie and his father-in-law, Dvorak. It's strong stuff - essential listening, if your nerves can take it. (April 10)

 Bohemian Spring is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891) from Sunday until April 22.

The ricocheting, brass-rich ebullience of his Sinfonietta was a direct response to the founding of Czechoslovakia in 1919. Freedom proved brief. In 1938, the Nazis arrived and Czech music once again demanded autonomy as the exiled Bohuslav Martinu produced his searing Concerto for Double String Orchestra in violent protest at the invasion. For many, however, it is Dvorak who is synonymous with Czech music. He made the world sit up and listen. In the late 19th century his work was deemed the embodiment of a "national" (as opposed to a "nationalistic") style, whence his famous invitation to the US, made in the hope that he would provide American music with a suitable model. Belohlavek is conducting Dvorak's Stabat Mater as the opening work of the Barbican season, the programme for which includes a number of spritual or religious works, including the British premiere of Petr Eben's Prague Te Deum, written after the velvet revolution of 1989. Under the communist regime, religious music was associated with freedom of speech. "It was always a fight to get permission to perform a religious piece," says Belohlavek, "and you had to be sure that there would be a good balance with other types of music. On the other hand, we never came to the situation where we couldn't perform the Stabat Mater. Every couple of years, you could put one of the main religious works on. They were always packed. People were waiting for them." Belohlavek knows all about the difficult relationship between Czech music and politics. The son of a lawyer, he was born in 1946 and trained at the Prague Conservatoire. "I was lucky that in the time of the Prague Spring in 1968, Sergiu Celibidache was working here, and he put on some masterclasses for conducting students," he says. Celibidache, considered by some to be one of the greatest 20th-century conductors, was based in Sweden at the time. "He invited me to visit him in Stockholm. That was my great chance. I lived in Sweden for two years to assist him and to study." After that came years of apprenticeship with the Czech Philharmonic, of which Belohlavek eventually became principal conductor from 1990 to 1992. He founded the Prague Philharmonia the following year in bizarre circumstances. Whereas in Britain we have military bands, the Czech Ministry of Defence had an entire orchestra at its disposal - namely the Prague Symphony. Its playing was, as Belohlavek put it, "dubious", and he was asked to establish a new ensemble to replace it. "I said no - I'd been in the army for two years." But when the ministry pointed out that they had the funding to train 40 young musicians, Belohlavek changed his mind - on condition that he be allowed to form a chamber orchestra. "People came from all over the country to audition. We had the cream of young musicians. We started work. Then there was a change in the Ministry of Defence. They cancelled everything. We were on the streets." Mercifully, another change in the law allowed him to continue to run the orchestra as a non-profit-making organisation, and he has turned it into a force to be reckoned with. When I leave him, I go round the corner to the National Theatre for a performance of Smetana's The Bartered Bride. As the overture begins, there is that familiar lurch "at the bottom of my belly", as Belohlavek would describe it, that I always get when I hear the piece. For many, this is the work with which the history of Czech music begins and that exemplifies its volatile exuberance, the immediacy of its impact and, above all, the heady sense of liberty that informs it. Is it any wonder that the word "Bohemian" is synonymous with freedom? The Czech list: Five essential Bohemian works Smetana: Ma Vlast Ma Vlast (My Country) is a cycle of six thematically interrelated tone poems that depict the Bohemian landscape and explore Czech legend and mythology. The whole ranks among the most staggering achievements in the symphonic repertoire, though complete performances in the UK are still rare. (Barbican, March 29) Dvorak: Stabat Mater A fervent Catholic, Dvorak began his Stabat Mater after the death of his daughter. Though written on a massive scale, this is a poignant, intimate work that strives for spiritual solace rather than the expression of intense grief. The Barbican's line-up of soloists is drawn from the outstanding ensemble of Prague's National Theatre. (Sunday) Janacek: The Fiddler's Child A hymn to the transforming power of music, this depicts an impoverished boy, haunted by the ghost of his dead musician father, whose playing releases him from the anguish of earthly existence. It explores the elation and sorrow of the human condition in music of intense compassion and vividness. (March 7 and 8) Martinu: Concerto for Double String Orchestra Written as the Nazis marched into the Sudetenland in 1938, the Concerto for Double String Orchestra is perhaps the most intensely political of Martinu's works, as well as his most thrilling. It is a passionate, virtuoso duel for two string orchestras locked in seemingly irreconcilable conflict. (March 21) Suk: Asrael The least overtly political of Czech composers, Suk is temperamentally and stylistically close to Mahler. Taking its title from the Islamic conveyor of souls to the afterlife, Asrael was written after the deaths of Suk's wife Otilie and his father-in-law, Dvorak. It's strong stuff - essential listening, if your nerves can take it. (April 10)  Bohemian Spring is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891) from Sunday until April 22.

webTitle: Dome auction cut back after claims of asset-stripping

fields.headline: Dome auction cut back after claims of asset-stripping
fields.standfirst:
Technology equipment is withdrawn

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Thousands of items of technology equipment have been withdrawn from the auction of the Millennium Dome's contents, amid accusations that the sale was an exercise in asset-stripping which could jeopardise the future of the attraction.
fields.body:
Thousands of items of technology equipment have been withdrawn from the auction of the Millennium Dome's contents, amid accusations that the sale was an exercise in asset-stripping which could jeopardise the future of the attraction.

The 1,600 withdrawn lots, comprising approximately 2,050 items, include 442 Pentium computers and 198 plasma screens, some unused, which have been at the centre of claims that the auction is a "fire sale" that might sabotage the plans of those bidding for the dome while providing a poor return for the taxpayer.

Also withdrawn from the auction, which continues until tomorrow, are hundreds of items of lighting equipment, ticket kiosks from the plaza in front of the dome, and 238 metal and wood benches.

In a statement published yesterday on the website of auctioneers Henry Butcher, the New Millennium Experience Company, which organised the year-long exhibition, said it had "determined that there will be no sale of assets that could prejudice future use of the dome as a visitor attraction, sporting venue or for commercial or business use," specifically taking into account "items [that dome bidder] Legacy plc had indicated they would need if they proceeded with their bid for the dome".

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary and a longtime critic of the dome, said the move was evidence of a "shambolic" approach to the sell-off. "If they had seriously thought about it beforehand these items would never have appeared in the sale catalogue," he said.

"I am pleased that they are responding to criticism - it is the right thing to do - but it is more evidence that the sale has not been thought through."

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the dome's former chief executive, has accused the government of sabotaging his plans to continue operating the site as a visitor attraction.

But Gez Sagar, head of media at NMEC, insisted the withdrawals were not a response to criticisms. He said the items had been listed in the catalogue "effectively on standby" in case Legacy, which had expressed an interest in them, pulled out of the bidding. "We had to be prepared for the possibility that Legacy would announce they were withdrawing altogether, in which case all these items would have been under the hammer."

Mr Sagar said that Mr Gerbeau had now "written to us stating that he is entirely happy with the timetable".

"He told us that the two parts which would undermine his interest if they were sold were the Home Planet Zone and the Timekeepers Zone. They are intact and not on sale."

fields.headline: Doggone
fields.standfirst: Is 'bitch' really just another word for 'woman', as a TV watchdog said this week?  Joan Smith  thinks not
fields.trailText: Is 'bitch' really just another word for 'woman', as a TV watchdog said this week? Joan Smith thinks not.
fields.body:
Hot news from the Broadcasting Standards Commission: the word "bitch" is no longer offensive. On the contrary, it is apparently OK to call the Queen a bitch, according to a ruling about the use of the word in the satirical BBC programme Have I Got News For You. The BSC's reasoning - wait for it, everybody - is that when employed by a black comic, the word simply means "woman" and is not insulting.

What about a white comic? Or a gay Jewish comedian? Would that still be a bit iffy? The BSC needs to clarify its categories here. I also wonder whether, when coming to this frankly bizarre decision, it sought the opinions of a cross-section of British women. I mean, if BSC members felt like approaching a few of us, giving a high five and exclaiming "Yo, bitch", they might reach a different conclusion. Just because "bitch" has become ubiquitous in some quarters doesn't mean we must meekly accept it.

Its connotations are to do with our supposed animal nature - "A woman is but an animal, and an animal not of the highest order," according to Edmund Burke - and insatiable sexual appetite. In 1811, the Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue described it as "the most offensive appellation that can be given to an English woman, even more provoking than that of whore". Indeed the word was so derogatory, according to Hugh Rawson in A Dictionary of Invective, that it lost its original status as unisex insult - something that "happens fairly often to words with bad meanings".

We all know, however, that words change their meaning over time and the BSC's ruling reflects an increasingly common argument: "bitch" has lost its unpleasant associations and become interchangeable with other words that denote female members of the human race. Like slut, slag and whore, presumably.

When the American feminist Elizabeth Wurtzel wrote a book called Bitch, she was working in the feminist (and gay) tradition of reappropriating insults, as well as making an attempt to celebrate "bad" behaviour. But the book's publication was not followed by hordes of women suddenly describing themselves, ironically or otherwise, as bitches.

Most of my friends hesitate to use the word even about women they dislike, understanding that its nastiness is generic rather than specific. Where it has come to be used in everyday discourse is West Coast gangsta rap and the wider culture it influences, including the white rapper Eminem. And I don't think I am being unfair when I suggest that the defining characteristics of that culture do not include an equal opportunities, positive discrimination mind-set towards women.

"We like women but we don't like bitches," a member of the seminal rap outfit Niggaz With Attitude once announced on British television, neatly making the point that these identities - good girl, bad girl, bitch and ho - are once again being imposed from outside. Nor is it a defence that female rappers working alongside artists like Dr Dre and Eminem have begun to apply the terminology to themselves; in a male-dominated, misogynist culture, some women always end up, consciously or not, colluding with their own oppression.

What people are saying, when they inform us that "bitch" is now an acceptable synonym for "woman", is that we still don't have a right to self-definition. Would the BSC tell gay men they shouldn't be offended if a heterosexual man calls them faggots? Perhaps it would, given that we keep being informed we don't have a right to challenge the vituperative language of Eminem. He's talented, you see, so that makes it OK.

Perhaps, in a world of vacuous, overinflated celebrities, people are so confounded by even a modicum of talent that they don't understand that someone can be gifted and offensive. Bit of a strain on the brain, that one. But what is clear about the word "bitch" is that the people who have brought it into the mainstream have a lot of unpleasant, reactionary ideas about women and sexuality.

I would recommend members of the BSC to look at their ruling in the light of an observation from the American linguist Alleen Pace Nilsen. People, she has written, "are hesitant to call a female dog a bitch. Most of us feel that we would be insulting the dog." Quite. I don't think I will be writing for the Guardian Bitch Page in the foreseeable future.

fields.headline: Six key states push world to 9bn people
fields.standfirst:
 By 2050, the UN says, 90% will live in a developing country
 In Europe, the proportion of children could fall to 14%

Special report: global population
fields.trailText: Rapid population growth and relatively high fertility levels in the world's 48 least developed countries, and rising life expectancy everywhere, will help push the world's population from 6.1bn to about 9.3bn by 2050, according to a UN report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Rapid population growth and relatively high fertility levels in the world's 48 least developed countries, and rising life expectancy everywhere, will help push the world's population from 6.1bn to about 9.3bn by 2050, according to a UN report published yesterday.

It estimates that the world's population is growing by 1.2% annually, or 77m people, and six countries account for half the increase: India, China, Pakistan, Nigeria, Bangladesh and Indonesia.

The population division of the UN department of economic and social affairs points to growing imbalance between the developed and developing world, the population growth concentrated overwhelmingly in those countries least able to support it. The 48 least developed countries are expected to nearly triple their population, from 658m to 1.8bn.

These increases, if realised, are certain to intensify pressure on food and water resources in many parts of the developing world, and they present an enormous challenge to international aid, poverty reduction and education programmes. They are also expected to exacerbate problems such as global warming and environmental degradation.

More international migration will be another consequence, the report says,

In the EU, increased immigration will be essential if workforce levels are to be sustained as the indigenous population ages, it argues.

"The population of the less developed regions is projected to rise steadily from 4.9bn in 2000 to 8.2bn in 2050," it says.

Even this startling projection is based on the assumption that fertility will continue to decline. If that failed to happen, the population of less developed regions would reach an enormous 11.9bn.

Looked at another way, the UN figures suggest that within 50 years nine out of every 10 people will be living in a developing country. One in every six will be living in India where the current population of just over 1bn is projected to rise by 600m.

By contrast, population levels in Europe and Japan are projected to decline sharply because fertility is falling below the "replacement level" - that is to say, below an average of 2.1 children a woman.

By mid-century the populations of Germany and Japan will have fallen on current trends by 14%, that of Italy by 25% and that of Russia and Ukraine by between 28% and 40%.

But this trend will be mitigated to some degree by more immigration, the report says, amounting to a net average annual gain in developed countries of about 2m.

"Because of low fertility, this migration has a significant impact ... Without migration, the population of more developed regions as a whole would start declining in 2003 rather than in 2025."

Britain, for example, has a fertility level of only 1.6 but its total population, currently 59m, is likely to be about the same in 2050, owing to immigration.

The United States is likely to remain a prime target for migrants, giving it an annual influx of about 1m people and a projected population by 2050 of about 400m; it has 280m now.

The report suggests that Africa, one of the areas of biggest population growth, will have three times as many people as Europe by 2050 - in all, 2bn Africans against 800m now. That compares starkly with the situation in 1950, when Europe accounted for almost a quarter of the world's population and Africa only 8%.

The population explosion in Africa, Asia and Latin America would be even more dramatic but for the impact of the HIV/Aids epidemic, the report says. But despite an expected 300m deaths in 50 years, the continent's population will still rise.

"For the nine most HIV affected countries in Africa, the population is projected to increase from 115m in 2000 to 196m in 2050. Even in Botswana, where HIV prevalence is 36%, or in Swaziland and Zimbabwe, where it is above 25%, the numbers are projected to increase significantly; by 37% in Botswana, 148% in Swaziland and 86% in Zimbabwe.

"Only in South Africa, whose fertility is lower than that of Botswana or Zimbabwe, does the growth rate of the population become negative during 2010-2025, being positive thereafter."

Although Aids has reduced life expectancy by three years in the 45 countries worst hit, the average human life span is still increasing there and elsewhere.

Futhermore, the life expectancy gap between rich and poor countries appears to be closing. In less developed regions, life expectancy will increasby 12 years, to 75, in the next 50 years; in developed regions, it will rise by seven years, from the current 75 years to 82. In Britain, life expectancy is currently 78 years, rising to 83 by 2050.

The prospect for the industrial world is one of elderly populations and shrinking workforces ever more dependent on migrant labour.

"The older population of the more developed regions has already surpassed the child population and by 2050, there will be two older persons for every child."

One-fifth of all Europeans were aged 60 or more in 1998. By 2050 they may represent more than one-third of all adults, with children making up only 14% of the population.

fields.headline: Russian colonel on trial for killing Chechen woman
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: A Russian colonel went on trial yesterday for kidnapping and murdering an 18-year-old Chechen woman, the first member of the Russian forces prosecuted for human rights abuse since the war in Chechnya began.
fields.body:
A Russian colonel went on trial yesterday for kidnapping and murdering an 18-year-old Chechen woman, the first member of the Russian forces prosecuted for human rights abuse since the war in Chechnya began.

Colonel Yury Budanov, commander of the 160th Tank Regiment, admitted killing Kheda Kungaeva, from Tangi Chu, but denied that it was murder.

Relatives of the dead girl, squeezed in beside army officers in the courtroom in the southern town of Rostov-on-Don, had little confidence that justice would be done.

Outside, a handful of Col Budanov's supporters protested against his trial, saying he was being sacrificed because the army wanted to be seen willing to prosecute officers.

While cautiously welcoming the trial, human rights groups remain critical of widespread Russian reluctance to investigate or prosecute troops for dozens of other alleged atrocities against civilians.

According to an investigation by Human Rights Watch, Kungaeva died at the end of a a drunken night last March when the colonel celebrated his daughter's birthday with fellow soldiers at Tangi Chu.

Sometime after midnight he and three others took an armoured personnel carrier, drove into the Kungaev family's front garden, walked into the house, and took Kheda away.

About two hours later, it is alleged, Col Budanov strangled her. She was buried, but her body was dug up and returned to her family two days later.

Col Budanov is alleged to have said that he detained Kungaeva because he thought she was a sniper who had killed some of his comrades. He claims that he lost his temper and strangled her during an interrogation. A medical examination of her body suggested that she had been raped, the press reported.

After the murder senior officers sought to make an example of Col Budanov and repeatedly and publicly accused him of rape and murder.

The Kungaeva family are angry that the rape charges were dropped.

The army portrayed Col Budanov's behaviour as "an exceptional example of wanton criminality by a serviceman," a Human Rights Watch spokesman said, but abduction rape and murder represented a pattern of crimes perpetrated by federal forces in Chechnya.

"If there is only this one trial ... then it would be not a step forward but just a show trial."

As the trial opened, reports of other alleged abuses by the Russian military continued to surface from Chechnya.

The Council of Europe commissioner for human rights, Alvaro Gil-Robles, who arrived in Chechnya yesterday, said he would try to investigate the claim by the journalist Anna Politkovskaya that Chechen villagers were being persecuted by Russian forces.

The bodies of 20 more Chechens were found in a mass grave yesterday in the deserted and ruined holiday village near the main Russian garrison at Khankala, outside the capital, Grozny. Thirty-six corpses have been unearthed since the weekend.

In a rare interview published yesterday, the Chechen independence leader Aslan Maskhadov called on the Russians to begin talks.

"Wars have to end at some point and this can only be done by talks," he said. Russian officials refuse to talk to the rebel leaders.

He claims that he lost his temper and strangled her during an interrogation. A medical examination of her body suggested that she had been raped, the press reported. After the murder senior officers sought to make an example of Col Budanov and repeatedly and publicly accused him of rape and murder. The Kungaeva family are angry that the rape charges were dropped. The army portrayed Col Budanov's behaviour as "an exceptional example of wanton criminality by a serviceman," a Human Rights Watch spokesman said, but abduction rape and murder represented a pattern of crimes perpetrated by federal forces in Chechnya. "If there is only this one trial ... then it would be not a step forward but just a show trial." As the trial opened, reports of other alleged abuses by the Russian military continued to surface from Chechnya. The Council of Europe commissioner for human rights, Alvaro Gil-Robles, who arrived in Chechnya yesterday, said he would try to investigate the claim by the journalist Anna Politkovskaya that Chechen villagers were being persecuted by Russian forces. The bodies of 20 more Chechens were found in a mass grave yesterday in the deserted and ruined holiday village near the main Russian garrison at Khankala, outside the capital, Grozny. Thirty-six corpses have been unearthed since the weekend. In a rare interview published yesterday, the Chechen independence leader Aslan Maskhadov called on the Russians to begin talks. "Wars have to end at some point and this can only be done by talks," he said. Russian officials refuse to talk to the rebel leaders.

webTitle: Fault grinds slowly towards next California quake

fields.headline: Fault grinds slowly towards next shock
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: On either side of the San Andreas fault, which runs almost the length of California, cities move apart at the rate of a few centimetres a year. But at the fault itself, the rocks remain jammed together for years at a time. When they finally give, say scientists at the US Geological Survey, the movement accelerates from practically nothing to 3,000mph.
fields.body:
On either side of the San Andreas fault, which runs almost the length of California, cities move apart at the rate of a few centimetres a year. But at the fault itself, the rocks remain jammed together for years at a time. When they finally give, say scientists at the US Geological Survey, the movement accelerates from practically nothing to 3,000mph.

Shocks like this over thousands of years build up a pattern of smaller faults, far below the surface rock, threatening the plains that lie west of the San Andreas.

An earthquake in January 1994 wakened Los Angeles to the fact that it was 10 miles above a new kind of hazard: a "blind thrust" fault. Great segments of rock strata had suddenly ridden one over the other, creating shockwaves but leaving no evidence on the surface that anything much had happened.

The Northridge area of the city felt the full force. There were 57 deaths.

Afterwards, research was intensified into the likelihood of what Californians have always called "the big one".

The most violent earthquake of modern times - one that sent a tsunami surging towards Japan - may have been in the region of the American north-west that encompasses Portland, Oregon, and Seattle, but that was 300 years ago. The most vivid was the 1906 San Francisco quake, in which the fault moved almost six metres (20ft) in a few seconds, but most of the damage was done by the fire that followed.

With so much business investment and the proliferation of high-rise buildings up and down the west coast since then, the potential scale of a Californian catastrophe has soared.

The state is still one of the planet's seismology laboratories, but researchers gave up the tantalising dream of earthquake prediction a decade ago. Since then, the focus has been on education and preparedness, as experts tried to calculate how violent the ground movements might be in future shocks.

The Granada Hills around Northridge has risen by 15cm since January 1994, researchers say: in effect, the earthquake was still quietly going on.

Another blind thrust fault runs almost 30 miles from downtown Los Angeles to the Coyote Hills in northern Orange county. It has yet to show what it can do.

webTitle: Horseracing: Little to cheer in champion's yard

fields.headline: Little to cheer in champion's yard
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Once you leave the M5 and branch off down the B-road to Nicholashayne you start to come across them - the disinfectant-soaked straw pads strewn across village entrances and farm gates. The sad, tell-tale signs that the West Country is gripped by fear.
fields.body:
Once you leave the M5 and branch off down the B-road to Nicholashayne you start to come across them - the disinfectant-soaked straw pads strewn across village entrances and farm gates. The sad, tell-tale signs that the West Country is gripped by fear.

At champion trainer Martin Pipe's Pond House stables in deepest Somerset there is an air of gloom and despondency as the season's holy grail, the Cheltenham Festival, seems to be slipping away over the horizon.

For the last four months every member of the stables - from the lowest of the lads to the headman himself - has been working towards this goal.

And while, at the moment, racing is only suspended for seven days, few believe the ban will not be extended to blot out the Cheltenham showpiece.

Pipe has straw pads across his driveway and disinfectant buckets in the yard; no one can enter unless they dip their feet and there are no excuses - not even the stablelass who complained to the trainer that she had a hole in her sole.

A racing yard is normally full of hustle and bustle - cheery, whistling stablelads going about their business, horseboxes driving runners to the races, owners coming to look at their horses.

Now there is none of this. True, the irrepressible Pipe is still scurrying around - he cannot overnight change the habit of a lifetime - but there is an air of resignation about him when he sits down to talk about the crisis.

"They say there is only a minimal risk of us spreading the disease by carrying on, but any risk is too great," he said. "If we brought it back here we would never get over the feeling of guilt.

"I can't honestly see Cheltenham going ahead, but for the next week at least we have to pretend that everything is normal and continue to bring the horses to concert pitch.

"For racing it might seem bad news and losing Cheltenham would be terrible. But when put into perspective it is certainly not a disaster and we will live to fight another day."

He is not expecting a Cheltenham bonanza coming in his direction this year anyway. But for a man who always plays his cards from under the table, you would not expect him to talk-up his chances.

"I don't think we will race. In in any case, I haven't got a banker this year (he usually tells you what it is as he welcomes it back into in the winner's enclosure at another meeting) although I must have made over a hundred entries.

"I have eight in the Cathcart Chase, the best of which are probably Lady Cricket and Blowing Wind. Even so, I would not be confident of winning that.

"However, I have a very nice horse called Royal Auclair, who I think will go well in the Supreme Novice Hurdle. He has just come to me from France and won very easily on his first run at Sandown."

He will be represented by Cyfor Malta in the Gold Cup, a race he has yet to win and which last year saw the tragic death of his brilliant young chaser Gloria Victis who was going very well until his fatal fall.

Cyfor Malta was off the track with leg trouble for two years before returning to be a soundly-beaten third behind See More Business at Cheltenham in January.

"He disappointed us that day, but the ground was dreadful and he has been going well recently," added Pipe.

"He cantered this morning and we will carry on with the same routine with him - three days cantering a week and two pieces of work - but if the meeting is stopped we will have to ease off on his feed and let him wind down.

"That is the trouble. We have been preparing these horses to be at their peak in 10 days time and they are all pretty wound up. It will be as much of a let down for them as it will be for us if we suddenly have to take our feet off the accelerator."

Pipe has overcome plenty of adversity in his life and he will get over this, as will his stable staff, despite the fact that they are seeing their Cheltenham bonuses disappearing in the gloom.

The wages for stablelads are not great. What makes up for it is the reflected glory of "doing" a big winner and the percentages and presents from grateful owners which go along with it. But for now they will not be able to look forward even to that.

webTitle: Panic as huge quake strikes Seattle

fields.headline: Panic as huge quake strikes Seattle
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: An earthquake measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale rocked the American city of Seattle last night, sending office workers on to the streets in panic and causing minor damage.
fields.body:
An earthquake measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale rocked the American city of Seattle last night, sending office workers on to the streets in panic and causing minor damage.

The effects were felt as far away as Salt Lake City - 700 miles from the epicentre - and there were reports of 12 injuries, three serious.

There were widespread power cuts in the Seattle area, with an estimated 17,000 customers left without power.

The earthquake which struck at 6.55pm (GMT) was centred 35 miles south west of Seattle. Office workers used fire escapes to evacuate skyscrapers in downtown Seattlle. Screams erupted at a hotel where Microsoft founder Bill Gates was addressing a conference. He was whisked away as the audience rushed to the exits.

Buildings swayed and rubble fell into the streets. Seattle-Tacoma international airport was closed after damage to the control tower.

An earthquake measuring 5.4 hit El Salvador and Nicaragua, but there were no reports of injuries.

webTitle: Threat to census as disease cases grow

fields.headline: Threat to census as disease cases grow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Eight new cases of foot and mouth disease were confirmed yesterday - the worst day yet - bringing the total number of outbreaks to 26 and drawing ever larger areas of the country into movement restrictions. Suspected cases were discovered for the first time in Northern Ireland, a potentially catastrophic development for the province's export business.
fields.body:
Eight new cases of foot and mouth disease were confirmed yesterday - the worst day yet - bringing the total number of outbreaks to 26 and drawing ever larger areas of the country into movement restrictions. Suspected cases were discovered for the first time in Northern Ireland, a potentially catastrophic development for the province's export business.

The continued spread of the virus and the problems of containing it led the government to consider postponing the population census due on April 29 - also putting the much forecast general election date of May 3 in jeopardy.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, speaking in the Commons, said the census could be postponed for the first time in peace time.

Yesterday's outbreaks and new suspected cases in Scotland and Northern Ireland brought the numbers of animals condemned to slaughter to 13,942 sheep, 2,476 cattle and 1,852 pigs.

The Welsh Office last night announced that in addition to the two new confirmed cases in Powys yesterday there were another six under investigation throughout the principality. In Northern Ireland, which ministers had hoped would remain disease-free, a flock of sheep in South Armagh, some of which had been bought at Carlisle market and had "dangerous contacts", were being slaughtered as a precaution.

The six new cases in England yesterday were at farms at Llangarron in Herefordshire, Melton Mowbray and Fenny in Leicestershire, North Fambridge in Chelmsford, Essex, and Highampton, Devon, close to an earlier confirmed case, and an abbatoir at Great Harwood, Lancashire. The Welsh cases were at Felindre and Pains Castle, both in Powys.

The Heddon-on-the-Wall outbreak among pigs in Numberland remains the main suspect as the source of the outbreaks and has led the government to order a review of whole issue of pigswill and allowing pork and other meats to be routinely fed back to pigs.

webTitle: Belgrade investigates Milosevic for gold theft

fields.headline: Belgrade investigates Milosevic for gold theft
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic began moving gold out of the country even before he lost the elections last autumn, according to allegations in the Serbian press.
fields.body:
Former Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic began moving gold out of the country even before he lost the elections last autumn, according to allegations in the Serbian press.

The Belgrade prosecutor's office ordered the police to investigate the reports yesterday: the first legal move against Mr Milosevic

Speculation that Mr Milosevic, who is under police guard in the exclusive Dedinje district of the city, could be arrested within days has been rife.

On Friday his secretive former head of the interior ministry, Rade Markovic, was arrested and accused of ordering the murder of four members of the opposition Serbian Renewal Movement in October 1999.

Up to 12 former police officers have been arrested, and others are said to have fled across the border into Republika Srpska, the Serb-run statelet in Bosnia.

Officials are trying to dampen the public excitement surrounding the possible arrest of Mr Milosevic, insisting that the investigations must strictly follow the law.

The Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunic, the constitutional lawyer who defeated Mr Milosevic in elections on 26 September, has spoken out against "revolutionary justice".

"Milosevic will not be charged until all facts have been established," the deputy prime minister, Zarko Korac, told the newspaper Blic yesterday.

Mr Korac is one of the few ministers to support the former president's extradition to the Hague.

But an anonymous official told the news agency Beta yesterday that a deadline of March 10 had been set for Mr Milosevic's arrest.

The latest reports suggest that 173kg (380lb) of gold was taken out of Yugoslavia illegally between September 21 and November 2 last year, and that money from its sale was transferred to bank accounts in Cyprus and Greece.

Yugoslavia has been under growing international pressure to arrest Mr Milosevic. But while the new authorities in Belgrade say he should be charged with any political murders and economic offences in his own country, the international war crimes tribunal insists that he should be tried in the Hague for genocide.

Carla del Ponte, the tribunal's chief prosecutor, said yesterday: "I have heard too often that public opinion in Yugoslavia is not ready to accept international justice, or that the persons indicted by the tribunal would become heroes if delivered to the Hague .

"I strongly reject these statement, which ... stand in blatant contradiction with the great many messages we keep receiving from members of the [ruling Yugoslav] DOS coalition, from government officials in Belgrade, from Montenegro, from Vojvodina, local NGO's and groups of ordinary citizens.

Ms Del Ponte was in Sweden to press the EU, of which Sweden holds the rotating presidency, to make aid to Yugoslavia conditional on full its cooperation with the tribunal.

She also suggested March 31 as a deadline for the authorities in Belgrade to prove that they are willing to do so.

Nick Wood in Pristina adds : A Serb policeman was injured when heavy fighting, including artillery, mortar and machine-gun fire, broke out yesterday along a 25-mile stretch of the provinical border between Kosovo and southern Serbia.

Earlier, Russian soldiers serving with the Nato-led peacekeeping mission in Kosovo, reported the discovery of an elderly Serb couple who had been beaten to death with an axe in their home, four miles inside the Kosovan border.

The fighting on the boundary came less than 24 hours after Nato foreign ministers decided to draw back the three-mile buffer zone in Serbia which ethnic Albanian rebels have used to launch their attacks on Yugoslav forces.

webTitle: Trucker 'shut air vent and let 58 migrants die'

fields.headline: Trucker 'shut air vent and let 58 migrants die'
fields.standfirst:
Driver showed no emotion when bodies were found, court told

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Driver showed no emotion when bodies were found, court told.
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver attempting to smuggle 60 Chinese illegal immigrants into Britain closed the air vent on the side of his truck before boarding a ferry, "sealing the fate" of 58 who were found dead at Dover, a court heard yesterday.

Perry Wacker showed no emotion when the bodies were discovered at Dover, and made no effort to check the welfare of his human cargo during the six-hour crossing as he watched videos and enjoyed a meal, Maidstone crown court was told.

The bodies of the 54 men and four women, and two men who survived, were discovered early on June 19 last year by customs officers who searched Wacker's lorry at Dover's eastern docks. All 58 were found to have suffocated.

Wacker, 32, from Rotterdam, denies 58 counts of manslaughter and four of conspiring to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants. Ying Guo, 29, a Chinese interpreter, denies a charge of conspiring to facilitate the entry of illegal immigrants. She also pleaded not guilty.

Opening the case for the crown, Victor Temple QC said Wacker helped load the Chinese into the refrigerated container on his lorry, hiding them behind a cargo of tomatoes on June 18.

The 60 illegal immigrants had paid a Snakehead criminal gang to smuggle them from China to Europe.

They gathered from two safehouses at a warehouse in Rotterdam's Waalhaven docks before climbing aboard Wacker's lorry.

"These luckless and unfortunate people were obliged to sit or squat in that airtight container with little or no room to move, diminishing amount of air and only a little amount of water," Mr Temple said.

Around 2.30pm that afternoon Wacker set off for the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, passing through Antwerp and Ghent before reaching Zeebrugge around 6pm.

Throughout the journey, the small air vent of the container was tied open with a piece of rope to prevent it swinging closed.

Before boarding the ferry, however, Wacker closed the vent, Mr Temple said.

"Wacker closed the vent and the prosecution says that in doing so, he sealed the fate of 58 of the 60 inside. The reason for closing of the vent was to prevent customs or the ferry company hearing noises of any kind from inside the container.

"During the crossing Wacker made no effort to check on the welfare of the Chinese. Instead he contented himself with a meal and watching films upstairs.

"All this by a man who knew of the appalling conditions of the container. That it was hot and there was deprivation seemed to be of no concern to him.

"The vents would remain closed until after the lorry reached customs in Dover. The vent was closed between 6pm and 6.30pm and the lorry boarded the ferry at 7.15pm. Just after 12.15am on June 19 the driver drove off the ferry."

When customs officials discovered the bodies Wacker remained impassive, the jury of nine women and three men was told.

"Wacker was standing nearby totally unmoved. He had no sympathy, no nothing. The crown say commercial gain took precedence over human life."

The court would heard that Wacker and Guo were part of a criminal conspiracy organised by the Snakehead gang.

"Both the defendants... had aligned themselves to and were playing an important part in the plan to smuggle these 60 people. Both knew that others were involved and that behind the operation was a professional crime syndicate, the Snakeheads," he said.

The Snakehead smugglers trade on the privations of life in China, encouraging people to flee for the west for as much as £20,000 each. As the money is paid in instalments the Snakeheads take care to protect their investment and minders accompany the illegal immigrants at all times, the court was told. In Rotterdam the Snakeheads' interests, and the final preparations for the transport, were represented by a Turkish gang who engaged Wacker.

Wacker was closely involved in the purchase of the lorry and trailer, and advised others in the purchase of the container.

He also paid for and collected the tomatoes that were to act as the dummy cargo, along with a friend and fellow conspirator Leo Nijveen, also a Dutch lorry driver. Wacker helped construct a frame in the rear of the container on which the tomatoes were placed, the jury heard.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Global words | The top 400
fields.body:
Global words
An ambitious plan to develop a contemporary version of the Rosetta Stone - the granite slab that translated Egyptian hieroglyphics into ancient Greek - is being built by a team of international language experts. According to the founders of the Rosetta Project, between 50% and 90% of the world's languages are predicted to disappear in the next century.

The project is ongoing and native speakers are encouraged to participate. An online database is available at www.rosettaproject.org.

The top 400
The UK fared well last month in the list of the most famous 400 people on the internet, compiled by ranking the number of times each name comes up on the search engine www.alltheweb.com. Sting was the most famous Brit on the net at number 11. Elton John came in at 13, ahead of Tony Blair at 17, one place above Jenifer Lopez.

Give it
The idea of a virtual high street is nothing new, but ItsGoodToGive.co.uk is one of the few to offer a more ethical deal. Every time you buy from one of its partner sites, ItsGoodToGive will donate 50% of all revenue raised to its partnership charities. These include the RNIB, the Royal British Legion and the British Heart Foundation.Users can divide this donation to either each of the 15 chosen charities or to the one of their choice.

Women only
Pink Noises is an electronic music site specifically for women. Edited by the New York-based Analog Tara, the site is well designed and offers artist profiles, interviews and some pithy essays on music culture.

Land
N55 is a collective of Danish artists who have hatched a beautifully idealistic project to set up a network of communally owned land (or LAND) over the web. Anyone who has LAND can donate it, and anyone can use LAND for any purpose - as long as they agree to leave it exactly as they found it. LAND has already been made available in Denmark, Norway and the US. Each LAND should be referenced and marked out by a specially constructed Cairn. A set of grid references can be found at www.n55.org.de.

Fax off
A number of MPs have asked their constituents to stop using FaxYourMP.com, the website that does exactly what its name suggests. They may not reply but you can still register your protest at www.FaxYourMP.com.

Workspheres
The Museum of Modern Art in New York is exhibiting Workspheres, celebrating innovative computer design and the future of the office. There is a smart-looking accompanying website at www.moma.org/workspheres/swfs/workspheres.html

Wap watch
Fully searchable, basic medical advice can be found at www.pocketdoctor.co.uk, and you can send someone a Wap birthday card at www.wapcardz.com. There is also a very good online journey planner at www.railtrack.co.uk/wap.

New & noted
 The Royal Mail has put a list of all UK postcodes online. Type in the address you need at www.royalmail.co.uk/paf
 Cheap Magazine subscriptions are now available at www.emagazineshop.com
 The site at www.stagnites.com offers weekend breaks, shopping and a survival guide.
* Tracy Hogg Enterprises Inc: www.babywhisperer.com
 The Rosetta Stone for Whassup can be found at www.budweiser.com/whassup/languages.

How to vote

www.homeoffice.gov.uk/elections

Operation black vote

www.obv.org.uk

Satirical spin
www.Spinon.co.uk

Independent information

www.parliamentaryelection.com

Live news feed

www.campaigning.co.uk

Unlimited coverage

www.theguardian.com/ countdown

fields.headline: Spot the difference
fields.standfirst:
Website copying may be widespread, but there are some simple measures you can take to protect your copyright. Chris Alden explains
More net news
fields.trailText: Website copying may be widespread, but there are some simple measures you can take to protect your copyright. Chris Alden explains
fields.body:
Mike Slocombe, the designer and creator of Urban 75, isn't the type you would expect to get agitated about the rights of the copyright holder.

He wears dreadlocks. He opposes legislation that threatens individual freedom of expression. He won't accept banners, tie-ins or ads on his site, funding it instead through freelance web design. But when Slocombe discovered last month that an organisation in the US had built web pages that looked like his own, even he was put out.

"I got emails from people in America saying, 'Are you involved in this site, or did you design it?' So I took a look, and shrieked in horror as I saw what looks like my site."

Parts of the pages in question - published by Narconon, a drug treatment programme in the US - were, Slocombe says, a close match to earlier designs on Urban 75. The look and feel were confusingly similar. Certain graphics were identical. Sections of code - including, Slocombe points out, JavaScript for a pop-up window not used on the Narconon pages - were almost identical.

Even phrases were remarkably similar, Slocombe says. A Google search on the Urban 75 catchphrase - We are entirely non-profit, no banners, no tie-ins, no ads - returned only Narconon, Urban 75 and sites linking to Urban 75.

The main difference, it seems, is ideological. Urban 75 offers information about drugs without condemning their use, but Narconon actively promotes treatment of addiction through techniques developed by L Ron Hubbard, the founder of the Church of Scientology.

Slocombe alleges that a copyright violation had taken place - but Gary Smith, Narconon's executive director, in an email to Online, said he "does not believe the websites in question include any copyright infringement".

The question of copyright on the internet is complex. "It's widely recognised," says Michael Chissick, the head of the online law team at Field Fisher Waterhouse, "that most things on a website - the software, text, photos, music, film - are copyright-protected works."

But it is normal practice for developers to, say, look at each other's code to educate themselves. Any page can be viewed as source code (a function in all browsers) or even copied (offline viewing, again a function in later browsers). A simple email of thanks will usually suffice.

It is also permissible to copy work if it is not a "substantial" portion of protected work, qualitatively speaking, or if it is not original. Work may also be explicitly placed in the public domain - free graphics libraries are available to developers, often in return for a link or a credit.

Despite such resources, copying is widespread, as the Lancashire designer Julia Hurst of spreadtheworld.com can testify. The man whom she says ripped off her site even advertised in the magazine of her local chamber of commerce.

"There was an advert for a web designer setting up three or four miles from me. I went to have a look at his site - and found it was my site.

"It looked different, but the words were verbatim. It was lifted wholesale, even to the extent that where he'd copied one page he'd put his pictures in but left my text."

She solved the problem by sending an email complaint - not only to her rival, but also to the local chamber of com merce and her ISP. The site was down within a few days.

If email doesn't do the trick, headed paper might. When a site in America copied whole pages from her site, Hurst asked her solicitor to write a letter. "They'd copied whole pages and put at the bottom 'Reproduced by kind permission of' - which gave them credibility, when courtesy was one thing they'd never extended me. That one the lawyer's letter sorted out."

But in the end, says Chissick, you need to be prepared to back up your claim. "If you haven't much money, the first thing you should do is write. If that doesn't work, your only real recourse is the courts - and that's what they're there for."

It helps if you are well known. If many people can vouch for the fact that they saw your website at a certain date, or if screengrabs appeared in the press, that will be better proof than computer records that might more easily be fabricated.

But while a copyright case in the same country might not be too problematic, says Chissick, things could be more challenging overseas. It is usually the law in the country in which the website is hosted that will apply.

"As always with the internet, there's a difference between what the law says - thou shalt not copy somebody else's copyrighted work - and the practice."

The good news is that most countries are signatories to the Berne convention, which requires states to recognise "moral rights of integrity and attribution". But the law may still vary from place to place. In the US, the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act says an online service provider must take down a website if you allege it violates your rights - or become liable for damages.

Slocombe, a long-standing opponent of tough legislation such as the Criminal Justice Act and the RIP Act, describes this law as open to misuse, because protest sites that can't afford to fight legal claims could end up being intimidated.

But if the website declares it will defend itself against your claim, you have just 10 days to bring a case - or the service provider must put the site back up. So you have to be prepared .

The problem for a one-man show such as Urban 75 is that hardball is an expensive game to play. The Church of Scientology, famously litigious, has been an aggressive defender of its online copyright.

So Slocombe used a radical tactic: posting comparisons of the two sites on Urban 75, plus a section (later removed) inviting his readers to email concerns to Narconon and its service provider, Earthlink.

Earthlink has not replied to either the Guardian or, we understand, Urban 75. The company was founded by a Scientologist, Sky Dayton, although it has distanced itself from the church.

Narconon, it appears, did get a reply. According to Smith's email, "Earthlink did not see that there was any problem with the Narconon websites". The ISP, he adds, was "very concerned about the number of unsolicited emails that Narconon and Earthlink were receiving at the request of Urban 75."

But Urban 75 has won small victories. Narconon took down the "no tie-ins" phrase the day Slocombe wrote to them. They tweaked the graphics - replacing the orange chevrons first with an orange blob, then yellow arrows. They eventually removed the JavaScript function. Narconon made such changes, Smith says, because it "wanted to resolve all concerns amicably".

Small victories, but valuable to Slocombe, a man wedded to his online obsession. "I don't want people confusing my work with theirs."

How to protect copyright online
Companies have responded to copyright protection requirements by offering digital rights management services, which attempt to track copyrighted work on the net. Examples include www.siteprotector.com and www.contentguard.com.

To prove copyright in graphics, digital watermarking has been built into image manipulation programs such as Adobe PhotoShop. You buy into the service from a company such as Digimarc, and they will give you a watermark to use on your images. Under the US Digital Millennium Copyright Act, interfering with such watermarks or other anti-copyright devices will create copyright liability. Although not having it does not mean you aren't protected, it is always a good idea to put a clear copyright notice on your site. A licence or disclaimer telling users they are welcome to make copies for personal, but not commercial use, is typical.
