fields.headline: Psion is under pressure
fields.standfirst: Jack Schofield  on the future of handheld computing
fields.trailText: Jack Schofield on the future of handheld computing
fields.body:
Today, Psion is expected to show analysts its first internet-enabled mobile phone. But the small British company that pioneered handheld computing in the early 1980s will not have the market to itself. The competition includes almost every major player in the cellular phone market, plus a raft of handheld computer manufacturers with systems based on Palm's operating system and Microsoft's PocketPC.

Indeed, a small company based in Birmingham may already have stolen Psion's thunder. While many systems were shown at the recent GSM World 2001 mobile phone conference in Cannes, the one that attracted most attention was Sendo's featherweight multimedia phone.

Psion is being put under pressure by the success of Palm and Handspring in the market for PDAs (personal digital assistants), and this may show in the financial results it is also due to reveal today.

Palm is not complaining. On Monday, International Data Corporation, a US-based research company, said it expected sales of "smart handheld devices" to grow from 12.9 million units last year to more than 63.4 million by 2004.

But the bottom end of the computer market, made up of handheld devices, is converging with the top end of the phone market. The future may belong to merged PDA-phones. However, the battle for supremacy will be bitter, and may never be won.

Two years ago, it looked as though the market would go to Psion's Epoc operating system, which it spun off into a separate company called Symbian. Its backers included the West's phone giants, Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola. At least seven companies are thought to be building smart phones using Symbian's software.

The first Symbian-based smart phone, the Ericsson R380, went on sale late last year, and Nokia is expected to deliver the Communicator 9210, with a colour screen, in the next few weeks.

Today, however, victory for Symbian looks less certain. Handspring, founded by the people who started Palm Inc, has made a run with its VisorPhone, soon to be available in the UK. It is basically a Palm-based computer combined with a GSM phone module. Thus it should appeal to European Palm users who cannot buy Palm VII wireless handhelds. Nokia, Korea's Samsung and Japan's Kyocera are also expected to launch Palm-based phones.

Then there is the two-pronged attack based on Microsoft's PocketPC version of Windows CE. First, there are VisorPhone-style devices created by adding GSM modules to handhelds.

Next, there will be smart phones based on a smaller and more efficient version of the PocketPC software.

But the battle may not be decided on the merits of the hardware and software. For while the technology used by PDAs and smart phones is converging, they are usually sold on a different basis.

PDA buyers have to pay the full whack for their systems which can be more expensive than desktop PCs. Most phone buyers, by contrast, expect to pay little for their handsets, with the real cost covered by call charges.

So the real question will not be which £500 devices perform best, but which ones the network operators and their retailers knock out for £99.99 or less.

webTitle: Six Nations solution unlikely as crisis continues to spread

fields.headline: Six Nations solution unlikely as crisis continues to spread
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The chances of the Six Nations Championship being concluded this season looked increasingly remote last night as officials prepared to meet in London tomorrow to discuss ways of salvaging the tournament in the wake of the foot and mouth outbreak that is spreading across Britain.
fields.body:
The chances of the Six Nations Championship being concluded this season looked increasingly remote last night as officials prepared to meet in London tomorrow to discuss ways of salvaging the tournament in the wake of the foot and mouth outbreak that is spreading across Britain.

England's match against Scotland at Twickenham and France's trip to Rome to play Italy this weekend have survived the crisis but serious doubts now hover over several other fixtures, including next month's game between France and Wales in Paris and Ireland's remaining two home matches in Dublin against England and Scotland.

With this weekend's Wales-Ireland game already postponed, there are precious few alternative dates available, although the Six Nations chairman Allan Hosie is doing his best to sound defiant.

"It is wrong to say the championship could be scrapped. We are aware that the British Lions are going on tour on June 1 and are aware of domestic fixtures. But we must explain that international rugby football is a breadwinner for many unions."

Money-spinner or not, the Irish government will be extremely reluctant to take any risks with its farming industry and the mood in France could easily change if the virus makes it across their borders, threatening their visit to Twickenham on April 7.

April and May is now a vital period for professional clubs in England and France and, though April 29 is a likely revised date for the Wales-Ireland game, staging games in early autumn may well turn out to be the only alternative to cancellation.

That would certainly be the preferred option of the Lions coach Graham Henry, who says he is prepared to delay naming his 37-strong tour squad. "It may be that the announcement of the squad has to be put back, but my fear is the impact rearranged championship matches at the end of April or in May would have on the players," he said, suggesting Lions players might be tempted to hold back, thus devaluing the competition.

"If the rest of the championship programme is disrupted, it would make sense to reschedule the matches en bloc in September. Whether that is practical would be a matter for the Six Nations committee."

Henry, though, also recognises the financial imperatives. "The priority has to be to reschedule any postponed matches because the income from them is vital to the unions. From my point of view, though, I want the players who tour with the Lions to be as fresh as possible. When the Six Nations committee considers this matter, the needs of players have to be taken into account."

Representatives of France and Italy will take part in tomorrow's meeting by telephone, when Hosie will brief them on the outcome of talks with broadcasters and the sponsor, Lloyds TSB. "We are being responsible," insisted Hosie. "We are monitoring the ongoing situation, which is a cause for concern not only for rugby but for all sports where there is a movement of people."

The Scottish Rugby Union said that it had received calls demanding the postponement of Saturday's Twickenham game in order to minimise the spread of the disease but, after consulting the rural affairs department of the Scottish Executive, it has confirmed the team will travel south.

The French rugby president Bernard Lapasset and team manager Jo Maso, meanwhile, have sought to discuss the situation with the French agriculture ministry before committing themselves further.

"At the moment we haven't really been given a lot of information about this issue and we are trying to concentrate on the match against Italy," Maso said. "It is a pity, though, that this plague may unravel the entire tournament."

A similar view was expressed by England's captain Martin Johnson. "It would be a pity if it's not completed, but the situation is obviously very serious. We hope for everyone's sake it gets sorted out as soon as possible so people can get on with their lives. I'd like to think we could get it completed but it's not in our hands."

webTitle: Courtney Love action hopes to rock music biz

fields.headline: Love action hopes to rock music biz
fields.trailText: The singer Courtney Love is threatening to become "the music industry's worst nightmare" by challenging her contract with a music conglomerate in a court case which she believes will expose the "unconscionable and unlawful" behaviour of the business.
fields.body:
The singer Courtney Love is threatening to become "the music industry's worst nightmare" by challenging her contract with a music conglomerate in a court case which she believes will expose the "unconscionable and unlawful" behaviour of the business.

Her case, which was due to open in the Los Angeles county superior court yesterday, will be scrutinised by musicians who have long complained about exploitative contracts.

Love, the widow of Nirvana's Kurt Cobain, has often attacked the industry for using "unfair tactics" to exploit young musicians.

Now she plans to challenge her contract with Vivendi Universal in a no-holds-barred contest before a jury. The implications for the industry, still uncertain about the outcome of its battle with Napster's online music-swapping service, are enormous.

Love is basing part of her case on a section of Californian law relating to the actress Olivia de Havilland's action more than 50 years ago to free herself her from a long-term studio contract. It says entertainers cannot be tied to a contract for more than seven years.

So far the law remains untested by musicians. In general, record companies have renegotiated contracts and casesthreatened by performers such as Luther Vandross, Don Henley and Beck have been settled out of court.

While it is not unusual for musicians to challenge their contracts, Love seeks to extend her case to cover the whole industry and to challenge the right of conglomerates to take over the contracts of smaller companies they have bought.

The suit says that her band, Hole, signed a contract in 1992 with Geffen Records, which was sold to MCA, which was later sold to the drinks giant Seagram, which was then bought by French utilities and waste company Vivendi last year.

"I've sunk from being marketed by an American label that understood how to sell my music to a huge Canadian corporation that knows nothing but how to sell booze and finally slid down into the sewers of Paris," Love said.

Vivendi Universal has dismissed her claim as a "meritless, inflammatory diatribe" designed to attract attention.

webTitle: Turkey asks for $25bn in rescue loans

fields.headline: Turkey asks for $25bn in rescue loans
fields.trailText: Turkey is seeking $25bn (£17.4bn) in foreign loans to tackle the financial crisis which has devalued its currency, the lira, by 30% in the past week, increasing the country's external debt burden.
fields.body:
Turkey is seeking $25bn (£17.4bn) in foreign loans to tackle the financial crisis which has devalued its currency, the lira, by 30% in the past week, increasing the country's external debt burden.

Prime minister Bulent Ecevit confirmed that the loans were being sought. "This is our expectation, our wish," he said.

The loans are being negotiated with a consortium of foreign banks and would require the blessing of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, which might be asked for contributions.

Turkey was forced to abandon a pegged exchange rate, the backbone of an IMF-backed disinflation programme, last week when a row between Mr Ecevit and President Ahmet Necdet Sezer sparked fears of political instability.

Now the country faces heavy debt rollovers and has said it will announce details of how it plans to handle them after a week-long Muslim holiday that begins on Saturday.

The World Bank said yesterday that Kemal Dervis, one of its vice-presidents and expected to be Turkey's next central bank governor, would travel to Ankara to discuss the economic situation.

"Kemal Dervis has been asked by prime minister Bulent Ecevit to discuss the economic and financial situation in Turkey."

Mr Dervis is vice-president for poverty reduction and economic management at World Bank headquarters in Washington.

He is tipped to replace Gazi Ercel, who resigned at the weekend.

Turkey's main equities index closed 1.45% higher yesterday, reversing morning losses as investors positioned themselves for expected buying ahead of the holiday.

webTitle: Seattle shaken but it's not the 'Big One'

fields.headline: Seattle shaken but it's not the 'Big One'
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Seattle was hit by an earthquake which registered 7.0 on the Richter scale yesterday and sent thousands in the city centre scurrying into the streets from evacuated office buildings.
fields.body:
Seattle was hit by an earthquake which registered 7.0 on the Richter scale yesterday and sent thousands in the city centre scurrying into the streets from evacuated office buildings. The earthquake was felt 700 miles away in Salt Lake City, Utah.

Twelve people were reported injured, three of them seriously. A technology conference being addressed by Bill Gates came to an abrupt halt when the 15-second earthquake struck in mid-morning.

The epicentre was just to the south of the city's centre.

The earthquake came as research after the devastating earthquake in India last month suggested that the "blind thrust" faults which levelled parts of Gujarat and run beneath central Los Angeles could produce earthquakes of the same magnitude.

The earthquake that caused nearly 20,000 fatalities in India on January 26 registered 7.7 on the scale.

It had been assumed that the blind thrust faults in southern California were not capable of producing earthquakes of greater than 7.3 magnitude. But this week the research team who monitor earthquake potential for the state said that they would have to revise their estimates to 7.7 after the Indian earthquake.

An increase of 0.4 magnitude at that point on the Richter scale would produce an earthquake with 2.5 times more energy.

Researchers in California now believe that there is a 70% probability of a major earthquake in San Francisco's Bay Area within the next 30 years.

The earthquake that killed 67 people and caused $7bn (about £4.9bn) in damage in the San Francisco Bay area in 1989 registered 7.1 on the scale.

The Northridge quake centred in a Los Angeles suburb in 1994, which killed 60 and was linked to a blind thrust fault near Los Angeles, registered 6.7.

"[Gujarat] sort of raises the bar for what the maximum earthquake-detection threshold is for blind thrust faults," said William Lettis, an earthquake hazard consultant and a member of the research team sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute.

"As a geologist, can you go out and easily find a fault that will produce a future 7.7 earthquake?" he said.

"The answer is no, and that's an important lesson."

The new earthquake and the findings come only days after the Bay Area experienced a smaller tremor registering 4.4 and centred 11 miles to the east of San Jose in Silicon Valley, which was also felt in Marin county.

The effects of that earthquake were felt for around five minutes.

While Californians are used to minor earthquakes - they all have their own earthquake experience story - the new findings indicate that if the "Big One" does come it could be even more serious than expected.

Thrust faults tend to be particularly damaging to tall buildings, because they accelerate vertically.

Earthquakes along another type of fault, known as a strike-clip fault, move horizontally. The San Andreas fault is of the latter type.

As people increasingly migrate into earthquake zones, particularly ones near the coast, scientists suggest that a big earthquake could claim as many as 1m victims this century - about as many as have died from earthquakes in the past 100 years.

The Global Earthquake Response Centre does have some comfort for Californians, however.

On its website it asks: "Could a powerful enough earthquake cause California to break off and fall into the ocean?"

The reply is: "No. It's a common misconception."
fields.bodyText: Seattle was hit by an earthquake which registered 7.0 on the Richter scale yesterday and sent thousands in the city centre scurrying into the streets from evacuated office buildings. The earthquake was felt 700 miles away in Salt Lake City, Utah. Twelve people were reported injured, three of them seriously. A technology conference being addressed by Bill Gates came to an abrupt halt when the 15-second earthquake struck in mid-morning. The epicentre was just to the south of the city's centre. The earthquake came as research after the devastating earthquake in India last month suggested that the "blind thrust" faults which levelled parts of Gujarat and run beneath central Los Angeles could produce earthquakes of the same magnitude. The earthquake that caused nearly 20,000 fatalities in India on January 26 registered 7.7 on the scale. It had been assumed that the blind thrust faults in southern California were not capable of producing earthquakes of greater than 7.3 magnitude. But this week the research team who monitor earthquake potential for the state said that they would have to revise their estimates to 7.7 after the Indian earthquake. An increase of 0.4 magnitude at that point on the Richter scale would produce an earthquake with 2.5 times more energy. Researchers in California now believe that there is a 70% probability of a major earthquake in San Francisco's Bay Area within the next 30 years. The earthquake that killed 67 people and caused $7bn (about £4.9bn) in damage in the San Francisco Bay area in 1989 registered 7.1 on the scale. The Northridge quake centred in a Los Angeles suburb in 1994, which killed 60 and was linked to a blind thrust fault near Los Angeles, registered 6.7. "[Gujarat] sort of raises the bar for what the maximum earthquake-detection threshold is for blind thrust faults," said William Lettis, an earthquake hazard consultant and a member of the research team sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute. "As a geologist, can you go out and easily find a fault that will produce a future 7.7 earthquake?" he said. "The answer is no, and that's an important lesson." The new earthquake and the findings come only days after the Bay Area experienced a smaller tremor registering 4.4 and centred 11 miles to the east of San Jose in Silicon Valley, which was also felt in Marin county. The effects of that earthquake were felt for around five minutes. While Californians are used to minor earthquakes - they all have their own earthquake experience story - the new findings indicate that if the "Big One" does come it could be even more serious than expected. Thrust faults tend to be particularly damaging to tall buildings, because they accelerate vertically. Earthquakes along another type of fault, known as a strike-clip fault, move horizontally. The San Andreas fault is of the latter type. As people increasingly migrate into earthquake zones, particularly ones near the coast, scientists suggest that a big earthquake could claim as many as 1m victims this century - about as many as have died from earthquakes in the past 100 years. The Global Earthquake Response Centre does have some comfort for Californians, however. On its website it asks: "Could a powerful enough earthquake cause California to break off and fall into the ocean?" The reply is: "No. It's a common misconception."
fields.bylineHtml: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Equitable replaces chief
fields.body:
Equitable replaces chief

Equitable Life chief executive Chris Headdon was replaced yesterday after less than three months in the job as the insurer continued its attempts to put its troubles behind it.

His successor, who starts as chief executive today, is appointed actuary Charles Thomson, 52, who joined Equitable Life from insurer Scottish Widows in January.

Mr Headdon was appointed chief executive on December 8 following the resignation of Alan Nash. A spokesman said he is moving to a senior position at Clerical Medical, the insurer subsidiary of Halifax bank which is taking over the investment management of Equitable's with-profits fund as part of the bank's acquisition of the mutual insurer's operations.

TBI takes over Luton airport

TBI, the regional airport operator, yesterday took control of Luton in a deal worth £82m. It is planning to buy the 65% stake in the airport from Barclays' Private Equity.

Barclays Capital said it had made an "outstanding return" since it bought a £15m stake at Luton in August 1998.

Keith Brooks, TBI's chief executive, said he thought the big distinction between TBI and Barclays was that his company was "an established and experienced airport operator".

De Beers cuts sales forecast

De Beers, the subject of a takeover offer by some of its biggest shareholders, yesterday forecast a 15% fall in rough diamond sales this year.

De Beers said it was aiming for sales of $4.8bn (£3.3bn) this year after a record $5.67bn last year. It blamed the weakening US market.

De Beers shares hit a record high last month after news of an $18bn bid for the firm by a consortium led by Anglo American and South Africa's Oppenheimer family.

Reckitt profits increase 62%

The popularity of Lemsip and Mr Sheen helped Anglo-Dutch consumer products company, Reckitt Benckiser, post a 62% increase in profits for its fourth quarter.

The household cleaning products group, which was formed in 1999 by Reckitt & Coleman's takeover of Dutch company Benckiser, reported a post-tax profit for the full year of £275m, compared with £200m for the year before.

Net income for the fourth quarter was £97m, up from £62m for the previous quarter. The surge in profits is due to strong growth in sales and savings associated with the merger, the company said.

BAT cigarette sales hit record

British American Tobacco yesterday said it sold a record 807bn cigarettes last year, despite a swath of litigation in the US, alleged collusion with smugglers and increasing advertising restrictions.

Shares in BAT closed 18p higher at 556.75p after the company announced a 27% rise in operating profits as a result of a merger with Rothmans. Underlying pre-tax profit for the year to January rose to £1.52bn from £1.37 in 1999.

fields.headline: Greenspan stays his hand
fields.standfirst:
 Fed chief's gloom deepens
 Pressure on shares as emergency rate cut ruled out
fields.trailText:
 Fed chief's gloom deepens
 Pressure on shares as emergency rate cut ruled out
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in NewYork, Jonathan Watts in Tokyo and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
Share prices were under renewed pressure in New York last night after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the US Federal Reserve, dashed hopes that he would respond to fresh signs of weakness in the world's biggest economy with an emergency cut in interest rates.

Although Mr Greenspan told Congress that the US's economic downturn had not yet run its course, he hinted that the Federal Reserve's interest rate-setting committee would wait for its next scheduled meeting in a month's time before easing policy.

Markets had been scenting the possibility of a repeat of the unscheduled half-point rate cut in early January, and responded to the comments by driving down share prices on Wall Street. Both the Dow Jones and the technology-driven Nasdaq composite index declined, with the latter reaching a 26-month low.

Fears that the world's second biggest economy, Japan, is also on course for a recession this year were heightened yesterday when the government was forced to bow to a chorus of political and international pressure yesterday by lowering interest rates.

The cut of a tenth of a percentage point represented a huge loss of face for Japan's central bank governor, Masaru Hayami, who has faced unrelenting criticism since last August, when the bank ended its zero interest rate policy.

As late as Tuesday, Mr Hayami was insisting that the economy no longer needed the crutch of this "money for nothing" policy because it was on the road to recovery. But figures showing a 4% drop in industrial production last month forced a U-turn yesterday. The Bank of Japan cut its key overnight call rate from 0.25% to 0.15%.

At one point yesterday, the Nikkei index in Tokyo slumped to its lowest level in 15 years. It recovered slightly, but still closed at a 28-month low of 12,883. Analysts said the central bank's decision to ease its monetary stance will provide only a limited respite for the Japanese economy, which is increasingly being seen as the "sick man" of Asia.

In his second testimony given to the US Congress this month, Mr Greenspan said that the risks continued to be "skewed toward the economy's remaining on a path inconsistent with satisfactory economic performance".

Analysts in the US said that Mr Greenspan's view of the American economy had become gloomier in the two weeks since his last testimony, and they are taking for granted that the Fed will cut rates for a third time this year at its next meeting.

Mr Greenspan's statement yesterday marked a change from the earlier speech, in which he said consumer confidence was still "at a level that in the past was consistent with economic growth".

The Conference Board issued a report this week which revealed that confidence had fallen for five straight months to a four-and-a-half year low. At the same time, GDP growth rates - a measure of total economic output - also fell to the slowest quarterly growth rate for five years.

Economists have become notably more bearish in the past month. Ian Shepherdson, chief US economist at High Frequency Economics, believes that GDP growth rates could fall into negative territory, signalling a recession. "With key leading indicators nosediving, the worst is still to come," he said yesterday.

fields.headline: Baird loses M&S appeal
fields.trailText: Textiles group William Baird yesterday lost an appeal court case against retailer Marks & Spencer, its claim for more than £50m in compensation being rejected.
fields.body:
Textiles group William Baird yesterday lost an appeal court case against retailer Marks & Spencer, its claim for more than £50m in compensation being rejected.

William Baird's shares, which have lost more than a third of their value since the beginning of the year, dropped a further 11%.

The firm sued M&S for losses and damages after the retailer dropped it as a clothing supplier in 1999, ending a 30-year partnership. Baird, which owns brands such as Windsmoor and Planet, claimed that it was entitled to three years' notice, and that the retailer had failed to give reasonable warning.

In June the high court dismissed the principal claim and yesterday the appeal court upheld that decision.

Baird was forced to close 16 factories and sack 4,500 employees at the time, and said it would face costs of more than £50m, a figure later revised to top £110m.

Analysts' reactions yesterday were mixed. One said this would prove to be "a technical blip" for Baird, which supplies uniforms to McDonald's restaurants, but another described it as "one more nail in the coffin for Baird".

David Suddens, Baird's chief executive, said: "We were hoping to get some compensation, but we are not in financial difficulty. It is not a crippling blow." The board would consider an appeal - a course of action its legal advisers had recommended.

M&S said: "We have always said there is no legal basis for Baird's claim."

fields.headline: ARM falls out of favour
fields.trailText: There are few companies listed on the London Stock Exchange with a better track record than chip designer ARM Holdings.
fields.body:
There are few companies listed on the London Stock Exchange with a better track record than chip designer ARM Holdings.

Aside from watching the value of their investment increase many times over, investors have been treated to an almost unbroken stream of earnings surprises. Since it floated in April 1998, ARM has beaten the City's earnings expectations every time it has reported. But one analyst, Mustapha Omar of stockbroker Collins Stewart, is calling the end of the winning streak.

On the back of a series of profits warnings from some of ARM's biggest customers - Texas Instruments (TI) and Matsushita for example - Mr Omar has lowered his pretax profits forecast for ARM from £45m to £38m. Effectively he is predicting a profits warning.

Mr Omar says it is ominous that these customers are blaming their current predicament on a slowdown in chip sales for wireless devices.

Some 25% of ARM's revenues come from royalties. These are directly linked to the number of ARM designed chips sold by licensees like Texas Instruments. It is a 100% margin business.

Working on the basis that Texas Instruments expects a 20% fall in revenues from its wireless chip business, Mr Omar expects ARM to make £38m this year. But it could be a lot worse. "Across the board all their customers are really struggling,"he said.

ARM shares ended the session 20p lower at 310p, a long way from joint-house broker Morgan Stanley's new target price of 800p. Chartists reckon next stop for the share price is 260p.

After spending most of the day in positive territory, leading shares ended lower after some typically delphic comments from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan.

Addressing the House of Representatives financial services committee he sent a mixed message to a market that had been hoping for clarity on the Fed's rate cutting plans.

Although Mr Greenspan warned the US economy faces below par economic growth he stopped short of hinting the Fed would cut rates ahead of its next policy meeting on March 20. As a result the FTSE 100 surrendered a near 60-point gain to close 23.3 points lower at 5,917.9.

"Soon they will be talking about the psychologically important 5,900 level," quipped one trader.

Nonetheless, there were some bright spots. Consumer products group Reckitt Benckiser topped the FTSE 100 leaderboard, rising 47p to 950p, after strong full-year figures, while Abbey National jumped 38p to £11.67 after merger talks with Bank of Scotland, 17p higher at 755p, were abandoned.

Speculation that Bass, down 8p at 723p, has tabled a takeover offer, supported hotels group Hilton, up 7p to 223p, while elsewhere the weak performance of the Nasdaq following Mr Greenspan's comments saw the FTSE Techmark 100 close 50.29 points lower at 2,303.37.

Optical components maker Bookham was among the worst performers, losing 67p to 511p after JDS Uniphase - the heavyweight of the sector - axed 10% of its workforce citing slower demand.

Other big tech casualties included Kewill Systems, 18p weaker at 262p, and Emblaze Systems, down 17.5p at 360p.

In the meantime, automation and controls group Invensys slipped 3.25p to 155.25p after ABN Amro slashed its profits forecasts for the next fiscal year by £120m.

Lower down the ladder, WH Smith advanced 31p to 521p following an upbeat analysts' visit to its retail operations.

Market professionals were also trying to lay their hands on the shares of regional water company Mid-Kent, up 10p at 547.5p. According to the gossips a 650p-a-share bid from a French company is on the way.

Last week Mid Kent announced that it had received a number of approaches about a possible takeover.

webTitle: Infobank delay release of full year figures

fields.headline: Infobank timing matters
fields.trailText: When a technology company delays the release of its full year figures by a week, traders tend to worry and mark the shares lower.
fields.body:
When a technology company delays the release of its full year figures by a week, traders tend to worry and mark the shares lower.

Infobank, the software developer, did exactly this yesterday and saw its shares gain 1p to 151.5p.

Market professionals think the delay (until March 12) is a signal that good news is in the pipeline. They reckon the results have been put back to coincide with a boardroom appointment.

Infobank's chief executive, Graham Sadd, recently said that the company has been trying to strengthen its board. Traders would not be surprised if this involved making an external appointment at a very senior level, possibly chief executive.

Management changes or not, analysts at WestLB Panmure see significant upside for a share price which has been barely trading above its cash value.

fields.headline: Vodafone sells French stake
fields.trailText: Vodafone yesterday raised £7.6bn from the sale of its 10% stake in France Télécom back to the French group.
fields.body:
Vodafone yesterday raised £7.6bn from the sale of its 10% stake in France Télécom back to the French group.

Vodafone had held the shares as payment for mobile operator Orange - which France Télécom bought last year for $36bn (£25bn).

Yesterday's deal, hammered out since the February 12 flotation of Orange, sees France Télécom paying €102 per share to Vodafone, some 54% above the market price.

The first payment of €6bn (£3.8bn) is due on March 5, followed by a €600m payment on March 26 and the remainder on March 25, 2002.

When it bought Orange last year, France Télécom hoped to raise €14bn-15bn from the float of 25% of the mobile operator, which would have covered the debt to Vodafone in full.

As it became clear that the float's proceeds would be considerably less, bankers for the two companies arrived at the new arrangement.

France Télécom's finances have become increasingly precarious as its debts have risen to €60bn, and credit rating agencies downgraded the company last week.

In a separate announcement yesterday, the company said it would delay a plan to buy a majority stake in the main Polish telecoms operator, citing difficult market conditions. The announcement threw the Polish treasury into turmoil; its 2001 budget hinges on a successful sale of the shares.

Yesterday, Vodafone became the first UK operator to offer mass availability of next-generation GPRS (global packet radio service) mobiles.

webTitle: 21 groups banned under new terror law

fields.headline: 21 groups banned under new terror law
fields.standfirst:
Special report: human rights in the UK
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The government yesterday banned 21 groups, the majority Islamic, which it has branded as terrorist under a new law enabling it for the first time to proscribe organisations targeting foreign states.
fields.body:
The government yesterday banned 21 groups, the majority Islamic, which it has branded as terrorist under a new law enabling it for the first time to proscribe organisations targeting foreign states.

The list includes the PKK, the Kurdish Workers' Party which has a large following in Britain; ETA, the Basque separatist group; LTTE, the Tamil separatist group, and a number of Sikh organisations.

They also include Al-Qai'da, a loose organisation led by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi now living in Afghanistan wanted in the US over attacks on American embassies in East Africa in 1998.

The Home Office concedes the large majority of the groups on the list - which does not include animal rights or environmental activists - have not attacked British targets. However, Jack Straw told MPs yesterday he was "entirely satisfied" that they were all "concerned in terrorism" under the new, broad, definition laid down in a law which came into force earlier this month.

He said his decision, which will not be effective until it has been approved by parliament, was based on the advice of MI5 and lawyers. Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, insisted that the move was not directed at any "specific community" or those campaigning "in a peaceful way for political change". He told journalists: "Any perception that we are targeting the Muslim community is entirely wrong".

Home Office ministers arranged meetings with ethnic groups before announcing the list. One of those who attended, Yousuf Bhailok, secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain, last night expressed his "grave concern" at the list. It included groups engaged in legitimate activities against the abuse of human rights or for the liberation of Palestine, he said.

Mr Clarke insisted the home secretary had acted independently. "Foreign policy was not a consideration", he said.

The new Terrorism Act, which for the first time allows the home secretary to proscribe foreign-based groups, defines terrorism as "the use or threat of action" designed to "influence the government or to intimidate the public ... for the purpose of advancing a political, religious, or ideological cause". Actions cited include those involving "serious violence against a person" in Britain or abroad. The act covers fundraising.

The measure, like its predecessor, the Prevention of Terrorism Act, covers Northern Ireland-based groups, 13 of which - on both sides- will remain proscribed. However, charges under the PTA have rarely been made in Northern Ireland where the police have usually used conventional criminal legislation against suspected terrorists. Under the act, which makes it an offence to invite support for, or attend meetings by proscribed groups, individuals and groups can complain to an appeals commission.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said: "Banning organisations and criminalising membership is a serious attack on basic rights of free speech and assembly."

 The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, last night met the UK Association of the Palestinian Community. Dr Ghada Karmi, its chairman, said many Palestinians felt they were unfairly under surveillance on suspicion of terrorism.

Proscribed organisations

 Al-Qa'ida: inspired by Osama bin Laden, made no attacks in UK.

 Egyptian Islamic Jihad: UK not directly targeted.

 Al-Gama'at al Islamiya: directed primarily at Egyptian government, no evidence of terrorism by UK members.

 Armed Islamic Group: aimed at Algerian government, no overt presence, UK-based members provided logistical support.

 Salafist Group for Call and Combat: also aimed at Algeria, no overt presence in UK.

 International Sikh Youth Federation: UK fundraising and other support.

 Babbar Khalsa (Sikh): fundraising but never attacked Western interests.

fields.bodyText: The government yesterday banned 21 groups, the majority Islamic, which it has branded as terrorist under a new law enabling it for the first time to proscribe organisations targeting foreign states. The list includes the PKK, the Kurdish Workers' Party which has a large following in Britain; ETA, the Basque separatist group; LTTE, the Tamil separatist group, and a number of Sikh organisations. They also include Al-Qai'da, a loose organisation led by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi now living in Afghanistan wanted in the US over attacks on American embassies in East Africa in 1998. The Home Office concedes the large majority of the groups on the list - which does not include animal rights or environmental activists - have not attacked British targets. However, Jack Straw told MPs yesterday he was "entirely satisfied" that they were all "concerned in terrorism" under the new, broad, definition laid down in a law which came into force earlier this month. He said his decision, which will not be effective until it has been approved by parliament, was based on the advice of MI5 and lawyers. Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, insisted that the move was not directed at any "specific community" or those campaigning "in a peaceful way for political change". He told journalists: "Any perception that we are targeting the Muslim community is entirely wrong". Home Office ministers arranged meetings with ethnic groups before announcing the list. One of those who attended, Yousuf Bhailok, secretary general of the Muslim Council of Britain, last night expressed his "grave concern" at the list. fields.headline: At this price? ARC International
fields.trailText: While shares in ARM were hit hard yesterday, its Hertfordshire-based rival, ARC International, joined the growing number of hi-tech companies saying their prospects should not be benchmarked against the more troubled firms in the technology sector.
fields.body:
While shares in ARM were hit hard yesterday, its Hertfordshire-based rival, ARC International, joined the growing number of hi-tech companies saying their prospects should not be benchmarked against the more troubled firms in the technology sector.

Announcing a fivefold rise in revenue to £10.6m for the year to January, the company claimed to have shielded itself from problems faced by other technology companies.

Nevertheless, analysts said investors who had lost out on technology stocks last year were likely to treat ARC - which is still some way from profitability - with caution. Yesterday, ARC shares closed down 5p at 159p.

Howard Brooks, an analyst at Beeson Gregory, said there was some truth to ARC's exemption claims because royalties only make up about 5% of its revenue. It is the more mature chip designers, such as ARM, that are likely to suffer as royalties slow down, he said. "For small, innovative companies, trading is driven by licence contract wins and product development."

Others pointed out that ARC's fourth quarter revenue growth of 10% was a significant drop from the 35% rate recorded for the three months to October. Pre-tax losses for the year increased to £16.4m, from £5.5 in 1999.

Shares in ARC have also been hit by concerns about the imminent expiry of lock-up arrangements undertaken by major shareholders - which still hold around 60% of equity - when the company floated last year.

Rumours abound that ARC is considering a secondary offering of shares to let some of its early investors sell stock when their lock-ups expire at the end of March.

Among those which could jump ship is Apax - which last week sold its stake in Autonomy after a similar lock-up agreement expired. Others include the Sans Trust and Nomura.

If such a secondary offering materialises, cheap shares in ARC may be a smart medium or long term investment.

webTitle: Crippled industry may cost economy £1bn loss

fields.headline: Crippled industry may cost economy £1bn loss
fields.standfirst:
Bill Movement ban 'losing farmers £50m a week'

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth disease could cost the British economy up to £1bn in lost output, economists estimate.
fields.body:
Foot and mouth disease could cost the British economy up to £1bn in lost output, economists estimate.

The disease is already proving crippling for the farming industry. The National Farmers' Union estimates that the ban on livestock movements is costing its members £50m a week in lost sales.

If the outbreak is contained, the backlog of animals is likely to be sold at knockdown prices. Hauliers are losing £4-5m in business through the ban on movement, the Road Hauliers Association said.

In the first instance, compensation will have to be paid to farmers to cover about 15,000 sheep, 2,200 cattle and 1,800 pigs which are destined to be slaughtered after coming into "dangerous contact" with infected animals. This will cost the government approximately £2m.

The longer term impact on an industry, which is already weakened by string of recent crises, could be devastating. Farming incomes fell by a third in the aftermath of the BSE crisis, which, unlike foot and mouth, only affected beef producers.

"This could be the final nail in the coffin of the livestock industry, which accounts for third of agriculture output," said Danny Gabay at the global financial firm JP Morgan. "It's hard to imagine what would induce Europeans to buy British produce again."

Because agriculture accounts for such a small proportion of output - just 1.3%, down from 2% a decade ago - the direct cost to rest of the economy, assuming the outbreak is controlled within the month, will be about £450m, said Mr Gabay. It would shave around 0.05% off growth.

However, the indirect impact is potentially double that. The freeze on movement across the countryside has already hit the racing industry, sports events, tourism, agricultural suppliers and food manufacturing. "The indirect impacts are difficult to compute but you can come up with some quite unpleasant numbers. The longer that this goes on, particularly the restrictions on the movement of people, the more costly it becomes."

Thousands of meat process workers could be made redundant in the next few days, warned the GMB union, which reported that 520 people in the north east had been placed on indefinite lay-off at two plants, Cranswick Country Foods' pork meat process plant at Preston, near Hull, and Dawn Meats' processing plant and abattoir, near Bridlington.

"This is not a farming crisis, it is an industrial crisis," said a spokesman yesterday.

The cost so far in compensation for slaughtering could already exceed £2m. Approximately 14,700 sheep, 2,200 cattle and 1,860 pigs have come into "dangerous contact" with infected animals and will be slaughtered.

But Britain's betting industry was upbeat yesterday. The bookmakers William Hill said the crisis could knock up to a third off the daily bets placed on horses, but that the industry no longer depended on just horse racing, and punters would "soon get used to racing from South Africa and Europe".

The government has already pledged a £168m compensation package for farmers hit by the disease. But there is speculation that Gordon Brown, the chancellor, might, in next week's budget, help the beleaguered farming community.

The Ministry of Agriculture said it had not computed the costs of vaccination against its blanket policy of mass slaughter. "If we vaccinated, it would be two years after the last vaccination that Britain could be declared a foot and mouth free country," said a spokeswoman yesterday. "It's a complicated balance between strategies."

A past president of the British Veterinary Association yesterday said it was impossible to put a price on vaccination costs against slaughtering all animals in contact with the disease. "There is no licensed vaccine in Europe. A cost-benefit analysis in the 1980s showed it was cheaper to slaughter. The biggest argument against vaccination is the cost. There are seven types of the virus and numerous sub-types. If we vaccinated it would take Britain two years before we could declared FMD free."

fields.headline: Dumb no more
fields.standfirst: Maybe we're getting smarter
fields.trailText: Is it too hopeful, too naive, to hope that now might be the time to strike from the language that dread phrase "dumbing down"? For nearly a decade those two words have been used to slam a culture getting more stupid and less literate by the hour.
fields.body:
Is it too hopeful, too naive, to hope that now might be the time to strike from the language that dread phrase "dumbing down"? For nearly a decade those two words have been used to slam a culture getting more stupid and less literate by the hour. It has become shorthand for the curmudgeonly belief that the country is going to the dogs, that nothing is as good as it used to be. In this view 21st-century Britain is a land where people watch too much television, play mind-numbing video games and can barely string a sentence together: we are dumb and we are going down.

Today we publish some powerful and heartening evidence to the contrary. For what is one of the largest growth areas in leisure activity? Is it use of the Sony Playstation 2 or a mass addiction to televised wrestling? It is not. Instead, the hot pastime of the hour is ... reading. A new study has found that one of the fastest-growing forms of social gathering is the reading group - an entertainment that involves nothing more complicated than a group of people gathering to discuss a good book. Fifty thousand Britons are at it and the numbers are rising all the time.

The groups' favourites are mainstream, but literary - from the inevitable Captain Corelli to the much-loved Birdsong. Tastes are not parochial: the groups have lapped up Memoirs of a Geisha and The Shipping News, as well as novels from India, Canada and the American south (though not many from continental Europe make the Top 20).

And this reading fad is not confined to the monthly groups. From bus queues to airports, people can be seen with their nose in a book. Add to that the current craze for quiz shows which make general knowledge cool, a Chinese-language feature film nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars and a whole new TV network, BBC4, to be filled with intellectual content, and a new trend emerges. Say goodbye to dumbing down. Behold the era of braining up!

fields.headline: Stan Cullis
fields.standfirst: A shrewd centre-half who became England's youngest captain, as a manager he led his club to three League titles and two FA Cup victories
fields.trailText: A shrewd centre-half who became England's youngest captain, as a manager he led his club to three League titles and two FA Cup victories.
fields.body:
Stan Cullis, who has died aged 84, managed Wolverhampton Wanderers during the club's European glory days in the 1950s and steered them to three League titles. He was also one of the finest centre-halves of his day and a former England captain.

Cullis was born in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, but his father was a Wolverhampton man, and Wolves could thank Cullis senior for the fact that Stanley went to Molineux. Several major clubs had shown interest in him when he was playing as a teenager for the Ellesmere Port team, but his father, wanting to get him to Wolves, wrote to recommend him. They signed him up in 1934, after a trial. He became skipper of the A team at 17, the reserves at 18 and the first team by the time he was 19. An especially notable month for him was May 1939, when, in Bucharest, against Romania, he was made captain of the England team, the youngest ever at the age of 22. England won 2-0.

The Wolves team were known as the Buckley Babes, after their flamboyant manager, Major Frank Buckley. His emphasis was very much on youth. He had fielded the 16-year-old outside-left, Jimmy Mullen, later to become an English international of renown, in the FA Cup semi-final of 1939. The team, moreover, were supposed to derive their pace and energy from monkey glands, though this may be the stuff of legend.

At all events, they were red-hot favourites to win the final at Wembley, against a seemingly workaday Portsmouth team. But when the book which players of each team were expected to sign before the game was brought from the Wolves dressing-room into Portsmouth's, the Pompey players suddenly decided they were on to a good thing. So nervous were the Wolves team that their signatures were shaky and illegible. Portsmouth won at a canter, 4-1.

Salt may have been rubbed into Cullis's wounds by the fact that following tradition, Madame Tussaud's waxwork display featured models of the two captains shaking hands before the game; Cullis himself, and Portsmouth's Jimmy Guthrie. Usually, those models would be in place for only a year. But since "official" football was abandoned in 1939, Cullis and Guthrie remained their waxwork selves till after the FA Cup Final of 1946.

In the era of the third back game and the stopper centre-half, Cullis was sometimes misnamed an attacking centre-half; a figure which had long disappeared from British football. But he was certainly what you might call a footballing centre-half. Though strong in the tackle and capable in the air, he was skilful and composed on the ball. The sight of him coolly holding off the challenge of several Scottish forwards when playing for England at Wembley on a snow-covered pitch in January 1942 was one not easily forgotten.

He was, perhaps, polished rather than elegant. His arms-akimbo style led his fellow England players to nickname him Flipper. But he had their deep respect, not least throughout the war, when he was the centre of a famous half-back line, with the two Everton players Cliff Britton and Joe Mercer on either side of him. His use of the ball, besides, was always shrewd. All three players, like so many professional footballers, were drafted into the Army Physical Training Corps. This meant being based at Aldershot, and the little local Third Division football club was thus able to field the England half-back line in its entirety as "guest" players.

Cullis, who never lost his Black Country accent, would have won infinitely more than his 12 international caps had wartime internationals been officially recognised. As it was, he did have the satisfaction of playing in one of England's most triumphant pre-war games, when they thrashed the German team 6-3 in May 1938 in the Olympic Stadium, Berlin, after being obliged to give the Nazi salute.

Eddie Hapgood of Arsenal, a celebrated captain of England himself, picked Cullis in his best-ever team, calling him "an intelligent, defensive centre-half who varied his play by attacking when the situation warranted this method. Stanley has mannerisms which sometimes annoy onlookers, but nothing ruffles him. He goes his own way, thoughtfully, always looking for the opportunity of a crack down the middle."

Hapgood also told the tale of how Cullis surprised the other England players on tour in Europe, after they had been teasing him about his study of foreign languages. Always a great one for self-improvement, a night-school man, Cullis was known to have applied himself to Esperanto; and to French. An England player who had been foremost in the taunting challenged Cullis to ask a Frenchman for directions. Far from being discomfited, Cullis conversed with the man in fluent French.

His playing career came to a disappointingly early end, for those who admired him. Serving with the army in Europe, he inevitably lost fitness and returned early in 1946 for an embarrassing game for Wolves against Arsenal at Tottenham, so short of pace that he was most untypically reduced to grabbing his opposing centre-forward, Reg Lewis, by the shirt, to the scorn of the crowd.

He recovered form to captain Wolves with flair and authority in the first post-war official season, which began with a shattering 6-1 win against Arsenal. Wolves seemed odds on for the Championship, but an appalling winter with its endless cancellations extended the season well into the summer. Wolves faltered on the harder going, and lost their last match at home to Liverpool - and with it lost the title to their opponents.

So, at only 31, and after 152 League games for Wolves, Cullis retired to become assistant manager, then, in 1948, manager itself. He would prove a highly motivated and successful one, though his tactics did not endear him and his team to everyone. He proved a powerful, authoritarian figure. Most of his players would have died for him, but there were those, youngsters especially, who later complained that he had treated them harshly.

Wolves' methods were deeply influenced by the theories of Charles Reep, a retired RAF wing commander, who had worked as an accountant. In those pre-computer days, Reep's elaborate theories of match analysis were expounded in the old News Chronicle in an infinity of squiggly diagrams. The essence of the theory was that the ball should be propelled into the danger zones as quickly as possible, ideally with long passes. So the premium was on pace and power, rather than ball-play and an elaborate build-up.

"Flying wingers" were the essence of Wolves' game, and Cullis had them par excellence in the now mature Jimmy Mullen, on the left, and little Johnny Hancocks, bought cheaply from nearby Walsall, on the right. They poured their centres into the penalty box where such attackers as Jesse Pye, bought from Notts County as an inside-right but converted to centre-forward, exploited them with foot or head.

Sitting in the press box in front of Cullis, when he himself was above in the directors' box - managers didn't then shout and scream from the dug out - could be a revealing experience. "Tip-tap, tip-tap," he would acidly say when the passes weren't long enough for him. "Here it comes, the classical stuff!" And, when a throw-in went wrong, "That's Clamp's classical throw-in, see?" To be followed by a satisfied, "Thump-thump, thump-thump!" when the long balls started going in.

However controversial the style, there was no doubt about the consistent success. And the superb individual goal which the red-haired Irish international inside- forward Sammy Smyth scored for Wolves when they beat Leicester 3-1 in the 1949 Cup Final at Wembley would have graced any team.

Cullis had the ideal adjutant in his, and England's captain, Billy Wright, a blond wing-half of boyish enthusiasm, who later in his career became a fine centre-half and was always, like Cullis himself, a Wolves player.

Famous floodlit victories were won at Molineux against Hungary's then formidable Honved (3-2), despite the presence of six of the Hungarians who had humbled England at Wembley; Moscow Dynamo (2-1) and Moscow Spartak (4-0). Wolves won the League championship in 1954, 1958 and 1959, finished runners-up in 1950, 1955 and 1960, and came third in 1953 and 1956. They also lifted the FA Cup in 1949 and in 1960, though Blackburn, their victims, were reduced to 10 men. In the dressing room afterwards one saw the humorous side of Cullis, lamenting that the cup was a nuisance: "You have to take it to this flopping fete and that flopping fete." He never swore.

In Europe, however, Wolves' style was much less effective and there were two memorable thrashings - by a polyglot Barcelona, notably in the mud of Molineux, when five goals were conceded.

Wolves slid away in those early 60s, living in the shadow of Manchester United and Matt Busby. In September 1964 they dropped the pilot. Cullis was rather shabbily dismissed, and Wolves have never really been the same since.

After vowing not to return to football and spurning a big offer from Juventus, Cullis re-emerged as manager of Birmingham City a year later, but somehow the virtue seemed to have gone out of him and he could not conjure up the same success. After leaving Birmingham in 1970, he worked in a photography business. In 1992, Wolves and Aston Villa played a testimonial match for him, and there are plans for a statue outside Molineux.

His wife Winifred predeceased him, and he is survived by his son, Andrew, who became a vicar, and daughter, Susan.

He was, perhaps, polished rather than elegant. His arms-akimbo style led his fellow England players to nickname him Flipper. But he had their deep respect, not least throughout the war, when he was the centre of a famous half-back line, with the two Everton players Cliff Britton and Joe Mercer on either side of him. His use of the ball, besides, was always shrewd. All three players, like so many professional footballers, were drafted into the Army Physical Training Corps. This meant being based at Aldershot, and the little local Third Division football club was thus able to field the England half-back line in its entirety as "guest" players. Cullis, who never lost his Black Country accent, would have won infinitely more than his 12 international caps had wartime internationals been officially recognised. As it was, he did have the satisfaction of playing in one of England's most triumphant pre-war games, when they thrashed the German team 6-3 in May 1938 in the Olympic Stadium, Berlin, after being obliged to give the Nazi salute. Eddie Hapgood of Arsenal, a celebrated captain of England himself, picked Cullis in his best-ever team, calling him "an intelligent, defensive centre-half who varied his play by attacking when the situation warranted this method. Stanley has mannerisms which sometimes annoy onlookers, but nothing ruffles him. He goes his own way, thoughtfully, always looking for the opportunity of a crack down the middle." Hapgood also told the tale of how Cullis surprised the other England players on tour in Europe, after they had been teasing him about his study of foreign languages. Always a great one for self-improvement, a night-school man, Cullis was known to have applied himself to Esperanto; and to French. An England player who had been foremost in the taunting challenged Cullis to ask a Frenchman for directions. Far from being discomfited, Cullis conversed with the man in fluent French. His playing career came to a disappointingly early end, for those who admired him. Serving with the army in Europe, he inevitably lost fitness and returned early in 1946 for an embarrassing game for Wolves against Arsenal at Tottenham, so short of pace that he was most untypically reduced to grabbing his opposing centre-forward, Reg Lewis, by the shirt, to the scorn of the crowd. He recovered form to captain Wolves with flair and authority in the first post-war official season, which began with a shattering 6-1 win against Arsenal. Wolves seemed odds on for the Championship, but an appalling winter with its endless cancellations extended the season well into the summer. Wolves faltered on the harder going, and lost their last match at home to Liverpool - and with it lost the title to their opponents. So, at only 31, and after 152 League games for Wolves, Cullis retired to become assistant manager, then, in 1948, manager itself. He would prove a highly motivated and successful one, though his tactics did not endear him and his team to everyone. He proved a powerful, authoritarian figure. Most of his players would have died for him, but there were those, youngsters especially, who later complained that he had treated them harshly. Wolves' methods were deeply influenced by the theories of Charles Reep, a retired RAF wing commander, who had worked as an accountant. In those pre-computer days, Reep's elaborate theories of match analysis were expounded in the old News Chronicle in an infinity of squiggly diagrams. The essence of the theory was that the ball should be propelled into the danger zones as quickly as possible, ideally with long passes. So the premium was on pace and power, rather than ball-play and an elaborate build-up. "Flying wingers" were the essence of Wolves' game, and Cullis had them par excellence in the now mature Jimmy Mullen, on the left, and little Johnny Hancocks, bought cheaply from nearby Walsall, on the right. They poured their centres into the penalty box where such attackers as Jesse Pye, bought from Notts County as an inside-right but converted to centre-forward, exploited them with foot or head. Sitting in the press box in front of Cullis, when he himself was above in the directors' box - managers didn't then shout and scream from the dug out - could be a revealing experience. "Tip-tap, tip-tap," he would acidly say when the passes weren't long enough for him. "Here it comes, the classical stuff!" And, when a throw-in went wrong, "That's Clamp's classical throw-in, see?" To be followed by a satisfied, "Thump-thump, thump-thump!" when the long balls started going in. However controversial the style, there was no doubt about the consistent success. And the superb individual goal which the red-haired Irish international inside- forward Sammy Smyth scored for Wolves when they beat Leicester 3-1 in the 1949 Cup Final at Wembley would have graced any team. Cullis had the ideal adjutant in his, and England's captain, Billy Wright, a blond wing-half of boyish enthusiasm, who later in his career became a fine centre-half and was always, like Cullis himself, a Wolves player. Famous floodlit victories were won at Molineux against Hungary's then formidable Honved (3-2), despite the presence of six of the Hungarians who had humbled England at Wembley; Moscow Dynamo (2-1) and Moscow Spartak (4-0). Wolves won the League championship in 1954, 1958 and 1959, finished runners-up in 1950, 1955 and 1960, and came third in 1953 and 1956. They also lifted the FA Cup in 1949 and in 1960, though Blackburn, their victims, were reduced to 10 men. In the dressing room afterwards one saw the humorous side of Cullis, lamenting that the cup was a nuisance: "You have to take it to this flopping fete and that flopping fete." He never swore. In Europe, however, Wolves' style was much less effective and there were two memorable thrashings - by a polyglot Barcelona, notably in the mud of Molineux, when five goals were conceded. Wolves slid away in those early 60s, living in the shadow of Manchester United and Matt Busby. In September 1964 they dropped the pilot. Cullis was rather shabbily dismissed, and Wolves have never really been the same since. After vowing not to return to football and spurning a big offer from Juventus, Cullis re-emerged as manager of Birmingham City a year later, but somehow the virtue seemed to have gone out of him and he could not conjure up the same success. After leaving Birmingham in 1970, he worked in a photography business. In 1992, Wolves and Aston Villa played a testimonial match for him, and there are plans for a statue outside Molineux. His wife Winifred predeceased him, and he is survived by his son, Andrew, who became a vicar, and daughter, Susan. Stanley Cullis, footballer and manager, born October 25 1916; died February 27 2001

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Police 'stop and search' declines
fields.body:
Police 'stop and search' declines

The number of people stopped and searched by police has fallen to its lowest level since 1997, according to Home Office figures published yesterday.

Police in England and Wales used stop and search powers 857,000 times in the year 1999/2000, compared with nearly 1.1m the previous year.

Boxer tagged for assault

Former world heavyweight boxing champion Herbie Hide was yesterday ordered to wear an electronic tag for four months after being convicted at Norwich magistrates' court of assaulting a civil servant in a nightclub.

Boxing authorities are deciding whether Hide, 29, of Bawburgh, Norfolk, can fight with the tag.

Cathedral fire was arson

The fire at Coventry cathedral this week is being treated as arson, police said yesterday.

Insurance experts have been assessing whether the blaze in the basement could have caused lasting damage to priceless works of art.

Two crushed by dustcart

Two men were crushed to death and a woman was badly injured last night when a dustcart overturned on their car on the M1 at Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire.

The dustcart driver was taken to hospital with minor injuries and shock.

24 for trial over attack

Magistrates at Reigate, Surrey, yesterday sent 24 people for trial at Guildford crown court in connection with an attack on a hunt kennels when a cottage was stoned and a police car wrecked.

fields.headline: Defendants 'implicated' in earlier near disaster
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Perry Wacker and Ying Guo were both implicated in a previous attempt to smuggle illegal immigrants to the UK less than two months before the fatal transport in June, Maidstone crown court was told.
fields.body:
Perry Wacker and Ying Guo were both implicated in a previous attempt to smuggle illegal immigrants to the UK less than two months before the fatal transport in June, Maidstone crown court was told.

During this crossing a similar tragedy was narrowly avoided when 50 Chinese concealed inside a lorry driven by Leo Nijveen began to run out of oxygen.

On April 5 2000 Nijveen, a friend and colleague of Wacker's, boarded the 3.30am crossing from Zeebrugge to Dover with a container lorry, ostensibly to deliver yoghurt. Also in his truck were 50 Chinese illegal immigrants attempting to seek asylum in the UK.

"During the crossing those in the container realised they were running out of air," said Victor Temple QC, for the prosecution.

"Fortunately they managed to attract Nijveen's attention and he released them. Fifty Chinese were rounded up by the crew and immigration officers then interviewed them."

When asked if any of them had relatives or friends in the UK, seven gave Ying Guo's name and telephone number, variously describing her as a friend, relative, or friend of a relative, Mr Temple said.

Nijveen was arrested but released without charge as there was insufficient evidence to indicate that he knew the Chinese were on board.

Documents found in the cab carried Wacker's fingerprints as well as Nijveen's, and indicated that Wacker knew of the transport, the jury heard.

"These confirm the closeness of the relationship [between Wacker and Nijveen]," Mr Temple said.

"It is inconceivable that Nijveen did not tell Wacker about what happened ... especially as his lorry was impounded and the firm charged £10,000."

fields.headline: African queen
fields.trailText: One of the most celebrated images in African art - the 500-year-old face of a queen mother who never saw her son after he became king, but fought for him in war - goes on show in a permanent British Museum exhibition on Saturday.
fields.body:
One of the most celebrated images in African art - the 500-year-old face of a queen mother who never saw her son after he became king, but fought for him in war - goes on show in a permanent British Museum exhibition on Saturday.

The brass head is that of Idia, mother of Esigie, ruler of Benin, which is now part of Nigeria, in a period when Henry VII and Henry VIII were kings of England.

Near it, in the museum's new African galleries, is a less striking but older artefact, a manilla, a bronze bracelet which has become one of the world's commonest forms of ornament. When it was found in Igbo-Ukwu, Nigeria, it was assumed to be an imitation of a design imported by western colonisers. But this manilla is from the 9th or 10th century AD, long before colonisation.

The exhibition marks Africa's heritage to the world by displaying 600 works in metal, wood, brass, pottery and other materials. It is the biggest show yet of the total of 200,000 African artefacts in the museum's ethnography collection, now back under one roof after 30 years in the Museum of Mankind in London.

Its centrepiece is a wall of 93 brass figures taken from the front of the Benin king's palace after the British conquered the territory in 1893. Of these the masterpiece is queen mother Idia's head. Her son was born in 1504 and died in 1550.

John Mack, senior keeper, said: "Unlike previous mothers of future kings, Idia was not put away when her son was crowned. Instead he created the title of Iyoba (queen mother) and built a palace for her.

"She consulted him through intermediaries but the two never again saw each other face to face."

fields.headline: Sir Charles Fletcher-Cooke
fields.standfirst: Tory MP whose ministerial career ended abruptly over his relationship with a Borstal boy
fields.trailText: Tory MP whose ministerial career ended abruptly over his relationship with a Borstal boy.
fields.body:
Sir Charles Fletcher-Cooke QC, the Tory MP for Darwen, Lancashire, from 1951-83, and Home Office minister from 1961-63, who has died aged 86, was both whimsical and highly intelligent. He will probably be remembered for the press photograph of him looking like a frightened gargoyle taken in the wake of the incident that ended his promising ministerial career. Homosexuality was then still a prison offence. The press pack had been alerted that the police had arrested his handsome 18-year-old friend Andrew Turner, a delinquent with three convictions, driving Fletcher-Cooke's Austin Princess without a driving licence or insurance.

He resigned his ministerial office on the pretence that he had only been "misguided" in trying to help Turner. Fletcher-Cooke continued to serve Darwen, and its troubled textile industry, until its boundaries changed in 1983.

A number of his fellow Tories had it in for him, because he could not control his barrister's trick of scoring off the less clever. Some right-wingers, like Sir Cyril Osborne, did not forgive his left-of-centre "one nation", pro-European approach, attributing it to his early political beginnings as a Labour candidate in 1945 in East Dorset, which he missed winning by only 1,500 votes. The Sunday Express was fond of quoting his statements from the time, like "Ethically and practically, socialism is indisputably correct and its application by a Labour government will produce order and beauty"

He was born into a professional London family, impoverished because his father had died from his Gallipoli wounds. Both he and his older brother John held scholarships at Malvern College. A further scholarship took him to Peterhouse, Cambridge, where he was both editor of Granta and president of the Union in 1936, emerging with a first.

In 1938, he qualified for the Bar, winning first-class honours, and began as a Chancery barrister. With MJ Albery, he produced a textbook on monopolies and restrictive practices. From 1939-45 he went into wartime intelligence, emerging as a lieutenant-commander on the Joint Intelligence Staff. After his near-miss in East Dorset, he resigned as Labour candidate for Poole in 1948, attributing his "deconversion" to his experience as Britain's official legal adviser in the 1948 Danube Conference after two years working on British properties seized by the Romanian and Yugoslav communist regimes.

He was runner-up for the Darwen nomination for the 1951 election, but finally selected when the candidate, Vyvyan Adams, drowned. Fletcher-Cooke won by 3,180 votes, and in 1958 became a QC. His slightly supercilious whimsy stood out among mostly stodgy Tory MP lawyers. He claimed that Greek Orthodox clerics were anti-British because Britain had shorn them of their tax-gathering powers.

He defended his constituency, claiming that visitors would not find there "the crowded couch of incest among warrens of the poor". But mostly he sought to protect local textile factories against Indian tariff barriers and the growth of Hong Kong's exports. In the late 1950s, he became preoccupied with foreign affairs, emerging as secretary of the Tory MPs' foreign affairs committee and of the executive of the European movement.

In 1958, he urged the UN to set up an authority to oversee the abolition of all weapons of mass destruction. His future seemed rosy in 1959 when he was re-elected with a bigger majority, and married Lady Avebury, the former actress Diana King. Promotion came at last in 1961, when he was named under-secretary of state at the Home Office. He enlivened proceedings by departing from civil service replies: he insisted there was no evidence that a high proportion of crimes of violence were committed by psychopaths, although it had been suggested that Joan of Arc, Napoleon and Lawrence of Arabia all had psychopathic personalities.

The only touchy subject he handled was to deny the existence of a homosexual underground in appointments to residential youth establishments. In February 1963, an informer tipped off the press that the Borstal boy Andrew Turner was living with Fletcher-Cooke. His wife said: "We are separated"; they divorced in 1967. The prime minister, Harold Macmillan, accepted his resignation with brutal brusqueness. With the support of his constituency association, Fletcher-Cooke continued as Darwen's MP, and was knighted in 1981.

fields.headline: Dame Ruth Railton
fields.standfirst: The National Youth Orchestra's founder, she believed in the liberating effect of creative endeavour
fields.trailText: The National Youth Orchestra's founder, she believed in the liberating effect of creative endeavour.
fields.body:
Slender, wiry, other-worldly, but with a manner that could be intimidating as well as endearing, Dame Ruth Railton, who has died aged 85, was a strange mixture of fantasy and realism, a disciple of the liberation of human creativity by whatever means.

She is most likely to be remembered for founding the National Youth Orchestra in 1947 and the Junior Music School, but she was also interested in psychic research and always described her interests as "everything".

She was born in Folkestone, of wealthy parents who had connections with the Salvation Army. After St Mary's School, Wantage, and the Royal Academy of Music, she became director of music or choral work for several schools, before deciding after the war to act on her theory that the practice of music could be liberating - even for those who did not intend to take it up as a career.

Then, as now, only a minority of youngsters - such as Sir Simon Rattle and Mark Elder - became professional musicians after going through the NYO. Her first idea was to found a full-time junior school of music. But she decided that costs would be too high and that it would be more practicable to leave general education to the ordinary schools, and compress a musical education into holiday courses.

Sometimes the orchestra went abroad - Hamburg, Berlin, Brussels, Amsterdam, Paris - and some of the most distinguished musicians of the day were soon pleased to conduct it when they realised that Ruth Railton's ear for budding talent ensured disciplined enthusiasm in lieu of experience.

Her methods were invigoratingly unconventional, drawing on a vivid imagination combined with a ruthless talent for realpolitik. She once settled a difference of opinion on the interpretation of Stravinsky by announcing crushingly, "Why, I danced at the first performance of The Rite of Spring!" By the time the opposition had worked out that she could not have been born at the time, their case had been lost and she had moved on. She thought nothing of commanding British Rail to halt expresses at obscure stations so that her orchestra could get on or off, and usually got what she wanted.

Those who endured her auditions were apt to describe them as the most harrowing experiences of their lives. The school, too, was apt to be wearing on the nerves of the more timid. When some pupils became noisy in the corridors, Dame Ruth stopped one of the offenders and demanded: "You! Don't speak! Tell me what you think you are doing!"

Musically her aim was clearer and slightly less disorientating: she wanted the players to sound as if they meant it. It was her great gift to have the power to establish an orchestral tradition in spite of the rapid turnover of young players. The NYO regularly showed well against established orchestras - notably at the Proms - and several records sold equally well.

Ruth Railton became a Dame in 1966, but it was not until 1993 that the story of her orchestra, Daring To Excel, was published. Her marriage to Cecil Harmsworth King, Lord Northcliffe's nephew and head of the Mirror group, was an unexpected alliance of two individuals not obviously designed for marriage.

The Daily Mirror naturally supported the National Youth Orchestra, though few readers ever heard it, and King regarded his wife with dry amusement as a law unto herself. His affection for her was fully reciprocated. None of the political strife which involved him - as when he rashly campaigned to get Harold Wilson toppled and was toppled instead by the IPC board - really got to her. She was a governor of the Royal Ballet School from 1966 to 1974, and after King's death in 1987, she first lived in their home outside Dublin, then swapped it for a flat nearer the city centre. She continued to attend NYO concerts or annual open meetings for ex-members, laughing at any suggestion that she had ever intimidated anybody: a creative fantasist to the last.
