fields.headline: Childcare benefits count for nothing
fields.trailText: Executive women are positive and confident about their future. They do not regard their gender as an issue in the workplace and believe childcare benefits, stock options and prestigious titles are of little or no importance.
fields.body:
Executive women are positive and confident about their future. They do not regard their gender as an issue in the workplace and believe childcare benefits, stock options and prestigious titles are of little or no importance.

The findings of a new pan-European survey of middle and senior ranking female executives suggest that women in management positions across the continent now believe that they are being treated quite fairly at work.

Nevertheless, 28% still believe it is important to look physically attractive at work. However there are big national variations, with 46% of German women, compared to just 8% of UK women, making an effort with their appearance at work.

Similarly only 6% of British women thought it important to be feminine in their work role - compared to 48% in France and 41% in Italy.

But flirting for promotion is out across the continent. Only 3% of European women think it is a route to success - with the "flirtiest" being Germans, and even then, only 6% of them turn on the charm.

The survey, commissioned by the Wall Sreet Journal Europe and conducted by Lieberman Research, shows that women across Europe rate job satisfaction as the most important characteristic, although being promoted and paid fairly - and having a life outside work - were also extremely important.

Most women executives feel there is no difference whether they work for, with or supervise a man or woman. Broken down, French, Italian and Swedish women - 40%, 36% and 7% respectively - felt they worked better for a male boss. Only 13% of British women thought women made better supervisors.

The "Queen Bee" syndrome - where women at the top actively do down female competitors - is also a thing of the past, according to the survey.

Only 11% of the 1,114 women who took part in the survey thought women competed with them.

Childcare benefits were the bottom of the executive women's wish list. The survey shows that they simply want to earn good money and make their own decisions about how to solve their childcare issues.

Four in 10 women across Europe worry that they will miss out on promotion while they are away on maternity leave - although only a third in the UK.

Three quarters of women in the survey were mothers, and half felt their country's laws provided enough maternity leave. In the UK 61% of women were happy with their maternity leave provisions - even though the legal requirements in Britain are below those of other European countries.

Forty per cent of the British respondents also said that their company policies on maternity leave were better than the legal minimum.

Europe-wide, 80% of women feel that female executives are treated equally to men.

Over half of Italian women believe there are more female executives in top jobs than there were five years ago, while only 38% of women in the UK thought there had been any increase in the numbers of high ranking females.

fields.headline: Scientists upgrade the 'Big One'
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Revised calculations by scientists based on the devastating earthquake in India last month suggest that the type of subterranean faults that led to parts of Gujarat being levelled could produce quakes of similar magnitude in Los Angeles.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and Tim Radford
fields.body:
Revised calculations by scientists based on the devastating earthquake in India last month suggest that the type of subterranean faults that led to parts of Gujarat being levelled could produce quakes of similar magnitude in Los Angeles.

The earthquake that caused nearly 20,000 fatalities in India on January 26 registered 7.7 on the scale.

It had been assumed that the kind of fault known as a "blind thrust", common to both areas, was not capable of producing earthquakes of greater than 7.3 magnitude. But this week the research team monitoring California's earthquake potential said that it would have to revise its estimates to 7.7 after the Indian earthquake.

An increase of 0.4 magnitude at that point on the Richter scale would produce an earthquake with 2.5 times more energy.

Researchers in California now believe that there is a 70% probability of a major earthquake in San Francisco Bay Area within the next 30 years.

The earthquake that killed 67 people and caused $7bn (about £4.9bn) in damage in the Bay Area in 1989 registered 7.1 on the scale.

The 1994 quake centred in a Los Angeles suburb, Northridge, which killed 60 and was linked to a blind thrust fault near Los Angeles, registered 6.7.

"[Gujarat] sort of raises the bar for what the maximum earthquake-detection threshold is for blind thrust faults," said William Lettis, an earthquake hazard consultant and a member of the research team, which is sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute.

Blind thrust faults are smaller faults created over time along main faultlines. They run far below the surface rock.

In the case of California's San Andreas fault, they threaten the plains that lie to the west.

The 1994 earthquake in the Los Angeles suburb of Northridge awakened the area to the fact that it was 10 miles above this hazard.

Great segments of rock strata had suddenly ridden one over the other, creating shockwaves but leaving no evidence on the surface that anything much had happened.

Since January 1994 the Granada Hills around Northridge have risen by 15cm, researchers say: in effect, the quake is quietly continuing.

Another blind thrust fault runs almost 30 miles from downtown Los Angeles to the Coyote Hills in northern Orange county. It has yet to show what it can do.

Just a few days ago the San Francisco area felt a small tremor registering 4.4 and centred 11 miles to the east of San Jose in Silicon Valley. The effects were felt for around five minutes.

While Californians are used to minor earthquakes - they all have their own earthquake experience story - the new findings indicate that if the "Big One" does come it could be even more serious than expected.

Thrust faults tend to be particularly damaging to tall buildings, because they accelerate vertically.

webTitle: Prince 'feels deeply' for rural community's plight

fields.headline: Prince 'feels deeply' for rural community's plight
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales last night voiced sympathy for farmers hit by the foot and mouth outbreak and said the rural community had suffered "miserably" for years.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales last night voiced sympathy for farmers hit by the foot and mouth outbreak and said the rural community had suffered "miserably" for years.

Prince Charles used an anniversary party for Radio 4's The Archers to say how deeply he felt for farmers and others, such as hauliers, who face losing their livelihoods.

The prince praised the drama for its handling of the foot and mouth crisis, and said its broadcasts would help to explain to the wider public about the "frightening" outbreak.

Producers on the programme have been working frantically to insert last-minute items to reflect the latest crisis gripping the rural community.

The prince said last night: "The quick reaction to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease ... would have helped explain to the non-farming community how desperate and frightening the outbreak is to farmers and the rural community." Press Association

fields.headline: Lesbian triangle 'led to murder bid'
fields.standfirst: Accused woman attempted suicide, court told
fields.trailText: A lesbian police sergeant tried to kill her fellow officer girlfriend and then commit suicide because she believed her lover was having an affair with a third policewoman, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A lesbian police sergeant tried to kill her fellow officer girlfriend and then commit suicide because she believed her lover was having an affair with a third policewoman, a court was told yesterday.

Inspector Sara Glen, 31, described how she had desperately tried to fight off her lover Sergeant Tina Nash, 41, who had pinned her down and proceeded to strangle her using a T-shirt as a ligature until she blacked out.

Miss Glen told a jury at Bristol crown court she had thought she was dead when Nash attacked her as she slept during the night of March 31 last year.

Relations had become strained after she had tried to end her relationship with Nash. The situation deteriorated further after Nash became intensely jealous of a blossoming friendship between Miss Glen and another policewoman, Sergeant Katherine Willoughby, the court heard.

Miss Glen told the court Miss Willoughby had expressed feelings for her. She said she told her she just wanted a break from relationships to clear her head.

The couple, both of whom are serving officers in the Hampshire force, had gone to bed at Miss Glen's flat in the village of Bartley, in the New Forest, when the incident happened, Miss Glen said.

She described waking to find Nash on top of her pulling a ligature tighter and tighter round her neck.

"Her knees were either side of my arms and she was sat astride me with my arms underneath her knees. I could not move. I tried to push up and it was quite clear I couldn't. The ligature just got tighter and tighter round my neck and the force was very strong," she said.

She added: "I remember thinking I was going to die and there was nothing I could do. I remember it going very black and very, very quiet. I thought 'So this is what it feels like to be dead'."

Mark Dennis, prosecuting, told the jury that Nash, who had taken a cocktail of 34 paracetamol tablets and wine in an attempt to kill herself, had left Miss Glen for dead, although she later came round.

"It was a premeditated and determined attack done at a time when she could no longer cope with the breakdown of the relationship," he said.

Mr Dennis told the jury Miss Glen called for an ambulance when she came round because she was concerned about the state of her girlfriend, the defendant.

But he said that she hid when paramedics arrived because she was terrified about publicity.

The jury heard how Nash made no comments about the incident when she was interviewed by detectives. But Mr Dennis said she told officers: "I'm very much in love with Sara. I never wished to do her any harm."

Nash, of Cowplain, near Portsmouth, denies attempting to murder Miss Glen, but Mr Dennis told the jury she had admitted causing her actual bodily harm.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Five killed in minibus accident
fields.trailText: Five people were killed and two were injured when their minibus was involved in a collision with a heavy goods vehicle last night.
fields.body:
Five people were killed and two were injured when their minibus was involved in a collision with a heavy goods vehicle last night.

The accident happened on the B4336 between Llanfihangel-ar-arth and Llanllwni, 12 miles north of Carmarthen, west Wales, police said.

Five people were confirmed dead at the scene and at least two others were taken to the West Wales general hospital in Carmarthen, Dai Davies, Dyfed Powys police spokesman, said.

It was understood that the five dead had been travelling in the minibus. All were believed to be from the local area.

Mr Davies said one of the casualties had been a woman, but could not yet confirm specific details of anyone else involved.

He added: "The lorry driver is injured, but I believe he is alive. There were no children involved. As far as we know they were all adults. It was a horrific, tragic accident in which five people lost their lives."

The cause of the crash remained unclear. But he confirmed the minibus had caught fire and ended up in a hedge at the side of the road following the impact.

Mr Davies said weather conditions had not been particularly bad at the time of the accident.

Dyfed Powys police said names were not being released until the victims' families were informed.

 In another incident, an elderly woman in a car ended up stranded on a railway line at Petersfield, Hampshire, last night, police said.

Inspector Mark Wise of Hampshire police said the woman became confused at a level crossing, turned right and partially drove on to the track.

Mr Wise said the level crossing on the lane was a half barrier type. He added: "We have been able to avert possibly a major incident at this location."

webTitle: New leader in top rank of women

fields.headline: New leader in top rank of women
fields.standfirst: Scardino ousted by dot.com wunderkind
fields.trailText: Two years ago, the name Fabiola Arredondo was unknown. Today, she will be named as the most influential businesswoman in Europe. The Spanish-American thirtysomething heads a list of 30 women regarded as the most inspirational female business figures.
fields.body:
Two years ago, the name Fabiola Arredondo was unknown. Today, she will be named as the most influential businesswoman in Europe. The Spanish-American thirtysomething heads a list of 30 women regarded as the most inspirational female business figures.

The top 30 was assembled by a panel of business professors for the Wall Street Journal Europe. They assessed nearly 150 women executives in Europe, ranking each in terms of influence in their industries and in European business.

Ms Arredondo ousted Marjorie Scardino, the Texan-born chief executive of the Pearson media empire and still the only female chief of a FTSE 100 company.

In fashion, the top ranked woman is Donatella Versace, just ahead of Miuccia Prada. Elisabeth Murdoch and Marina Berlusconi - daughters of two of the world's biggest media moguls, also make the list, along with Marianne Nivert, the president and chief executive of Telia, Sweden's equivalent of BT, and Anne Lauvergeon, the chief executive of French nuclear reprocessing and recycling group Cogema.

Julie Meyer and Martha Lane Fox -along with Ms Arredondo - are the female face of the dot.com business world. The photogenic Ms Meyer founded networking group First Tuesday.

Computers have generated two of the top 30 - Olga Dergunova, the boss of Microsoft Russia and Isabel Aguillera, director-general of Dell Spain. The male-dominated world of motor manufacturing has produced two more - Ford's Barbara Kux and Citroen's Magda Salarich.

Top five

1 Fabiola Arredondo Former head of Yahoo!'s European arm

At first glance Fabiola Arredondo seems an unlikely candidate for holder of the title of Europe's most influential businesswoman.

But for those who know her, the recognition is just another step in the seemingly relentless rise of the woman who has come to symbolise a new breed of dot.com wunderkinds.

American-born to Spanish parents, Ms Arredondo has shattered in spectacular fashion the glass ceiling that stops women from reaching the top of corporate life.

Until last month she was head of the European operations of Yahoo!, the huge US internet portal. Appointed in 1997 to what was then a 13-person outfit, she has turned it into a multi-country operation with 500 employees and a revenue of £79m.

The success led to flatter ing cover stories in Newsweek, appearances on Question Time and a position as a government adviser on the future of media and communications.

Today she is expected to outline for the first time the secret "private business interests" that prompted her to quit Yahoo!.

Ms Arredondo, the wife of Pret A Manger sandwich chain chief executive Andrew Rolfe, arrived in the UK armed for success, having completed her education at Stanford and Harvard universities and speaking five languages.

She had got a taste of Wall Street with investment bank JP Morgan and worked in the media industry with BMG, the record label owned by German communications group Bertelsmann. BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the BBC, managed to snaffle her as distribution director until her eye was caught by the internet.

But friends say she left as she found working for a public service-owned organisation frustrating. Her new venture is likely to see her in total control. Her star is in the ascendancy again. John Cassy

2 Marjorie Scardino From shrimp farming to 'first lady'

Marjorie Scardino has come a long way from running a shrimp farming business in the deep south of the US. In the four years since becoming chief executive of Pearson, owner of the Financial Times and Penguin Books, she has become used to the title of the "first lady of the Footsie".

She has had to. As the only woman chief executive in the FTSE 100, Ms Scardino has no competition. She is also part of another trend - that of hiring managers from overseas to run British companies from Marks & Spencer to Barclays and BA.

After an initially lukewarm reception from the City, the Texan-born executive has built unflagging support in the Square Mile. She turned Pearson from a rambling collection of assets to a focused media business, selling broker Lazards, Madame Tussaud's and Mindscape, the CD-rom maker. The disposals, she once said, were so obvious "even a blind monkey could have done them".

In their place she has bet on the online education market with a series of US acquisitions.

Pearson's television assets were merged last year with those of CLT-Ufa in RTL, Europe's largest TV and radio group. She is also a director of America Online.

Ms Scardino, 53, who retains a southern lilt, entered the media when she launched a Pulitzer Prize-winning Savannah newspaper with her journalist husband Albert. Despite critical acclaim, the paper was not a commercial success. She joined the US edition of the Economist, in which Pearson had a stake, eventually becoming chief executive and trebling circulation.

Ms Scardino has since performed the same trick with Pearson's valuation, nearly trebling it to £12bn.

A glowing profile in the Atlanta Journal noted that she now lives in "Knightsbridge, an elite London neighbourhood, and socialises with English nobility". David Teather

3 Clara Furse Accepting LSE, the 'poisoned chalice'

Clara Furse has leaped spectacularly into the limelight this year with her new job as chief executive of the London Stock Exchange. The 43-year-old mother of three is the first woman to hold the post and was a surprise choice for the job, which many regard as a poisoned chalice.

But she came with a track record that may make her an ideal choice to restructure the organisation that not so long ago operated like a gentleman's club but which now needs to be a tough, hi-tech commercial business.

She may favour chic little suits in baby blue and pastel pink, but Ms Furse is regarded as a woman with an iron fist and a steel will.

Her background is in the complex world of derivatives. She was previously head of Credit Lyonnais Rouse, where she wielded the jobs axe and introduced new technology. She has also been deputy chairman of Liffe.

Born in Canada to Dutch parents, she has lived in the UK since she was a teenager and speaks Dutch, German, Spanish and French. Julia Finch

4 Donatella Versace Platinum brain pushes designs to new heights

Donatella Versace was once regarded as little more than her brother's little sister and muse. But after Gianni's murder in Miami in 1997 the woman with the trademark curtain of platinum hair took over as both the business and design brains behind the Milan fashion house and the multimillion lire empire has gone from strength to strength.

When he died, she said, "I knew what I had to do. I never thought about stopping. I felt Gianni telling me what I had to do."

Ms Versace - age kept secret - dresses the world's A-list celebrities. Last year she was Madonna's bridesmaid.

She has altered the style of Versace. The trademark raunchy dresses have not been eradicated but the designs have moved away from the overtly sexual towards a cooler, simpler chic.

Ms Versace has little time for women who do not work. "I would not design for a woman who does not work because a woman must have a relationship with the world," she said recently.

5 Anita Roddick Maverick with an eye on the wider horizon

As businesswomen go, Anita Roddick is undoubtedly one of the most influential, unusual and eccentric of her generation.

It is now more than 25 years since Ms Roddick set up shop in Brighton, with a £4,000 bank loan on a platform of rejecting animal testing and embracing ethical trading practices. In that time the Body Shop has expanded to an 1,800-shop international empire and created a £30m fortune.

Yet Ms Roddick insists she is uninterested in money. She drives a 10-year-old VW Golf, often takes public transport and has told her daughters that they will not inherit her millions. "Far better to give it away," she says.

In recent years the Body Shop has had problems and Ms Roddick has transferred her attention to wider issues, like human rights and globalisation.

She recently took time to "travel with hobos" in the US. She is a director of the Ruckus society, which runs a camp teaching the tactics of peaceful civil disobedience. Julia Finch

She had got a taste of Wall Street with investment bank JP Morgan and worked in the media industry with BMG, the record label owned by German communications group Bertelsmann. BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the BBC, managed to snaffle her as distribution director until her eye was caught by the internet. But friends say she left as she found working for a public service-owned organisation frustrating. Her new venture is likely to see her in total control. Her star is in the ascendancy again. John Cassy 2 Marjorie Scardino From shrimp farming to 'first lady' Marjorie Scardino has come a long way from running a shrimp farming business in the deep south of the US. In the four years since becoming chief executive of Pearson, owner of the Financial Times and Penguin Books, she has become used to the title of the "first lady of the Footsie". She has had to. As the only woman chief executive in the FTSE 100, Ms Scardino has no competition. She is also part of another trend - that of hiring managers from overseas to run British companies from Marks & Spencer to Barclays and BA. After an initially lukewarm reception from the City, the Texan-born executive has built unflagging support in the Square Mile. She turned Pearson from a rambling collection of assets to a focused media business, selling broker Lazards, Madame Tussaud's and Mindscape, the CD-rom maker. The disposals, she once said, were so obvious "even a blind monkey could have done them". In their place she has bet on the online education market with a series of US acquisitions. Pearson's television assets were merged last year with those of CLT-Ufa in RTL, Europe's largest TV and radio group. She is also a director of America Online. Ms Scardino, 53, who retains a southern lilt, entered the media when she launched a Pulitzer Prize-winning Savannah newspaper with her journalist husband Albert. Despite critical acclaim, the paper was not a commercial success. She joined the US edition of the Economist, in which Pearson had a stake, eventually becoming chief executive and trebling circulation. Ms Scardino has since performed the same trick with Pearson's valuation, nearly trebling it to £12bn. A glowing profile in the Atlanta Journal noted that she now lives in "Knightsbridge, an elite London neighbourhood, and socialises with English nobility". David Teather 3 Clara Furse Accepting LSE, the 'poisoned chalice' Clara Furse has leaped spectacularly into the limelight this year with her new job as chief executive of the London Stock Exchange. The 43-year-old mother of three is the first woman to hold the post and was a surprise choice for the job, which many regard as a poisoned chalice. But she came with a track record that may make her an ideal choice to restructure the organisation that not so long ago operated like a gentleman's club but which now needs to be a tough, hi-tech commercial business. She may favour chic little suits in baby blue and pastel pink, but Ms Furse is regarded as a woman with an iron fist and a steel will. Her background is in the complex world of derivatives. She was previously head of Credit Lyonnais Rouse, where she wielded the jobs axe and introduced new technology. She has also been deputy chairman of Liffe. Born in Canada to Dutch parents, she has lived in the UK since she was a teenager and speaks Dutch, German, Spanish and French. Julia Finch 4 Donatella Versace Platinum brain pushes designs to new heights Donatella Versace was once regarded as little more than her brother's little sister and muse. But after Gianni's murder in Miami in 1997 the woman with the trademark curtain of platinum hair took over as both the business and design brains behind the Milan fashion house and the multimillion lire empire has gone from strength to strength. When he died, she said, "I knew what I had to do. I never thought about stopping. I felt Gianni telling me what I had to do." Ms Versace - age kept secret - dresses the world's A-list celebrities. Last year she was Madonna's bridesmaid. She has altered the style of Versace. The trademark raunchy dresses have not been eradicated but the designs have moved away from the overtly sexual towards a cooler, simpler chic. Ms Versace has little time for women who do not work. "I would not design for a woman who does not work because a woman must have a relationship with the world," she said recently. 5 Anita Roddick Maverick with an eye on the wider horizon As businesswomen go, Anita Roddick is undoubtedly one of the most influential, unusual and eccentric of her generation. It is now more than 25 years since Ms Roddick set up shop in Brighton, with a £4,000 bank loan on a platform of rejecting animal testing and embracing ethical trading practices. In that time the Body Shop has expanded to an 1,800-shop international empire and created a £30m fortune. Yet Ms Roddick insists she is uninterested in money. She drives a 10-year-old VW Golf, often takes public transport and has told her daughters that they will not inherit her millions. "Far better to give it away," she says. In recent years the Body Shop has had problems and Ms Roddick has transferred her attention to wider issues, like human rights and globalisation. She recently took time to "travel with hobos" in the US. She is a director of the Ruckus society, which runs a camp teaching the tactics of peaceful civil disobedience. Julia Finch

fields.headline: The perils of loyalty
fields.standfirst:
Clinton's supporters stood by him through thick and thin. Then he let them down

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As he left office, Clinton used a customary presidential prerogative to grant a large number of pardons. But the baroque squalor of this list of fraudsters, drug dealers and tax dodgers floored even Clinton's most craven apologists.
fields.body:
As the Lewinsky impeachment hearing came to an end, a joke in Washington said that Bill Clinton was a man who goes through a car-wash in an open-topped car, and everyone gets wet except him. With the startlingly awful manner of his leave-taking from the White House, Clinton has finally been drenched. But then so, once again, has everyone else who has had anything to do with him or ever defended him. This man's career stands as a dreadful warning against the perils of solidarity and loyalty.

As he left office, Clinton used a customary presidential prerogative to grant a large number of pardons. But the baroque squalor of this list of fraudsters, drug dealers and tax dodgers floored even Clinton's most craven apologists. Most egregious of all was the pardon to Marc Rich, an immensely rich financier, whose money was made dealing with South Africa under apartheid, Iran under the Ayatollah terror, and Iraq under Saddam. Rich holed up in Switzerland for many years rather than face charges of vast tax evasion.

Even by Clinton's standards it was a pardon too far - and was followed by an explanation too far. Roughly speaking, Clinton said that "the Jews made me do it, them and their money". He had been persuaded to see the merits of Rich's case, Clinton said, by Israeli and Jewish-American lobbyists who had been in receipt of Rich's largesse.

Worse still, this was true. The Israelis who pleaded for him included the departing prime minister Ehud Barak and the rightwing mayor of Jerusalem, Ehud Olmert (who was bunged $25,000 by Rich). In America, there were Abra ham Foxman, head of the Anti-Defamation League, and Rabbi Irving Greenberg, who wrote his request for a pardon on the letterhead of the US Holocaust Memorial Council, which he chairs.

All of this looks like a cruel parody designed by a malicious anti-semite to bolster age-old prejudices about the cunning of international Jewry and the power of Jewish money. To some Jews it looks more like a travesty of a genuine and honourable usage of communal solidarity and mutual help.

Rabbi Eric Yoffie, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, has attacked those Jewish- American leaders with a savagery a non-Jew could not easily match. By allowing themselves to be "bought" by Rich, he says, they "have undermined our community's moral fabric, jeopardised our political standing, disillusioned our youth and compromised the sacred values of our tradition". Another way of putting it is that they have allowed instincts of solidarity to be twisted into mere omerta , unconditional loyalty with no questions asked.

B ut then isn't that the story of the Clinton presidency? For all its eight years, it has illustrated the dangers of team spirit, and the limits of "my enemy's enemy is my friend". That can be a good principle in diplomacy and an essential one in wartime. Yet it is a dangerous maxim in politics and a disastrous one in any moral discourse.

The liberal-left supported Clinton as the lesser evil, or because he was their enemies' enemy. And look where it led them. Democrats stuck by Clinton while he abandoned every principle of the party. "Progressives" stuck by him while he moved ever further to the right. Most painful of all was the way feminists stuck by him. At best, his attitude to women was the most boorish kind of droit du seigneur ; at worst it seems to have been rape in the full sense. But he was "pro-choice", wasn't he?

You need to be on guard against the distorting effects of "the peculiar loathing" the Clintons have attracted from the American right, the Guardian warned the other day. Surely it is more impor tant to be on guard against the distorting effects of team spirit, of what the Poles used to call "partyness", of "my country right or wrong".

Almost Clinton's first prominent appearance on the national stage was when he returned to his home state, for reasons of personal political calculation, to be present when a brain-damaged black man was put to death. Was it rightwing to feel revulsion? At the height of the Lewinsky scandal, he sent American aircraft, for reasons of personal political calculation, to bomb a harmless pharmaceutical factory in Sudan and kill an innocent man. Is it "peculiar" to loathe the man?

The most poignant, or piteous, reaction to the Rich pardon came from Richard Cohen of the Washington Post. Speaking for all those who had loyally supported Clinton over the years, he ad dressed the former president: "I now have this to say: You let me down. Yes 'me' - me and everyone else who has ever defended you _ You may look bad, Bill, but we look just plain stupid."

Perhaps this accusation really is unjust. It scarcely took the Rich pardon to make Cohen and others like him look stupid for standing by their man for so long. "The moral stain of this sordid affair has begun to engulf us," Rabbi Yoffie wrote about Rich. But then the moral satin of Clinton's career has engulfed very many people for years past.

At least Hillary Clinton and the Friends of Bill might spare us any more bleating about a vast rightwing conspiracy which has blackened his name. And maybe the Israeli government will hesitate to give Marc Rich a state funeral, as it did Robert Maxwell.

webTitle: Trials offer hope of Alzheimer's remedy

fields.headline: Trials offer hope of Alzheimer's remedy
fields.trailText: Researchers have managed to clear away the notorious plaques that form on the brain in Alzheimer's disease.
fields.body:
Researchers have managed to clear away the notorious plaques that form on the brain in Alzheimer's disease. They applied antibodies directly through tiny holes in the skull and got rid of most of the plaques in three to eight days after treatment.

The experiment so far has only worked on mice, according to a report in Nature Medicine today. There is no way of knowing whether the treatment also restored memory, or brain function. But it showed something unexpected: that the degeneration of a mammal brain might be reversible.

Alzheimer's disease is fast becoming the fourth biggest killer in the developed world: the memory loss and confusion that adds up to senile dementia is marked by the formation of puzzling plaques or amyloid-beta deposits in the working parts of the brain. In 1999, scientists with Elan Pharmaceuticals found they could prevent the formation of these plaques in Alzheimer-prone mice by vaccinating them with a protein found in those plaques.

Today, working with a medical team, they reveal that they cleared away 70% of these plaques after they had formed.

"No one has ever directly demonstrated the clearance of amyloid-beta deposits," said Brian Bacskai, a neurologist at Massachusetts general hospital. "This was an especially surprising process because it was so rapid. It really took only a few days for what looks to be almost complete clearance of amyloid-beta deposits."

 Microbiologists at the Independent University of Barcelona said yesterday that the protein-based brain damage of BSE and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease might also be reversible. The evidence comes from observation of protein behaviour in bacteria.

webTitle: Youth jail 'a stain on prison system'

fields.headline: Youth jail 'a stain on prison system'
fields.standfirst:
Chief inspector condemns 'breathtaking' neglect

Special report: policing crime
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The treatment of teenagers held at Brinsford young offenders' institution, near Wolverhampton, is condemned as a "stain on the prison system" in an official inspection report published today.
fields.body:
The treatment of teenagers held at Brinsford young offenders' institution, near Wolverhampton, is condemned as a "stain on the prison system" in an official inspection report published today.

Bullying is so rife that it was a significant factor in at least two out of five suicides in eight months, says the report by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons.

He describes the inspection, in June last year, as "one of the most disturbing that my team and I have carried out".

It disclosed a level of neglect and lack of understanding of the young prisoners' needs that was "breathtaking".

Sir David says he was particularly angered to discover that such bad conditions still existed within a young offenders' institution despite similar damning reports into Feltham, London; Glen Parva, Leicestershire; Portland, Dorset; and Werrington, Staffordshire.

"That conditions as disgraceful as those at Brinsford exist is shameful enough, but the fact that this report follows similar situations at other [young offenders' institutions] is inexcusable," says the chief inspector, particularly in the face of the government's concentration on youth justice.

"This should never have been allowed to happen by the prison service itself, but I am sorry I did not intervene earlier to ensure the treatment afforded to young prisoners was of an acceptable standard."

Sir David promises to return to Brinsford in six months' time but says he "fears, on the evidence of past experience, nothing may have happened to rectify the situation".

The inspection report details the lack of any workshops and the limited opportunities for association and exercise, with too many young people spending far too much time locked in their cells.

The inspection team itself saw evidence of bullying and concluded that staff had either surrendered to what they regarded as the inevitable or were fighting a rearguard action.

Sir David says he was disappointed to find that only lip service was being paid to the implementation of new child protection measures.

Youth jails were brought within the provisions of the Children Act, which are supposed to lead to the intervention of outside social services staff when children are found at risk of abuse.

The chief inspector found that while the child protection log had been set up at Brinsford, no cases had been entered into it.

Martin Narey, the director-general of the prison service, claimed that significant progress had been made at Brinsford since the inspection, including the provision of more than 20 hours a week of purposeful activity out of prisoners' cells.

"As Sir David knows, the introduction of functional management across the juvenile estate from April 1 will give additional scrutiny to the management of under 18s at Brinsford, and ensure greater consistency," he said.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Shutdown shortcut | Defragging
fields.body:
Shutdown shortcut
I read recently about a shortcut to shut down Windows without going through the Start menu. Could you tell me how to do it? Linda Waddington
linda_wad@yahoo.com.

Jack Schofield replies: It is a bad idea to shut down too quickly, as Microsoft has found with Windows 98SE and Me on some very fast computers. IDE hard disk drives store data in their own cache memories before writing it to the hard drive. Windows has no way of knowing if the drive has finished the job. In a fast shutdown, cached data may be lost, leading to corrupted files. Microsoft has therefore released a patch to add a two-second delay to the shutdown process. See article Q273017 at http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/ rticles/q273/0/17.asp

However, there are a number of utilities that provide a more convenient shutdown routine. Examples include CloseFast 2000 <a href="http://www.davecentral.com/12045.html ), ShutDown NOW! ( www. dworld.de ) and ShutDownKing ("www.shutdownking.de/ english/ ). I have not tried them. You can also learn how to make your own shutdown button very easily at the PC Clinic at www.md4pc.com/questions/05.htm .

Defragging
When I run Defrag, I find it keeps restarting because "disk contents have changed". I was told that this could be cured by using Control-Alt-Delete to end all tasks except Explorer and Systray, but I still experience the problem with Defrag and Scandisk. I have Windows 98SE. Michael Ennals
michael@mjennals.icom43.net

JS: Your approach should work. Sometimes it doesn't.

The easiest way to run Scandisk is to go to Start|Shutdown and select Restart in MS-DOS Mode. Simply type Scandisk at the C:\WINDOWS> prompt.

To run Disk Defragmenter, either restart your PC in Safe Mode or try a "clean boot". Microsoft's help file describes both approaches in article Q186978 at http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/q186/9/78.asp

Anti-virus time
I have a 486 laptop running Windows 3.1 but it has no CD. Where can I get an anti-virus program for it? I also have a desktop PC with internet access so I could download a program that will fit on a floppy. Cowan Ervine
carol@ervine.freeuk.com

JS: I recommend Frisk Software's F-Prot for DOS, which is small and free for personal use. You can download a copy from www.complex.is/f-prot/Download.html (FP-Win costs $25 for one year's use). The file is too big for a floppy, but you can unzip it on your desktop PC before copying it. The most recent version was launched on January 18. Sign.def , the virus definition file, dated February 16, is only 830K.

You could copy large files to your laptop using a compression program that spans disks. For example, with WinZip 7, you can use Windows Explorer to create a new archive on a floppy, such as A:\massive.zip (or whatever). Use the mouse to drag and drop files into that. When the floppy is full, WinZip will ask for another. However, you cannot do this with an existing zip file, and you cannot remove files once the archive occupies more than one disk.

Before scanning for viruses, you should boot your PC from a write-protected floppy disk that is known to be virus-free. This could be the Windows Startup Disk created when the operating system was installed, or the one you made as soon as you got your new PC.

To make one, go to Start|Settings|Control Panel and double-click the icon for Add/Remove Programs. Click on the tab for Startup Disk, then click the button labelled Create Disk.

Capitals offence
My version of Microsoft Word gives me a capital at the beginning of a line when it is not wanted. How can I eliminate it? Eric Liggett
eliggett@onetel.net.uk

JS: That is Intellisense being helpful. Go to Tools|AutoCorrect and untick the box that says Capitalize first letter of sentences. Clicking on tabs such as AutoText and AutoFormat As You Type will let you disable other annoying functions.

Which OS?
I'm thinking of buying a computer to replace my Windows 95 machine. I would like to be able to use the printer, scanner, Zip drive and favourite old games I own. Should I choose Windows ME or Windows 2000? I've checked various manufacturers' web sites and all provide Windows 2000 drivers for the hardware I want to use, but not all offer drivers specifically for Windows ME. Chris Doncaster
christopher.doncaster@ntlworld.com

JS: Windows 2000 is a far better operating system but it was not designed for home users. Having tried the upgrades, I'm sticking with Windows 98SE with IE5 and Windows Media Player 6.4 until Windows XP (eXPerience) is launched, possibly in September. XP is Windows 2000 for consumers, and has a "cool" new interface. See www.winsupersite.com/showcase/windowsxp_luna.asp.

Cold comfort
My 233MHz PC used to work superbly. Recently, however, it seems to suffer from the cold and appears to need warming up to function properly. After starting up it runs for about two minutes and then freezes. It needs another two or three stop-starts before it gets into its stride and works perfectly. Is it just getting old, like me? Will it be better in the summer? Keith Clark
Keith.S.Clark@ks2728.freeserve.co.uk

JS: I would guess the most likely cause is a loose connec tion. Take the lid off and make sure all the memory chips, expansion cards, cables and power plugs are securely plugged in. (Make sure the power is off, and that you are not carrying an electrostatic charge.) It might also be a cracked motherboard, or a faulty power supply, though the hardware geeks out there may have other suggestions. Temperature changes can create tiny differences that may have an effect, but I can't think of a simple way to isolate the problem.

Outlook poor
Where do I find Outlook, please? This is apparently required to synchronise my Psion Revo. Brian Casey
brigantia13@hotmail.com

JS: Outlook is the PIM (Personal Information Manager) included as part of Microsoft Office, and (says Microsoft) supplied with PocketPC handheld computers. It provides a calendar, addressbook, to-do list, email client and other functions. Many people have their data in Outlook and want to transfer it to their handheld, so synchronising with Outlook is important.

Psion does not provide it, though at least it now includes PsiWin, so you can back up your Revo to a Windows PC. If you feel the need to buy Outlook 2000, it is available separately for about £90. The Revo also synchs with, for example, Lotus Organizer.

For example, with WinZip 7, you can use Windows Explorer to create a new archive on a floppy, such as A:\massive.zip (or whatever). Use the mouse to drag and drop files into that. When the floppy is full, WinZip will ask for another. However, you cannot do this with an existing zip file, and you cannot remove files once the archive occupies more than one disk. Before scanning for viruses, you should boot your PC from a write-protected floppy disk that is known to be virus-free. This could be the Windows Startup Disk created when the operating system was installed, or the one you made as soon as you got your new PC. To make one, go to Start|Settings|Control Panel and double-click the icon for Add/Remove Programs. Click on the tab for Startup Disk, then click the button labelled Create Disk. Capitals offence My version of Microsoft Word gives me a capital at the beginning of a line when it is not wanted. How can I eliminate it? Eric Liggett eliggett@onetel.net.uk JS: That is Intellisense being helpful. Go to Tools|AutoCorrect and untick the box that says Capitalize first letter of sentences. Clicking on tabs such as AutoText and AutoFormat As You Type will let you disable other annoying functions. Which OS? I'm thinking of buying a computer to replace my Windows 95 machine. I would like to be able to use the printer, scanner, Zip drive and favourite old games I own. Should I choose Windows ME or Windows 2000? I've checked various manufacturers' web sites and all provide Windows 2000 drivers for the hardware I want to use, but not all offer drivers specifically for Windows ME. Chris Doncaster christopher.doncaster@ntlworld.com JS: Windows 2000 is a far better operating system but it was not designed for home users. Having tried the upgrades, I'm sticking with Windows 98SE with IE5 and Windows Media Player 6.4 until Windows XP (eXPerience) is launched, possibly in September. XP is Windows 2000 for consumers, and has a "cool" new interface. See www.winsupersite.com/showcase/windowsxp_luna.asp. Cold comfort My 233MHz PC used to work superbly. Recently, however, it seems to suffer from the cold and appears to need warming up to function properly. After starting up it runs for about two minutes and then freezes. It needs another two or three stop-starts before it gets into its stride and works perfectly. Is it just getting old, like me? Will it be better in the summer? Keith Clark Keith.S.Clark@ks2728.freeserve.co.uk JS: I would guess the most likely cause is a loose connec tion. Take the lid off and make sure all the memory chips, expansion cards, cables and power plugs are securely plugged in. (Make sure the power is off, and that you are not carrying an electrostatic charge.) It might also be a cracked motherboard, or a faulty power supply, though the hardware geeks out there may have other suggestions. Temperature changes can create tiny differences that may have an effect, but I can't think of a simple way to isolate the problem. Outlook poor Where do I find Outlook, please? This is apparently required to synchronise my Psion Revo. Brian Casey brigantia13@hotmail.com JS: Outlook is the PIM (Personal Information Manager) included as part of Microsoft Office, and (says Microsoft) supplied with PocketPC handheld computers. Psion does not provide it, though at least it now includes PsiWin, so you can back up your Revo to a Windows PC. If you feel the need to buy Outlook 2000, it is available separately for about £90. The Revo also synchs with, for example, Lotus Organizer.

webTitle: Youth jail 'a stain on prison system'

fields.headline: Youth jail 'a stain on prison system'
fields.standfirst: Chief inspector condemns 'breathtaking' neglect
fields.trailText: The treatment of teenagers held at Brinsford young offenders' institution, near Wolverhampton, is condemned as a "stain on the prison system" in an official inspection report published today.
fields.body:
The treatment of teenagers held at Brinsford young offenders' institution, near Wolverhampton, is condemned as a "stain on the prison system" in an official inspection report published today.

Bullying is so rife that it was a significant factor in at least two out of five suicides in eight months, says the report by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons.

He describes the inspection, in June last year, as "one of the most disturbing that my team and I have carried out".

It disclosed a level of neglect and lack of understanding of the young prisoners' needs that was "breathtaking".

Sir David says he was particularly angered to discover that such bad conditions still existed within a young offenders' institution despite similar damning reports into Feltham, London; Glen Parva, Leicestershire; Portland, Dorset; and Werrington, Staffordshire.

"That conditions as disgraceful as those at Brinsford exist is shameful enough, but the fact that this report follows similar situations at other [young offenders' institutions] is inexcusable," says the chief inspector, particularly in the face of the government's concentration on youth justice.

"This should never have been allowed to happen by the prison service itself, but I am sorry I did not intervene earlier to ensure the treatment afforded to young prisoners was of an acceptable standard."

Sir David promises to return to Brinsford in six months' time but says he "fears, on the evidence of past experience, nothing may have happened to rectify the situation".

The inspection report details the lack of any workshops and the limited opportunities for association and exercise, with too many young people spending far too much time locked in their cells.

The inspection team itself saw evidence of bullying and concluded that staff had either surrendered to what they regarded as the inevitable or were fighting a rearguard action.

Sir David says he was disappointed to find that only lip service was being paid to the implementation of new child protection measures.

Youth jails were brought within the provisions of the Children Act, which are supposed to lead to the intervention of outside social services staff when children are found at risk of abuse.

The chief inspector found that while the child protection log had been set up at Brinsford, no cases had been entered into it.

Martin Narey, the director-general of the prison service, claimed that significant progress had been made at Brinsford since the inspection, including the provision of more than 20 hours a week of purposeful activity out of prisoners' cells.

"As Sir David knows, the introduction of functional management across the juvenile estate from April 1 will give additional scrutiny to the management of under 18s at Brinsford, and ensure greater consistency," he said.

fields.headline: Straight talking
fields.standfirst: Black rappers rant loudly against gays and lesbians. Many black preachers and activists echo their sentiments. Now a controversial new book asks why the black community can't come to terms with the truth about its sexuality.  Dave Hill reports
fields.trailText: Black rappers rant loudly against gays and lesbians. Many black preachers and activists echo their sentiments. Now a controversial new book asks why the black community can't come to terms with the truth about its sexuality. Dave Hill reports.
fields.body:
Few who saw it will forget it. There was Shabba Ranks, Jamaica's rude, lewd, skirt-chasing dance floor superstar, explaining to the audience of Channel 4's The Word that he was at one with the Bible in believing all the "batty boys" should be put to death. And there was stand-in presenter Mark Lamarr, with his retro-rockabilly sideburns and crest of gleaming hair, getting more and more annoyed until he finally exploded: "That's crap, and you know it!"

The optimistic view that Planet Pop is a place where barriers of race, sex and sexuality dissolve into a universal live-and-let-live rhythm took a nasty jolt that night in 1994. Two cultures clashed with clamorous incomprehension: a black heterosexual braggart invoking the good book to justify his view that every gay man should be slain; a white media figure representing a young, western postmodernity for which homophobia is every bit as wicked as racism. After two decades in which the Big Beat had been associated, implicitly or directly, with progressive social movements of some or other kind, here was a spectacle that seemed to reflect rather more than a spat between two well-known people on a gross-out TV show.

Here was a divide that seemed to run disturbingly along racial lines. Yes, white rockers Guns 'n' Roses sang songs of queer-bashing too, just as Eminem does now. But Shabba Ranks was only one among many high profile black musicians loudly and proudly giving grief to gays. Nor was the sentiment restricted to raggas and rappers. Black preachers, black activists and black politicians were at it too, not only from the Caribbean and North America, but also from Africa and all points between, including Britain.

Of course, homophobia was running deep in plenty of white communities too. But suddenly, it was as if no force on this earth united its people of colour quite like their loathing of the Queer Nation. There were, though, pockets of dissent. Among those watching The Word that night was Delroy Constantine-Simms, born and raised in a council estate in Wolverhampton but very much a citizen of the world. Growing up in the 70s, his black identity was influenced by his revolt against the pentecostal churches he was forced to attend both by his family at home and his relatives in the Bronx, and by his interest in the funkier pan-African take on black existence offered by Jah Rastafari.

Homosexuality, though, was a far more distant country. At least, it was until the day he spotted a black friend walking through Wolverhampton holding another fellow's hand. "When I followed them around a corner, I saw the two of them kissing. I thought, 'Oh my God.' I was in a state of shock." Also, he was angry. That was partly because he was disgusted, and partly because he felt betrayed: "He was always going on about 'those gays, they're this and that'. I thought it was hypocrisy." It was a bit sickening too, because his friend was extremely popular with the ladies, including one or two whom Constantine-Simms would have liked to be more popular with himself.

Two important things came out of the experience. One was that his friend, having been spotted in the closet, felt an obligation to stop hogging the womenfolk's affections: "It was a bonanza for me on the girl front," recalls Constantine-Simms, warmed by the memory. The other important thing was that when, a few years later, Shabba Ranks came on the box preaching extermination in the name of the Lord, it spurred Constantine-Simms, by then a freelance writer and researcher, to stir up a more constructive rumpus around the touchy subject of blackness, gayness and the links between the two.

The result is a book called The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in Black Communities, a collection of academic essays by mostly American writers that contend, among other things, that same-sex exploitation and desire are the parts of slavery that black historians won't face up to, that the Bible offers no sort of guidance for anyone's sexual morality, and that those ever-swaggering, fag-baiting, women-hating, cock-clutching crews of hip-hop boys have got more of the Greek about them than they would wish to admit.

Not surprisingly, it's this final assertion, elaborated in the book by the Rolling Stone critic Touré, that has brought Constantine-Simms to the attention of the black public in this country. He made the front page of the Voice under the headline "Hip-Hop Has Gay Roots", accompanied by a piece predicting that his views were "set to cause outrage in the black community."

Constantine-Simms told the Voice that much hip-hop sartorial style goes back to dress codes in prisons where black inmates became gay "husbands" or "wives", and that the street fashion for low-slung, baggy trousers is a throwback to black male prostitutes of the 40s who wore them to assist easy access for their clients.

And then there's the sheer, relentless, exclusive boys-togetherness of rap performers themselves, perhaps protesting their super-masculinity just a bit too much: "As in so many homosexual political fantasies," Touré writes, "homophobia is a mask for gayness." He also observes: "Gangsta rappers en masse have much in common with drag queens."

How does the big bad Puff Daddy respond? His thoughts are yet to be recorded. But the Voice has had calls from indignant chaps in saggy slacks, and Constantine-Simms has received some unpleasant emails at the Blacknet website where he is news editor. Despite warm comments from black women, he detects much stony disapproval, especially from the churches.

"There's a lot of confusion there," he believes. "On the one hand the Europeans gave them the Bible, on the other they see the same white culture taking liberal attitudes to homosexuality." There is also, he argues, a deep defensiveness within black Britain that, while understandable, makes it resist debates that present a challenge to conservative beliefs. "We're small and closely knit, and I have gone against the grain. People see what I have done as earning a dirty living."

The book covers a wide territory, from the concealed potentials of the outwardly heterosexist Million Man March to sometimes dense deconstructive studies of entertainment icons, including the soul singer Luther Vandross and basketball stars Dennis Rodman - a sensational cross-dresser - and Magic Johnson.

One of the most fascinating sections is Charles Clifton's re-reading of slave narratives, so central to the efforts of civil rights-minded historians to reveal the untold stories of a collective black past. Clifton detects in some slave texts the subtle airbrushing of any form of erotic experience that would have offended the Victorian values of the times.

He also challenges what he sees as a failure to address these elisions by those who have promoted slave narratives in the name of black consciousness and self-esteem. Bluntly, the notion of black male slaves either being the humiliated victims of homosexual rape or engaging in consenting gay sexual relations with each other or their white masters, whether for money or for love, does not fit comfortably with the preferred liberationist picture of a proud African people who were beaten but never broken. The former is too shaming, the latter smacks of unmanly collusion.

Constantine-Simms detects that such preoccupations with orthodox masculine mastery drive homophobia, misogyny and the self-destructiveness of men as they strive to achieve impossible manly ideals. And this all impacts destructively on black communities.

His mission, he says, is "to get those communities to talk about it," though it may be a while before they do so with his glee and gusto. "I used go to New York every summer," he recalls, "and one day I was in this park, which I didn't know was popular with black gay guys. There I was with my tight ass in my Lycra cycling shorts, and there were all these guys whistling at me! I thought, 'hey, interesting!' " And how courageous today that he is thinking it out loud.

 The Greatest Taboo: Homosexuality in Black Communities, edited by Delroy Constantine-Simms, is published by Alyson Books and distributed in the UK by Turnaround, priced £12.99.

webTitle: One killed, nine wounded in northern Israel blast

fields.headline: One killed, nine wounded in northern Israel blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Suspected Palestinian militants set off explosives today in an attack in which one person was killed and nine were hurt.
fields.body:
Suspected Palestinian militants set off explosives today in a taxi van after undercover police pursued them for 50 kms (31 miles), stopped the vehicle and tried to arrest them. One person was killed and nine hurt, including three in serious condition, police said.

One suspect, who was seriously wounded, was flown by an Israeli air force helicopter to a hospital, police said. It was not immediately clear how many attackers may have been involved, though police said most of the passengers, among them Arabs and Jews, were innocent bystanders.

The explosion near the Israeli Arab town of Umm el-Fahem came only a day after police safely detonated a bomb in Tel Aviv left in a plastic bag.

Security sources said there might have been a connection between the thwarted Tel Aviv attack and today's explosion. The suspects responsible for today's blast got into the taxi van in Tel Aviv.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility. Israel's deputy defence minister Ephraim Sneh said he believed the explosion was set off by Palestinian militants, possibly activists of the Islamic militant group Hamas or Islamic Jihad. Mr Sneh held Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat responsible for the blast.

"As long as activists of Hamas and the Jihad are walking around free in the West Bank and Gaza, the responsibility is of those who let them walk around freely," Mr Sneh said. "We see the Palestinian Authority as responsible for the situation."

Police also said the assailants were apparently Palestinians. The explosion went off shortly before 2 pm (noon GMT).

Witness Ilan Zvuluni said he was a few car lengths behind the taxi van. "I saw wounded people lying on road, a boy among them."

Soldiers treated some of the wounded, Mr Zvuluni said.

Police said the van had been under surveillance since it left Tel Aviv, about 50 kms (31 miles) away. When the van approached the intersection, "a police car blocked the path of the suspect car," said Bentsi Saar, police commander of northern Israel. "Those sitting in the van, probably terrorists, set off the explosive device," Mr Saar said.

fields.headline: Earthquake rocks Seattle
fields.standfirst:
Thousands flee buildings as tremor is felt 700 miles away

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: A state of emergency has been declared in Seattle after a major earthquake shook the US Pacific north-west yesterday, causing one death, serious injuries and widespread damage in the city. Tremors were felt as far away as Salt Lake City, Utah.
fields.body:
A state of emergency has been declared in Seattle after a major earthquake shook the US Pacific north-west yesterday, causing one death, serious injuries and widespread damage in the city. Tremors were felt as far away as Salt Lake City, Utah.

A man died of a heart attack north of Seattle as a result of the quake, Washington state Governor Gary Locke said. Twenty-five people were injured in the Seattle area, five seriously, according to Jim Mullen, Seattle Director of Emergency Services. Across the state, 163 people were reported injured, three seriously.

Mr Locke said losses could run into billions of dollars. Seattle's corporate pride - Boeing, Microsoft and Starbucks - all sustained damage.

The earthquake, which was measured at 6.8 on the Richter scale, closed the Seattle-Tacoma airport, prompted searches for people trapped in buildings, sent thousands of office workers scurrying into the streets, and brought a technology conference being addressed by the head of Microsoft, Bill Gates, to a dramatic halt.

It struck just after researchers in California had announced that the risks of major damage from a quake in the area were greater than had been expected.

The new assessment was prompted by findings in the wake of last month's devastating earthquake in Gujarat, India, which killed about 20,000.

The epicentre of yesterday's earthquake was about 36 miles south-west of Seattle and 11 miles north-east of the state capital, Olympia.

One of the most powerful quakes in the area for more than half a century, it caused extensive damage in central Seattle and elsewhere in the city.

Flights in and out of the city were immediately halted, as were all train arrivals and departures, while the damage was assessed.

Twenty-five people were injured, four seriously, but the initial reaction was that the city's earthquake preparations had proved largely effective, particularly considering the force of the earthquake.

The tremor began at 10.54am and lasted for about 45 seconds. It caused alarm in Seattle's highrise office buildings which swayed visibly.

"I work downtown, in one of those 'new and earthquake-improved' buildings on rollers or whatever they are, and boy, this thing moved," a local resident, Alicia Kamenick, said.

"I'm still a little freaked out, but it sounds like we were lucky. It was deep enough so there wasn't as much damage as there could have been."

President George Bush described it as "a serious situation" and said he had contacted the federal emergency management agency (Fema), which handles such events, and had been assured that everything was under control.

It emerged yesterday that one of the budget cuts proposed by the new administration is $25m (about £17m) from a Fema programme which prepares communities to deal with earthquakes.

The mayor of Seattle, Paul Schell, said that the preparations made for such eventualities appeared to have paid off. "The city's infrastructure seems to have come through this in pretty good shape," he said.

About 20,000 people lost power as a result of the shock, according to the local utilities board. It was also felt south of Seattle in Portland, Oregon, and picked up by siesmologists in California.

A strong earthquake also shook the capital of El Salvador yesterday. It was reported to be of a magnitude of 5.4.

Tim Radford writes: The Seattle earthquake should not have come as a shock: researchers calculated 10 years ago that while the US north-west seemed fairly stable, it could be subject to the worst seismic violence of all.

The earth's crust is broken into huge plates of rock, grinding and bumping against each other, and most earthquakes and volcanoes are at the spots where they meet.

Seattle, with Vancouver, Canada, and Portland, Oregon, is where a plate of ocean basalt meets the plate bearing the American continent.

Further south, around San Francisco and Los Angeles, two plates slide past each other with an almost continuous rumble of shocks.

Seattle and the cities near it are subject to different forces. Under Seattle, the ocean basalt dives deep into the earth's mantle, throwing up the Cascade mountain ranges, and several volcanoes.

One of these, Mount St Helens, exploded with awesome force in 1980.

But even then, Cascadia was thought to be a relatively safe place. Then seismologists began to ask themselves why there were huge layers of peat buried beneath dunes of sand far inland. The only sensible answer was that tsunamis - so called tidal waves - had repeatedly inundated the coast.

Japanese scientists looking at a sequence of tsunami damage found written evidence of one that washed over their main island, Honshu, 300 years ago.

They calculated that it could only have come from a massive earthquake which must have occurred along the coast near modern-day Seattle on the night of January 26 1700.

Their US colleagues calculated that this quake must have been a magnitude of 9 - an intensity that would release thousands of times more destructive energy than anything seen in history in California.

Twenty-five people were injured in the Seattle area, five seriously, according to Jim Mullen, Seattle Director of Emergency Services. Across the state, 163 people were reported injured, three seriously. Mr Locke said losses could run into billions of dollars. Seattle's corporate pride - Boeing, Microsoft and Starbucks - all sustained damage. The earthquake, which was measured at 6.8 on the Richter scale, closed the Seattle-Tacoma airport, prompted searches for people trapped in buildings, sent thousands of office workers scurrying into the streets, and brought a technology conference being addressed by the head of Microsoft, Bill Gates, to a dramatic halt. webTitle: Eriksson gives his verdict on England's victory

fields.headline: 'Let's hope we can go on like this'
fields.trailText: What manager and players thought about it all.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson was understandably pleased with his first game in charge, although to describe the undemonstrative Swede as delighted would probably be carrying things a bit too far.

"Both the result and the performance pleased me. To win 3-0 is a good result. They created something but we deserved to win," he said.

"The performance, if you take away the first 20 minutes, was very good. It was my first time with the fans and they were marvellous. Maybe we had a few nerves early on but Spain have a very good team. It is not easy to control the game for 90 minutes."

Having spent only three days with the squad he was willing to admit to being encouraged. "It is difficult in the beginning to see new faces and learn the names. We've started very well and let's hope that we can go on like this."

For those players who had failed to make the 31 that were called up he had words of hope. "All English players can come into this squad if they're good enough and the only thing I'm really sorry about is that we couldn't play all of them."

Nick Barmby, one of only four England players to see out the full 90 minutes, was not about to dwell on the result. Instead the Liverpool forward was already looking ahead to the World Cup qualifier against Finland three weeks on Saturday. "It gives us confidence to pick up points in the qualifying campaign. Everyone played well," he felt.

He agreed with his coach that England had made an uncertain start but was at pains to point out that the opposition were intent on a win. "Spain were taking it seriously. Look at their players: Mendieta and Raul and the rest. You see them week in, week out. They were taking it seriously so give credit to England."

Of his own contribution he said: "The goal came when we picked up the pace. We were finding our feet for the first 20 minutes, then we created a lot of chances."

His fellow goalscorer Ugo Ehiogu said: "I was told to be positive and enjoy myself when I came on. You tend to give up hope after being out of the England picture for a long time. This is a learning curve for me. It was nice to be in."

The captain for the night David Beckham added: "It was great to have the armband still and walk out there in front of so many fans. The manager told me last night that I was captain. He said there was no reason to change it and told me to go out and enjoy it and it meant a lot to me."

His role in the side - he would prefer to play in the centre rather than wide right - had not been discussed. "It was hard to notice any difference between England managers. I have only been with the boss for two or three days. His record speaks for itself, though.

"We haven't had a lengthy conversation about where I play. We'll just have to see. I played out wide tonight and it worked well at times."

The surprise selection in the team, the debutant Chris Powell, did not care where he played. He was just happy to be a part of the action. "It was really something I won't ever forget," he said.

fields.headline: Eriksson directs cool running
fields.trailText: So after all the xenophobic ranting, finally there is something to cheer. England seem to have got themselves a coach who knows his job. The omens are good.
fields.body:
After all the xenophobic ranting, finally there is something to cheer. Quietly, for now, but even that is a relief.

At the very least, England have got themselves a coach who knows his job. And, to judge by the saved penalty with whichNigel Martyn preserved a clean sheet on Sven-Goran Eriksson's debut, perhaps a lucky one as well.

After an understandably tentative start at Villa Park against talented opponents, England grew in composure and invention as the evening progressed. Each man understood his task and performed it in a way that made it clear how well Eriksson communicates with his players, of whatever nationality.

Nevertheless, there were gasps of amazement, probably from as far away as Charleroi, when it was announced that his first starting line-up was to include Philip Neville. At least the Swede had twigged that the younger Neville brother is more comfortable at right back than on the left, where he made that disastrous error against Romania last summer. His presence, and that of Chris Powell, strengthened the pre-match suspicion that Eriksson intended to field virtually two complete teams. Given the lack of time available to him before the World Cup qualifying matches, this seemed a perfectly sensible idea.

The team that started the match was otherwise not radically different in personnel or philosophy from those we have seen before, and began the evening with the familiar mixture of good intentions and mediocre execution. For a quarter of an hour the Spanish players' greater finesse reflected the previous evening's display by their Under-21s, who had given their English counterparts such a remarkable lesson in the arts of the game - abetted, of course, by Howard Wilkinson's perverse insistence on playing players such as Owen Hargreaves and Malcolm Christie, inexperienced and probably nervous, out of position. Eriksson certainly has more common sense than that.

The inclusion of five Manchester United players gave the senior team an inherent sense of structure, the Old Trafford contingent no doubt reassured by the presence of Steve McClaren, their club coach, issuing instructions from the touchline. Eriksson's choice of 4-4-2, the formation derided by Wilkinson this week as hopelessly old-fash ioned, also helped the players to feel comfortable as a unit on a night when they must have been experiencing an unusual degree of pressure to justify their selection as individuals.

Neville and David Beckham linked and covered for each other with practised assurance on the right, but the surprise was the contribution made by Powell on the opposite flank. Clearly unimpressed by bigger reputations, he dispossessed Mendieta, skinned Guardiola, and showed great presence of mind when he stood off Raul as the Real Madrid star wriggled into the area. When the opportunities arrived, his crosses were delivered with calm accuracy. Even if he never plays another game in an England shirt, he did himself credit in a way that paid implicit tribute to the talent-spotting abilities of Eriksson and Tord Grip.

Late in the first half England moved up a gear, signalled by a slick move with which Paul Scholes, Nick Barmby and Beckham put Michael Owen through. Four minutes later, the attack that produced Barmby's goal displayed a marvellously lethal simplicity, requiring instant imagination and judgment from Owen and Andy Cole. Thereafter the momentum never left them.

Eriksson would also have been pleased by the unselfishness with which his two first-choice strikers worked for each other. Clearly desperate to score his first goal for England, and unlucky not to do so when Casillas saved his shot after a run across the width of the penalty area, Cole was nevertheless prepared to provide Owen with the chance for a shot which Casillas turned away under the bar a few seconds before half-time.

Another touch of the unexpected, immediately after the interval, came with the arrival of Emile Heskey in place of Beckham, as part of a squadron of substitutes. With Owen and Cole keeping their places, this gave England the option of an out-and-out attacking trident - something Eriksson may have in mind for Albania or Finland, although possibly not when the squad makes the trip to Munich for the rematch with Germany.

Liverpool's leading scorer appeared to take to his role wide on the right with enthusiasm, tracking back to cover the left flank of Spain's attack as willingly as he fastened on to the volley that doubled England's lead.

So impressively had England constructed their moves in the second quarter of the game that Frank Lampard and Gavin McCann were able to come on after half-time and join a midfield which retained its shape and purpose even though three-quarters of its constituents had changed. McCann's first involvement, a pass bent just in front of Cole's run, was a genuine touch of class. Or perhaps that is the effect a good coach can have. And the absence of Steven Gerrard, Steve McManaman, Kieron Dyer, Michael Carrick and Ray Parlour, not to mention the unwillingness to risk Joe Cole after his training-ground injury, put an even healthier complexion on the performance of England's midfield.

It would be unwise to mistake an encouraging beginning for an excuse to start waving the flags. But the hallmark of last night's performance was a confidence that spread throughout the team as the match progressed. If that is Eriksson's first gift to his new charges, it seems unlikely to be his last.
