fields.headline: Taggart dream fades as Northern Ireland crumble
fields.standfirst: Helstad 20, 49; Carew 30, Stensaas 37
fields.trailText: Norway go to Windsor Park in the vain hope of a competitive encounter.
fields.body:
It is hard to see what this match accomplished for either team. Northern Ireland were left soundly beaten and demoralised, and a visiting side who were seeking a competitive encounter hardly had to break sweat in a comfortable victory.

It could have been so different. Gerry Taggart, skipper on the occasion of his 50th cap, should have given the host nation a dream start with a goal after only two minutes. Peter Kennedy whipped in a swerving free-kick but though the Leicester City defender raced into space he ballooned his header high over the bar.

Glenn Ferguson, a part-timer who plays in the Irish League with Linfield, did not look out of place, and after releasing David Healy then Jon McCarthy with precision passes his volley was saved by the Everton keeper Thomas Myhre.

But the whole scenario changed in a 10-minute spell midway through the half. A mistake by Newcastle United's Aaron Hughes presented Thorstein Helstad with a chance he could hardly miss. Hughes attempted to find Maik Taylor with a back-pass which fell hopelessly short, and the Brann hit-man gleefully struck the opening goal.

Northern Ireland were stunned but Norway struck again just on the half-hour, this time Valencia's giant John Carew beating Taylor with a wicked volley.

And with the Irish reeling and struggling to cope against the quicksilver Norwegian attack, Stale Stensaas snatched a third seven minutes before the interval.

Suddenly the controversial comments attributed to the Norwegian manager Nils Johan Semb - that Northern Ireland were not good enough to prepare his side for World Cup qualifiers against Poland and Belarus - didn't look too far off the mark.

Neil Lennon, the target of sectarian abuse from sections of the crowd, was taken off at half-time as Sammy McIlroy understandably opted for a tactical change.

Mark Williams and Stuart Elliott also came on as the Irish switched to a flat back four. But if McIlroy was hoping that his team might still salvage at least some pride he was mistaken; within four minutes Norway added a fourth goal.

Helstad was again the scorer, running through the reshuffled but still ineffective defence to score with a right-foot shot. With the game lost - only Jim Whitley's panicked clearance prevented a fifth - McIlroy opted for further substitutions as both sides relaxed.

Northern Ireland (3-5-2): Taylor (Fulham); Hughes (Newcastle), Taggart (Leicester), Murdoch (Preston); McCarthy (Birmingham), Magilton (Ipswich), Lennon (Celtic), Whitley (Manchester City), Kennedy (Watford); Healy (Preston), Ferguson (Linfield).

Norway (4-5-1): Myhre; Bergdolmo, Lundekvam, Stensaas, Berg; Solskjaer, Tessem, Larsen, Bakke, Helstad; Carew.

Referee: Kenny Clark (Scotland).

webTitle: Enic backs Graham but Bayern move for Campbell

fields.headline: Enic backs Graham but Bayern move for Campbell
fields.trailText: Bayern Munich have entered the market for Tottenham Hotspur's Sol Campbell just as Spurs' new owner Enic promised to try to keep the centre-half.
fields.body:
Bayern Munich have entered the market for Tottenham Hotspur's Sol Campbell just as Spurs' new owner Enic promised to try to keep the centre-half.

Bayern's vice-president Karl-Heinz Rummenigge told the German newspaper Bild: "We're hoping that it will happen. But with a player of his class you're never alone."

Campbell is out of contract in the summer but yesterday David Buchler, the new executive vice-chairman who will be responsible for the day-to-day running of Spurs, said: "I don't think there is any supporter who wouldn't want Sol, Darren Anderton and the rest of our top players to stay, and I am going to do everything I can to persuade them to."

Enic gave the club's manager George Graham a vote of confidence as it moved into White Hart Lane. The English National Investment Company completed its takeover, raising its stake in the club to 29.9%, and Sir Alan Sugar stood down as chairman.

Buchler, a 49-year-old chartered accountant and holder of a Spurs season ticket, said: "We have a manager who has lost only one of the last nine games, and who has led us into the quarter-finals of the FA Cup. That isn't bad and I think we have got to give him credit for that."

But Buchler said there would be no major spending on players until the future of the transfer market was resolved. "It is a case of looking at a club which has money and finding out how to spend it properly in order to achieve the success you want. More than £40m has been spent on players over the past five years and you have to ask why we have not got a successful side."

Middlesbrough's hopes of enticing the Spanish international striker Dani to Teesside have been dashed. The player wants to stay at Barcelona as Patrick Kluivert's understudy. Boro's manager Bryan Robson rekindled his interest in the 26-year-old forward despite having a £12m offer rejected last summer.

The League Managers' Association yesterday insisted that Bruce Rioch did not resign as Wigan's manager although the Second Division club said that he had asked to be "released from his position". In a statement the LMA said: "Having spoken with Bruce Rioch over press reports that he has resigned as manager at Wigan, we are able to categorically state that this is not true."

Lincoln City have appointed the former Grimsby Town manager Alan Buckley to replace Phil Stant, who was sacked on Tuesday.

fields.headline: The verdict on Sven's men
fields.trailText: David James (Aston Villa) 6/10
fields.body:
David James (Aston Villa) 6/10

Made it clear he had no desire to be diving about to impress Eriksson and would be happy with a quiet night. With just one straightforward save to make he got just that.

Phil Neville (Man Utd) 6/10

Surprise starter at right-back. Never beaten but didn't look as dangerous coming forward as Chris Powell. One good cross but hardly made himself undroppable.

Sol Campbell (Tottenham) 7/10

Shown up once by Raul but gave his customary powerful performance, full of strong challenges and important headers . However his distribution from the back remains suspect.

Rio Ferdinand (Leeds) 7/10

Won his share of headers and looked tidy. His most eye-catching contributions, though, were two fine long passes to the left flank and one strong run out of defence.

Chris Powell (Charlton) 7/10

Far from overawed he kept the highly talented Gaizka Mendieta quiet and was never shown up. Also looked dangerous coming forward before his calf strain.

Nick Barmby (Liverpool) 7/10

Scored the first goal of Hoddle's reign and repeated the trick for Eriksson. Good contribution not a natural crossing threat from the left.

Nicky Butt (Man Utd) 6/10

Set the tone with a ferocious early challenge and gave a tenacious display. Unlikely though to retain his place when Steven Gerrard is available.

Paul Scholes (Man Utd) 6/10

Not at his best, though he improved as the first half went on, getting England's first shot on target in the 25th minute and playing some nice passes towards the interval.

David Beckham (Man Utd) 7/10

More peripheral than he would have liked, showing again why his future should lie in the centre. Managed a few decent crosses though.

Andy Cole (Man Utd) 7/10

Made an impressive display, holding the ball up well and showing plenty of neat touches. Looked isolated at times initially but grew in understanding with Owen.

Michael Owen (Liverpool) 7/10

More effective as the deep-lying striker than many had expected, running at players at pace from withdrawn positions. Showed good vision with the pass which released Barmby for the first goal.

webTitle: Arts: Do we need film censorship?

fields.headline: Anything goes?
fields.standfirst: As two controversial new films are passed, chief censor Robin Duval tells  Andrew Pulver  why we still need him
fields.trailText: As two controversial new films are passed, chief censor Robin Duval tells Andrew Pulver why we still need him.
fields.body:
After a quiet few months, the British Board of Film Classification is back in the news. The organisation that certifies our movies, trims our videos and keeps a discreet watch over the activities of the more repulsive end of the moving-image industry is taking it both ways at the moment.

Four days ago, the BBFC passed two controversial foreign-language films: the French rape-revenge drama Baise Moi, and the Mexican parable Amores Perros, with its dog-fighting scenes, as worthy of certification. Four days before that, the BBFC - and specifically its director Robin Duval - drew snarls of rage from a number of newspaper commentators in the wake of an address he gave to the Royal Society of Arts on February 21.

A throwaway line in his closing remarks, that a parental-guidance element might be added to the 12-certificate rating, resulted in a raft of newspaper stories that the BBFC is planning to "decriminalise underage access to films and videos" and pretty much do away with a mandatory ratings system.

From his office in London's Soho Square, Duval is about as annoyed as a careful committee man can get. "We accept absolutely they have a valid point of view," he says, "but we cannot separate this from a sadness that they are not professional enough to check their actual stories with us."

Gripes over, Duval stresses that, as ever, the BBFC is struggling to satisfy the twin demands of aesthetic envelope-pushing (the Baise-Mois of this world) and protecting audiences, and most particularly children, from whatever harm cinematic images may wreak.

"For every piece of research into the causal relationship between film and behaviour, another study will almost always have the opposite results. The only area in which the research is robust enough to stop us in our tracks is in the area of sexual violence." Hence the problems with the rape scene in Baise-Moi, and the decision to cut a single shot. The BBFC's ruling on the film, available on the BBFC website, states that "its extreme sexual imagery is unmatched elsewhere in the rape scene. Without it, the sequence remains a compelling portrayal of the ugliness and horror of rape. With it, the scene takes on a more explicitly pornographic dimension and is a matter of serious concern."

Sex and pornography have been major recent concerns of the BBFC - partly because horror and ultraviolence don't seem to be on the menu so much in a post-Scream universe ("horror just seems to have exhausted itself"), and partly because the climate does genuinely seem to be easing. Tussles with the Home Office and the Video Appeals Committee over the status of the hardcore R18 certificate (a designation for films only available in licensed sex shops) form one end of the scale; sniffing out trouble from the avant-garde form the other.

Duval notes that they passed hardcore shots in The Idiots and Romance, but cites Didn't Do it For Love, an S&M documentary by veteran German subversive Monika Treut (whom he charmingly refers to as "a Scandinavian lady") as a film that fell foul of the BBFC strictures on potentially lethal copycat stuff ("it was to do with asphyxiation"). Sick, the Bob Flanagan film, he considers "very difficult to watch" but "very valuable."

Suggestions that Jack Straw is overly involved in certification decisions meets with an indignant denial. "It's inconceivable that the view of an individual politician would lead us to change our classification of a film. It absolutely doesn't have an input into the decision-making process." Crash, he notes, was passed by the BBFC, but banned by Westminster council; neighbouring Camden, two years ago, allowed the release of an uncertified Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Story of O ("completely unnecessary"; the BBFC, he says, would have passed such dated material with no problem).

It's a possibility that the proposed cross-media regulator Ofcom might take video certification off the BBFC's hands. Any suggestion, however, that the Board itself might disappear is rapidly scotched. Cinema, it seems, is an independent self-regulating industry and will stay that way.

fields.headline: Cullis, Wolves' relentless general, dies
fields.standfirst: Frank Keating remembers a great manager of iron determination
fields.trailText: An XI of legendary English football club managers from the second half of the 20th century would probably comprise Busby, Rowe, Ramsey, Shankly, Paisley, Revie, Robson, Ferguson, Nicholson and Clough . . . with Stan Cullis unquestionably in the team at centre-half. Yesterday Cullis joined the first six in their celestial touchline dugout.
fields.body:
An XI of legendary English football club managers from the second half of the 20th century would probably comprise Busby, Rowe, Ramsey, Shankly, Paisley, Revie, Robson, Ferguson, Nicholson and Clough . . . with Stan Cullis unquestionably in the team at centre-half. Yesterday Cullis joined the first six in their celestial touchline dugout.

On these pages once, John Arlott called Cullis "the passionate puritan", which was probably spot-on. As an implacable but stylish No5, Cullis played 12 times for England (and on a further 20 occasions in wartime matches) but it was with Wolverhampton Wanderers that his name is imperishably coupled.

As a player from 1934-1947 he helped make Wolves a force in the land; then as manager till 1964 he made them a force in the world. He was in the Wolves senior team at 17 and captain at 19; by 22 he was captain of England. "Passionate puritan", sure, and a ruthless disciplinarian as well, but he also brought an enlightened intellect to the game.

Like so many others with much still to offer, he was allowed to drift away from soccer by the Football Association and he had long been a forgotten figure when, out of the blue this winter, a rewarding biography* was published by Jim Holden in which the writer poignantly answered his own question: "You may wonder how Cullis feels about the fall from grace of his beloved Wolves and their endless struggle to recapture the glories he routinely gave them? Sadly, we cannot know. By the time this book was conceived it was too late to ask him . . . his health and his memory too frail, he lives quietly and peacefully in a nursing home in the Malvern Hills, unable to recall the past with any clarity."

Cullis was born, the youngest of 10, in 1916 on the Wirral where his father, a devout Wolves fan, had been "relocated" for the war effort with the Wolverhampton Corrugated Iron Company.

Cullis told me once that his ambition had been to be a "campaigning journalist" and at 16 he was going to night school to that effect when his aptitude for football attracted various league clubs.

His father ordered: "You'll go to one club and no other." It was of course Wolves, then managed by the "martinet of Molineux", Major Frank Buckley, from whom, he said, he "learned to handle footballers with a rigorous authority, and far more iron than velvet in your touch".

Like an old-fashioned No5, in fact. Another sometime Guardian writer, Arthur Hopcraft, described Cullis playing in his heyday: "An intent crouch, bald forehead jutting belligerently forward, he seldom allowed himself a careless contact with the ball. He defined the position 'centre-half' for me, not just by the way he went crushingly into a tackle or hit a long pass firmly to one of his wingers: it was the sternness of the man himself which fixed the role - being a centre-half was an austere responsibility which permitted no frivolous embellishments of manner."

In May 1947 the final match of the season had Wolves playing Liverpool for, in effect, the league title. Liverpool won, and Cullis retired there and then to the manager's office. He at once fashioned a fit and vibrant team - long, direct passes, clever wing play and first-time shooting - and he drove them on with a relentless, impassioned determination. They won three league championships and the FA Cup twice, but most famously - this before official European competition - he arranged what he called "prestige" floodlit matches against foreign opposition in 1954 and 1955. Moscow Spartak were beaten by 4-0, Moscow Dynamo by 2-1, and Honved (with six of the Hungarians who had humiliated England in 1953) by 3-2, which had the Daily Mail's front-page banner proclaiming "Cullis's Kings of the World".

Between 1949 and 1960, Cullis's Wolves finished out of the top three only three times. In 1964, however, after two mediocre seasons, a brash new chairman, John Ireland, suddenly sacked him.

Cullis said: "I simply created a yardstick which people could criticise me against." He managed Birmingham City, successfully enough, for five more seasons, but the whole game knew his heart and soul remained at Molineux.

Retired comfortably to the Malverns, he wrought for a few years some concise Sunday journalism and courteously welcomed any passer-by wanting to chew the fat about his beloved club. Three times in the three decades that I have lurked in this corner of these pages, I have been instructed to cover the "old gold turns to dross" story, that is the decline into toothlesness by the once fierce and feared Wolves. Each time I'd go to Molineux via Malvern.

After my last visit, about 10 years ago, I received a letter in a bold, neat hand: "Our conversation refreshed me, but I am not sure I quite managed what I had meant to, which was to avoid any suggestion of 'blowing my own trumpet' - but after John Ireland had so obviously enjoyed sacking me after my 30 years of service to the club, I received two particular letters which you might like to quote: one from Sir Matt Busby saying Wolves would never again enjoy the reputation they had established in the football world and forecasting 'this will surely be the beginning of the end for them', and another from Bill Shankly expressing the very same opinion, although hardly in the same parliamentary language used by Matt."

Yesterday, at last, good, stern Stan broke free of his bitter, umbilical Molineux. Now, in peace, he can happily haunt the place for ever.

*Stan Cullis - The Iron Manager, by Jim Holden (£15.99, Breedon Books).

fields.headline: Tim Richards
fields.trailText:
Tim Richards

Lawrence Batley Theatre, Huddersfield

****
fields.body:
Tim Richards has a fondness for throwing musical ideas into a huge melting-pot and then clanging you over the head with it. His nine-piece band's performance in Huddersfield was a lumbering, terrifying juggernaut of sound that left some of the more traditional jazz enthusiasts in the audience with their heads in their hands.

Yet it all began so quietly, with little warning of the apocalypse to come. Over the Moon eased us into a mysterious world of gently glowing vibraphones and enigmatic chord progressions, Richards' keyboards maintaining a spectral presence and evoking the spirit of Pink Floyd. Indeed, it soon became clear that here was a band playing rock'n'roll cunningly disguised as jazz. Richards' ensemble writing grew more noisy and dense as if he wanted his horns and reeds to match the thundering rage of Nirvana, and every last riff was drenched in the blues.

The slow, funky numbers sounded sleazy, with Dave Colton's self-indulgent guitar bringing George Clinton's Funkadelic irresistibly to mind. Some of these pieces went on too long, using generic blues progressions that offered insufficient harmonic support to the front-line horn solos. However, time stood still during the band's hard post-bop excursions, during which they steamed and soared as if there were no tomorrow, drawing gasps of amazement from some sections of the audience and white-faced terror from others.

For all the fire and brimstone of the group work, it was in the solo and small group passages that we were treated to the really interesting stuff. During Up the Creek the brass and woodwind instruments were mischievous and anarchic, taking it in turns to gang up on each other, while Tom Herbert's bass solo had all the swagger of a tom-cat patrolling his neighbourhood.

But the highest accolades must be reserved for young drummer Seb Rochford. With his enormous hair, dangling cigarette and expression of bored insolence he may just be the coolest-looking drummer in jazz right now, and judging from his astounding solo, he may also be a genius.

webTitle: Abbey surrender leaves two banks prey to takeover

fields.headline: Abbey surrender leaves two banks prey to takeover
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Abbey National yesterday abandoned it long-running merger talks with Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Abbey National yesterday abandoned it long-running merger talks with Bank of Scotland.

Both banks are now expected to lose their independence, with the way clear for Lloyds to pursue its £19bn takeover of Abbey and BoS prone to an opportunistic takeover bid from a rival such as Barclays.

With the fate of Lloyds' attack now resting with the competition commission, which is expected to report by mid-July, there was intense speculation last night that Abbey's chief executive, Ian Harley, would be forced to resign.

In its surprise statement to the stock market, Abbey simply cited "the continuing uncertainty created by Lloyds TSB, which may or may not be able to put an offer to Abbey shareholders later this year".

Behind the scenes there was a furious round of briefings and counter-briefings, with both parties blaming each other for the failure of a plan which would have created a new force in British retail banking.

BoS said it was disappointed, adding: "We still believe firmly in the logic of this merger which would create increased shareholder value, increased competition and greater choice in the banking sector."

Lloyds, which is preparing a tough defence for the competition authorities, said: "We are pleased the distraction has gone away."

Facing the prospect of two failed marriage attempts in less than 18 months - having lost NatWest to its rival Royal Bank of Scotland - BoS was said to be reeling from the news, although some of its supporters insisted that it was still possible to structure a deal attractive enough for Abbey's shareholders.

One option already discussed by Abbey and BoS involves a joint venture with an unnamed mainland European insurance company which would inject cash to be distributed as a sweetener to shareholders.

Other City sources stressed that the fact that Lloyds was offering a substantial cash incentive to shareholders, while the Abbey-BoS marriage was a nil-premium merger, made the deal untenable.

If Ian Harley now stays at Abbey he should start working in shareholder's interests and support Lloyds through the regulatory process," one corporate financier said.

Analysts noted that the future ownership structure of much of the banking sector lies in the hands of the competition authorities.

Denise Kingsmill, the deputy competition commissioner, will meet with three of her colleagues tomorrow to discuss the government's terms of reference for investigating Lloyds' proposed takeover.

Mrs Kingsmill is no stranger to controversy, having handled the investigation into the price of British cars last year. She faces four months of intense lobbying as Lloyds argues that it should be allowed to breach the informal 25% ceiling on market share of current account holders, which a takeover of Abbey would breach.

Facing the prospect of two failed marriage attempts in less than 18 months - having lost NatWest to its rival Royal Bank of Scotland - BoS was said to be reeling from the news, although some of its supporters insisted that it was still possible to structure a deal attractive enough for Abbey's shareholders. One option already discussed by Abbey and BoS involves a joint venture with an unnamed mainland European insurance company which would inject cash to be distributed as a sweetener to shareholders. Other City sources stressed that the fact that Lloyds was offering a substantial cash incentive to shareholders, while the Abbey-BoS marriage was a nil-premium merger, made the deal untenable. If Ian Harley now stays at Abbey he should start working in shareholder's interests and support Lloyds through the regulatory process," one corporate financier said. Analysts noted that the future ownership structure of much of the banking sector lies in the hands of the competition authorities. Denise Kingsmill, the deputy competition commissioner, will meet with three of her colleagues tomorrow to discuss the government's terms of reference for investigating Lloyds' proposed takeover. Mrs Kingsmill is no stranger to controversy, having handled the investigation into the price of British cars last year. She faces four months of intense lobbying as Lloyds argues that it should be allowed to breach the informal 25% ceiling on market share of current account holders, which a takeover of Abbey would breach.

fields.headline: Ann Murray
fields.standfirst:
Ann Murray
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Ann Murray
Wigmore Hall, London
****
fields.body:
For anyone who didn't know what a perceptive and versatile recitalist Ann Murray is, her Wigmore Hall programme on Tuesday, with Graham Johnson as her resourceful accompanist, should have provided clinching evidence. It ranged from Mozart to Cole Porter, via Wagner and Ravel, and to each group of songs Murray brought a perfectly judged sense of style and delivery. Just as on the operatic stage, she knows exactly how to communicate with an audience and what to tell them, while vocally she sounded on better form than she has for several years.

The Mozart provided a nicely graded start, from the simple lyric of the early Die Zufriedenheit, through the most heartfelt of all his songs, Abendempfindung, to that strange and rather repellent piece of masonic mumbo-jumbo, Eine Kleine Deutsche Kantate. The opening recitative of this piece at least gave Murray the chance to raise the dramatic temperature by several degrees. By then she was ready to tackle Wagner's Wesendonck Lieder, which typically she never tried to turn into a wordless display of vocal beauty. There was no sense of surfing the accompaniments here, as so many performances do; each song was carefully observed, each text projected with maximum clarity, while Johnson made sure that every harmonic adventure was relished.

A mixed bag of Ravel, including his arrangement of Robert Burns's Ye Banks and Braes and the sensual slow waltz of Fascination, provided more opportunities for sharp-witted characterisation. Then it was on to Cole Porter for the real treat of the evening. The best-known numbers were reserved for the encores - At Long Last Love and a melting version of Every Time We Say Goodbye, taken very slowly and seriously. The group that ended the published programme were less familiar. Murray really twisted the knife with some of Porter's more cynical lyrics - no wonder The Tale of the Oyster, a vicious allegory of social climbing, was dropped from his 1929 show Fifty Million Frenchmen after complaints from the audience. And she relished his matchless rhyming schemes. Who else, in After All I'm Only a Schoolgirl, could rhyme "Aphrodite" with "nightie"?

fields.headline: Tavener undone by modernist malaise
fields.standfirst:
Endymion Ensemble
Purcell Room, London
***
fields.trailText:
Endymion Ensemble
Purcell Room, London

***
fields.body:
John Tavener's music is conceived as a spiritual balm to heal the wounds of a divided and troubled world. Introducing his programme with the Endymion Ensemble, part of its Composer Choice Series, he urged the audience to "listen with the intellectual organ of the heart" and to find a way to vanquish "the demon of modernism". Tavener's concert of his own music - alongside works by Anton Webern, Arvo Part and the 12th-century mystic Hildegard von Bingen - was contemplative rather than aggressive.

Tavener's Akhmatova Songs for string quartet and soprano featured Patricia Rozario as soloist. Rozario has inspired many of Tavener's recent vocal works and she possesses a voice of extraordinary refinement and accuracy. Even in the cruelly exposed lines of these settings, which frequently soar into the voice's highest register, Rozario nearly always maintained her focused tone and technical assurance. She brought the same qualities to Hildegard's settings of visionary religious texts, O viridissima virga and Ave, generosa. Accompanied only by an austere drone, Rozario crafted a rapturous serenity.

Tavener's love of Hildegard's music is not just spiritual but aesthetic. The ornamentation in his settings of Anna Akhmatova's poetry - as well as the subdued melancholy of his Thrinos for solo cello, performed by Jane Salmon - seems to be directly inspired by Hildegard's vocal writing. But a comparison between two composers highlights the problems with Tavener's musical worldview. Although he writes his music to save contemporary consciousness from the evils of modernism, Tavener is wholly reliant on the "modernist" institutions of concert halls and recording companies for his success. Instead of listening to his music "with the heart", we listen to it as an aesthetic object, in much the same way as we listen to a Beethoven symphony. Hildegard's music was not designed as a work of art as we now understand the term, but Tavener's, for all his protestations, most definitely is.

All this isn't to deny the sheer beauty of music such as Tavener's The Child Lived, a setting of words by his spiritual advisor Mother Thekla, for soprano and solo cello. It's just to point out that the composer's project of world-renewal is necessarily doomed because his music plays the very games his philosophy tries to denigrate: a decidedly modernist contradiction.

fields.headline: The Secret Garden
fields.standfirst:
The Secret Garden
Aldwych, London
**
fields.trailText:
The Secret Garden

Aldwych, London

**
fields.body:
How far can you change a well-known book and its meanings when you transpose it from page to stage? The trick is to get a balance between narrative and theme, what it might have meant when it was first published and what it could mean to us now.

When Adrian Noble commissioned and directed a stage version of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe a few years ago he never succeeded in escaping the storyline. The whole thing felt like a BBC Sunday teatime serial, quite enjoyable but plodding and worthy. With this American musical version of Frances Hodgson Burnett's famous children's book the balance has tipped the other way. The bare bones of the story are still there, but its meanings have been distorted to provide an entertainment that is primarily for adults rather than children.

This is most apparent in the way that the children - the disagreeable orphan Mary Lennox, the crippled Colin and the free-running, free-thinking Dickon, all of whom are central to the story - are brushed aside in favour of the grown-ups. The tale ceases to be one about children taking control of their lives and becomes one in which they are agents of the emotional salvation of the adults. The main characters are now Archibald Craven and three ghosts - his dead wife Lily and Mary's parents Rose and Albert, who died in a cholera epidemic in India.

It may suit the purposes of a schmaltzy American musical but this appropriation does a disservice to both the book and the children who presumably will make up a large part of the audience. Children own little enough in our society as it is, and to have their literature taken away and turned into a kind of mystic, new age musical that makes grown-ups feel better about themselves is an insult too far.

In Hodgson Burnett's book the neglectfulness of adults allows the children to mature and thrive; here it is transposed into an emotional and social ill that must be talked out, worked through, cured. This isn't theatre, it is therapy for the price of a seat in the stalls. The adaptation subscribes to the idea that a hug will make everything better. But why should Mary Lennox want to be embraced by two dead people who ignored her when they were alive? The book does not countenance such emotional dishonesty.

If these issues don't worry you, you can have a reasonably enjoyable night out, one that fulfils the same function as skiving off work in the afternoon and watching a very classy made-for-TV weepie. It is, as you'd expect from the Royal Shakespeare Company, done in some considerable style, although in many ways the most effective scenes are the simplest, particularly those that evoke India.

There are minor irritations: Dickon is far too old and Misselthwaite Manor teems with so many servants that it would be impossible to get a moment alone there, let alone have a secret. Mrs Medlock and the doctor are turned into a gothic-villain double act and, as so often happens in musicals, there is a tendency towards a saucer-eyed, stage-school style of acting - though not from the children themselves, who are both very good.

The title alone will ensure an audience but be aware that, as an emotional and imaginative experience, this doesn't begin to touch the book.

Booking until June 2. Box office: 0870-400 0805.

fields.headline: Byronic Cura hogs the limelight
fields.trailText:
Jose Cura

Barbican, London

****
fields.body:
Jose Cura's long-awaited Verdi tribute wasn't quite the one-man show that some had anticipated. Backed by the London Symphony Orchestra, he shared the honours with the soprano Daniela Dessi and the conductor Pier Giorgio Morandi, each of whom were allotted almost equal time on the platform. Inevitably, however, the testosterone-fuelled Argentinian hogged the limelight whenever he appeared. For much of the time you were conscious of his putting on a self-dramatising act.

He kicked the evening off with Manrico's Serenade from Il Trovatore. In the opera it is sung offstage, and Cura duly began it in the artist's room, bounding on to the platform at the line "A troubadour is greater than any king". He was dressed to slay, looking impeccably Byronic in tight pants and a flowing black silk shirt. Thereafter he played games with the audience. He conducted the overture to Nabucco himself. The house went wild, and Cura, having left the podium, kept peering back into the auditorium with a look of surprise as if to say: "Is all this for me?" In the duet from the third act of Aida, he joined Dessi by making a grand entrance at the back of the stalls. Had there been an available chandelier, I suspect he might have swung from it.

True, such antics do break down the formulaic structure of the operatic extracts concert, but they also detract mightily on occasion from the singing. Fortunately Cura wins hands down on musical talent alone. Although he has been dubbed "the fourth tenor", his voice and style hark back to a previous generation of performers, the great tenors of the 1950s such as Franco Corelli and Mario del Monaco. The sound is dark and thrilling, his delivery ballsy and impactive. He's a fine vocal actor, colouring his voice to suit each character, a fact that emerged only gradually during the evening.

The first half of the concert focused on Verdi's flamboyant heroes - dangerously glamorous figures such as Corrado from Il Corsaro, Ernani and Radames, the principled warrior from Aida. Each of them was rawly, thrillingly portrayed, though it wasn't until after the interval that we were able to appreciate the full depth and range of Cura's singing. Here he offered us the self-doubting Alvaro from La Forza del Destino and his Don Carlos - introverted, neurotic and profoundly moving. As an encore, he gave us a glimpse of his Otello, tracking Dessi's Desdemona in the love duet from the first act with the touching naivety of an enraptured innocent.

Dessi, sadly, isn't in his league. She's unfailingly accurate and sensitive to both phrasing and textual nuance, but the tone sometimes curdles and you miss the opulent sheen of truly great Verdi sopranos such as Renata Tebaldi and Leontyne Price. Morandi, however, is a real find, an immaculate judge of the pace, ebb and flow of this music. The playing by the LSO was simply to die for.

fields.headline: Lloyds advisers earned their £200m
fields.standfirst: Notebook Abbey driven to abject surrender
fields.trailText: The fees earned by investment banks can make the head spin. The team of corporate finance and other advisers working for Lloyds TSB in its attempt to take over Abbey National, for instance, will probably trouser £200m or more if their client succeeds.
fields.body:
The fees earned by investment banks can make the head spin. The team of corporate finance and other advisers working for Lloyds TSB in its attempt to take over Abbey National, for instance, will probably trouser £200m or more if their client succeeds.

Sometimes - and only sometimes - the financiers can be seen to earn their money. We saw gob-smacking evidence of this yesterday when Abbey's putative plan to merge with Bank of Scotland was blown off the planet.

This was achieved through an awe-in spiring investment banking attack, led by JP Morgan and Merrill Lynch. Lloyds, goaded into action by the competitive threat posed by the "fifth force" in retail banking which a merged BoS-Abbey promised, wrapped Abbey's chief executive, Ian Harley, in the most aggressive bear hug. Skipping around takeover panel rules, laying only outline terms on the table, Lloyds created a three-month window for itself before making a highly conditional bid, giving the predator all the time it needed to garner crucial institutional support.

There are two versions of how and why the Abbey-BoS deal collapsed.

One says Peter Burt, BoS's chief executive, dined with five institutional heavyweights last Friday and was told simply that a nil-premium merger with Abbey was untenable when Lloyds was offering a 30% premium laced with cash. The fund managers would not allow BoS to go ahead and cement a deal while Lloyds' offering was sitting at the competition commission.

Another version says Abbey simply bottled it. BoS knew all along it would have to find some way of sweetening the deal and pursued every lateral cash-raising idea. Abbey was nervous, unsure it could sell any sort of enlarged deal to shareholders. Leaked details - in these pages - of the BoS-sponsored plan to bring a European insurer into the mix proved to be the final straw, it is said.

Whatever the catalyst, the betting is that Abbey's directors were tearing themselves apart last night. All very exciting for purveyors of high City drama.

Beyond the boardroom blood and investment banking bonuses, this is a disaster for customers of British banks. A BoS-Abbey merger, run by the Scots, promised a real competitive challenge to the "big four" banking cartel. A Lloyds takeover of Abbey, which will involve physically wiping Abbey off the high street, will give one player control of almost a third of current accounts in the land - not to mention giving umpteen thousand people the sack. As for BoS, it will probably fall into the hands of Barclays, and the cartel will be strengthened another notch.

A lot is now riding on Denise Kingsmill at the competition commission. We must hope she can hold her nerve rather better than did Ian Harley.

In a word:

Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan is known for his delphic utterances. Yesterday he was in top form. Here we provide a translation of elements of his testimony.

Greenspan: "The economy appears to be on a track well below the productivity-enhanced rate of growth of its potential and, even after the policy actions we took in January, the risks continue skewed toward the economy's remaining on a path inconsistent with satisfactory economic performance."

Trans: We could be in for a recession.

Greenspan: "There is no question that the so-called wealth effect has been a very prominent factor in the major expansion in economic activity, especially since 1995, and clearly with the market reversing, that process does indeed reverse ... Whether it of itself is enough to induce a significant contraction which in retrospect we will call a recession is yet too early to make a judgment on."

Trans: We could be in for a recession.

Greenspan: "What we have not seen is, how does that new technology affect the decision-making process when the rate of growth begins to fall? And I guess we could reasonably presume that it was the reasonable expectation that the just in time inventory process, to take one aspect of the decision-making process, would not only affect how inventories were accumulated on the upside but presumably accelerate the adjustment process on the downside."

Trans: I'm worried about recession.

Greenspan: "There's always a distinction between our various measures of consumer confidence and, indeed, what people think, feel and say, and what they do. In the last couple of months, during the period when the indeces, the proxies for consumer confidence, have gone down extraordinarily rapidly, it has not been matched by a concurrent decline in consumption expenditures.

"What we do not know, however, is whether that merely is something which has been delayed, and that ultimately the adjustment in consumer expenditures will indeed, after the fact, reflect the most recent patterns of consumer confidence."

Trans: I'm very worried about recession.

fields.headline: Bradford & Bingley to close 88 branches
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Bradford & Bingley announced yesterday it is closing 88 branches and cutting 300 jobs, two months after it converted from a building society to a bank.
fields.body:
Bradford & Bingley announced yesterday it is closing 88 branches and cutting 300 jobs, two months after it converted from a building society to a bank.

The group said the closures formed part of its cost-cutting strategy and would boost profits. In its first results since its December flotation, B&B also announced a 25% increase in full year pre-tax profits to £231m. But shares closed down 7p at 289.75p because the figures were below analysts' expectations. After one-off costs mostly related to conversion, pre-tax profits were £158.7m -£4m up on 1999.

B&B has 1.5m shareholders, the vast majority former society members with 250 shares each. Last night this holding was worth £724.

webTitle: Britons just love a day at the office

fields.headline: Britons just love a day at the office
fields.standfirst: Work site
fields.trailText: We may moan about our bosses and workload, but in reality Britons love nothing more than a day in the office, claims a new pan-European survey.
fields.body:
We may moan about our bosses and workload, but in reality Britons love nothing more than a day in the office, claims a new pan-European survey.

The study, which asked over 17,000 people how they saw themselves, found that Britons were far more likely than their neighbours to describe themselves as career-oriented. It also threw up other surprises for students of national characteristics. The stressed French are too busy fretting to enjoy their traditional long lunches, while the Italians are less passionate than even the British.

Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial Society, said he was unsurprised to discover that Britons were so attached to their work.

"The participation rates of women in Britain are much higher than in other European countries, so you would expect more of those questioned to be much more engaged in work," he explained.

"Britain also has more flexibility in its labour market, and although that's often seen as a bad thing, it means workers have much more choice about the hours and the way they work."

He added: "All the evidence shows that people are getting more of a sense of community from work, so being serious about your career is not the opposite of being serious about your life and friends and personal development. For many people, work is where all that happens. We may well be picking up on positive trends."

The Reader's Digest surveyed people in 18 European countries, asking them how they perceived themselves, and which institutions they trusted.

Despite our career focus and our soaring divorce rate, Britons remain all in favour of marriage, with 80% of respondents claiming they had a great deal of confidence in the institution.

In comparison, only 19% of Britons had quite a lot or a great deal of faith in the EU.

fields.headline: An ocean of guitar noodles
fields.standfirst:
Ocean Colour Scene
St George's Hall, Bradford
**
fields.trailText:
Ocean Colour Scene

St George's Hall, Bradford

**
fields.body:
Ocean Colour Scene stroll on stage in an assortment of greyish clothes and make the most polite sound that has ever been produced by a wall of Marshall amplifiers. It's surprisingly pleasant to hear tunes such as The Circle and Better Day. After all, they're well-written pop songs and sung well. Something, however, is jarring and it's hard to figure out what.

Perhaps it is the large, druggy projection that swirls hypnotically across the back of the stage. This is presumably ironic, given that Ocean Colour Scene are the least psychedelic band to emerge from the Midlands since the Electric Light Orchestra. Or perhaps it's the rabid, inflamed passion of the crowd, who all seem to think they're watching the Clash circa 1977. Maybe it's a combination of both.

Either way, the nice-looking chaps on stage seem pleased by the rock'n'roll atmosphere they are inexplicably generating, and singer Simon Fowler even goes so far as to lift a can of lager at us and mumble something into the microphone.

The roars of approval grow more and more frenzied as the music becomes more and more innocuous. The moddish white soul of In My Field tries to evoke the Who but quickly dissolves into tedious repetition, any potential energy stifled by an endlessly recurring guitar noodle and the four-square drumming of Oscar Harrison. Profit in Peace gets the crowd waving their lighters in the air, but while the recorded version had a bit of subtlety, here it's hammered into the ground with almost grim determination.

The band constantly evoke the sound of other artists while always managing to leave out something vital. So we get Thin Lizzy without the testosterone, the Jam without the urban anger, Sheryl Crow without Sheryl Crow. But the crowd simply do not care. Without doing anything extraordinary, this very average band have managed to inspire love, devotion and the belief that they are doing something exciting. Perhaps, in this respect, they are strangely brilliant after all.

At the Royal Centre, Nottingham (0115-989 5555), tomorrow, then touring.

fields.headline: New-look England amaze everyone
fields.standfirst:
Barmby 38, Heskey 54, Ehiogu 70
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: The reign of Sven-Goran Eriksson as the nation's first foreign coach began with a performance of growing confidence and expertise as Nick Barmby, Emile Heskey and Ugo Ehiogu ensured a dream start for England's new manager.
fields.body:
Abba be praised, England appear to have rediscovered the art of winning. After an awkward start on a bitterly cold night here the reign of Sven-Goran Eriksson as the nation's first foreign coach began with performance of growing confidence and expertise and an impressive victory over an accomplished but defensively suspect Spanish team.

Goals from Nick Barmby, Emile Heskey and Ugo Ehiogu having assured Eriksson of a win, Nigel Martyn added to the evening's satisfaction by saving a penalty from Javi Moreno after Ehiogu had been harshly adjuged to have fouled the Spain striker.

Eriksson's inaugural choice of team woke everyone up with a start. A heavy Manchester United presence - five as it turned out - had been expected but not with Phil Neville at right-back.

The 31-year-old Chris Powell's first cap at left-back was less of a surprise than that. Otherwise the side that began the match looked adequate to be going on with, and the team which that finished the game was always going to be somewhat different.

In the opening minute a tenacious tackle from Nicky Butt announced English intentions and might even have brought Eriksson a goal had Nick Barmby, having nutmegged Manuel Pablo, not put a hasty shot wide.

With Michael Owen dropping off Andy Cole, which is not the Liverpool striker's normal role, and Barmby ever busy, England were full of positive attitudes, but once Spain established a close-passing pattern they found it difficult to get hold of the ball.

Had Ismael Urzaiz shown more composure when meeting a long, dropping centre from Pablo Spain might have taken an early lead but the big striker sliced his shot wide.

There were little glimmers of English optimism, like the moment when Powell's first run up the left flank took him smoothly past Josep Guardiola before a well-judged cross from the Charlton defender that deserved someone taller than Barmby on the end of it. But the contrast between Spain's careful build-ups from the back and England's tendency to wallop the ball forward myopically was unavoidable.

Eventually a point was reached when Andy Cole was the only England player in the opposing half while the rest of his colleagues waited anxiously the other side of the halfway line for what Spain might do next. Few if any of Eriksson's club sides have given the ball away with such abandon as his new charges were doing last night.

At least Powell was enjoying himself, another forward run helping to set up a chance for Paul Scholes, whose long shot, though it did not trouble Iker Casillas, was better than nothing. A few minutes earlier Helguera's dipping 30-yarder had brought David James into action for the first time.

England, settling down, improved towards half-time. For much of the opening half-hour David Beckham, a peripheral figure on the right, was virtually a non-playing captain but in the 31st minute he moved to the middle to thread a pass through the defence for Scholes to touch the ball on to Owen.

The alertness of Casillas denied Owen a shot but the moment quickly proved portentous. Seven minutes later, as Cole laid the ball off short to Owen, Spain were caught out by the timing of Barmby's run through the middle. Owen's astute lob set up his Liverpool team-mate for a chance and Barmby did not miss it, calmly clipping a shot past Casillas's left hand.

Thus did history repeat itself. Barmby it was who had opened England's scoring in Glenn Hoddle's first game, a World Cup qualifier in Moldova five years earlier.

The Anfield combination of Owen and Barmby, linking well with the Old Trafford twosome of Scholes and Cole, finished the first 45 minutes in the ascendancy. For the second half, however, Eriksson's promise of at least half-a-dozen changes was duly fulfilled.

In goal James gave way to Nigel Martyn, Ugo Ehiogu and Michael Ball replaced Rio Ferdinand and Powell, who had a calf strain, Frank Lampard and Gavin McCann came on for Butt and Scholes in midfield and Emile Heskey appeared on the right wing with Beckham handing the captain's armband to Campbell.

This reshuffle apart all that changed was the score. In the 54th minute, after a corner from Lampard, Ehiogu's powerful challenge denied Casillas a proper clearance. The ball dropped to Heskey, who volleyed in England's second goal.

Spain remained a danger on the break but their defence grew worse at set pieces and another corner brought England a third goal. Ehiogu, granted a free header by poor marking, nodded Lampard's corner past Casillas. For the former Aston Villa player scoring his first goal for England at the Holte End on only his second international appearance was indeed the stuff that dreams are made of.

England (4-4-2): James (Martyn, h-t); P Neville (G Neville, 78min), Ferdinand (Ehiogu, h-t), Campbell, Powell (Ball, h-t); Beckham (Heskey, h-t), Butt (McCann, h-t), Scholes (Lampard, h-t), Barmby; Owen, Cole.

Spain (4-3-2-1): Casillas (Canizares, 64); Manuel Pablo, Unai, Abelardo (Javi Moreno, 55), Romero; Guardiola (Etxeberria, 80), Helguera, Luis Enrique (Sergi, 64); Mendieta (Victor, 64), Raul (Baraja, 81); Urzaiz (Paco, 58).

Referee: K Vassaras (Greece)
